webTitle: Way Back When with Frank Keating

fields.headline: Dawn of Brodie the net prophet and the perennially culpable ref
fields.trailText: It is prime time for football anniversaries.Time therefore to note when the aspects of beautiful game that we take for granted actually came into being.
fields.body:
It is prime time for football anniversaries. For omens too, for everyone knows Tottenham Hotspur only win the FA Cup when there is a "one" at the end of a year. The London club set the sequence in motion a century ago this spring when they beat Sheffield United by 3-1 in a replayed final.

Also in 1901, Tottenham played host to arguably the first international match involving a team from outside the British Isles - England 12, Germany 0 - which an upstaged Football Association at once pronounced "unsanctioned and unofficial" and said such a concept in the future was deemed "unworkable for the obvious variety of administrative and logistical reasons". It was not to sanction an "official" international for another seven years - Austria 1, England 6, Vienna, 1908, as part of preparations for that summer's Olympic Games competition in London.

That pioneering international at Tottenham took place with football's structures scarcely formed. Only 10 years before, for instance, had referees been given exclusive powers to arbitrate, and penalty-kicks had been added to the laws. That same seminal year, 1891, had seen goal nets made compulsory. There also took place a crucial meeting in Sheffield between the fledgling Football League and its rival Football Alliance in which an elite "Premier" English league was almost formed. The proposal was a merger which would result in three national divisions of just 12 clubs each. After "heated debate" the idea was thrown out - in no time the first two divisions of the Football League had 40 clubs taking part, and it was not long till representation in the congested four divisions numbered over 90.

Goal nets were "invented" by the go-ahead city engineer of Liverpool, JA Brodie. A year or two before, he had noticed in the local press an increasing number of dis putes concerning the validity of goals and had dashed off, apparently in less than half an hour, a choice of possible designs involving goalposts (the hitherto common taped "crossbar" had been banned by the FA in 1882 and three fixed pieces of wood made compulsory) with netting affixed, sent it off to the local patents office and, to all intents, forgotten all about it.

The 1890-91 season began with a series of whinges over disputed scores by spectators and players alike, and before Christmas 1890 Brodie had a pair of nets made up. The Old Etonians' northern side agreed to use them for a game at their Liverpool ground in Stanley Park.

The experiment was a palpable success and Brodie circulated the clubs. By January 1891, at Nottingham Forest's old pitch at Woodward's Field on the town side of Trent Bridge, Brodie had hung his two nets on the goalposts before a prestigious North v South fixture, and 110 Marches ago, the league agreed that nets should be compulsory by the start of the 1891-92 season "when it was agreed with the patentee what price should be paid for the netting".

Certainly, they were billowingly installed at the Oval for the 1892 "Brummie" Cup final between West Bromwich Albion and Aston Villa - by which time, well pleased, Brodie continued with his day job at the council and settled down to engineering Britain's first dual carriageway, Liverpool's handsome Queen's Drive. He later helped design for the government the far more regally sumptuous New Delhi - but goal-nets will forever be his most notable memorial.

Before 1891, referees in football were like today's new-fangled "third umpire" in Test cricket. Through the 1870s and 1880s clubs had been required to provide an umpire of their own and the two of them made all the decisions, halting play originally by waving a white handkerchief and, doubtless, bellowing - a whistle was only introduced in 1879 (again at Nottingham Forest).

Before each kick-off, the two umpires were expected to appoint a touchline "referee" who could only make his defining decision if the two of them appealed to him to settle their own dispute. But in 1891, the role of the umpires was drastically diminished. They were banished to the touchlines, to be called "line-men", and it was the referee who was allowed to roam the pitch as "sole arbiter".

I daresay the change only helped focus the increasing venom by crowds on to one man when his decisions went against their team, as this poignant letter by a referee to the correspondance columns of the Preston Standard that year testified. It followed the previous Saturday's match at Bolton between the local side and Preston North End:

"Dear Sir, Immediately the game had started I could see too much emnity all along the ranks of spectators for the match to be played in any amiable spirit as I found myself being cursed and sworn at by a body of dirty low blackguards, who stood at the goal and touchline nearest the entrance gates and threatened at once to smash my (adjective) jaw when the game was over. I was vexed, but continued to give my decisions honestly and fairly ...

"After the affair was over I was tackled at once by a flock of infuriated beings in petticoats supposed to be women, indeed mothers too if I may judge from the innocent babes suckling at their breasts. They brandished their umbrellas at me, and voted me everything that was bad ... I then got into a house to dress, but my whereabouts was discovered and the same rabble swore to wait till I came out ..."

Ah, the beautiful game. And so it goes on.

webTitle: Real warm up for O'Leary's men

fields.headline: Real warm up for O'Leary's men
fields.trailText: European round-up A controversial refereeing decision overshadowed a thrilling 2-2 draw between Real Madrid and Barcelona while Bayern Munich missed the chance to return to the top of Germany's Bundesliga after a shock defeat at Hansa Rostock.
fields.body:
A controversial refereeing decision overshadowed a thrilling 2-2 draw between Real Madrid, who meet David O'Leary's Leeds in the Champions League tomorrow night, and Barcelona.

"I feel like I've had my wallet stolen," said the Barcelona president Joan Gaspart after Rivaldo's last-minute strike was ruled out for offside. "I think someone has decided that Barcelona shouldn't win the league this year."

Rivaldo had already scored twice to cancel out close-range strikes from Raul when his low left-foot shot was deflected past Iker Casillas but disallowed because three teammates were retreating from offside positions.

Steve McManaman, who withdrew from the England squad for last week's friendly against Spain because of injury, started the game and created Raul's second goal. Real are now nine points ahead of their fierce rivals in the Spanish league with 13 games to play.

Lille extended their French first division lead to three points when they beat Marseille 1-0 thanks to the goalkeeping excellence of Gregory Wimbee. And Sonny Anderson's 81st-minute goal secured a 2-1 victory for Lyon over their title rivals Bordeaux, who had been 1-0 up.

Bayern Munich missed the chance to return to the top of Germany's Bundesliga after a shock 3-2 defeat at Hansa Rostock. They remain only one point behind Borussia Dortmund, the league leaders, but their manager Ottmar Hitzfeld questioned their ability to win a third successive title.

"We are in a very serious situation," said Hitzfeld, whose team have already lost as many games as in the whole of last season. "The main problem is we are not aggressive enough and we cannot control a game." Bayern play Lyon in Group C of the Champions League tomorrow; Spartak Moscow, Arsenal's opponents in the same group, did not play at the weekend.

Ruud van Nistelrooy made his long-awaited comeback from a knee injury on Saturday. The PSV Eindhoven striker, who came so close to joining Manchester United last year, came on in the 34th minute against Roda JC Kerkrade and although the game ended goalless he came the closest to scoring, hitting the bar from close range.

fields.headline: Strupar puts Derby in sight of sanctuary
fields.trailText: Football has a talent for making chumps out of those of hasty words and Jim Smith, with almost three decades of managerial know-how behind him, would never put his neck on the line when the guillotine could still crash down.
fields.body:
Football has a talent for making chumps out of those of hasty words and Jim Smith, with almost three decades of managerial know-how behind him, would never put his neck on the line when the guillotine could still crash down.

But for the first time this season his Derby side, having leapfrogged Everton and Aston Villa into the relative sanctuary of 14th position, can look at the Premiership table without the need to wince.

With another two wins the restoration job will have been completed and top-flight status confirmed, a remarkable transformation for a side who in mid-November were still waiting for their first Premiership win.

Since Colin Todd brought his coaching nous into the equation and Taribo West swapped la dolce vita of Milan for an East Midlands motel, Derby have been unrecognisable from the dishevelled outfit that were aimlessly grubbing around for points through the autumn.

Watching them inflict what was ultimately irretrievable first-half damage on Tottenham, there were times when their early-season angst seemed little more than a trick of the mind.

For Spurs, reality bites hard. It is no surprise that a man of George Graham's legendary conservatism builds his team around a compact defence but, when that is malfunctioning, there is little left over to admire.

In midfield Tim Sherwood and Steffen Freund are one-paced and one-dimensional. Without Darren Anderton and the attack-minded wing-back Stephen Carr the team is too often bereft of width and penetration.

In Les Ferdinand and the on-loan Andy Booth their attack on Saturday comprised one striker who, it could be argued, is rapidly going over the hill and another who never made it up the slope in the first place.

A plethora of up-and-coming stars suggests better times ahead but this was a galling day for Alton Thelwell, culpable for Branko Strupar's 33rd-minute penalty after making a pig's ear of controlling a high ball and subsequently up-ending Malcolm Christie in his desperation to retrieve the situation.

"I'll be having a chat with Alton to let him know that just because he is in the first team it does not mean he is the finished article," growled Graham.

The Spurs manager is also to have further talks with Enic about its blueprint for the club, not least in the wake of a public admission yesterday that the new owner is considering a move from White Hart Lane. "We are looking at whether we need a purpose-built stadium which will have a better chance of housing all the fans who cannot get into matches," said the new executive vice-chairman David Buchler.

First things first, however. Most Tottenham fans would prefer to oversee the construction of a new team rather than a new ground.

Derby led from the 12th minute, Strupar volleying in a flicked-on corner to claim his first goal since returning from two hernia operations. Though the home side invited trouble by defending too deeply in the second half Tottenham lacked any kind of ingenuity. They were all huff and puff but no guile.

A blooper by the otherwise impeccable West, heading Sol Campbell's harmless punt over Andy Oakes, was the first Premiership goal Derby had conceded in more than six hours but, with the odd flutter here and there, they survived some concerted pressure to propel themselves within touching distance of safety. "Two more wins," nodded Todd. "Just two more wins."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Smith's exercise in frustration
fields.trailText: Unless Coventry and Manchester City can string together an unlikely sequence of victories in the final weeks of the season, Everton are probably only one win away from Premiership safety.
fields.body:
Unless Coventry and Manchester City can string together an unlikely sequence of victories in the final weeks of the season, Everton are probably only one win away from Premiership safety.

That is some cause for relief, given their inability to beat a Newcastle team so depleted that the manager Bobby Robson did not have a single defender to put on the bench.

Robson told the former England captain Alan Shearer beforehand that he would have to switch to centre-half if one of the starting pair were injured. And with Everton's strikers so lacking in scoring form, he would doubtless have managed it standing on his head.

It would have been amusing, though, to have seen Shearer arguing the case for the defence for once, having spent all game protesting to the referee David Elleray about the forwards' lot and the failure to award a penalty when he tangled with David Weir.

Shearer was booked for following club instructions to stand in front of the ball to prevent opponents taking quick free-kicks, one such having caused Newcastle's defeat to Manchester City last week. And a player of lesser stature might have seen red for his protracted arguments over the late penalty that rescued Everton. Who does Shearer think he is? A Manchester United player?

Robson said: "He thought he should have had a penalty early on and then he began to get frustrated with the referee. It happens, but I suppose you are paid to suffer frustration."

If Shearer really wants to understand the meaning of frustration, he should try standing in the shoes of Everton's manager Walter Smith, who once again saw his side miss outstanding chances to wrap up the game, finally leaving him relieved to salvage a point.

Francis Jeffers, when he was fresh and hungry at the start of the season, would not have hesitated over his early chance, created by Thomas Gravesen and Kevin Campbell. But he struck his shot poorly and Shay Given made a comfortable save with his foot.

Campbell missed another after Gary Naysmith courageously risked GBH from Andrew Griffin to get in his cross. Naysmith was carried off on a stretcher, followed by Alex Nyarko after a tussle just before half-time, and two minutes after the interval Everton's substitute David Uns- worth sliced the ball needlessly into his own net.

Paul Gascoigne, out since November with a thigh injury, came on for Abel Xavier to try to produce some magic and, when Steve Caldwell was adjudged to have brought down Campbell, he picked up the ball as if to take the penalty. He was soon shoved off it by Michael Ball and Unsworth, who had a spat over whose right it was. Unsworth was successful in that one and just as successful with the kick, planting it into the bottom corner.

"He's very confident with his penalties," said Smith, who must wish he could say the same of his strikers in sight of goal.

fields.headline: Reuser points the way to Europe
fields.standfirst: Ipswich go third as Burley's handiwork shines through
fields.trailText: After a recent splutter of three straight league defeats Ipswich have recovered form at just the right time and move up to third to keep their dreams of European qualification alive.
fields.body:
The farming community may be in crisis but the Tractor Boys go rumbling on. In coming from behind to defeat a seemingly doomed Bradford yesterday George Burley's side climbed back into third spot and remain on course for a place in Europe. Today Bradford, tomorrow Barcelona.

This victory was reward not just for Ipswich's dominance but for their patience. Refusing to abandon their passing principles after they undeservedly fell behind to Benito Carbone's free-kick, they were rewarded with two fine strikes from Martijn Reuser and a header from Mark Burchill in 15 second-half minutes.

Burley refuses to talk of the club making it into Europe for the first time since 1983 but the chances of that fantasy becoming reality look promising. Of 10 remaining matches only one is against a current top-seven side, Liverpool.

After a recent splutter of three straight league defeats Ipswich seem to have recovered form at the right time.

"They say the league never lies," Burley said. "We're in third position on merit, knowing we have some very tough games coming up. We have enjoyed being in the top six. It's virtually the same squad that got us promotion. There have been one or two additions but it shows it's very much teamwork and effort."

It is a tribute to Burley's coaching too, of course, and to his eye for a player. Hermann Hreidarsson, who arrived from Wimbledon in the close season, was again impressive. But it was Reuser, who spent the end of last season on loan from Vitesse Arnhem and signed in the summer for £1m, who caught the eye.

This was only the Dutchman's third Premiership start but it is hard to see him being dropped now. Having not found the net since last season's play-off final against Barnsley, he scored two fine goals, the second a 20-yard free-kick.

"I'm pleased for Martijn," Burley said. "He's a very talented player. There's no doubt when you come from abroad it takes time to adapt to the pace of the game. I had a chat with him on Friday and said he had to work harder and show more. He certainly did that."

Bradford, who denied Ipswich promotion on the last day of the 1998-1999 season, operate on a similar budget, yet their time in the Premiership has been one long struggle. Thirteen adrift of safety, they know their time is all but up. Their manager Jim Jefferies talked of "if the inevitable happens".

For all Bradford's hard work, the gulf in quality was appreciable and Jefferies knows he must cut the wage bill and rebuild an ageing squad. "I can't fault them for effort," he said. "What they need to play at Premiership level they have not got: the ability and legs."

Ipswich have both, yet Bradford had gone ahead with their first shot on target in the 27th minute. Eoin Jess tapped the ball aside and Carbone, making only his second start of the year after being among those told they could leave by Jefferies in January, beat Richard Wright from 30 yards.

Had Carbone not failed, stretching from three yards, at 1-1 the outcome might have been different but Ipswich deserved their win. Having gone close several times, they equalised on the hour.

Reuser intercepted Andy O'Brien's misplaced pass on the left flank and beat the same player inside the area before curling a perfect shot beyond Gary Walsh.

When a Hreidarsson run was stopped illegally by Ashley Ward near the edge of the box, Reuser sent his free-kick beyond Walsh. The Dutchman also sent over the corner from which Hreidarsson's header was glanced in by Burchill.

Hreidarsson, apparently thinking he had scored, dived into the crowd. "I hope the people in the crowd are still alive because he's such a big bloke," Reuser said.

Bradford's hopes of staying up look dead. For Ipswich the European dream lives on.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

"They say the league never lies," Burley said. "We're in third position on merit, knowing we have some very tough games coming up. We have enjoyed being in the top six. It's virtually the same squad that got us promotion. There have been one or two additions but it shows it's very much teamwork and effort." It is a tribute to Burley's coaching too, of course, and to his eye for a player. Hermann Hreidarsson, who arrived from Wimbledon in the close season, was again impressive. But it was Reuser, who spent the end of last season on loan from Vitesse Arnhem and signed in the summer for £1m, who caught the eye. This was only the Dutchman's third Premiership start but it is hard to see him being dropped now. Having not found the net since last season's play-off final against Barnsley, he scored two fine goals, the second a 20-yard free-kick. "I'm pleased for Martijn," Burley said. "He's a very talented player. There's no doubt when you come from abroad it takes time to adapt to the pace of the game. I had a chat with him on Friday and said he had to work harder and show more. He certainly did that." Bradford, who denied Ipswich promotion on the last day of the 1998-1999 season, operate on a similar budget, yet their time in the Premiership has been one long struggle. Thirteen adrift of safety, they know their time is all but up. Their manager Jim Jefferies talked of "if the inevitable happens". For all Bradford's hard work, the gulf in quality was appreciable and Jefferies knows he must cut the wage bill and rebuild an ageing squad. "I can't fault them for effort," he said. "What they need to play at Premiership level they have not got: the ability and legs." Ipswich have both, yet Bradford had gone ahead with their first shot on target in the 27th minute. Eoin Jess tapped the ball aside and Carbone, making only his second start of the year after being among those told they could leave by Jefferies in January, beat Richard Wright from 30 yards. Had Carbone not failed, stretching from three yards, at 1-1 the outcome might have been different but Ipswich deserved their win. Having gone close several times, they equalised on the hour. Reuser intercepted Andy O'Brien's misplaced pass on the left flank and beat the same player inside the area before curling a perfect shot beyond Gary Walsh. When a Hreidarsson run was stopped illegally by Ashley Ward near the edge of the box, Reuser sent his free-kick beyond Walsh. The Dutchman also sent over the corner from which Hreidarsson's header was glanced in by Burchill. Hreidarsson, apparently thinking he had scored, dived into the crowd. "I hope the people in the crowd are still alive because he's such a big bloke," Reuser said. Bradford's hopes of staying up look dead. For Ipswich the European dream lives on.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Kirkland saves Sky Blue blushes
fields.trailText: Predicting the outcome of an encounter between a team who cannot win away from home - Chelsea - and one incapable of winning anywhere - Coventry - would surely not have taxed the most incompetent of tipsters.
fields.body:
Predicting the outcome of an encounter between a team who cannot win away from home - Chelsea - and one incapable of winning anywhere - Coventry - would surely not have taxed the most incompetent of tipsters.

The sides duly served up a stalemate. But if that was wholly predictable, like City getting themselves into a pickle almost every springtime, the lack of goals after plenty of goalmouth pinball but precious little wizardry came as a surprise.

"It could have been 3-3," opined the Coventry manager Gordon Strachan. That the irascible Scot was not left cursing some all-too-familiar phil anthropy from his defenders owed much to a cocktail of profligate finishing by Chelsea and excellent goalkeeping by Chris Kirkland.

Strachan took something of a gamble by dropping the Swedish international Magnus Hedman and replacing him with a teenager whose only other game against Chelsea had ended in tears. At Stamford bridge in November the 19-year-old Kirkland was wrongly sent off and Chelsea won 6-1.

With City showing the never-say-die qualities which may yet prove the decisive factor in preserving their Premiership status, there was never any danger of a repeat humiliation. According to Chelsea's captain Dennis Wise, however, the difference between a draw and long-overdue away win for his side was Kirkland.

"He saved them," said Wise. "I first came across him at an England training camp and I thought he was good then. He proved that against us and I'm sure he's got a bright future."

Though Kirkland's presence augurs well for their defence, Coventry still have a problem scoring despite the arrival of John Hartson. His trademark strongarm tactics, including dispatching Marcel Desailly into an advertising hoarding as the pair tried to claim the ball for a throw-in, unsettled the Chelsea defence.

But City lack a predator to play alongside the Welsh international and feed off his headed knockdowns and flick-ons. With the best will in the world Craig Bellamy is no Ian Wright but rather a winger who creates chances, as he did for David Thompson and Moustapha Hadji.

Both went begging and City are still searching for the win that Strachan believes will move their fight for survival into overdrive. "I have not set a target of wins," he said, "but I am convinced that once we get one we will be on our way.

"We had enough chances to beat Chelsea and those chances were made by sheer endeavour rather than skill. You cannot expect teams at the bottom of the league to play cosmic football."

Increasingly you cannot expect Chelsea to play cosmic football either. But that is a view not shared by Wise, who said: "People are bound to be impatient because of all the success we've enjoyed. But it's a new time now and we've got to get on with it. That means getting this season out of the way and in some way qualifying for Europe." Via the Inter-Toto Cup, perhaps?

fields.headline: Official linked to ticket row
fields.trailText: The Football Association has called on Uefa to investigate whether Philippe Piat, a leading players' union figure in negotiations on the future of the transfer system, allegedly supplied black market tickets at Euro 96.
fields.body:
The Football Association has called on Uefa to investigate whether Philippe Piat, a leading players' union figure in negotiations on the future of the transfer system, allegedly supplied black market tickets at Euro 96.

The FA wrote to Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner last week asking him to investigate whether Piat, the vice-president of the international players' union Fifpro, provided tickets which ended up on the black market.

The FA carried out investigations into the matter after Euro 96 and raised questions about whether the now defunct firm David Dryer Sports Travel was selling unauthorised tickets. The FA alleges that Piat was involved with two companies it believes supplied David Dryer with most of its Euro 96 tickets.

It is understood that the FA has urged Uefa to look into the matter given the prominent position held by the Frenchman, who is also the head of France's professional footballers' union.

Piat, who works alongside Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers Association, at Fifpro, has been a hardline figure in the negotiations with the European Commission.

If true, the allegations could be a serious embarrassment for Fifpro. One of Piat's colleagues, the Fifpro general secretary Theo van Seggelen, has described the allegations as "unbelievable".

Van Seggelen added: "I have never heard about this, we have never spoken about it and I cannot believe it. He is absolutely not involved in this."

fields.headline: Nationwide  round-up
fields.trailText: Nottingham Forest's play-off hopes were hit after they "committed suicide" at Wolves, where for the second successive season they ended the game with nine men.
fields.body:
Nottingham Forest's play-off hopes were hit after they "committed suicide" at Wolves, where for the second successive season they ended the game with nine men.

Their charity did not ended there, and Gareth Edds put the ball into his own net after 48 minutes to set Wolves on their way to a 2-0 win.

"I don't think my team lost their discipline, we just committed suicide," said David Platt, after Andy Johnson was sent off just before the break for punching Kevin Muscat in the face and Marlon Harewood received a second caution in the 89th minute.

Preston moved above Forest in eighth after a 2-0 win at Selhurst Park which left Crystal Palace firmly back in the relegation mire.

Tranmere, ahead of Sunday's FA Cup quarter-final against Liverpool, dropped back to the bottom after turning a 1-0 half-time lead into a 3-1 defeat by Crewe. "We've got to concentrate on getting points in the league," said John Aldridge. "People have asked all season why we play so well in the cups and not in the league, but I can't answer that. I've said it before but it's driving me mad."

Reading were the big winners of the weekend in the Second Division, beating their promotion rivals Rotherham 2-0 while all the clubs above them dropped points.

Wigan were particularly poor, failing to break down a limited if hard-working Swindon side in a 0-0 home draw. The visiting manager Andy King enthused: "We were awful today but at least we battled. Last week we were just awful."

Carlisle remain marooned on the bottom of the Third Division after Darlington inflicted their seventh home defeat of the season, 2-0.

fields.headline: Wiltord puts his case for Spartak
fields.trailText: Despite scoring a timely hat-trick to erase memories of Arsenal's drubbing at Old Trafford last week, Sylvain Wiltord is still not guaranteed a place for the match against Spartak Moscow tomorrow night.
fields.body:
Sylvain Wiltord scored a timely hat-trick to erase memories of Arsenal's drubbing at Old Trafford a week earlier but even that may not be enough to guarantee him a place in tomorrow night's Champions League encounter with Spartak Moscow. "I don't just look at the goals you score," said Arsène Wenger enigmatically. "I haven't made up my mind for Tuesday."

The Arsenal manager is renowned for promoting competition among his strikers but even so that was probably not the most tactful thing he could have said. Wiltord is notorious for not taking a place on the bench lying down and, when the record £13m signing was dropped for the match against Lyon in February, he claimed the decision had "stuck in his throat".

That was just one of several outbursts since he joined from Bordeaux last August, among the others being: "I was annoyed and disappointed not to be in the team. I thought I'd have played straight away up front"; and "I'm suffering from not being able to express myself and from not playing two games in succession".

They were not comments designed to ingratiate himself with the man who bought him but, now he is scoring goals for fun and giving Wenger the sort of headache managers secretly enjoy, the urbane manager seems quite prepared to let those bygones be bygones.

"I know that patience is not the biggest quality in our society any more but it took him time to settle, because of the language, because it's the first time he left the country, and as well as that I couldn't give him a run because of the competition we have in the team, so it took him longer to adapt.

"But I like the way he plays; he's mobile and he is difficult to mark because he goes everywhere. He has found the right pace and adapted to the English game and he complements everybody."

Three goals in 33 minutes was more than enough complementary medicine to cure Arsenal of their Manchester United hangover. The first came from a mistake by Stuart Pearce who headed the ball tamely to the feet of Robert Pires; and, when the right-winger put Wiltord through, he buried the ball emphatically.

Another mistake from Pearce allowed Wiltord to wriggle free for his second, and then he timed his run perfectly to collect Frederik Ljungberg's pass and slot home his hat-trick goal and his eighth this new year.

A weakened West Ham must now regroup for another London derby with Chelsea on Wednesday and their FA Cup quarter-final against Tottenham on Sunday. Paolo di Canio will be back after suspension but there are doubts about the fitness of Frédéric Kanouté, Joe Cole and Michael Carrick, all absent on Saturday.

With Trevor Sinclair and Steve Lomas also injured, the Hammers' manager Harry Redknapp lamented: "I can't afford to be without six top players, especially against a team like Arsenal. I knew it was all over before half-time."

It meant a disappointing first return for the former Highbury favourite Nigel Winterburn, wearing the captain's armband and given a standing ovation before the match, but a comfortable comeback after injury for Tony Adams, who was relishing the week ahead which climaxes with a Cup quarter-final against Blackburn or Bolton on Saturday.

"Come next Sunday we could be still in the runners-up place in the Premiership and close to reaching the quarter-finals of the Champions League and the semi-finals of the FA Cup," he said in the programme. "That is not a bad position to be in at the beginning of March." Reports of Arsenal's demise have been greatly exaggerated.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Internet lectures on groundbreaking new site

fields.headline: Star thinkers in 'e-learning' launch
fields.standfirst:
Brief free taste for public but internet expositions by top academics such as Richard Dawkins and Niall Ferguson will then be licensed

More net news
fields.trailText: Three eminent dons will deliver interactive, online lectures on a ground breaking internet site to be launched today.
fields.body:
They are among the greatest thinkers of the day, driving forward an understanding in a range of disciplines from the origins of the cosmos to the nature of consciousness. But from today, 12 of the world's leading academics will be available to expound on their latest theories at the touch of a button.

Richard Dawkins, evolutionary biologist, Niall Ferguson, controversial history professor and the media's current academic favourite, and Sir Martin Rees, the astronomer royal, are three of the eminent dons who will deliver interactive, online lectures on a ground breaking internet site to be launched today.

In a development which may herald the web's coming of age as a powerful educational tool, the series of "e-lectures" will cover topics as diverse as the human genome project, Shakespeare's Othello and the relationship between power and money.

Alongside the eminent British contingent, will be three leading American academics, including Steven Pinker, the world-renowned professor of brain and cognitive sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

His lecture, the Ingredients of Language, poses some fundamental questions. "How does language work?" he asks. "What is the trick behind our ability to share so many different kinds of ideas, merely by making noise as we exhale? ... the prediction that regular forms are generated by rule whenever memory fails helps to make sense of the many puzzles of language, such as how children learn their mother tongue, where language resides in the brain and why no one really seems to know the plural of Walkman."

Richard Halkett, who set up Boxmind - the company producing the e-lectures - with two fellow Oxford graduates three years ago, said: "Everybody has heard of Richard Dawkins, Niall Ferguson and the others. They might have heard them on the radio or seen them on television but very few will ever have had the chance to hear them deliver a lecture. Now they can log on and see them put forward their greatest theories."

Boxmind claims the site will blow apart traditional approaches to study. Because the lectures are not delivered by a live webcast but by a broadcast of filmed material, users can stop the action at any point and follow the extensive links on each page for in-depth background information on specific points. The lectures can also be rewound and examined line by line for weaknesses in the argument.

The technology used for the site - www.boxmind.com - is as inventive as the concept. Each lecture screen is split into four. In the top left, a talking head delivers the lecture, while synchronised slides run in the top right. In the bottom right there is a synchronised transcript of the entire lecture - complete with embedded footnotes - next to the relevant web links.

The 12 lectures will form the foundations of a growing archive. But there is one drawback: the resource is open to members of the public only until the end of the month. After that, the lectures will be licensed for use by individual universities, which will also be able to have their own academic staff delivering lectures in the same way.

"It is a pity that the public won't be able to access them," said Mr Halkett. "But the reality of internet businesses since the dot.com collapse is that we have to make real money."

The technology driving the site has potential far beyond academia. One option already under discussion is a deal with publishers for similar sites to tie in with new book releases, especially in the booming popular science market. That opens the possibility of readers being able to log on and have ready access to leading authors - Stephen Hawking, for example - to take them through their latest work.

The launch of the e-lectures is also likely to intensify demands for high quality online learning. So far the internet's potential as an educational resource has been limited by the sheer volume of information it carries.

In February last year, David Blunkett, the education secretary, announced plans for the world's first national e-university, offering a "British university education" worldwide.

But since then the grand plan has foundered, with many sceptics dubbing it an irrelevant white elephant on a par with the Millennium Dome. The government itself admits that the project is at least four years from fruition.

But Mr Halkett said the new e-lectures were proof that the internet could be made to deliver. "We started off building an online library but we quickly realised how scarce decent material is out there. We decided to produce our own and now we have a lecture series which offers dynamic, unrivalled access to the most persuasive thinkers of the day."

Heavy hitters in the groves of academe

The site's first 12 lecturers are:

Richard Dawkins
Fellow of New College, Oxford, and Charles Simonyi, professor of the public understanding of science. Lecture title: Survival of the Fittest - the Fittest What?

Niall Ferguson
Professor of political and financial history, at Oxford. Lecture title: The Cash Nexus - Money and Power in the Modern World.

Sir Martin Rees
Astronomer Royal and Royal Society professor at Kings College, Cambridge. Lecture title: Cosmic Evolution.

Daniel Dennett
Professor of philosophy, and director of the Center for Cognitive Studies at Tufts University, Massachusetts. Lecture title: Consciousness: More Like Fame Than Television.

Peter Atkins
SmithKline Beecham fellow and tutor in physical chemistry at Lincoln College, Oxford. Lecture title: The Second Law.

John Kay
Fellow of St John's College, Oxford, and visiting professor of economics at the London School of Economics. Lecture title: The Foundations of Corporate Success.

David Womersley
Fellow and tutor in English literature and senior tutor of Jesus College, Oxford. Lecture title: Tragedy and Individuality in Othello.

John Searle
Mills professor of the philosophy of mind and language, University of California at Berkeley. Lecture title: Consciousness, Free Will and the Brain.

Sir David Weatherall
Regius professor of medicine at Oxford. Lecture title: The Human Genome Project and the Future of Medical Practice.

Ian Stewart
Professor of mathematics at Warwick University. Lecture title: Order and Chaos in Mathematics and Nature.

Nicola Lacey
Professor of criminal law at LSE. Lecture title: Criminal Law and Modern Society.

Steven Pinker
Peter de Florez professor in the department of brain and cognitive sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Lecture title: The Ingredients of Language.

The government itself admits that the project is at least four years from fruition. But Mr Halkett said the new e-lectures were proof that the internet could be made to deliver. Lecture title: Survival of the Fittest - the Fittest What? Niall Ferguson Professor of political and financial history, at Oxford. Lecture title: The Cash Nexus - Money and Power in the Modern World. Sir Martin Rees Astronomer Royal and Royal Society professor at Kings College, Cambridge. Lecture title: Cosmic Evolution. Daniel Dennett Professor of philosophy, and director of the Center for Cognitive Studies at Tufts University, Massachusetts. Lecture title: Consciousness: More Like Fame Than Television. Peter Atkins SmithKline Beecham fellow and tutor in physical chemistry at Lincoln College, Oxford. Lecture title: The Second Law. John Kay Fellow of St John's College, Oxford, and visiting professor of economics at the London School of Economics. Lecture title: The Foundations of Corporate Success. David Womersley Fellow and tutor in English literature and senior tutor of Jesus College, Oxford. Lecture title: Tragedy and Individuality in Othello. John Searle Mills professor of the philosophy of mind and language, University of California at Berkeley. Lecture title: Consciousness, Free Will and the Brain. Sir David Weatherall Regius professor of medicine at Oxford. Lecture title: The Human Genome Project and the Future of Medical Practice. Ian Stewart Professor of mathematics at Warwick University. Lecture title: Order and Chaos in Mathematics and Nature. Nicola Lacey Professor of criminal law at LSE. Lecture title: Criminal Law and Modern Society. Steven Pinker Peter de Florez professor in the department of brain and cognitive sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Lecture title: The Ingredients of Language.

fields.headline: Souness thrives in second-chance saloon
fields.trailText: A season of comebacks in Blackburn looks increasingly likely to end with the club back in the Premiership after a two-year absence. When Fulham beat them 2-1 in October Blackburn were 15th and struggling; since then they have lost twice and are surging inexorably upwards.
fields.body:
A season of comebacks in Blackburn looks increasingly likely to end with the club back in the Premiership after a two-year absence. When Fulham beat them 2-1 in October Blackburn were 15th and struggling; since then they have lost twice and are surging inexorably upwards.

So pleased is Graeme Souness, whose managerial career seemed close to ruin not so long ago, with this personal and professional change of fortune that he is busy handing second chances to, it seems, anyone who comes to his attention.

On Saturday the marauding wing-play of Damien Duff was mirrored on the right by Keith Gillespie, who was starting his first game at home in more than 11 months. He might have considered his original exclusion somewhat harsh as his last match, against Sheffield United, was won 5-0.

But consider the case of Eyal Berkovic, who completed 90 minutes for the first time since August - when he scored a hat-trick in Celtic's 7-0 win over Jeunesse Esch.

"It's an amazing turn-around," Gillespie said - of himself, rather than his team. "I never thought I'd play for this club again and I was as amazed as anyone when the manager called me in and said he'd give me a second chance. It was just a case of working hard and hoping something happens."

A loan spell at Wigan made little difference and another month on the sidelines followed before his recent return. "It was difficult. I've been used to first-team football for all my career so those four months were tough, but I've worked hard in training and seem to be getting the reward.

"But it's not easy when you've been out for as long as I have. Fortunately I've joined a winning side, my fitness is getting better with every game but a lot of the time you get by on sheer adrenalin."

It is a similar story with Berkovic, who may have been sidelined at Celtic but remains a bright, perceptive presence in midfield. It was he who finally broke down an organised if uninspired West Brom, exchanging passes with David Dunn and cutting back to the unmarked Marcus Bent. A permanent move would probably suit both player and club.

"I don't think about Celtic any more, just Blackburn," he says. "When I came I said we need to get out very quick from this division, and I think it will be easier playing in the Premiership because it is more quality."

Sven-Goran Eriksson is not the only international coach doing the rounds of league grounds. Berkovic's performance was watched by the Israel coach Richard Møller Nielsen, another Scandinavian verbally brandishing a diploma in diplomacy. "I was very pleased with what I saw," he said, "and of course I wish Blackburn all the best of luck about the promotion." They may not need it.

fields.headline: Royle looks lost for everything but words
fields.trailText: After Manchester City beat Southampton 2-0 at the Dell last October they were 10th in the Premiership. Thumped 5-0 by Arsenal in their next game, Joe Royle's team have slid inexorably out of the light and into the undergrowth where they continue to scuffle about with increasing uncertainty, their legs entangled and their brains befuddled.
fields.body:
After Manchester City beat Southampton 2-0 at the Dell last October they were 10th in the Premiership. Thumped 5-0 by Arsenal in their next game, Joe Royle's team have slid inexorably out of the light and into the undergrowth where they continue to scuffle about with increasing uncertainty, their legs entangled and their brains befuddled.

This was a truly awful match, redeemed in the eyes of Southampton by one touch of real class from Dan Petrescu. Glenn Hoddle's views on certain aspects of life may be peculiar but there is no doubting his ability to organise a side, and City had neither the wit nor the quality to turn matters round after the Romanian's delightful volley.

Royle's sides are never short on effort, and he did win the FA Cup while at Goodison Park, but there appears something antique about Royle's methods now. Of the teams promoted last season, City were clearly the least able of the three, and it is of no surprise that they have struggled. Their one player of genuine class is Andrei Kanchelskis who, although long past his prime, remains capable of inflicting damage, provided somebody gives him the ball in the right area.

City have no such midfielder, consequently Kanchelskis finds himself marginalised, particularly at Maine Road where Royle's team have lost nine times this season. Forced to attack, City flounder and become increasingly susceptible at the back. "Two strikes against us in 180 minutes and no points," grumbled Royle, in reference to both this match and the previous 1-0 home defeat by Tottenham.

Their own 1-0 win at Newcastle had infused City's long-suffering fans with a cautious optimism, which quickly evaporated in the face of excellent goalkeeping by Paul Jones and a towering performance in the centre of defence by Dean Richards. And even when Petrescu clearly handled the ball in the second half, no penalty was given, with the referee Jeff Winter unsighted and his assistant similarly so.

"I always felt they didn't believe they could get the result," said Hoddle. "They keep getting a glimmer of light but it's all about getting a couple of back-to-back wins." City have managed that once this season, against Southampton and Bradford City, and time is fast running out.

After the unexpected three-point bonus at St James' Park, this was to have been the start of a run of seemingly productive matches for Royle's team, against Southampton and Aston Villa at home, Bradford City and Everton away. It is now doubly essential that they win away against Bradford a week on Saturday.

With nine matches remaining, five of them away, City cannot be written off, although it is difficult to be optimistic after this disjointed, uninspiring performance. Royle insists that morale has never been a problem, which may be true, but lack of talent clearly is. Royle's admission that "at times we've lacked a bit of guile" was simply preposterous. There was no guile whatever in this game.

Essentially there was little to choose between City and Southampton. The difference was that Hoddle made far better use of his limited resources within a framework his team were comfortable with. Royle, faced with a building collapsing in the wind, seems capable only of blaming the weather.

fields.headline: Relief for Rix on debut as Pompey play up at last
fields.trailText: The Pompey chimes resonated with relief after Graham Rix's first foray into football management brought Portsmouth their first win since January.
fields.body:
The Pompey chimes resonated with relief after Graham Rix's first foray into football management brought Portsmouth their first win since January.

These have been testing times at Fratton Park. Two wins in 20 games prior to Rix's appointment had left the spectre of relegation hanging over the South Coast club and led to the removal of the fans' favourite Steve Claridge from the managerial hot seat.

The outspoken comments by Claridge regarding his now clearly untenable position at the club, and the unwelcome attention to Rix's past off-field misdemeanours, were not ideal preparation for the former Chelsea coach's first game in charge. However, the fraught Portsmouth press officer, who threatened to abandon the post-match press conference if there were questions about the manager's personal life, need not have worried.

A hard-earned if not totally convincing win meant that the focus of proceedings was firmly fixed on football. After a scrappy opening period Portsmouth settled this match with two second-half strikes. The first came from Luke Nightingale, who rounded off a neat move after 56 minutes by planting an emphatic finish past Nikolaos Michopoulos from 12 yards.

The 20-year-old's first league game settled the hosts' nerves and thereafter they dominated proceedings. Burnley, who have not won away from Turf Moor since October, were killed off 13 minutes later when Gordon Armstrong bodychecked the lively Steve Lovell in the box and Michael Panopoulos doubled the lead from the penalty spot.

Afterwards a palpably relieved Rix urged against over-optimism. "I've been looking forward to today all week and I'm delighted for the club. There's a long way to go but the win is good for confidence.

"We want to stay in the First Division; that is our priority this season. We've got another game on Wednesday and we need another positive result and performance."

But the new manager was under no illusions about the size of the task he has been set by Portsmouth's Florida-based chairman Milan Mandaric. "It's a big job in every sense," said Rix. "The chairman wants to be in the Premiership as soon as possible. Portsmouth has been a sleeping giant for ages and everyone in football knows this is a football town."

There was also relief at being back in football after he became one of the first victims of Claudio Ranieri's purge on English-speaking personnel at Stamford Bridge. "I'm happy to be back in football. I've missed it too much. Saturday afternoons at home watching Sky Sports is not the same; you miss the adrenalin rush."

Rix was guarded on his offer of a coaching role to Claridge. "Don't ask me about Steve Claridge. I've given him a few days off to think about it and it's up to him. He phoned me on Friday night to wish me good luck, which was nice of him."

fields.headline: Quivering Boro speed up the ageing process
fields.trailText: It is hard to distinguish the frozen shivers from the nervous shakes on Teesside these days. Having watched, cursed and ultimately despaired of their team's shortcomings on Saturday, Middlesbrough fans arrived home to discover they had actually put another point between themselves and the relegation zone. But they may have aged a few years in the process.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
It is hard to distinguish the frozen shivers from the nervous shakes on Teesside these days. Having watched, cursed and ultimately despaired of their team's shortcomings on Saturday, Middlesbrough fans arrived home to discover they had actually put another point between themselves and the relegation zone. But they may have aged a few years in the process.

The run of draws that had extended Terry Venables' 12-game unbeaten start and prompted deceptive security has been transformed into a winless seven-match streak.

With Charlton, their safety assured, playing with slick aplomb, home nerves began jangling within two minutes. Radostin Kishishev advanced down the right flank and crossed for Jonatan Johansson, completely unmarked, to nod wide.

Five minutes later Claus Jensen obligingly passed the Finnish striker's cross into Mark Schwarzer's midriff, and by the time Shaun Bartlett ballooned over the bar early in the second half many of the home faithful had been reduced to gibbering wrecks.

"It only takes one bad ball or a missed tackle to start the crowd off," said Schwarzer, who missed the death throes of Boro's relegation in 1997 - a demotion which still haunts Teesside - with a broken leg. "It doesn't help when the fans go off at us, but they get frustrated and it's understandable.

"But we are in a far better position now than we were four years ago. We were conceding goals all over the place in '97 and I think we are a better side now, even if we had better individuals back then."

What Boro wouldn't give for the creative fizz of a Juninho, Paul Merson or Nick Barmby to spark their shot-shy front line into life. Only when Christian Karembeu marauded forward after 71 minutes did the home side suggest self-confidence, but even the Frenchman prompted boos seven minutes later when he squared Alen Boksic's cross to a Charlton defender rather than shoot at goal.

Otherwise Boksic - who forced Sasa Ilic into a late save and retained his air of untapped class - and the demoralised Hamilton Ricard cut isolated figures. At least Dean Windass, who should complete a £600,000 move from Bradford today, will provide a more rugged link between midfield and attack, allowing the Croatian to concentrate on tormenting defenders rather than withdrawing into midfield in search of the ball. The Colombian, racked with self-doubt, may be beyond salvation.

"We should have won the game after the start we had," said the Charlton and England defender Chris Powell, who ended a fairytale week with an immaculate defensive display.

"Boro haven't lost, but three points are paramount at the moment. It's getting a bit tight now. But they are creating chances and I think they will stay up. Just."

fields.headline: Lennon and Co end on a cheery note
fields.trailText: Celtic maintain their 13-point lead over Rangers.
fields.byline: Mike Wilson  at East End Park
fields.body:
Familiarity may breed contempt, but these frequent contests between Celtic and Dunfermline do allow the Pars' manager Jimmy Calderwood to continue his search for the Holy Grail of a tactical formation that will thwart the Scottish Premier League leaders.

Calderwood, who saw a 2-4-4 formation at Hearts last week end in a 7-1 defeat, tinkered in the knowledge that these two meet again on Wednesday in a Tennents Scottish Cup replay.

This win maintains Celtic's 13-point lead over second-placed Rangers in the SPL. The first goal was struck by Stilian Petrov following a diagonal pass from Henrik Larsson in the 11th minute. Two minutes later Chris Sutton exited with damaged shoulder ligaments, but Celtic's dominance continued as Larsson curled a free-kick into the top corner for his 32nd league goal of the season.

Dunfermline ran risks at the back yet no one was prepared to make the adventurous movements from midfield that were Celtic's stock in trade.

However, they caused a minimal shift in the balance of play in the second half by moving the physical David Moss into a forward position and relieving Youssef Rossi of his unequal struggle with Didier Agathe, who was shackled more effectively by the pace of the substitute Chris McGroarty.

Celtic's third came courtesy of Neil Lennon's shot drilled low from a corner, his first for the club. The away support was determined to cocoon him with affection in stark contrast to the sectarian abuse he received from a group of Northern Ireland fans in midweek. His international future will be decided over the next few days after further discussions with the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill and the player's family, including perhaps an uncle who was at Windsor Park and felt intimidated. "I don't mind the booing, it doesn't bother me. But it is my family I have to consider," said Lennon.

Of Sunday's victory, O'Neill said: "To win in such style was magnificent." However, he suggested comments made on Friday indicating an interest in bolstering the squad with players of the quality of Spurs' Sol Campbell were "a bit of fun". "I'm now going for Figo and Rivaldo," he joked.

fields.headline: Boa Morte sent off in spitting row
fields.trailText: Fulham dominated but lost their composure, and Luis Boa Morte, as this scrap between first against second ended all square.
fields.body:
For a true assessment of the disparity between these teams it is necessary to move quickly away from the scoreline and fix instead on the First Division table, particularly the respective points tallies. First against second ended all square here but it is no exaggeration to suggest that the outcome could have been as convincing as that from last Sunday when the Premiership's leading lights met up.

There was no Manchester United-Arsenal reprise because Fulham permitted Bolton to score from a direct free-kick early in the second half - it was their only attempt on target - and then allowed their own smoothly assured game to disintegrate. Their discipline went as well when the substitute Luis Boa Morte was shown the red card after retaliating with a mouthful of spittle for a heavy challenge from Robbie Elliott.

"He spat in my face twice," said the Bolton defender, who had to be held back by colleagues after the 80th-minute flashpoint. "Spitting is just something you don't do in football and he did it twice."

There can be no excusing Boa Morte's reaction even in the face of a robust rearguard deployment which sometimes leant towards physical excess.. Fulham must expect that kind of approach when their extravagant movement and passing ability leave them untouchable by opponents.

"In footballing terms they are way above everybody else," conceded the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce, and it hurt him to admit it with his own team next in line, albeit 12 points behind.

Yesterday's result was all- important for Bolton because, having lost heavily at home to Blackburn the previous weekend, they could ill afford another crushing defeat, not with the race for second place intensifying and with their fifth-round FA Cup replay with Blackburn following on Wednesday.

Yet no other outcome looked possible as Fulham were quickly into their stride, moving the ball with precision and pace across the full width of the pitch even though their opponents put five in midfield and set out to frustrate. Corners were a particular problem in the first half and after four minutes Simon Charlton was forced to clear off the line as Louis Saha met Bjarne Goldbaek's delivery. Later in the half Dean Holdsworth and Elliott came to the rescue in similar fashion.

Bolton were contributing in full to their own discomfort. Maybe disorientation is a natural consequence when faced with an opposing side who protect their possession so assiduously. Nothing else could explain what happened to Colin Hendry when he completely missed his kick and set up John Collins, who could only strike the post.

It did not seem to matter when, in the 42nd minute, a delicious piece of craft broke Bolton's grim resistance. Sean Davis and Rufus Brevett combined and Saha's neat turn produced a pass for Barry Hayles, who expertly threw off Hendry's challenge before dispatching a clinical finish.

Bolton pulled level through Per Frandsen's set piece six minutes after half-time. And despite Lee Clark never tiring in his prompting and Collins finding the woodwork again, Fulham couldn't break their visitors' resistance. So, as the man on the public address said, just a 12-point lead.

fields.headline: New author Holloway starts his sentence
fields.trailText: The public address man at Queens Park Rangers spoke excitedly of a new chapter in the club's history beforehand but sadly for the new author, Ian Holloway, there was no immediate twist in the plot on Saturday.
fields.body:
The public address man at Queens Park Rangers spoke excitedly of a new chapter in the club's history beforehand but sadly for the new author, Ian Holloway, there was no immediate twist in the plot on Saturday.

Received warmly by a below-average crowd, Holloway now has 12 games to craft a thriller from a horror after Rangers let slip a half-time lead and fell back into the relegation places. Otherwise the mirth generated by an erroneous reference to this "Division Two clash" in his programme notes will taste bitter when reality bites.

"It's exceptionally tight," he said. "If we were to win two games on the spin we could be up to 16th place.

"Everybody knows where the club was and where it is now - and they're absolutely scared to death of where it might end up. That's a massive point to me."

Holloway took Bristol Rovers to the brink of the Second Division play-offs last year before an end-of-season wobble cost them a place but this season Rovers' own relegation fears prompted his sacking at the end of January.

Diminutive and genial, he spoke candidly of his hopes to bring the best out of the Rangers squad inherited from Gerry Francis - despite being overrun in the second half here, they did not drop their heads and give up - and conceded that glances are being cast towards the March 22 transfer deadline.

"We're trying to bring players into certain areas," he said. "We've got to bombard it [the transfer market] and we've got three weeks to do it."

The dancing hordes in the School End told of a different story as Sheffield United leapt into the play-off places.

After Michel Ngonge headed Rangers in front, United's wide-right maestro Paul Devlin ran the show.

Ludek Miklosko flapped his whippy cross to Shaun Murphy, who drilled an equaliser; Georges Santos headed in Bobby Ford's cross from the left soon after and then Devlin charged through the defence and laid off sublimely for Santos to end the contest.

Neil Warnock, the United manager, was pleased to rise above the dotted line but flirt ing with the play-offs brings a nervy quest for perfection.

"There were times when we were 3-1 up when we did things I don't want us to do," he said.

"If we start thinking we're a good team, we become a bad team; if we are on top of our game, we are a good team."

With weeks of elation, anguish and convoluted mathematics ahead, spare a thought for poor Mrs Warnock.

"My missus is panicking, she's expecting on May 22," the manager said, his baby due six days before the play-off final.

It is a world away from Holloway's mission. "I'm going to try," he said. "That's what they're going to put on my headstone: 'Here lies Olly: he tried'." - an endearing, if peculiar, way of asserting he and Rangers are not dead yet.

fields.headline: Well-travelled shortlist for Impac award
fields.standfirst: Full list of nominated titles on the Impac website
fields.trailText: The Impac literary award, notable for its unpredictability, its refreshingly wide range of foreign fiction and its belated nature (the current award honours titles published in 1999) has announced its shortlist for 2001.
fields.body:
The Impac literary award, notable for its unpredictability, its refreshingly wide range of foreign fiction and its belated nature (the current award honours titles published in 1999) has announced its shortlist for 2001.

The judges for this unique Irish award, which is open to books in any language, have drawn up a shortlist from over 70 nominations made by 100 selected libraries throughout the world. Each library was allowed to nominate up to three novels and the eventual list spanned such diverse titles as Günter Grass's My Century and John Grisham's The Testament.

No English writers made the shortlist, and out of the six, two - The Love You Promised Me by Spanish writer Silvia Molina and the Russian satire The Clay Machine-Gun by Victor Pelevin - are translations.

Scotland and Ireland are represented by Andrew O'Hagan's powerful tale of the end of socialist ideals, Our Fathers, and Colm Tóibín's modern tragedy of morals and manners, The Blackwater Lightship. Canadian writer Alastair McLeod's look at his celtic roots, No Great Mischief, also made the shortlist, as did Margaret Cezair-Thompson's story of three women born into a divided, troubled Jamaica, The True History of Paradise.

Now in its fifth year, the winner is chosen by an international panel of judges, which this year includes Indian writer Amit Chaudhuri and American historian Allen Weinstein. The winner receives IR£100,000 if the book is written in English and IR£75,000 if the book is in English translation, allowing the translator to pick up IR£25,000.

Nicola Barker won last year's award for her novel Wide Open.

The winner will be announced on May 14 2001.

The shortlist

The Love You Promised Me by Silvia Molina
Not yet published in the UK, this award-winning novel focuses on a two-day trip the protagonist Marcela, a professional woman in her 40s, takes to reflect on her recently ended affair with a much older married lover. Molina combines emotional shifts in Macela's life with the political situation in Mexico during the country's 1994 elections.

The True History of Paradise by Margaret Cezair-Thompson
Told from the perspectives of three women, this first novel from Jamaican-born Cezair-Thompson blends history and fiction in a tale of personal identity and family loyalties set against the backdrop of Jamaica's troubled political state in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

The Blackwater Lightship by Colm Tóibín
Shortlisted for the Booker Prize, this story of gay identity, Irish conservatism, family conflict and mortality is told in spare, bleak prose. Three generations of infighting women gather by the bedside of the favourite son, who is dying of Aids.

Our Fathers by Andrew O'Hagan
This grimly realist tale of Scotland, socialism and family conflict also made the Booker shortlist. The narrator must come to terms with the tragedy of his grandfather, once a social improver with grand dreams and now reduced to desolation.

The Clay Machine-Gun by Victor Pelevin
Manic satire from the brightest young star of Russian literature. In a parallel life, the hero is a soldier in the 1917 Revolution; in the here and now, he's a patient in a psychiatric clinic, undergoing untrustworthy therapies. A worthy successor to Bulgakov's The Master and Margarita.

No Great Mischief by Alastair McLeod
In delicately poetic prose imbued with Gaelic cadences, McLeod examines the roots of the clans who fled Scotland for Cape Breton 200 years ago, but whose connection to their long-lost homeland remains profound.

webTitle: Tories cheer as Hague spurns middle ground

fields.headline: Tories cheer as Hague spurns middle ground
fields.standfirst:
Leader launches bitter personal attack on Blair as 'foreign land' diatribe warns of perils of another Labour victory

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Leader launches bitter personal attack on Blair as 'foreign land' diatribe warns of perils of another Labour victory.
fields.body:
Nudged in between rows of flag-waving Conservative diehards, who cheered William Hague to the rafters in Harrogate yesterday, a handful of glum-looking Tories sat in near silence.

The party's pro-Europeans, a rare breed these days, looked on in dismay as Mr Hague lurched further to the right with his warning that Labour would turn Britain into a "foreign land".

"This speech is going to do nothing to reach out to the centre ground," a Europhile Tory said. "This is all we need as we head into an election."

If Mr Hague had his eyes genuinely set on Downing Street, the Europhile's criticisms would have been justified. Elections, as Labour learned so painfully, tend to be won on the centre ground.

In the face of repeatedly dire opinion polls, however, the Tory leadership has privately abandoned any hope of victory and is concentrating instead on shoring up its core base. Central Office strategists calculate that if enough lifelong Tories - 2m of whom stayed at home in 1997 - turn out on polling day, then Mr Hague should win back enough seats to set his sights on a victory at the election after next.

Any doubts that Mr Hague might try to take the battle to the centre ground were quickly dispelled when he dismissed health and education in a few paragraphs of his speech. Instead, he devoted an entire page to asylum seekers, and more than a page to grim warnings about how Tony Blair's enthusiasm for Europe would destroy Britain.

After delegates were shown a video of the prime minister, accompanied by funereal music, Mr Hague issued his chilling warning as he invoked Rupert Brooke. "Let me take you on a journey to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair," he said. "The Royal Mint melting down pound coins as the euro notes start to circulate. Our currency gone forever ... The jail doors opening as thousands more serious criminals walk out early to offend again."

Warming to his theme, Mr Hague launched a highly personal attack on the prime minister, accusing him of feeling embarrassed at being British.

"If there's one thing that sets me apart from Tony Blair, it's this: I'm not embarrassed to articulate the instincts of the people of our country," he said. "The governing of this country has drifted far away from the decent, plain speaking common sense of its people. It's time to bring it back. It's time to bring Britain home."

A Labour victory, Mr Hague declared, would remove the need for further elections because Mr Blair would allow Brussels to take over Britain. In an attempt to win back anti-Europeans, who may be tempted to vote for the UK Independence Party, threatening key Tory marginal seats, Mr Hague said: "I appeal to all those people who may not have voted Conservative before but who believe in an independent Britain. At this coming election, lend us your vote. Vote for us this time so that your vote will mean something next time, and the time after, and the time after that."

Tory officials denied that Mr Hague was playing the race card, because they said that his warning of a "foreign land" did not apply to asylum seekers. But Mr Hague is acutely aware that such a term is highly loaded and will be used to characterise his entire speech.

His remarks on asylum also struck a shrill tone. He was careful to make clear that Britain should offer protection to people fleeing persecution, saying: "We should make Britain a safe haven but not a soft touch."

But he warned of "immediate deportion" for anyone whose asylum claim was rejected, a process that will take weeks under the Tories, and he lambasted illegal asylum seekers who had "elbowed aside" genuine applicants.

Mr Hague's supporters left Harrogate last night delighted that their leader had once again made waves with a headline-grabbing speech. Other Tories were left wondering whether Michael Portillo had sensed where the future lies. The shadow chancellor made clear his unequivocal opposition to the euro over the weekend, but he did so in less strident terms. His performance even won a standing ovation from the pro-European Mainstream group.

Speech was by hardline columnist

Daniel Hannan, a hardline Eurosceptic Tory MEP, has been drafted in as one of William Hague's main speech writers for the general election, signalling a further move to the right by the leadership.

He had his first outing in the speech yesterday by Mr Hague, which bore similarities to recent articles and speeches Mr Hannan has written. Even his critics acknowledge that Mr Hannan is an eloquent writer, one whose grasp of history will, Tory central office hopes, add some weight to Mr Hague's speeches.

A controversial figure, Mr Hannan has come close to suggesting that Britain should withdraw from the European Union. Pro-European Tories are likely to react to the appointment of the Daily Telegraph columnist with dismay. Last year he raised more than £100,000 to help the "no" camp in the Danish euro referendum campaign.

Mr Hannan is being brought into central office to replace Danny Finkelstein and George Osborne, Mr Hague's main speech writers, who are fighting seats in the general election.

fields.headline: Blair bids for green lobby
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will tomorrow try to put flesh on his commitment to fight global warming, by promising extra investment to remove Britian's dependence on fossils fuels, such as oil and gas.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will tomorrow try to put flesh on his commitment to fight global warming, by promising extra investment to remove Britian's dependence on fossils fuels, such as oil and gas.

In his second big speech on the environment in a few months, Mr Blair is expected to announce extra cash for solar, wind and wave power as he promises that 10% of British energy will derive from renewable sources by 2010. He will predict the renewable energy market will reach £1bn by 2010.

The move comes as the Commons environmental audit select committee prepares this week to issue a damning indictment of the government's decision to freeze fuel duties in the pre-budget report without making a serious assessment of the environmental impact.

The select committee chairman, Sir John Horman, said the government's balancing measures were cosmetic.

Mr Blair is expected to promise to meet German and Japanese levels of solar power investment.

There have been long-standing complaints that getting planning permission for wave power projects is cumbersome and over-long.

Underlining the seriousness of the potential crisis, Michael Meacher, the environment minister, yesterday warned that Britain could face out breaks of malaria unless the international community got a grip on global warming.

Mr Meacher hopes the speech will mark a turning point in the government's relations with an increasingy sceptical environmental lobby.

Mr Blair's speech suggests party pollsters are telling him that he needs to raise the issue if he is to enthuse disaffected younger voters. The Liberal Democrats and the Greens have both been heavily critical of Labour's inactivity over the environment. Mr Meacher told BBC1's On the Record yesterday: "Renewable energy is ... at the centre of the switch away from fossil fuel ... to the renewable sources of energy ... above all, solar and the hydrogen fuel cell for cars".

fields.headline: Mandelson likely to be exonerated
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson is to be broadly exonerated of deliberately lying or improperly lobbying for a passport on behalf of the Indian tycoon Srichand Hinduja.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson is to be broadly exonerated of deliberately lying or improperly lobbying for a passport on behalf of the Indian tycoon Srichand Hinduja.

But the detailed conclusions of an official inquiry by Sir Anthony Hammond QC have yet to be written, and the report may raise doubts about Mr Mandelson's judgment in handling Downing Street inquiries about his role.

Mr Mandelson met Sir Anthony on Friday for two hours to clarify aspects of the proposed narrative of the affair in the report. Mr Mandelson's lawyers are still disputing passages of the report - which may not be published until Friday or even next week - suggesting that some findings may be critical.

Friends of Mr Mandelson are anxious that accounts in the Sunday newspapers might falsely raise expectations and alienate his limited support within Downing Street.

Tony Blair would personally be embarrassed by a report which entirely exonerated Mr Mandelson since it would raise questions about his judgment in dismissing him and the haste with which the No 10 press secretary Alastair Campbell acted in supporting his effective dismissal.

Downing Street is hopeful that the report will state that it had to act quickly over Mr Mandelson's future because of the pressure of political events. It believes Mr Mandelson showed a lack of judgment and failed to be open with all the potentially relevant facts at the time of its inquiries into his role before his resignation at the end of January.

Mr Mandelson believes the report will show that the whole episode was characterised less by malice than by honest misunderstandings. He told one friend that "the whole saga is rife with crossed wires, Chinese whispers and hazy recollections".

The report is also likely to exonerate the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, in his efforts to get a passport for the Hinduja brothers, but it will heavily criticise the chaotic and inadequate way in which the Home Office keeps its records.

The Hammond inquiry has found no documentary evidence within the Home Office that a phone conversation took place between the Home Office minister Mike O'Brien and Mr Mandelson, then working in the Cabinet Office, in 1998. Nor does it appear that any civil servant in the Home Office definitely recalls any verbal reference to the conversation Mr O'Brien cites.

But Sir Anthony is likely to conclude the call did, on balance, occur, in part because Mr O'Brien, as a more junior minister at the time, was more likely to recall the conversation than Mr Mandelson.

The inquiry has also found that on the eve of Mr Mandelson's resignation the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, was inadvertently misinformed that Mr Mandelson's former private secretary in the Cabinet Office, Emma Scott, had remembered the phone call between Mr Mandelson and Mr O'Brien.
