webTitle: MP accuses ministers of deceit in Chinook crash inquiry

fields.headline: MP accuses ministers of using deceit to block inquiry into Chinook crash
fields.trailText: Ministry of Defence officials and ministers have "deliberately distorted" the findings of a defence select committee report so as to back a ban on a new inquiry into the 1994 Chinook helicopter crash on the Mull of Kintyre, an insider says.
fields.byline: Stuart Millar  and  Richard Norton Taylor
fields.body:
Ministry of Defence officials and ministers have "deliberately distorted" the findings of a defence select committee report so as to back a ban on a new inquiry into the 1994 Chinook helicopter crash on the Mull of Kintyre, an insider says.

The Tory MP Crispin Blunt has become the first committee member to publicly accuse ministers of misleading MPs and the public by claiming that its 1998 report supports the official line that the pilots were to blame for the crash.

The attack comes at a time when ministers will face the strongest challenge yet to the official version, as peers demand a House of Lords investigation in to the crash. Lord Chalfont, who is supported by several peers, will today propose the setting up of a Lords select committee to challenge the verdict blaming the pilots.

The government is likely to oppose the motion. It is understood ministers will again cite the 1998 report as support for their line that only pilot error, not a technical malfunction was behind the crash.

This line has been consistently used by ministers and officials to dismiss a damning report, into the MoD's handling of the crash, by the public accounts committee last November. It accused the MoD of "unwarrantable arrogance", "flawed logic", and "shocking" aircraft test procedures.

The Guardian has obtained a letter dated January 10 2001 from the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, to Virginia Bottomley, the constituency MP for the family of one of the pilots. Mr Hoon said: "The [PAC] conclusions run contrary to those [of] the defence committee .. that "there was no compelling evidence of fundamental flaws in the design of the Chinook or its components".

Mr Blunt, an adviser in the MoD at the time of the crash, told the Guardian: "These statements are not true. We .. did not look into the crash but were concerned with the operation of the Chinook fleet now."

Lord Chalfont said: "A Lords committee is the only route left open to us."

webTitle: Budget to give public jobs boost

fields.headline: Budget to give public jobs boost
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: An extra £500m-£800m to help teacher and police recruitment and ease bed blocking in the NHS is expected to be a surprise element in Gordon Brown's pre-election Budget on Wednesday.
fields.body:
An extra £500m-£800m to help teacher and police recruitment and ease bed blocking in the NHS is expected to be a surprise element in Gordon Brown's pre-election Budget on Wednesday.

The extra spending for 2001-02 is on top of the generous allocations set out in last summer's spending review. The cash, currently being negotiated by the Treasury, Downing Street and spending departments, is seen as a high-profile commitment to public services.

The package, likely to be finalised in meetings tonight, would be used to fund a pay scheme to encourage retired teachers to return to work, or to encourage supply teachers to work permanently.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, believes levels of teacher training are acceptable, but there is a serious problem of teacher shortages in classrooms.

Jack Straw also wants extra cash to fund his package to recruit extra police and ease housing problems. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is looking for money to ease continuing bed blocking in the NHS and meet targets for reducing cancelled operations.

Tony Blair is understood to be supporting the key workers package, partly because he believes it will be attractive to middle income, middle-aged Britain.

Some Labour strategists believe Mr Brown's Budget is excessively targeted at welfare benefit reforms to help the poor, many of whom do not bother to vote.

The package can in part be funded from £2.8bn savings in the social security budget generated by lower than predicted unemployment.

The extra cash for health is despite figures due to be published today showing NHS waiting lists rose by little over 5,000 in January, ensuring the government will meet its target to cut waiting lists by 100,000 at the time of a May election. Waiting lists are 120,000 below the figure at the time of the 1997 election. If the waiting lists had risen by as much as 11,000 - in line with January 2000 - the government's flagship pledge would have been in serious danger. The number of operations cancelled in January was 0.8%.

The bulk of the chancellor's measures will be aimed at cutting fuel duty and increasing the basic rate for pensioners by £5 for single people and £8 for couples and offering respite in fuel duty. In last December's pre-budget report he earmarked £1.75bn for pensions and fuel.

But the Budget will also contain a populist commitment to remove betting tax, replacing it with profits tax on the betting firms.

The new children's credit, available to 5m poorer families, is to be set at a maximum £520 - £10 a week.

In an attempt to broaden the Budget's appeal, Mr Brown is also expected to bow to pressure from Tony Blair and offer a token income tax cut for the middle classes. He will enlarge the slice of income covered by the 10p starting rate of tax by an extra £500, a move that would save the average household £60 a year.

He has rejected calls from within the Downing Street policy unit for a 1p cut in the basic rate of tax, which would cost almost £3bn.

Although Mr Brown is on course to chalk up a record £18bn government surplus this fiscal year, he has consistently ruled out a giveaway budget that might prevent the Bank of England from cutting interest rates again.

Thanks to a buoyant economy which has boosted tax revenues and kept spending on unemployment low, Mr Brown should still be able to announce that he is banking £16bn of his surplus.

The Bank's monetary policy committee starts its two-day meeting on Wednesday, as Mr Brown delivers his Budget. Some City analysts believe it might announce another rate cut when the meeting ends.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: For God's sake, get on with it Tony

fields.headline: For God's sake, get on with it Tony
fields.standfirst:
This phoney peace before the general election is a strain on us all

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: March 5: This phoney peace before the general election is a strain on us all, writes Roy Hattersley.
fields.body:
The sooner we hold a general election the better it will be - not for the Labour party, which will win whatever the date, but for the country, which deserves to be spared the extra weeks of not very covert campaigning.

The idea that polling day should be postponed because of the foot and mouth epidemic is the symptom of an even more virulent disease. It is called humbug and comes in a variety of strains. The most debilitating form of the contagion infects the opposition. In every other national crisis since the war - I write with the authority of a veteran, indeed casualty, of the "winter of discontent" - the government's critics have demanded an immediate dissolution of parliament. Tim Yeo, who speaks for the Tories on agriculture, continues to say that Labour ignores, neglects and perhaps even despises, rural Britain.

Why not ask rural Britain to express its opinion of the Labour party? The Tory party is anxious to postpone the election date because it is hoping for something to turn up between now and the autumn. Most of the shadow cabinet (we can make anexception for Andrew Mackay) are not stupid enough to think that a sudden change of fortune could bring victory. But William Hague's anxious followers - desperate for a result that will extend their hero's active life - pray that if they postpone the inevitable by three or four months, some national catastrophe might reduce Labour's majority to under three figures. Not a hope. They should think of the general election as a visit to the dentist. Sensible to get it over quickly.

A second sort of humbug comes from the political romantics. They have, in their minds, a bogus picture of general election campaigns. Their fantasies include brave party workers, battling against the elements as they go from door to door determined to win over another floating voter. Canvassing was never the feature of general election campaigns that party agents found it convenient to claim. In 1964 - after winning the 13th most marginal Tory seat for Labour in Britain - the Sparkbrook constituency Labour party was congratulated by national headquarters for "achieving perhaps the most extensive canvass in the country". We knocked on 60% of the doors.

Since then, old-fashioned techniques - like actually meeting voters face to face - have been replaced by telephone calls, mail shots and, increasingly, email messages. No doubt some canvassing still goes on. But no great democratic damage will be done if candidates, anxious not to spread foot and mouth disease, deny themselves the pleasure of tramping from one muddy farm track to another. If the Derbyshire village which I know best is anything to go by - where, true to the Peak District tradition, there is a farm opposite the church just round the corner from Main Street - there will be plenty of country cottages opening on to the road, with residents who can be annoyed by canvassers without the fear of spreading anything except boredom. After all, although we have all stopped walking our dogs over the hills, the postman still delivers letters.

The most stupid of all the arguments against a spring poll calls itself "respect for the farmers". It is based partly on the notion that elections are a frivolity whereas milk and meat production is real life. According to that view, practising democracy while cows and pigs are at risk is like chewing gum at a funeral. Daft though that idea is, the suggestion that, while movement restriction orders last, farmers will be denied the chance to participate in the campaign is barely less fatuous. The point would have been well made in Midlothian in 1879 when hundreds of crofters crowded to every rural railway station in the hope of hearing Mr Gladstone speak. Charles Kennedy need fear no such danger.

No doubt a number of MPs, fearful of losing their seats, and a handful of ministers, anticipating the sack, will go on deploying every argument for delay they can think of. Such people are a feature of pre-election periods. They were particularly vociferous during the late summer of 1978 when they persuaded Jim Callaghan to wait until 1979. That precedent should encourage the prime minister to brush such self-serving pleading aside.

The positive case for going ahead with the election is even stronger than the negative argument against postponing it. Once a government has the smell of battle in its nostrils, it thinks of nothing but the campaign. During the phoney peace which precedes the real conflict every decision is taken and every speech made with the poll in mind. I have enough respect for Jack Straw to believe that he would not have made his attack on lawyers for defending their clients had he not been anticipating difficult questions about crime rates on the hustings. Securing a second term has always been Tony Blair's preoccupation. Sometimes it has seemed the only purpose that the first term had. The best thing for the country is for him to get on with it.

webTitle: Feature: Dulling down. Andy Beckett on New Labour.

fields.headline: Dulling down
fields.standfirst:
Until recently the government had 600 targets for improving services. Can you remember one of them? If not, you're not alone - most of Labour's policy pronouncements seem designed to combat insomnia. Andy Beckett on the tyranny of 'hyper-rationalism'

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Until recently the government had 600 targets for improving services. Can you remember one of them? If not, you're not alone - most  of Labour's policy pronouncements seem designed to combat insomnia.  Andy Beckett  on the tyranny of 'hyper-rationalism'.
fields.body:
Matthew Taylor is a brisk, youngish man with gel in his cropped hair and a lean face that suggests austerity and purpose. He works in a tight top-floor set of offices with ink on the carpets, high above the chain cafes and raucousness of Covent Garden in central London. Until quite recently, as far as such things are measurable, he was probably New Labour's favourite intellectual. His father is the prominent left-leaning sociologist, Professor Laurie Taylor.

During the mid-90s, Taylor junior ran the party's highly valued "rapid rebuttal unit", defending its new ideas from attack. From 1996 to 1998, as Labour's director of policy, he was in charge of coming up with more. In 1997, he helped write the general election manifesto. In 1998, he became head of the government's preferred think tank, the Institute for Public Policy Research. Over a dozen of its employees have been recruited as advisers by Labour ministers. So, a few months ago, it seemed quite natural for Taylor to be asked to contribute to an important government project. With a new general election approaching, the prime minister was planning to write an article for Prospect magazine, laying out the philosophy behind Labour's next manifesto and, more generally, the party's fundamental aims and motives for being in office.

Taylor assembled his thoughts. A decade of his increasingly critical writings about capitalism and Labour's need to define itself more confidently was distilled and conveyed to Downing Street. Then, just before the article's publication last month, an ominous email came back from one of Blair's close aides. "It said: 'Sorry, the piece doesn't do justice to our discussions,'" Taylor says, with a piercing look.

This may have been an understatement. After almost four years in power, with the largest majority in Labour's history, and the Conservatives empty of rival ideas, all the prime minister had come up with was another cautious summary of the Third Way. Taylor is rather ruder about it: "The ridiculous, fatuous claim that a mild form of Christian democracy represents a new politics . . ."

His smooth, media-ready voice rises with the disappointment. Without sounding terribly regretful, he adds: "I've fucked my peerage."

It may be hard for others to feel quite so enraged by the four brief pages of Third Way, Phase Two. Like the current government in general, the article is more thoughtful in tone and international in outlook than anything you can imagine John Major, for example, ever managing. The end of communism, the future of capitalism, the need for a new British diversity, the contradictions of modern conservatism - all of these are busily covered. Every development in recent world history, it is neatly implied, has led inexorably to the creation and success of New Labour. Any lawyer would appreciate the sly blending of fact and assertion, any management consultant the numbered paragraphs.

But they numb you, after a while. The absolute certainty - Blair dismisses his critics for their "negativism" and "self-mutilation" in a couple of sentences - and the cool mist of political science jargon that settles on every sentiment are oddly alienating. There is nothing to stir any warm feelings of political attachment. "An economically competent government" with a "sense of social justice" is the wispy vision offered at the end. Interestingly, Prospect did not make the article its cover story.

The truth is that New Labour, now it is mature and governing, feels a bit boring. And around it, British politics seems to have frozen. Election turnouts since 1997 have been uniformly low, and are expected to remain so. The opinion polls remain almost exactly where they were that spring, and were throughout the mid-90s, in fact, from the very moment Blair became Labour leader. Inflation and unemployment, the reliable enemies of every government in recent British history, are at their lowest for a quarter of a century. Even the Daily Telegraph, the rallying point for Labour's most diehard opponents, had to admit last month that "Things Can't Get Any Better For Blair". The slightly desperate enthusiasm with which the media has covered his government's relatively minor splits and scandals, and even tried to turn patches of severe weather into Labour "crises", has only served to make Blair look more impregnable.

In a political system as volatile by design as Britain's is, this is close to unprecedented. The past few years, and probably the next few at least, constitute what more than a century of Labour activists have dreamed of during slow party meetings: "a historic opportunity". But, most of the time, you would never guess it. "Government policy is all a bit itsy bitsy, and we can't see the red thread," one of Blair's most senior advisers confesses.

Anthony King, professor of government at Essex University, is more robust: "If you have a government that is not thought to be delivering, with an opposition that is not worth thinking about, then that's a recipe for apathy."

Labour, from a leftish viewpoint, are not a bad administration - they have lowered the poor's taxes and raised their wages, rehabilitated public spending and rationalised Britain's pre-democratic constitution - yet somehow when ministers mention such things eyes begin to glaze over.

Last Monday, this started to happen just as Blair reached the phrase "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime", three paragraphs into his latest big speech on law and order. The day had promised more. It was a fresh blue morning of the kind that blessed the 1997 Labour campaign. He was visiting an im maculate new community centre on Percy Circus, a pretty oval of council flats and private terraces in King's Cross, an area of London once considered seedy and ruined but now swamped with optimistic schemes for development.

Blair's summary of Labour's 10-year plan for crime began confidently: not too heavy on the statistics and soundbites, quite sophisticated about the social context of criminals. But then, at the back of the long, warm room of pensioners and local worthies, the first pairs of eyes started to examine shoelaces. Other faces began to focus beyond the smiling grey-suited figure onstage, rattling off his lines about "the end of fatalism" and "progress in stages", on to distant rooftops and the clouds creeping up from south London. And, in their armchairs near the fire door, two elderly women with Scottish accents started talking between themselves quite audibly.

There is growing discussion among British political thinkers about the sources of such indifference. King points to the continued fraying of public services under Labour. The historian Peter Hennessy blames the over- selling of government policies: "They've had more visions than St Theresa." The think tank Demos perceives a current "disengagement" from party politics in almost all rich democracies. Everyone agrees about the dulling effect on all voters of an opposition as apparently hopeless as the Conservatives.

Yet there may be less measurable factors, too. One is New Labour's philosophy about how to govern, its overwhelming faith in figures and targets. "This is a hyper-rationalist generation of Labour politicians," says a Blair adviser. Even Taylor, in his world of policy seminars and filed periodicals, calls them "a technocratic government". There is some debate about whether this makes Labour old-fashioned, like white-coated experts from the 60s dispensing intricate predictions, or ultra-modern, like confident manage ment consultants. Either way, until last summer, there were 600 official targets for improvements to government services; when Taylor and others explained that this meant none of them could be "priorities", the number was reduced to a mere 200.

The root of this over-earnestness, and perhaps also of our reasons for yawning at it, goes back far into the history of the Labour party, and in particular its previous attempts at government. In 1924, the party's first national administration managed nine nervous months in office before being smeared as Soviet sympathisers and ejected. In 1931, the second brief Labour regime was overwhelmed by the consequences of the Wall Street crash. Next, between 1945 and 1951, Attlee offered six whole years of famous melodrama: a sterling crisis, ministers dying, acrimonious battles over the new welfare state. Wilson suffered another currency collapse in 1966, Callaghan the Winter of Discontent. A collective memory formed, both inside and outside the party, of Labour governments: always beleaguered, occasionally heroic.

After Blair's speech, there was a more detailed briefing for journalists at the Home Office. In a chilly room with the curtains drawn in mid-afternoon, full of old overhead projectors and the ghosts of past initiatives, the thick glossy brochures and "business plans" for Labour's anti-crime strategy were handed out. One objective listed in crisp bold type was "to reduce by 2004 the economic cost of crime as measured by an indicator to be developed by March 2001". The next day, the government's plans failed to make many front pages.

Perhaps this sense of anticlimax doesn't matter. "This is the first ordinary Labour government," says King. Maybe Britain is simply experiencing an extended, lukewarm period of social democracy, of the type our continental neighbours have often had since the second world war. Besides, the giddiness of May 1997 arguably never reflected a national infatuation with Labour: the party got an unspectacular winning share of a fairly small turnout. Add in the left's enthusiasm for shouting betrayal; the apathy bred by economic good times; the interminable wait for office during the mid-90s during which Labour lost much of its freshness; the preference of most political journalists, heightened by John Major's daily crises, for party intrigue in Westminster tea rooms over probing government policy on cold council estates. Perhaps the wonder is that New Labour ever excited us at all.

Taylor, however, does not share this fatalism. High above Covent Garden, in the IPPR's over-lit rooms, he is still thinking about historic opportunities, and how they can be lost. The current government, he says, has opted for "a politics of accommodation" - with the free market, with many Tory notions, with many traditional ideas about Britishness that can only ultimately help their enemies.

When Labour lose power, whether it's in five years' time or 15, he fears that people may still see a conservative country around them, may scarcely even register what sort of government has passed.

The day after our interview, on BBC Radio 5, the morning phone-in is about Labour's crime plans. The first caller criticises them in vague terms, then is asked by the presenter to suggest alternatives. Sounding pleased with himself, the caller proceeds to demonstrate, by suggesting exactly the same policies, that he has paid the previous day's launch no attention at all.
fields.bodyText: Matthew Taylor is a brisk, youngish man with gel in his cropped hair and a lean face that suggests austerity and purpose. He works in a tight top-floor set of offices with ink on the carpets, high above the chain cafes and raucousness of Covent Garden in central London. Until quite recently, as far as such things are measurable, he was probably New Labour's favourite intellectual. His father is the prominent left-leaning sociologist, Professor Laurie Taylor. During the mid-90s, Taylor junior ran the party's highly valued "rapid rebuttal unit", defending its new ideas from attack. From 1996 to 1998, as Labour's director of policy, he was in charge of coming up with more. In 1997, he helped write the general election manifesto. In 1998, he became head of the government's preferred think tank, the Institute for Public Policy Research. Over a dozen of its employees have been recruited as advisers by Labour ministers. So, a few months ago, it seemed quite natural for Taylor to be asked to contribute to an important government project. With a new general election approaching, the prime minister was planning to write an article for Prospect magazine, laying out the philosophy behind Labour's next manifesto and, more generally, the party's fundamental aims and motives for being in office. Taylor assembled his thoughts. A decade of his increasingly critical writings about capitalism and Labour's need to define itself more confidently was distilled and conveyed to Downing Street. Then, just before the article's publication last month, an ominous email came back from one of Blair's close aides. "It said: 'Sorry, the piece doesn't do justice to our discussions,'" Taylor says, with a piercing look. This may have been an understatement. After almost four years in power, with the largest majority in Labour's history, and the Conservatives empty of rival ideas, all the prime minister had come up with was another cautious summary of the Third Way. Taylor is rather ruder about it: "The ridiculous, fatuous claim that a mild form of Christian democracy represents a new politics . . ." His smooth, media-ready voice rises with the disappointment. Without sounding terribly regretful, he adds: "I've fucked my peerage." It may be hard for others to feel quite so enraged by the four brief pages of Third Way, Phase Two. Like the current government in general, the article is more thoughtful in tone and international in outlook than anything you can imagine John Major, for example, ever managing. The end of communism, the future of capitalism, the need for a new British diversity, the contradictions of modern conservatism - all of these are busily covered. Every development in recent world history, it is neatly implied, has led inexorably to the creation and success of New Labour. Any lawyer would appreciate the sly blending of fact and assertion, any management consultant the numbered paragraphs. But they numb you, after a while. There is nothing to stir any warm feelings of political attachment. "An economically competent government" with a "sense of social justice" is the wispy vision offered at the end. And around it, British politics seems to have frozen. Election turnouts since 1997 have been uniformly low, and are expected to remain so. The opinion polls remain almost exactly where they were that spring, and were throughout the mid-90s, in fact, from the very moment Blair became Labour leader. Inflation and unemployment, the reliable enemies of every government in recent British history, are at their lowest for a quarter of a century. The slightly desperate enthusiasm with which the media has covered his government's relatively minor splits and scandals, and even tried to turn patches of severe weather into Labour "crises", has only served to make Blair look more impregnable. In a political system as volatile by design as Britain's is, this is close to unprecedented. The past few years, and probably the next few at least, constitute what more than a century of Labour activists have dreamed of during slow party meetings: "a historic opportunity". But, most of the time, you would never guess it. "Government policy is all a bit itsy bitsy, and we can't see the red thread," one of Blair's most senior advisers confesses. Anthony King, professor of government at Essex University, is more robust: "If you have a government that is not thought to be delivering, with an opposition that is not worth thinking about, then that's a recipe for apathy." Labour, from a leftish viewpoint, are not a bad administration - they have lowered the poor's taxes and raised their wages, rehabilitated public spending and rationalised Britain's pre-democratic constitution - yet somehow when ministers mention such things eyes begin to glaze over. Last Monday, this started to happen just as Blair reached the phrase "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime", three paragraphs into his latest big speech on law and order. The day had promised more. It was a fresh blue morning of the kind that blessed the 1997 Labour campaign. He was visiting an im maculate new community centre on Percy Circus, a pretty oval of council flats and private terraces in King's Cross, an area of London once considered seedy and ruined but now swamped with optimistic schemes for development. Blair's summary of Labour's 10-year plan for crime began confidently: not too heavy on the statistics and soundbites, quite sophisticated about the social context of criminals. But then, at the back of the long, warm room of pensioners and local worthies, the first pairs of eyes started to examine shoelaces. Other faces began to focus beyond the smiling grey-suited figure onstage, rattling off his lines about "the end of fatalism" and "progress in stages", on to distant rooftops and the clouds creeping up from south London. The historian Peter Hennessy blames the over- selling of government policies: "They've had more visions than St Theresa." Everyone agrees about the dulling effect on all voters of an opposition as apparently hopeless as the Conservatives. Yet there may be less measurable factors, too. One is New Labour's philosophy about how to govern, its overwhelming faith in figures and targets. "This is a hyper-rationalist generation of Labour politicians," says a Blair adviser. Even Taylor, in his world of policy seminars and filed periodicals, calls them "a technocratic government". There is some debate about whether this makes Labour old-fashioned, like white-coated experts from the 60s dispensing intricate predictions, or ultra-modern, like confident manage ment consultants. Either way, until last summer, there were 600 official targets for improvements to government services; when Taylor and others explained that this meant none of them could be "priorities", the number was reduced to a mere 200. fields.headline: 'We were like the Macbeths' says Rantzen
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Esther Rantzen has complained that critics likened her marriage to the late Desmond Wilcox to that of "the Macbeths", writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Esther Rantzen says writing her controversial autobiography was more revealing than dancing naked. But she goes on to complain that some people thought her marriage to the late Desmond Wilcox was like that of the Macbeths "with our hands covered in blood".

In an interview published today, Ms Rantzen tells the Radio Times she has little time for journalists who criticised her for speaking out about her marriage and the death of her husband.

"Some people thought Desmond and I were the Macbeths, with our hands covered in blood," she says, adding: "There is a lot of bullying in journalism. You see targets come and go and once you are one - beware."

In the interview Ms Rantzen revealed that it was her late husband who persuaded her to press ahead with the publication of her autobiography, Esther, in which she portrayed Mr Wilcox's former wife as a bitter woman whom he had never loved.

The move propelled Ms Rantzen into an acrimonious and extremely public family row when Cassandra Wilcox, daughter of Mr Wilcox's first wife, hit back in an article written for the Daily Mail.

But Ms Rantzen is no stranger to a hostile press. The public popularity of her talk show, That's Life, was not matched among media commentators, who dismissed her as a lightweight over her penchant for phallic vegetables.

"When you're roundly ticked off in print you don't ignore it," she said. "Sometimes a bit of you thinks, 'That could be true'. It makes you check yourself out."

Ms Rantzen dismissed the talk shows of today as too middle-class, saying: "I was trained to focus on people who haven't got a great deal of money, nor a high-priced lawyer. Watchdog is fine, but there's a huge gap because it's too middle-class."

And she describes herself as "horrified" by that other Anne Robinson vehicle, The Weakest Link.

"If anyone wants to know the secret of the British psyche it seems that an awful lot of otherwise grown-up people enjoy being bullied by a ferocious woman of mature years wearing trousers," she said

webTitle: Accountants learn ethics from Barlinnie's worst

fields.headline: Accountants learn ethics from Barlinnie's worst
fields.trailText: Trainee accountants at Glasgow University are learning about business ethics the hard way Ð from sex offenders in one of Scotland's most infamous prisons.
fields.body:
Trainee accountants at Glasgow University are learning about business ethics the hard way Ð from sex offenders in one of Scotland's most infamous prisons.

A group of 40 students, a third of those studying accountancy, signed up for a new BA course in ethics, little realising what they were in for when they agreed to visit Barlinnie jail in east Glasgow. The all-male prison holds some of Scotland's worst offenders.

"We went to visit the sex offender unit. I think accountancy ethics is so much like rehabilitating sex offenders," said Dr Ken McPhail, Glasgow's lecturer in accounting and business ethics.

Sex offenders see their victims as objects, not as human beings. "That's what business does, it turns individuals into objects, it objectifies the whole process. You talk about greatest return, not human misery. What they do with sex offenders is role reversal to try to get them to see the other point of view, the point of view of the victim. That's important for accountants to learn," said Dr McPhail.

The students were first introduced to an accountant who laundered money and was given 18 months in Barlinnie. The message was blunt: break the law and you'll get to stay with 'Bob', who is three feet taller than you.

But according to Dr McPhail, it is the more subtle message that is the most important for trainee accountants to learn.

"The majority of accountants are quite well behaved and wouldn't break the law. But those law-abiding accountants are perhaps more dangerous than the law-breakers. In most cases in Barlinnie, these guys are from deprived areas where there are no jobs. I want my students to see what they are doing when they sit up in their office closing down factories."

fields.headline: MRC raises student grants
fields.trailText: Research students working in the medical sciences are to receive an extra £2,500 a year from this October, following a decision by the Medical Research Council to raise maintenance grants to a minimum flat rate of £10,000 a year.
fields.body:
Research students working in the medical sciences are to receive an extra £2,500 a year from this October, following a decision by the Medical Research Council to raise maintenance grants to a minimum flat rate of £10,000 a year.

PhD and Masters students in London will receive £12,500 a year under the new arrangements. The council is also offering 15 special fellowships worth up to £17,000 for 15 students working in MRC research institutes and centres.

Both existing students and new starters will receive the higher rate stipend in October this year. Previously, first year students received £7,450 (£9,900 in London), with an additional £450 and £500 in years two and three.

The announcement, following the council's review of research training policies, echoes similar moves by other government research councils. The government unveiled extra cash for PhD grants after the last Whitehall spending review to help recruit students.

In some subject areas, universities and research institutes have found it difficult to attract graduates into research training careers. Once uniform across subject areas, PhD grants now vary considerably for different research councils.

The increase in MRC grants will not be funded by a fall in the numbers of studentships Ü the number of new research studentships this year will remain the same at 365 PhDs and around 100 Masters.

The MRC is also funding an extra 80 Masters degree studentships from 2003. The council supports the "1 & 3" funding model for research students Ü postgraduates can spend a year researching for a Masters degree with the option to go onto a three year doctorate. High flyers can fast track onto a three year PhD.

The council has also introduced a £1m 'pre-doctoral fellowship' scheme which will allow 15 students to work in MRC units or institutes on a salary of around £17,000 per annum dependant upon age and experience (plus location allowance in London). Applicants of any nationality can compete for these awards and the first 15 fellows will start work in October.

the MRC website

fields.headline: Infrared answer to impotence
fields.trailText: Russian scientists have developed a new laser technique to cure male impotence.
fields.body:
Russian scientists have developed a new laser technique to cure male impotence.

The researchers found that irradiating the top of the penis for five minutes with an infrared laser enables it to re-gain the ability to have spontaneous erections.

After two weeks of this treatment all 24 male patients in a trial were able to get erections and some even increased the length of their penis.

The device has been developed by Dr Ekaterina Koultchavenia of the Novosibirsk Research Institute. Dr Koultchavenia presents her results in this month's issue of Opto & Laser Europe, a magazine published by the Institute of Physics.

The patients were first treated with a vacuum device that induced a passive erection. Dr Koultchavenia then used an integrated infrared laser to irradiate the top of the penis for five minutes. This treatment was repeated once per day for 15 days and proved to be more effective than vacuum treatment alone.

Koultchavenia told Opto & Laser Europe: "Almost all of our patients had previously been treated with vacuum decompression alone, but their complaint soon returned. We believe the success of our laser treatment is due to a massaging of the veins which leads to increased metabolism and nutrition of the tissue."

Dr Koultchavenia estimates that 40-60% of middle-aged men suffer from impotence, and while the condition is not life-threatening, it does dramatically reduce quality of life. She says her device, which she has patented and is hoping to commercialise, is effective, simple to use and has no side effects. She also hopes to apply a similar treatment to increase the size of breasts.

webTitle: Funding gap grows in higher education

fields.headline: Funding gap grows in higher education
fields.trailText: A growing divide between the haves and have-nots in higher education emerges from the annual shareout of government funds for the coming year.
fields.body:
A growing divide between the haves and have-nots in higher education emerges from the annual shareout of government funds for the coming year.

Announcing the distribution of £4.76bn for teaching and research, Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said it was a "good year" for universities and colleges.

The money available per student was going up "for the first time in living memory". "British higher education is in a healthy state," said Sir Brian.

But a number of hard-pressed new universities will suffer a cut in funding after failing to recruit enough students, and the settlement has done nothing to shake the vice-chancellors' conviction that the sector is £900m short of what it needs in order to do its job properly.

Paying the penalty for missing their recruitment targets are the universities of East London, Lincolnshire and Humberside, Luton, Nottingham Trent, South Bank, Sunderland, and De Montfort.

The funding council has tried to cushion the blow by moderating the amount the worst-hit institutions lose under the formula for student numbers. Luton, for example, has been subsidised to the tune of more than £5m over the past two years.

But universities are expected to take serious action to bring their finances back into balance. Luton is axing nearly 100 academic and administrative staff jobs. Lincolnshire and Humberside has decided to abandon its Hull campus and transform itself into the University of Lincoln. De Montfort is closing the Milton Keynes campus it opened in a recent burst of expansion.

Among the biggest winners in this year's funding stakes are old established institutions such as Nottingham University, which gets an extra £3.4m to teach additional students, Southampton (£2.5m), Leeds (£3.2m), Birmingham (£2.3m).

Bristol, Durham, Essex, Exeter, Liverpool, Newcastle, Sheffield, Queen Mary and Westfield College London and Warwick all receive more than £1m additional funding for increased numbers. These are the beneficiaries of the government's drive to expand numbers and the funding council's decision last year to relax the restrictions on how many students institutions were allowed to recruit. There were many more 18-year olds on the market to take up places.

It is not all gloom for new universities, however. Teesside is awarded more a rise of more than £2m for additional students, while Leeds Metropolitan and Plymouth also gain substantially.

Sir Brian said some universities and colleges were having to work hard to fill their places but overall, demand was rising. It was inevitable that some universities would be doing better than others in recruitment.

"We have an increasingly well informed student population who are careful about where they go."

And the general picture is complicated by the continued unpopularity of science and engineering among school and college leavers which appears to have hit both old and new universities.

The prestigious Imperial College London suffered a £1.8m holdback this year because it failed to meet its recruitment targets. Professor Rees Rawlings, the pro-rector blamed the shortfall on the 5% decline in the numbers taking maths and physics at A-level.

The decline in maths and economics may also explain why the London School of Economics has incurred penalties.

Some of the biggest gainers are not conventional universities at all. A massive 9% increase (nearly £8m) goes to the Open University and further education colleges get a 6.5% rise in funding for higher education courses, compared with an average 4% rise for all institutions.

The rise in further education recruitment is partly due to the fact that the lionÍs share of the new foundation degrees announced by David Blunkett, the education secretary, are due to be delivered in further education colleges (collaborating with universities). The rise in grants also reflect the government's goal of promoting part-time degrees as a way of increasing participation to its target of 50% of young people (those under 30).

Part-time courses are not proving as attractive as predicted, however. More than 14,000 new part-time places funded by the council in England last year remained unfilled (most of them on sub-degree courses like Higher National Diplomas). Sir Brian predicts that the government's targets will be met by a greater proportion of full-time students than in the original targets.

Scotland has already passed the target: by 1999/2000 58% or 17-30 year olds were in higher education or had participated.

Over the next ten years the number of 18 to 20 year olds in England is set to rise by 10%, compelling the funding council to find even more places. On past trends, school and college leavers are looking for full-time courses Ð and that will reinforce the advantage of the old universities. At the same time numbers in the older age group (25-29) who have been more interested in part-time courses will drop rapidly.

Sir Brian said some universities and colleges were having to work hard to fill their places but overall, demand was rising. It was inevitable that some universities would be doing better than others in recruitment. "We have an increasingly well informed student population who are careful about where they go." And the general picture is complicated by the continued unpopularity of science and engineering among school and college leavers which appears to have hit both old and new universities. The prestigious Imperial College London suffered a £1.8m holdback this year because it failed to meet its recruitment targets. Professor Rees Rawlings, the pro-rector blamed the shortfall on the 5% decline in the numbers taking maths and physics at A-level. The decline in maths and economics may also explain why the London School of Economics has incurred penalties. Some of the biggest gainers are not conventional universities at all. A massive 9% increase (nearly £8m) goes to the Open University and further education colleges get a 6.5% rise in funding for higher education courses, compared with an average 4% rise for all institutions. The rise in further education recruitment is partly due to the fact that the lionÍs share of the new foundation degrees announced by David Blunkett, the education secretary, are due to be delivered in further education colleges (collaborating with universities). The rise in grants also reflect the government's goal of promoting part-time degrees as a way of increasing participation to its target of 50% of young people (those under 30). Part-time courses are not proving as attractive as predicted, however. More than 14,000 new part-time places funded by the council in England last year remained unfilled (most of them on sub-degree courses like Higher National Diplomas). Sir Brian predicts that the government's targets will be met by a greater proportion of full-time students than in the original targets. Scotland has already passed the target: by 1999/2000 58% or 17-30 year olds were in higher education or had participated. Over the next ten years the number of 18 to 20 year olds in England is set to rise by 10%, compelling the funding council to find even more places. On past trends, school and college leavers are looking for full-time courses Ð and that will reinforce the advantage of the old universities. At the same time numbers in the older age group (25-29) who have been more interested in part-time courses will drop rapidly.

fields.headline: John Sutherland
fields.standfirst: Join a reading group. They raise the cultural tone of the country and what's more, Oprah Winfrey loves them
fields.trailText: Join a reading group. They raise the cultural tone of the country and what's more, Oprah Winfrey loves them.
fields.body:
David Blunkett's attempt last week to gain headlines for the government's adult literacy drive was comprehensively foiled by Chris Woodhead. The former (thank God) chief inspector of schools's parting shots provoked a public pissing match worthy of Wembley. The Blair-Blunkett initiative was drowned out by recrimination about who had done more harm to the country's education system.

The statistics on the nation's reading skills make grim reading for those able to perform the task. Seven million British adults are functionally illiterate. Every fifth grown-up you pass in the street possesses book skills inferior to those of the average 11-year-old.

Urgent as the problem of literacy is, it's not everything. Richard Hoggart asked the question 50 years ago. What, usefully, do you do with reading skills once you have them? You can decipher black marks on a white surface and can manage the Guardian crossword. Does that make for a better life?

I suspect that the author of The Uses of Literacy is heartened by the recent popularity of reading groups. All over the country bands of adults get together to discuss books of the day (or classics of yesteryear) and hone their literacy. It enriches their lives and our culture.

The reading group movement started 20 years ago in the US. Historically it is an outgrowth of the women's liberation movement and retains recognisable aspects of the 60s consciousness-raising group. In their purest American form, reading groups eschew all authority or institutional affiliation. They are a grassroots thing. Participants do not want "experts" coming in to tell them what a book means. They want to thrash it out themselves, democratically.

The spin-off from the reading group movement in the US has been remarkable, particularly among African Americans. This achievement is largely down to one person - Oprah Winfrey. Go into most US bookshops and you'll see a stand featuring "Oprah's picks". Another rack recommends titles for local reading groups, together with an array of would-be helpful guidebooks. The movement has been profitable for the US book trade and it woos the new market assiduously. What Oprah picks sells big.

The British movement, unlike its American counterpart, works better in alliance with friendly supporting institutions. Reading groups took root here about eight years ago, partly as an initiative of the Waterstone's chain.

The most successful groups are those which nestle in the country's network of public libraries. Traditionally these municipal institutions have seen themselves as providers of reading matter to a print-hungry but impoverished population. Free school meals for the mind. In an age of the low-cost paperback and generally high incomes we don't need free books any more than we need free lunches. We can buy our own.

Progressive public libraries realise that one way forward is an alliance with the reading group movement. Bradford's library is a frontrunner, sponsoring no fewer than eight groups. The syllabuses cover new and classic fiction, poetry, belles-lettres and Urdu literature.

Bradford's librarians have built up a store of expertise with which to serve their community. The trick, as its principal librarian, Robert Walters has discovered, is to create an environment within which shared reading can happen. All that is needed is a room, modest refreshments, a timetable, an agreed syllabus and rules of discussion. The library supplies the books (up to 10 per class) on loan. Otherwise its professional hands are kept off.

A literature director (paid for by a grant from the heritage lottery fund) helps organise a supporting programme of speakers, writers in residence, festivals and competitions. The whole thing costs very little, and it works. In ways that are palpable but difficult to measure, such activity as Bradford's raises the cultural tone of the country.

Sponsoring something as inherently freewheeling as readers' groups is tricky. They don't want handouts, but some judicious investment, funnelled through the existing public library structure, would have an immediate and gratifying payoff. The government could call it an adult super-literacy drive.

fields.headline: Bomb may be Panorama payback
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
The car bomb that exploded outside the BBC's London headquarters at the weekend may have been a revenge attack for a Panorama investigation into the Omagh bomb, police said today.

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
The car bomb that exploded outside the BBC's London headquarters at the weekend may have been a revenge attack for a Panorama investigation into the Omagh bomb, police said today.

As Britain was placed on high alert for further terrorist attacks, Alan Fry, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, said: "It could be retaliation. I cannot ignore that possibility as being a motive for this attack."

The Real IRA killed 29 people with a car bomb in Omagh in 1998, the single worst atrocity in 30 years of the Northern Ireland troubles, and Panorama named some of the members it claimed were involved in a programme last October.

No group has so far claimed responsibility for the blast outside BBC Television Centre in Wood Lane, west London, early yesterday morning.

However, as forensics continued a fingertip search of the scene, police said it was part of an ongoing campaign of "murderous attacks" by the Real IRA.

Mr Fry said that one particularly worrying development was that it was becoming difficult to tell the difference between the Provisional IRA and the Real IRA "on the ground".

He added: "It is quite clear that we are dealing with ruthless terrorists who are prepared to use ruthless tactics without any care for the consequences of their actions."

Police arrived at the BBC after two coded warnings were received, one at a London hospital and another at a charitable organisation, saying a bomb had been planted.

Only the prompt action of the emergency services in evacuating the BBC building and nearby residents avoided certain death as the blast from 10-20lbs of high explosives damaged nearby buildings.

Experts were trying to conduct a controlled explosion when the bomb detonated, leaving one railway worker with minor injuries.

The device was packed inside a red taxi with a black roof - registration D902 GYH - that was parked outside the BBC main entrance on the wrong side of the road with its headlights on.

It had been bought by a man who spoke with a Northern Irish accent from a dealer in Edmonton, north London, for £300 on Saturday morning.

He was white, about 30 years old and 6ft tall, wearing a short jacket and baseball cap.

Mr Fry asked the public to come forward if they saw the taxi, which did not have a Metropolitan Police license plate.

He said: "I know one witness believes they had an altercation with the driver of a red cab on Saturday evening. Did someone else meet someone who was less than friendly?"

Police want to speak to anyone who may have been in the Wood Green area between 10.30pm and 11pm to come forward and there is an information hotline on: 0800 789 321.

Detectives are linking the blast to last year's bomb at Hammersmith Bridge, a device placed on a railway line at Acton and the rocket attack on the MI6 building at Vauxhall, London.

Mr Fry could not say what type of high explosive was used in the attack but said it pointed to a disturbing growth of terrorist cells on the mainland.

Urging the public to be vigilant, he said: "Colleagues in the RUC would probably say the numbers are in the hundreds but growing, slowly but growing, and that is a worrying trend.

"It is evidence of their willingness through this campaign, despite the peace process, to bring their murderous attacks to the mainland and to London."

Police could not rule out a connection between the BBC explosion and the blast at a Territorial Army barracks in London that blinded and maimed cadet Stephen Menary, 14, on February 21.

A controlled explosion was carried out yesterday on a suspect vehicle near London's Victoria Station.

Downing Street branded the BBC bombing a "cowardly act". A spokesman said: "Those responsible can be in no doubt as to our determination to track them down and bring them to justice.

"There are those outside the peace process who are set on trying to turn the clock back to the days before the Good Friday agreement.

"So these actions may be designed to try to destabilise and frustrate the efforts of the government to secure the peace process," he said.

David Trimble, the province's first minister, said he believed the Real IRA had targeted London because of recent failed attacks in Ebrington barracks in Londonderry and Claudy RUC station.

Seamus Mallon, the deputy first minister, said: "Those responsible for this attack have no role to play in the creation of a future free from violence and the hatred of the past."

Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign minister, described the blast as "the mindless act of people who have rejected all attempts to bring peace to these islands, and who have no alternative to offer, except misery and grief".

 A 29-year old man from Londonderry was due to appear in court today charged with offences under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, Essex Police said. A spokesman said there was nothing to connect the man to yesterday's attack on the BBC.

Round-table talks to stabilise the Northern Ireland peace process are likely to take place later this week rather than tomorrow as anticipated, Stormont sources indicated today.

The British and Irish governments and pro-Good Friday agreement parties are expected to hold a round-table meeting on Thursday in a bid to break the deadlock over policing, IRA decommissioning, British demilitarisation and Unionist sanctions against Sinn Fein.

fields.headline: BBC sports chief slams Kirch
fields.trailText:
6pm: Peter Salmon has accused the Kirch Group of holding Britain to ransom over World Cup rights, reports Jason Deans
Feb 16: MPs warn Kirch over World Cup rights
fields.body:
BBC director of sport Peter Salmon has accused the Kirch Group of holding Britain to ransom over World Cup football rights.

"Kirch has put aside the interests of the British public in its quest for a payment for UK rights in the order of 40 times what was previously paid for the 1998 World Cup," said Mr Salmon to the all-party BBC group of MPs.

"And this for a competition being held in the Far East, giving us matches during the early morning in the UK."

Mr Salmon added that the "BBC and ITV have made a very competitive bid. Kirch refuses even to discuss it with us".

He questioned whether the Sydney Olympics would have been the same televisual event if they had been broadcast on pay-TV rather than the BBC.

"Would the Olympics belong to the nation or just a few fortunate subscribers?" he asked.

Commercial interests would snap up some events, like track and field, but who would bother with shooting or sailing, for instance?

"The stature of our Olympic heroes would simply evaporate," Mr Salmon said.

"It would be hero to zero. And so it will be in the World Cup 2002 if Kirch succeeds."

Mr Salmon promised a major interactive BBC Sport service at Wimbledon and the Open Golf this summer.

And he pledged there would be more emphasis on sports education and a continuing ambition to launch a dedicated sports channel.

webTitle: Portuguese PM under attack for bridge collapse

fields.headline: Portuguese PM under attack for bridge collapse
fields.standfirst: Audio from the scene (1min 35)
fields.trailText: Local residents showered the Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, in abuse today when he visited the scene of a collapsed bridge that sent 60 people to their deaths in the fast-moving river below.
fields.body:
Local residents showered the Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, in abuse today when he visited the scene of a collapsed bridge that sent 60 people to their deaths in the fast-moving river below.

The government has declared two days of mourning for those killed last night when a 116-year-old bridge over the Douro River gave way. Rescue workers have said there will be no survivors from the double-decker bus and two cars are thought to have plunged into in the murky water.

Dozens of local people screamed expletives at the prime minister, blaming the government for the deaths. Mr Guterres rejected the accusation and said he has ordered an official inquiry.

"No one of good faith would think there was any type of personal blame," Guterres said.

But local residents of the rural town in northern Portugal, about 180 miles north of the capital Lisbon, say the bridge was unsafe.

The local mayor, Paulo Teixeira, claimed he had warned the government, which is responsible for the bridge's maintenance, about cracks in the structure three years ago.

Manuel Fonseca, a local fireman, said he was angry about the accident. "It's a great tragedy that could have been avoided," he said. "The bridge was known to be unsafe."

Infrastructure minister, Jorge Coelho, called a night-time news conference in Lisbon immediately after the incident to announce his resignation. "I completely accept the political responsibility for this accident," he said.

This morning, thick mist prevented over 100 rescue workers from resuming their search. Later in the day, teams of divers strung cables across the river and searched for the bus and cars. The depth of the water into which the vehicles fell was believed to be 15m. Only one body has been recovered.

"Unfortunately, there's no one for us to save," rescue official Adao Barbosa said.

"It's going to be a very risky operation because of the powerful current," Mr Barbosa said. The sluice gates of a dam upstream from the site of the accident were closed in an attempt to reduce the river's flow.

Mr Barbosa said it was still not clear how many people were in the two cars, though they were thought to be carrying a total of 10 people.

A section of the stone and metal bridge (built in 1886) over the Douro, one of Portugal's major rivers, collapsed at 9pm GMT yesterday after a supporting pillar gave way.

fields.headline: When prudence turns dangerous
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is the too-lucky chancellor. The result is underspending and failure to reverse national decay, writes Will Hutton
fields.body:
It was Napoleon who wished for lucky generals, and every prime minister worth his salt should wish for lucky chancellors. Tony Blair chose well. He has a lucky chancellor - and Wednesday's Budget, with another judicious mix of spending increases and tax cuts, will cap Gordon Brown's four years of charmed fiscal stewardship. It's been a remarkable chancellorship and has transformed Labour's reputation for economic management. But luck sooner or later runs out - and even virtue has its costs.

His luck has been the wider economic context. There has been no world recession; the fallout of the Asian financial crisis was contained - indeed, the world carried on growing, and inflation everywhere has been depressed. Against this benign background Mr Brown's tax receipts have flowed and the British economy carried on performing well.

But if that luck fell to him, he has gone on to make his own. Mr Brown has played his economic management just as he planned in the long dark nights of opposition. The establishment of an independent Bank of England proved a masterstroke; its interest rate policy has been nearly faultless. Other Labour governments have spent in the first two years of a Parliament and endured the next three regretting it; Mr Brown has made his spending increases and tax cuts so they kick in for the next election rather than reward the vote at the last one. He raised taxes by some £17bn in the first two years of his term, and spent less in the first three years than even Margaret Thatcher in her pomp. The result is a stunning fiscal position that Mr Brown has continually underestimated.

Carl Emmerson, of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, calculates that Mr Brown has beaten his own Budget forecasts for the public surplus or deficit in the following year by approaching an average 1% of GDP - a bias any post-war chancellor would envy. It's not that getting the forecast wrong is unusual; it is underestimating it for four consecutive years that is so untypical. The joke about prudence is wearing thin. Mr Brown is so prudent that the financial markets do not believe his forecasts; they factor in a Mr Brown underprediction.

The most extraordinary year was in the spring of 1999 when he forecast he would borrow just £3bn in the following financial year. In the event there was a cash surplus of over £16bn, a swing of some £19bn to the good that is close to a post-war record. The combination of low inflation and consistent repayment of national debt - the best guess is that there will be another £16bn surplus in the current financial year alongside the £22bn of debt repayment financed by the mobile phone spectrum auction - has driven the interest rate on long-term British government debt to an astonishing 4.9 per cent, the lowest in the G7 except Japan and Germany. Britain is becoming the new Switzerland, with the lowest debt and inflation, and the largest budget surplus, in Europe.

Yet still the IMF and the European Commission are not satisfied - in part because they worry that Mr Brown's spending plans over the next three years will fritter away this strength, and in part because the IMF worries that the economy will buckle under the combined weight of private and public spending and reignite inflation - a warning it repeated last week. In particular, it worries that the build-up of capital investment will mean the government may have to borrow to finance capital spending, a position that Mr Brown explicitly permits in his definition of sound fiscal policy (the golden rule) but which offends the new conservative hawks in the US, who argue for permanent balanced budgets as part of their jihad against the state.

The IMF is wrong. Its hyperconservatism takes no account of the powerful disinflationary forces worldwide alongside an emerging surfeit of global productive capacity; the chances of an open economy such as Britain's suffering from a surge in inflation in this context is negligible. For, while part of Mr Brown's success lies in the strength of the economy and his own crafted strategy, the rest is explained by the Treasury's inability to make sure that the great spending departments actually invest the cash they have been allocated. Mr Brown will avoid mentioning the subject in his Budget speech, confident that the Conservatives are doctrinally unable to attack him, but the government is presiding over a fiscal scandal. It is so inefficient that it has been unable to invest the money allocated to it, so that public investment has sunk to new lows. This is not what Brown intended, but the feebleness of the opposition has prevented the collapse of public investment from becoming a hot political issue. Mr Brown is lucky in every sense.

But perhaps too lucky. Because the government has not decisively reversed the decay in the public infrastructure, and has underspent what it planned, absurdly it is finding itself criticised by the IMF and EU Commission for potentially loosening a fiscal stance that is much tighter than it ever wanted. If it had invested the near £10bn that it should have done over the last two years, the result would have been a lower surplus - but still much better than the surplus it actually forecast back in the spring of 1999. Moreover, we would all have begun to see a tangible improvement in the public infrastructure, while the adverse consequences of demand being higher than it was in actuality would have been trivial.

Nor is that all. There is much self-congratulation about how much better Britain has organised its pension system than its principal European competitors. We don't have a generous state pension scheme, as they have, and better still the majority of pensioners, present and future, have saved privately for their old age through their own or company pension schemes. As a result Britain has no impending fiscal crisis about how it is to pay for an ageing population living off generous state pensions.

But there is no such thing as a free lunch. For 20 years private pensions have proved an excellent investment, with annual returns on equity investment averaging 15% alongside high real interest rates; as a result pensioners have been able to buy rich annuities with their highly performing savings. But now the British national debt is falling to some 30% of GDP, carrying long-term interest rates and annuities to new lows. The assumptions on which private pension plans are based are being shredded.

Any pension scheme - private or occupational - that defines a final pension in terms of some relationship to the contributor's final salary is in crisis. Employers who offer these defined benefit schemes are facing breathtaking increases in their contribution rates and thus payroll costs in order to keep their pension funds solvent in this new universe of low annuity rates. Even if they launch a new pension scheme with less generous benefits they face maintaining the solvency of the old fund. Paradoxically, paying off the national debt and fiscal conservatism is proving a payroll tax - via lower annuity rates - on many employers as they raise their contribution rates to their pension fund. This will be hailed by the City as prudent and by his own supporters, as long as it is crafted to direct money at Labour's core constituency, as a political masterstroke. The other reality - national debt too low and government spending departments chronically unable to raise investment - will be forgotten. But this is a lucky chancellor.

webTitle: Australian grand prix: Call for safety review

fields.headline: Unpaid help in the line of fire
fields.standfirst: Call for safety review after the death of second official in five races
fields.trailText: Call for safety review after the death of second official in five races.
fields.body:
The fatal accident which befell a trackside marshal in the Australian grand prix, caused by Jacques Villeneuve running his BAR into the back of Ralf Schumacher's Williams-BMW, highlights the precarious role of those unpaid enthusiasts without whom a multi-million pound sport would long ago have stalled in the pits.

The death of the Queensland official, whose name is not being released before relatives are informed, came six months after Paolo Ghislimberti, a professional fireman from Trento, was killed by a flying wheel after a six-car pile-up at the Italian grand prix in Monza. The 50-year-old died in hospital and his daughter was said by race officials to have been among the 128,500 crowd.

Unconfirmed eyewitness reports said the marshal was killed in what appeared to be a freak incident. He was struck in the chest by a wheel which came off Villeneuve's car and flew through the 12ft x 2ft hole in the perimeter fence which he would use to wave warning flags. The incident is now the subject of a coroner's investigation.

While formula one racing has expanded dramatically over the past two decades and is now one of the world's best-funded international televised sports, the fact remains that the circuit is traditionally lined by voluntary officials.

A generation ago, marshals were on a par with the drivers and mechanics, people for whom motor racing was a hobby. It was their route to the inside of the sport they loved but in which they lacked the finance or connections to compete.

Today, the volunteer marshal still underpins the sport, waving warning flags, sweeping the track of debris and, if worse comes to the worst, rushing to the aid of drivers who may be trapped and injured inside their cars.

Yet while many drivers and engineers enjoy millionaire lifestyles, these fans remain unpaid as the sport's foot soldiers, happy to offer their services for nothing. Indeed, none of them would give a second thought about being paid for what amounts to a hobby.

At various times over the past three decades it has been suggested that the international motor racing community should provide funds for a corps of paid, professional marshals who would travel the world to work at the races.

The idea never got off the ground, largely because it would have required a major culture change on the part of the marshals themselves; few people would want to make a career out of full-time marshalling.

Patrick Head, the technical director at Williams, yesterday led calls for improved safety measures "You've got to ask if the marshal had proper protection where he was standing, because if you have open-wheel racing cars, it does not matter what you do about tying bits to the car," Head said.

"These cars are immensely fast and if they hit each other there are going to be bits flying around and you have to be realistic and decide how you are going to deal with it.

"There is no need to have a man with a flag out there - you can have a button to push with an arm that can come out with a flag on it."

Despite Head's comments, the problems of controlling flying debris within the confines of a race track continues to be a pressing issue.

Referring to the FIA's introduction of a tethering system to help prevent wheels flying off, the former world champion Jackie Stewart, one of the sport's original safety campaigners, said: "We've got to do even more about tying the wheels together - we need to do it even for wings and so forth. At 200 or 300 kph, you don't know where that type of debris is going to go.

"You have to ring-fence the race tracks with higher and stronger debris fences. You then have to police where the marshals stand."

However, the difficulties in guaranteeing the safety of marshals were highlighted earlier by the Australian grand prix chairman Ron Walker. "The track is inspected every day. We have a certificate to run the race and we do comply with all the rules and regulations. If you want to build a concrete wall right around the track, you won't have any spectators," he said.

The accident cast a huge cloud over the event and there was no spraying of champagne on the podium. "It seems a very insignificant race when there is a loss of life involved," said David Coulthard, visibly shaken. Villeneuve, whose father Gilles was killed at the Belgian grand prix in 1982, said his back was feeling a "little tight" and was later taken to hospital as a precaution.
