webTitle: Australian grand prix: Marshal's death mars Schumacher's victory

fields.headline: Marshal's death mars opener
fields.standfirst: Michael Schumacher wins the Australian grand prix but celebrations are muted, writes  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: The death of a track marshal cast a shadow over yesterday's Australian grand prix, which saw a flag-to-flag victory for Michael Schumacher.
fields.body:
The death of a track marshal on a sultry afternoon in the first week of a southern hemisphere autumn cast a shadow over yesterday's Australian grand prix, in which a flag-to-flag victory for Michael Schumacher's Ferrari carried the momentum that took him to last year's world championship into the opening race of the new season. The marshal was killed by flying debris in the wake of a high-speed accident between Ralf Schumacher, the champion's younger brother, and Jacques Villeneuve, both of whom emerged almost unscathed.

However extensive the efforts to make it safe, motor racing will always be a dangerous business, and not only for the drivers who are rewarded so generously for risking their lives in the cause of sport and spectacle. Marshals are unpaid volunteers who give up their spare time to make it possible for others to compete for glory. At Monza last September one of their number was killed when a wheel came off Heinz-Harald Frentzen's Jordan during a five-car pile-up. Yesterday in Melbourne it was the turn of a 50-year-old Queenslander, his identity still guarded several hours after the end of the race.

The two cars were running close together in sixth and seventh places as they approached turn three on the fifth of the race's 58 laps, with Villeneuve looking for an opportunity to force his BAR-Honda past Schumacher's Williams-BMW. Schumacher was in the middle of the track, with Villeneuve in line astern. Trying to guess his opponent's intention, Villeneuve moved his car to the outside of the track as they approached the right-hand turn at 175mph, only to discover that Schumacher was already applying the brakes.

The BAR's right front wheel hit the left rear wheel of the Williams, slewing Schumacher into a spin and launching Villeneuve into a flight which sent him up and over his rival before crashing down against the barrier. All four wheels and the front and rear wings were ripped from the BAR as it hurtled along the concrete wall, topped with safety netting, which lines the outside of the track. One of the many pieces of debris - possibly one of the wheels - hit and killed the marshal, who was standing on the outside of the turn, close to an aperture cut in the wire netting through which warning flags are waved. Seven other spectators were treated on the spot for slight injuries, none requiring further treatment.

In Schumacher's recollection, he had slowed normally. "I was on the brakes and being careful not to make any change of line," he said afterwards, going on to suggest that Villeneuve had made a misjudgment similar to that which brought the pair into contact in Montreal last year. Visual evidence, however, appeared to support Villeneuve's belief that the German driver had begun the process of retardation slightly earlier than usual, by enough of a margin to make the accident unavoidable.

So effectively are the drivers now protected that three of the weekend's accidents would probably have produced fatalities in the cockpit only six or seven years ago. Had improvements in the safety aspect of the cars not been ordered after the deaths of Ayrton Senna and Roland Ratzenberger at Imola in 1994, then Villeneuve, Luciano Burti and Michael Schumacher would all have been killed or crippled when their cars left the track at Albert Park at various times during the three-day meeting.

As for the marshal, his death meant that signs of celebration were scarce in the pad dock last night. Few drivers need much encouragement to admit the debt they owe to the volunteers whose lives are at risk from the start to the finish of every race. Yesterday's winner was clearly upset by the news of the fatality, his sorrow shared by David Coulthard and Rubens Barrichello, who finished second and third. "We have to look at how we can improve track safety for those people whose work enables us to go racing," Coulthard said.

The safety car came out and ran at the head of the field for 10 laps, while debris was cleared away and the medics went about their work, but the accident happened early enough in the race to have no discernible effect on its outcome.

This was the fifth grand prix in a row that Michael Schumacher has won from pole position, a statistic which will be preying on the minds of Ferrari's chief rivals. "We had a better car than McLaren this weekend," Ross Brawn, the team's technical director, said, "and what's pleasing is that we've got quite a lot of developments to come."

So clear-cut was the reigning champion's victory on this fast parkland circuit that his final winning margin over Coulthard, a mere 1.7sec, gave no indication of the true gap between the relative performance of the two cars.

Coulthard had a poor start, becoming entangled with Ralf Schumacher and the Jordan of Jarno Trulli in the run down to the first corner. The Scot recovered well enough to mount a respectable challenge, however, once Mika Hakkinen, his team-mate, had been forced out of second place when his front suspension failed just before half-distance, and Barrichello had slowed after an early brush with Frentzen put a front wheel of his Ferrari out of alignment. But the 10-second margin that lay between Schumacher and Coulthard after each had made his only pit stop gave the German a cushion which he was content to exploit over the final 15 laps, preserving his machinery while keeping a careful eye on the McLaren.

The first race of the season contained no suggestion that any of the other nine teams will soon be in a position to mount a serious challenge to Ferrari and McLaren. Olivier Panis, in his first race for BAR, finished in an apparently solid fourth place on the road, only to be given a 25-second penalty after the race for overtaking under a yellow flag, which moved him down to seventh in the standings. His misfortune brought joy to the Sauber team, giving fourth and sixth places to their young pair of Nick Heidfeld and Kimi Raikkonen, aged 23 and 21 respectively. Raikkonen, in only his 24th race since graduating from karts to cars, gave a remarkably assured display after making a poor start from 13th place on the grid. The young Finn ran consistently fast, made no mistakes, had the pleasure of overtaking Jean Alesi's Prost and the Benettons of Giancarlo Fisichella and Jenson Button, and was the last driver to finish on the same lap as the leader.

Last year's prodigy, in sharp contrast, endured the most miserable day of his short and spectacular formula one career. A year ago in Melbourne Button was the star rookie, holding sixth place in his first grand prix until the engine of his Williams-BMW gave way. Yesterday his new Renault-engined Benetton showed itself to be down on power and deficient in handling qualities, and the Englishman's chances of making a respectable showing were further reduced when he was given a early 10-second stop-and-go penalty after race officials spotted that his mechanics had been late in leaving the grid before the parade lap.

Juan Pablo Montoya, the 25-year-old Colombian driver who arrived from the US to take Button's seat in the Williams team, had worked his way up to fourth place during the pit stops, taking advantage of retirements and misfortunes, when his engine expired.

The first round of a new war between tyre manufacturers went firmly the way of Bridgestone, whose clients filled the top six positions. Panis was the highest placed runner on equipment supplied by Michelin, making a return to formula one after a 16-year absence. Eighth and 11th, also on Michelins, were the disappointing Jaguars of Luciano Burti and Eddie Irvine.

The increased level of competition among the tyre manufacturers, and the significance of their products to the performance of the cars on yesterday's grid, could easily be seen in the pole position time, which was four seconds faster than last year's figure, despite the governing body's efforts to reduce performance by applying new aerodynamic regulations. Trying to slow a formula one car down, it seems, is a bit like trying to make motor racing safe.

Yesterday his new Renault-engined Benetton showed itself to be down on power and deficient in handling qualities, and the Englishman's chances of making a respectable showing were further reduced when he was given a early 10-second stop-and-go penalty after race officials spotted that his mechanics had been late in leaving the grid before the parade lap. Juan Pablo Montoya, the 25-year-old Colombian driver who arrived from the US to take Button's seat in the Williams team, had worked his way up to fourth place during the pit stops, taking advantage of retirements and misfortunes, when his engine expired. The first round of a new war between tyre manufacturers went firmly the way of Bridgestone, whose clients filled the top six positions. Panis was the highest placed runner on equipment supplied by Michelin, making a return to formula one after a 16-year absence. Eighth and 11th, also on Michelins, were the disappointing Jaguars of Luciano Burti and Eddie Irvine. The increased level of competition among the tyre manufacturers, and the significance of their products to the performance of the cars on yesterday's grid, could easily be seen in the pole position time, which was four seconds faster than last year's figure, despite the governing body's efforts to reduce performance by applying new aerodynamic regulations. Trying to slow a formula one car down, it seems, is a bit like trying to make motor racing safe.

webTitle: 'Wake up to fair trade' say celebrities

fields.headline: 'Wake up to fair trade' say celebrities
fields.standfirst: The UK's third Fairtrade Fortnight gets underway with the backing of celebrities and policitians alike who want to urge the public to eat with a clear conscience
fields.trailText: The UK's third Fairtrade Fortnight gets underway with the backing of celebrities and policitians alike who want to urge the public to eat with a clear conscience
fields.body:
Angus Deayton, Janet Suzman, George Alagiah and Antony Worrall Thompson are just some of the celebrities who will be teaming up with the Fairtrade Foundation to launch the UK's third annual Fairtrade Fortnight - "Wake up to fair trade".

Over the next two weeks, the charity will urge us to start the day by eating a more thoughtful breakfast, in a nationwide campaign to promote a better deal for small-scale farmers in developing countries.

The crops these farmers produce, such as bananas, cocoa, honey, sugar, tea and coffee are subject to big fluctuations on the volatile world commodities market. Products that bear the Fairtrade mark - the UK's independent consumer guarantee of internationally agreed fair trade conditions - means that shoppers can be sure farmers are getting a price well above the low world market rates for their produce, and benefit from the security of long-term trading contracts.

Fair trade is backed by the international development secretary, Clare Short, as a significant way of alleviating poverty.

"Fair trade is a practical way for the public to bring a transformation to the lives of people in developing countries," says Ms Short. "By purchasing fair trade products, consumers are sending out a powerful message to supermarkets: that we care where our goods are coming from, and that they are produced in a decent way. As demand grows, these values are influencing mainstream sources and our purchasing power is sending ripples of change across the world."

There are now more than 70 fair trade products on sale, and the most recent one to be awarded the Fairtrade stamp of approval is orange juice from Cuba. Andy Redfern, international director of the fair trade company Traidcraft, helped to forge the relationship between Cuban fruit-growing cooperatives and Gerber, the UK's biggest drink packers.

"Rather than buy the fruit from estates, it was important to source these oranges from smallholders so the extra value from fair trade can filter back easily to the farming communities," says Mr Redfern. "Fair trade products have moved on - they have to be professionally produced, packaged and marketed to attract consumers' attention, and this orange juice will be pitched at the quality end of the mainstream market."

Mr Redfern hopes that the orange juice will follow on where fair trade bananas have already blazed a trail. With 95% of UK households buying bananas, they are an extremely valuable commodity, and as the first supermarket to stock the fair trade fruit last March, the Co-op is now stumping up serious money on television adverts promoting ethical shopping to support this year's campaign.

Nioka Abbott, a banana farmer on St Vincent in the Caribbean has come to the UK to speak at the launch of Fairtrade Fortnight where she will explain why the 200 farmers in the Windward Island Farmer's Association decided to become fair traders.

"Banana farming is very hard physical work. They are like babies - you have to be around them all the time. All my standard grade bananas are being sold to fair trade. It's making a big difference to our lives, because usually the price is so low we can scarcely manage to farm. Selling fair trade bananas we get more money and on every box of bananas there is an extra social premium which goes into the cooperative fund.

"Many of the women in our community are single parents and have to work in the fields so we are considering using the premium money to build a nursery. The other benefit is that being a fair trade farmer, we will use fewer chemicals which means we will be healthier and selling a healthier banana to the consumer. If fair trade could find a market to sell all our bananas, we would be happy for you to have all of them."

webTitle: Inter find Roma with too much in reserve

fields.headline: Inter find Roma with too much in reserve
fields.standfirst: Paul MacInnes on how the injury-hit league leaders still extended their advantage at the top of the table
fields.trailText: Serie A leaders Roma were without captain Cafu, midfielder Emerson and Gabriel Batistuta when they met Internazionale last night. What's more, Francesco Totti was called into action despite a thigh injury. A potentially tricky encounter, but one that Roma still won 3-2 thanks to two goals from their reserve striker, a certain Vincenzo Montella.
fields.body:
Serie A leaders Roma were without captain Cafu, midfielder Emerson and Gabriel Batistuta when they met Internazionale last night. What's more, Francesco Totti was called into action despite a thigh injury. A potentially tricky encounter, but one that Roma still won 3-2 thanks to two goals from their reserve striker, a certain Vincenzo Montella.

That Montella, according to the statistics, is the best striker in Serie A gives you some idea as to the strength of this current Roma side. At his former club Sampdoria, Montella scored 82 goals in 113 matches. He was so good his coach David Platt said he wouldn't sell him for £20m. Platt was duly sacked of course, and Montella made his way to the capital for £15m - since when he has spent most of the time on the bench. "I understand that rotation is important to the team," he said earlier this year, "but to be fair I don't see that I get my turn at Roma."

With a man-of-the-match display last night, that may change. Roma were 1-0 down within seven minutes at the Olympic stadium, Christian Vieri finishing an Alvaro Recoba through-ball with some venom. But two minutes later and Roma were level again when a Marcos Assuncao free-kick (seemingly deflecting off Montella) sped past Inter keeper Sebastien Frey.

Another Assuncao free-kick, in the 27th minute, provided Montella with his first goal of the game when it cannoned off the Inter bar and onto the Italian international's waiting forehead. But more neat play between Recoba and Vieri drew the game level before half-time - Vieri's angled shot finding its way past goalkeeper Antonioli.

There the game stayed tied until the 86th minute, when a rare forward burst from centre-half Walter Samuel was converted by a header from Montella. Roma had avenged their 2-0 defeat by Inter earlier in the season and increased their lead at the top of Serie A to five points. "Montella is a great striker," said coach Fabio Capello after the game. "I've always said it is important to have a pool of 25 players to have a strong team for the second half of the season." So back to the bench it is then.

Juve and Lazio enjoy their awaydays

Roma needed their win after the two teams hottest on their heels, Juventus and Lazio, both earned valuable away wins. Lazio beat Brescia 1-0 with a 59th-minute strike from Marcelo Salas, but were made to work hard by a Brescia side slowly pulling themselves away from trouble. With Roberto Baggio pulling the strings, and Serie A's striking surprise Dario Hubner (13 goals so far this season) causing havoc in defence, Lazio were fortunate to win, and Dino Zoff knew it. "We have been very very lucky tonight," Zoff said. Hubner concurred: "I don't think they played well."

Alex del Piero's up and down season continued for Juventus in their 2-0 win at Udinese. It was his thumping free-kick that crashed off the bar, allowing Gianluca Zambrotta to poke in the opener, and he also set up Filippo Inzaghi for the second. But with ten minutes to go, Del Piero got his second yellow card of the afternoon for a needless handball and went off for an early bath.

The result leaves Juventus in third place, six points behind Roma - Lazio, a point better off, have played one game more - but coach Carlo Ancelotti didn't exactly jump to Del Piero's defence. "The referee was right to send Del Piero off," he said, before going on to praise the rest of the side. "I'm really satisfied with this scoreline and this performance", he said. "We have to carry on with these performances. We have to do the best we can until the end of the Championship."

More misery for Milan

The end of the championship has surely arrived for AC Milan. The champions of 1999 are in eighth position in the league, outside the European places and 20 points behind Roma. A man up for most of their home match on Saturday, Alberto Zaccheroni's side could only muster a 2-2 draw with Parma, whose recent form under coach Renzo Ulivieri continues to be impressive.

Twice Milan were in the lead, the first a 20-yard strike from Paolo Maldini punishing a weak clearance by Gianluigi Buffon, the second a diving header from midfielder Guly. But Parma, despite the dismissal of Sabri Lamouchi in the 22nd minute, came back with a goal apiece from their expensively-assembled strikeforce of Savo Milosevic and substitute Amoroso.

Afterwards, Zaccheroni who takes Milan to Istanbul to face Galatasaray this Wednesday night, blamed defeat on a team decimated by injury. "The only crisis we have is an injury crisis," he said. "I thought it would be a really difficult match with my squad in such a state, but we created lots of chances. They only created two chances and scored from both." Bitter words from Zacc, whose name, coincidentally, rhymes with "sack".

webTitle: Will the Real IRA please stand up?

fields.headline: Will the Real IRA please stand up?
fields.standfirst: The Irish republican movement is deeply prone to schismatic tendencies, of   which the Real IRA is the latest manifestation
fields.trailText: The Irish republican movement is deeply prone to schismatic tendencies, reports Derek Brown, of which the Real IRA is the latest manifestation.
fields.body:
The amoeba-like propensity of the movement to divide and reproduce itself goes back nearly a century, to the birth of the Irish Free State and the bitter civil war which followed.

Sinn Fein and the original Irish Republican Army were bitterly divided over the treaty which partitioned Ireland. The pro-treaty faction became the government of the nascent state; the anti-treaty faction annexed the name IRA and fought on for a united Ireland.

Later, when the diehard leader Eamon De Valera abandoned the armed struggle and formed his Fianna Fail party, the movement was torn apart again. But it wasn't until the late 1960s that the movement underwent its most cathartic split.

By then, the IRA had shrunk in numbers and in militancy. Most of its leadership were more concerned with Marxist ideology than with machine guns.

When the modern Troubles erupted, they were regarded with derision by a new generation of ardent activists, who derided the ageing revolutionaries with the graffito "IRA = I Ran Away".

The militant tendency decided to form its own version of the republican movement, taking its name from the ad hoc, or provisional, committee set up for the purpose. The Provisionals were born.

In the early 1970s, there were bloody confrontations beteen the old and new versions of the movement. The old IRA were once again derided as the "Stickies" - the curious nickname derived from the fact that the paper lilies which they wore on Easter Sunday to mark the 1916 Dublin Rising, were gummed rather than fastened with safety pins. (For a time the Provisionals were known to some as "Pinnies" but the name never, so to speak, stuck).

The power struggle was one-sided, and the "Stickies" faded into oblivion. But the mid-1970s brought yet another schism, as hardline ideologues and militants broke off from the rump of the old guard to form the Irish Republican Socialist party and a new armed wing, the Irish National Liberation Army.

There was a brief but bloody three-sided feud involving the old and new versions of the IRA and the new upstart street army, before the INLA retreated to the sidelines of history.

The 1980s brought yet another upheaval, when the newly politically conscious young leadership of Sinn Fein, notably Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, decided to drop the movement's boycott of the Irish parliament.

The old guard was disgusted, and regrouped around the former IRA chief of staff, Ruari O Bradaigh. They called themselves Republican Sinn Fein, and spawned yet another armed group, the Continuity IRA.

The Continuity IRA is thought to be tiny and ill-equipped. Far more worrying is the faction of dissidents which is scandalised by the Provisionals' participation in the current peace process.

They call themselves the Real IRA, and are associated with the political movement known as the 32-County Sovereignty Committee.

The Real IRA was responsible for the worst single atrocity of the modern Troubles, the bombing which devastated the centre of the County Tyrone town of Omagh on August 15 1998.

The explosion killed 29 people, largely because the warning calls to the police were bungled. The wave of revulsion which followed, drove the Real IRA to declare a ceasefire a month later - a cynical pledge which it has frequently broken.

webTitle: Rail crash salvage work pauses for mourning

fields.headline: Rail crash salvage work pauses for mourning
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Salvage work on the devastation of the Great Heck railway disaster stopped briefly yesterday as local people and rescuers joined survivors of the crash and the families of three of the 10 fatalities at a service of remembrance and prayer.
fields.body:
Salvage work on the devastation of the Great Heck railway disaster stopped briefly yesterday as local people and rescuers joined survivors of the crash and the families of three of the 10 fatalities at a service of remembrance and prayer.

Mourners' cars lined the lane to the village for the full quarter-mile between the M62 and the railway to Ferrybridge power station, which the coal train involved in the tragedy never reached. Grieving for the loss of life and health, the Bishop of Doncaster, Cyril Ashton, also recognised the national shock after a succession of rail disasters.

Earlier, there had been tears during an impromptu service on the bridge above the wrecked trains, where 33 other passengers suffered serious injuries and 37 suffered cuts, bruising and shock.

British Transport police chaplain Miles Mitson conducted prayers and readings for the family of John Weddle, driver of the GNER Newcastle-London express, who died in the 125mph collision with a Land Rover which had slewed off the M62 onto the tracks. Flowers were also laid in the twisted cab of the Freightliner coal train, which collided moments later with the derailed express and one of whose two drivers, Stephen Dunn, was also killed.

Mr Dunn's sons, Andrew, 12, and James, nine, were taken to the scene by their mother, Mary, and Supt Tony Thompson of British Transport police, who is in charge of the crash scene. They left notes including one from Andrew, reading: "I promise I will do my best to help Mum. I will see you later. Love."

One of two cranes later lifted the broken-backed freight engine from the garden of the former chairman of Heck parish council, Arnold Whittles, whose house was missed by a matter of yards. Mr Whittles, who took more than 14 walking wounded in during the freezing aftermath of the crash on Wednesday, was among those remembering the dead and injured.

Four of the passengers killed have not yet been named, but it is thought certain that they include Steve Baldwin of Teesside University. A pioneer of research into the children's drug Ritalin, he is thought to have been on his way to London on the express, which left Newcastle at 4.45am.

The names of four victims apart from the drivers were released at the weekend. They are Christopher Terry, 30, a York IT consultant and church warden; Robert Shakespeare, an IT manager from Beverley, east Yorkshire; GNER buffet car chef Paul Taylor from Newcastle; and the express train's customer operations leader, Raymond Robson, 43, from Whitley Bay.

Police are expected to hand the site over to Railtrack today after a final check below engine debris and a set of wheels crushed into the embankment, which the cranes will remove tonight. The Land Rover, whose driver, Gary Hart, 36, of Strubby, Lincolnshire, is to face further questioning, has also been removed for forensic tests. Railtrack does not expect the link between Doncaster and York to open before the end of this week.

A 27-year-old Coventry man was arrested yesterday for allegedly wasting police time by falsely claiming a relative might have died in the crash.

fields.headline: Disability campaigners welcome reforms
fields.trailText: Disability rights campaigners have welcomed government plans to extend the employment rights of disabled people as the most significant reforms since the introduction of anti-discrimination legislation 30 years ago. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Disability rights campaigners have welcomed government plans to extend the employment rights of disabled people as the most significant reforms since the introduction of anti-discrimination legislation 30 years ago.

Under the proposals the police, fire fighters and prison officers would no longer be exempt from the Disability Discrimination Act. Cancer patients would also gain new rights to prevent employers from sacking them simply because of their illness.

Minister for disabled people Margaret Hodge said the new measures would "extend the rights of over 600,000 disabled people already in jobs and cover nearly seven million jobs previously excluded from the act".

Bert Massie, chairman of the disability rights commission said: "This is the most significant programme of reforms since disability rights legislation was first introduced 30 years ago. Once these measures are implemented we will all be living in a much fairer and inclusive society.

"The reforms will extend the protection of the Disability Discrimination Act to people diagnosed as having cancer or HIV even though it might be non symptomatic. Clarifying the definition of disability should reduce the number of cases that need to be resolved through legal action."

Mrs Hodge said although most employers respected the rights of the disabled, the disability rights taskforce had identified some shocking breaches of the law.

She said: "The task force report cites evidence of several women in remission from cancer, with less than a 50% chance of the cancer recurring, who have been sacked or selected for redundancy. This is shameful.

"The task force found that some employers discriminate against people diagnosed with cancer even though the cancer had no present effects, or was in remission. I know that the vast majority of employers would never behave in such a fashion and many employers are supportive; but for those that aren't, their employees need the protection of the law."

Ms Hodge said the government would also revise legislation covering the blind and partially sighted, as some people had had difficulty proving that they were disabled. Anyone who has been certified or registered under local authority schemes would be automatically counted as disabled, she said.

Small business will have until 2004 to make their premises accessible to disabled workers and public bodies will be legally bound to provide equal opportunities.

"Physically demanding jobs, like nurses and ambulance crews, are already covered by the act and it hasn't led to the recruitment of people who are clearly unsuited to such posts," said Mrs Hodge.

Paul Whitehouse, chief constable of Sussex Police and chair of the Association of Chief Police Officers' personnel management committee, said: "I welcome the extension of the DDA. It will require us to establish very clearly what the requirements are to be an effective police officer and also assist in ensuring that police officers do not have to retire early unnecessarily."

Stephen Alambritis of the Federation of Small Businesses said: "We welcome the government's proposals and hope that we can work with them, the disability rights commission and others to help small business prepare for the changes."

fields.headline: Controversy? Here's the Real deal
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe reports on the Real Madrid-Barcelona derbi. Oh, there were some other matches as well
fields.trailText: Sid Lowe reports on the Real Madrid-Barcelona derbi. Oh, there were some other matches as well
fields.body:
They're doing their nut in Barcelona. And not without reason. Sport described it as "The Theft of the Century!", maybe not the dramatic statement that was intended just two months into 2001, but you get the point. Likewise, El Mundo Deportivo's front cover screamed "ROBO" in enormous capitals and ironically reproduced one of the madridistas' chants: "¡Así, así, así gana el Madrí!" ("That's the way Madrid win!")

Barça president Joan Gaspart felt "like I've had my wallet stolen", while fellow director Gabriel Massfurroll sought to inflate the crime statistics: "It's not just ours," he said, "108,000 wallets have been robbed".

Rivaldo, meanwhile, sniffed something more sinister in the air. "Somewhere there are vested interests who want Real Madrid to be champions," he announced, glancing across at the grassy knoll. El Mundo Deportivo's columnist Santi Noller has bought the Brazilian's story: "This league championship already has an owner" he alleged hysterically. "Let's stop now to prevent any more heartache. Let them have their Liga!"

So, what's all the fuss about? It's that old Catalan favourite - bent refs in cahoots with Real Madrid. You see, on Saturday night Barcelona beat their eternal rivals 3-2 in the Bernabéu. Or at least, they thought they did, but their dramatic last-minute winner magically vanished with a wave of the linesman's flag; three Barça players were returning from an offside position (and hardly interfering with play) when Rivaldo's shot found its way past Iker Casillas.

Not surprisingly, Barça's players went mental. Marc Overmars sprinted off the bench and got pelted by the Madrid fans as he shot down the wing past Míchel Salgado (not for the first time) to have it out with the linesman. He was joined in battle by the rest of the side, apart from Rivaldo who just walked away smiling in disbelief. Things calmed down for a minute, literally, only to go off again at the final whistle - Pep Guardiola was pulled away from the ref by Madrid official Agustín Herrerín, who seemed to be quite enjoying himself. (Funny that.)

Barcelona had a point, but the suggestion that Saturday represented a return to the dark days of the Franco régime, when (sometimes) there really was something fishy going on, is a bit over the top - to say the least.

It looked a very harsh decision and even the notoriously partisan Madrid press was on the Catalans' side - AS and Marca both admitted that the goal was "perfectly legal".

One person who didn't agree - not publicly, at least - was the Man in the Moustache. The only person who's kept his copy of the little White Book, del Bosque conveniently declined to comment. "If the ref didn't allow it, it's not a goal," he said, before playing the managers' Get Out of Jail Free card: "From where I was I didn't see it."

Anyway, referee José Losantos Omar wasn't the man at fault. Asked if the ref had cost Barça the game, Guardiola was adamant: "No. The Linesman." And at least one Barça player had seen it coming, or so he claims. "I remember looking at the linesman and thinking: 'He's too young to officiate a game like this'." said Michael Reiziger.

Before the ninetieth-minute drama, there hadn't been as much fun as we'd hoped, despite some promising signs during the week. Madrid's proposed silent "welcome" never materialised for a start, possibly on the advice of the Man in the Moustache who admitted, "If I was in the crowd, I'd whistle Barça".

Maybe the unfortunate comments of the Mayor of Madrid, José María Álvarez del Manzano, also played a part. Manzano insisted that Madrid's fans should "welcome the foreign team with respect" - a Freudian slip from a Castilian centrist if ever their was one - and one which prompted Gaspart, clearly forgetting his own petrol-pouring role back in October, to go on the offensive again. "No-one," he said, "should tell fans what to do - not the Mayor of Madrid, not the president of Real Madrid, not the president of Barcelona," well, maybe him Joan, "not even the Pope."

The Corinthian spirit so lauded by Madrid's president Florentino Pérez did seem to have done a runner, albeit not to the extent decried by the more rabid members of the Catalan press, who either forgot what happened last time or thought, like Gaspart, that "nothing happened last time". A coach-load of Boixos Nois Ultras was pelted with stones and Barça's teenage keeper José Reina was punched by a Real Madrid fan when he went to retrieve the ball from behind the goal.

The chasing pack falter

As it turns out, the derbi result strengthened Real's position after Valencia drew 1-1 with Zaragoza and second-placed Deportivo lost 2-1 at Real Mallorca, the team with the best results against the big three: 10 points from twelve against Depor (twice) Madrid and Barça.

With the Big Two to come in the next two weeks, Luis Aragonés' side will have a big say in the title race, and might even grab a Champions League slot, having climbed to fifth above Villarreal, who lost 2-1 against Málaga on Sunday.

Dario Silva smashed two emphatic finishes past Pedro Contreras, but the real highlights were the electronic advertising boards - which clicked round to ARCE half-way through the second half - and the kids in the Madrigal crowd who, despite their tender years, displayed a total mastery of an impressive array of repartee with which to welcome their opponents. And the ref, of course.

Mid-table boring: just as well the bottom is exciting, then

While there were mid-table 0-0 bores between Espanyol and Alavés and Las Palmas and Atheltic Bilbao, things are really hotting-up down the bottom.

John Benjamin's Real Sociedad picked up "three wonderful points" with a 2-0 win over Rayo Vallecano, but it wasn't enough to get them out the bottom three, thanks to Santander's unfortunate centre-back, Ramis - he scored an own goal as his side lost 1-0 to Numancia.

Osasuna won 2-1 against Valladolid with two in four minutes from Iván Rosado, and Real Oviedo are rapidly closing in on the relegation zone. And despite Stan Collymore finally getting a game - well, 25 minutes - Radi Antic's side lost again, 1-0 to Celta.

Amid all the derbi hype, Spain's international against England in midweek - during which the England fans enquired whether Camacho's boys were, in fact, Scotland in disguise - has been quickly forgotten. Luckily. Not before a bit of a slating, mind you. Of all the abuse, Marca's headline on Thursday morning was surely the most hurtful. The national side now, said the Madrid-based daily, is "just the same as it was with Javi [Clemente]". Ouch.

fields.headline: TV producer joins Lib Dems' campaign
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: The Lib Dems have signed up TV programme-maker Anthony Palmer to produce its party political broadcasts, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have signed up TV programme-maker Anthony Palmer to produce its general election party political broadcasts.

Mr Palmer's most recent TV credit was Channel 4 documentary series Living by the Book.

He is currently working with Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy on a party political broadcast.

Learning by the Book was an RDF Television series following people who use self-help books.

Mr Palmer was responsible for the Learning by the Book episode that featured parents teaching toddlers to behave themselves.

Related story
Feb 27: Lib Dems unveil campaign poster

Mr Palmer's most recent TV credit was Channel 4 documentary series Living by the Book. He is currently working with Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy on a party political broadcast. Learning by the Book was an RDF Television series following people who use self-help books. Mr Palmer was responsible for the Learning by the Book episode that featured parents teaching toddlers to behave themselves. Related story Feb 27: Lib Dems unveil campaign poster

fields.headline: Welcome to the northern contest of mullets, mud and Maoris
fields.standfirst: Screen Break
fields.trailText: Rugby league, I know, is not to everyone's taste. Despite sporadic and often comic attempts to break out of its northern stronghold - anyone remember Southend Invicta? - the game remains as alien to most of the south of England as whippet racing, or reasonably priced beer.
fields.body:
Rugby league, I know, is not to everyone's taste. Despite sporadic and often comic attempts to break out of its northern stronghold - anyone remember Southend Invicta? - the game remains as alien to most of the south of England as whippet racing, or reasonably priced beer.

The late Peter Cook, for instance, according to Harry Thompson's magisterial biography, spent many of his final days watching satellite sports channels around the clock. Apparently he would watch any sport, however obscure, apart from rugby league, which he just could not stick.

While I yield to no one in my appreciation of Cook's comic genius, I feel there are aspects of the game he may have missed, so for those of you who share the late satirist's aversion maybe a few pointers from a northerner brought up in the game will prove helpful as a new season dawns.

Super League VI started at the weekend with two matches live on Sky. Note, that's Super League VI; not six, nor even 6, roman numerals being very much de rigeur for any game in which the bulk of the participants have a collar size higher than 18 (or XVIII, if you prefer). New satellite subscribers with limited previous experience of Super League will, I am sure, have found some aspects of match number I, Wigan versus Warrington, mystifying, so let us attempt clarification.

The first rule to remember is that when there is a brawl - and there was a peach in the Wigan match - the referee will study it carefully from the sidelines as punches fly in from all directions.

He will then enter into prolonged consultation lasting maybe an hour or two with his two assistants - usually chosen for something comic in their appearance rather than any special powers of observation - and then send off the player wearing a mullet.

You should know that there are only two hair styles in rugby league; the mullet, a haircut in which the sides and top of the hair are significantly shorter than the back, favoured by imports from rural New Zealand, where I suspect A Flock of Seagulls still have the top five records, and a very severe grade one which makes barrel-chested bullet-headed 18st forwards look even more fearsome than they otherwise would.

I find the mullet, quite apart from any nostalgic appeal, quite exciting when sported by a speedy muscular second rower bursting through the defence and I am encouraged to find I am not alone in my interest in the style - sometimes also known as a beaver paddle, a squirrel pelt, or a Tennessee top hat - as there is an entire web-site (mulletsgalore.com) devoted to it.

There was even a question in this newspaper's Notes And Queries section, asking why the mullet was so called. (One reader said it was "because it looks like you have a dead fish on your head", while another suggested it was named after the French fashion guru Henri Mollet, but that's Guardian readers for you). To those of you who wish to further your mullet studies, I commend Super League. These days, the only opportunity to study the style - business in the front, party round the back - is at WWF wrestling matches, concerts by 70s heavy rock dinosaurs, or in Billy Ray Cyrus's publicity shots.

Anyway, that is how come the Maori forward Tawere Nikau, almost blameless in the fracas, got first crack at the Wash And Go, after an almighty bust-up between a dozen or so Warrington and Wigan players. Another thing to say about brawls like the one in the Wigan game is that "it is not what we want to see in Super League," as commentator Eddie Hemmings said.

You had to agree with him, too, especially as Sky provided three opportunities to look at the punch-up from a variety of interesting and illuminating angles. I could have done with just one more replay actually, to convince myself of how much I really didn't want to see it.

I could not share in Eddie's condemnation of the brawl. I am amazed it does not happen more often. Rugby league players are models of restraint in my view. All through the match, they are in each other's faces - in a quite literal sense.

When a player is tackled, standard practice is to haul yourself up using the tackler's head for leverage, either grinding the palm of your hand into the flesh of his nose ("giving him a facial," as Eddie's sidekick Stevo calls it) or pushing his head down into the ground and forcing him to eat a large helping of south-west Lancashire mud.

Yet most of the time they resist the temptation to exact retribution, despite the abundant opportunities the game affords. If only these guys could carry the same sweet reason into the barber's chair.

Finally, the Aston Villa manager John Gregory last night became the latest football celebrity to be honoured with a guest spot on Sky's soccer soap Dream Team, and he was rather good in his smouldering, brilliantined way. Not yet ready for the Royal Shakespeare company, maybe, but better than Andy Cole.

martin@kelner.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Poster advertising booms
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Labour and the Tories are competing for poster sites because of a huge boom in poster advertising, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Labour and the Conservatives are struggling to secure poster sites for their pre-election campaigns because of a huge boom in poster advertising.

Poster experts say the industry is enjoying unprecedented success in the run-up to a possible May general election.

This is being fuelled partly by the political parties, but also by a recent spate of rebranding campaigns from the likes of Accenture - which until recently was known as Andersen Consulting - and the Post Office.

Fears over the economy also mean advertisers are cutting back, making the relatively cheap medium of posters more attractive than TV advertising.

According to poster-buying specialists Concord, less than 2% of so-called "supersite" billboards - those that carry 96-sheet posters - are still available in March.

This compares with an average of 9% for this time of year. And in April just 1% of the market is free compared with a norm of 53%.

The standard 48-sheet poster sites are also pretty booked up. In March, only 9% of sites are free compared with 19% at the same time last year.

And in April, the figure is 11% compared with a 46% average over the last two years.

The timing of the election - the government now looks almost certain to name May 3 - means voters will be bombarded with an intensive, four-week burst of advertising in the run-up to polling day.

So congestion in April could be a problem.

"I think both the Conservatives and Labour have just about managed to book the number of sites they wanted but they have probably had to compromise on quality," said Concord managing director Nigel Mansell.

"A lot of the bigger advertisers are starting to cut back on television and if they start transferring their budgets to posters it doesn't take much to start clogging up the market."

According to Concord research, Labour has little activity planned for this month but will launch a heavyweight (around 3,000 sites) 48-sheet poster campaign in April which will continue through to May.

The Conservatives are planning a medium-weight (about 2,000 sites) 48-sheet poster campaign for the second two weeks of March, and a heavyweight 96-sheet campaign for the last two weeks in April.

In previous elections the size of campaigns has not been an exact science.

This is because companies that support one or other of the parties have booked billboards in their own names, only to transfer them to the party of their choice later on.

But poster experts say this practice no longer exists.

In the last month suspicions have been raised that Dixons boss Sir Stanley Kalms is about to throw some billboards into the Tories' campaign after he cashed shares in.

But experts say the practice is largely obsolete. "Nowadays you tend to find that once an election is called there is some last-minute bargaining for extra space. That wouldn't happen if they had poster bookings they could call on," said one.

The size of the campaigns - roughly equivalent to that of a car launch - means both political parties are spending less than they did at the last election, when poster companies saw booking s of 5,000 sites from the two big parties.

This is probably because of new restrictions on the amount of money political parties can spend on their election campaigns.

Political parties focus on poster advertising because they are not allowed to use radio or television.

Newspaper advertising tends to be used to target specific markets rather than the general public.

On average, advertisers can expect to pay about £300 to run a 48-sheet poster for two weeks, plus a 20% agency commission, so a medium-weight 48-sheet campaign would cost around £720,000.

The scarcity of 96-sheet sites - there are only around 3,000 in the country - means they can cost three or four times that.

Supersites also tend to be in prime locations such as city centres, giving advertisers a double whammy effect.

Advertisers that cancel their poster bookings are liable to pay 15% of the cost of the site if they cancel within two months and a whopping 90% if they pull their ads with just a month to go.

Poster experts say the industry is enjoying unprecedented success in the run-up to a possible May general election. This is being fuelled partly by the political parties, but also by a recent spate of rebranding campaigns from the likes of Accenture - which until recently was known as Andersen Consulting - and the Post Office. Fears over the economy also mean advertisers are cutting back, making the relatively cheap medium of posters more attractive than TV advertising. fields.headline: BBC bomb rocks news operations
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The weekend bomb blast at the BBC has caused major disruption to news programmes, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 5: BBC bomb threatens peace process

'It was a fireball that seemed to fill the whole road'
Gallery: the blast in pictures
fields.body:
The bomb blast that rocked the BBC's White City headquarters at the weekend has caused major disruption to news programmes, with the whole of the corporation's new Stage Six news centre out of bounds and up to 1,000 journalists affected.

Earlier in the day, BBC news bosses planned to move the One O'Clock News but in the event it was broadcast from its usual location.

The backdrop of the newsroom - which was heavily damaged - was replaced.

BBC drama facilities at Centre House were also disrupted, with many staff working from home.

The BBC's two rolling news services, BBC News 24 and BBC World had to be combined for most of the Sunday.

BBC bosses are playing down the disruption to services. A spokesman said that by Monday evening it would be "business as usual".

But a thorough security review will follow the blast, which follows a series of recent security scares at the corporation.

"Whenever an incident like this happens, we review our security," said a BBC spokesman.

Security was tightened two years ago following the death of Jill Dando. Staff not only had to show their ID, but their belonging were also checked before they were allowed through the turnstiles at TV centre.

It was reviewed again four months later in September 1999 when a man got through security and ran amok at Stage Six, overturning computers and breaking glass.

He ran through the newsroom screaming and waving a wooden club, leaving newsreader Anna Ford and up to 100 other journalists including royal correspondent Jennie Bond badly shaken.

BBC bosses played down the latest incident, claiming that the only real damage had been to the front of the BBC building.

"The business of TV and radio is about having people coming and going through our doors. We depend on welcoming members of the public, and we have to balance the need for security with this," said a spokesman.

Newspaper photographs graphically show how up to a dozen of the plate glass windows in TV centre were smashed in the blast.

The bomb exploded at 00.20am on Sunday morning in front of the building in London's White City. Around 50 BBC staff had to be evacuated, but only one person - a London underground worker - is believed to have been hurt.

Security forces believe the bomb was planted by dissident Irish republican group the Real IRA.

It is believed the bomb could be a revenge attack by the group, prompted by the Panorama programme Who Bombed Omagh? which identified three men suspected to have planted the bomb which killed 29 people and two unborn children in 1998.

John Ware, who researched and presented the programme, was unavailable for comment.

The BBC refused to discuss whether additional security was to be provided for Mr Ware. who is believed to have been put under special protection ever since he made the award-winning documentary on the Omagh bomb.

fields.headline: Take a proper gander
fields.standfirst: A survey shows that party political advertising is a waste of money. But then doesn't effective propaganda work best without the target's knowledge?  Claire Cozens consults the people who have tried to tell you how to vote
fields.trailText: A survey shows that party political advertising is a waste of money. But then doesn't effective propaganda work best without the target's knowledge? Claire Cozens consults the people who have tried to tell you how to vote
fields.body:
It has been proved beyond doubt that advertising influences our decisions on everything from the beer we drink to the pills we take to cure the hangover. But if new research is to be believed, it has virtually no effect on our voting. In a survey published today by the Chartered Institute of Marketing, the vast majority of respondents claim to be completely uninfluenced by political advertising, with just 8% admitting that ads helped them to decide how to vote.

More worryingly, negative political campaigns such as the Conservatives' Demon Eyes may even drive voters into the arms of the opposition: for every person who said ads criticising other parties persuaded them to vote for the advertiser, five found them so irritating that they would be influenced in the opposite direction.

Asked which positive characteristics they associated with the three main parties, most respondents drew a blank. Fewer than 20% of the 1,043 adults questioned associated any party with the words "competent", "intelligent" or "forward-thinking" and only just over 20% felt the Labour party was "fit to govern".

But can we really believe what people tell the pollsters? Mark Wnek, creative director of Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper and the man behind Ken Livingstone's election campaign, thinks not. "Most people don't think they're affected by any advertising so it's no surprise that they don't think they're affected by political campaigns," he says. "If advertising does what it's supposed to, people don't know they're being influenced. If there's a prolonged background of negative messages people will take that on board. If it's unskilfully done, it might be counterproductive but if it's well done it will work."

Chris Powell, chairman of ad agency BMP DDB, which handled Labour's advertising during the last election, believes most good political ad campaigns are negative: "Of course people say they don't like it because we're all nice people and we don't want to be rude. But the truth is that positive advertising just doesn't work. Having said that, there's a difference between a slagging campaign and a reasoned attack. Ads like Demon Eyes don't work because there's no substance to them. But the Tories' Tax Bombshell ads in the 1992 election had real impact because they provided new information."

The ads used figures calculated by the Conservative party to show how much Labour would have to raise taxes to pay for all its spending pledges. The CIM points to the memorability of political slogans as evidence that political advertising is more influential than we think. Nearly half of those questioned remembered the slogan "It's time to get Britain working again" (from the 1992 election), while nearly a third could remember "Britain deserves better" (1997) and a similar proportion recalled "New Labour, new danger" (1997).

"We may not believe we are swayed by political adverts," says CIM's Claire Forbes, "but we certainly don't forget them easily. Marketing campaigns can change people's attitudes. The powerful drinking and driving campaigns by successive governments have changed public tolerance over the last two decades. Advertising has been an important influence in bringing about these changes, but voters are reluctant to concur that it can influence their political views."

Powell says an early lesson he learned in advertising was the discrepancy between how people say it affects them and the influence it actually has. He was sent out to the supermarket to monitor people's buying habits. One elderly chap said he paid no attention whatsoever to advertising and was more than likely to do the opposite of what they were telling him to do. But when Powell asked him which brand of dog food he favoured he replied: "Chum - because it's the one for pedigree dogs."

fields.headline: BBC1 drama fails to move
fields.trailText: 3.30pm TV overnights: Ballykissangel, starring Marion O'Dwyer, failed to improve BBC1's Sunday night drama ratings. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's Irish drama Ballykissangel failed to turn around the channel's woeful Sunday night drama ratings, coming off second best against ITV stalwart Heartbeat.

Ballykissangel had just 6m viewers and a 22% share, while Heartbeat pulled in more than double that audience, with 12.3m, according to unofficial overnights.

BBC1 schedulers had tried to give the new series of the long-running drama a leg-up by putting the first episode right after the Phil Mitchell shooting in EastEnders on Thursday night.

That got 7.7m, but even this bit of scheduling chicanery could not save the second instalment of Ballykissangel from a good drubbing in its 8.15pm Sunday night slot.

The previous Sunday on BBC1 the last episode of Monarch of the Glen got 6.9m against Heartbeat.

The final instalment of BBC1 three-parter Best of Both Worlds fared even worse than Ballykissangel from 9.05pm last night.

It had 4.8m and a 19% share, against London's Burning on ITV, with 10.1m.

But there was better ratings news elsewhere for BBC1 last week.

The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News enjoyed its best week since ITV resurrected News at Ten.

The BBC1 bulletin averaged 6.2m across the week, with viewing figures undoubtedly boosted by the worsening foot and mouth crisis and the Selby rail disaster.

News at Ten averaged 5.5m between Monday and Thursday, while Friday night's ITV Weekend News, which goes out from 11pm, had just 2.6m.

Overall, since News at Ten relaunched six weeks ago, the BBC1 Ten O'Clock News has averaged 5m; while the ITV late evening bulletin has averaged 5.1m.

Ratings for Channel 5 reality game show The Mole picked up on Friday night from 8pm as the identity of the saboteur among the contestants was revealed.

The Mole had 1.3m and a 5% share; compared with 0.8m the previous week.

Channel 4 gave a terrestrial premiere to Michael Douglas thriller The Game on Sunday night from 10pm.

The film took 2m and a 17% share.

fields.headline: Charity's great pantathon
fields.standfirst: Comic Relief 2001 may make more money for charity than the profits of all the dot.coms put together. Imogen O'Rorke looks at how the event's website will play a central role
fields.trailText: Comic Relief 2001 may make more money for charity than the profits of all the dot.coms put together. Imogen O'Rorke looks at how the event's website will play a central role
fields.body:
Due to the number of celebrities who will be taking them off, putting them on their heads or up for auction, Comic Relief 2001 will go down in the fundraising hall of fame as the "pants" year. "Pants to poverty", this year's slogan, will be up there with such corkers as Hale and Pace's "stonk" song (1991) and "the invasion of the comic tomatoes" (1993).

From a marketing perspective, however, 2001 will also be remembered as the year charity went high tech. For Comic Relief's new media strategy this year is anything but "pants". Cisco, Oracle, Energis, BT and Compaq make up the panoply of technology giants who have built the website - or online fundraising mall - at www.comicrelief.com.

With a new three-minute donation engine, a state-of-the-art database, e-commerce solutions, security firewalls, online tariff voting and 82 call centres (staffed by 15,000 volunteers), Comic Relief hopes to take fundraising to heights hitherto unknown. If 1999's bargain basement website collected £400,000, it will be interesting to see if it can exceed this figure with equipment worth at least £1m.

From PR to sheer pocket-emptying effectiveness, Red Nose Day has always been the king of charity showcases. It gets an enormous amount of airtime, celebrity support (200 stars already this year) and press coverage. In 1988, the experience of a red-carbuncled Lenny Henry encouraging us to "hit those phonelines" as we sat back and watched the grand total shooting up miraculously was an early taste of interactive TV.

From village cake stalls and sponsored streaks to 1999's successful campaign to "turn the web red" banner ad campaign, which is bigger this time, the organisers have had 13 years' experience in cross-platform interaction.This year, according to marketing director Amanda Horton-Mastin, new media technology is at the forefront of fundraising strategy. Only a month ago, you wouldnÍt have suspected it: a basic "coming soon" site with Henry inviting you to check out "one of the most crucial websites around" was all that was on show. Then on February 19, a handful of journalists were invited to the launch of a "new interactive donation experience", a live web event featuring Lenny Henry and Joanna Lumley, "taking you through the steps leading to the galaxy of stars" which boasts that it features the names of every person to make an online donation.

The idea is immediate gratification for anyone donating any amount of money (although sadly, due to a "software error", my name won't be joining the likes of Michael Barrymore). The network infrastructure and transaction system, designed by Cisco with NatWest Streamline Merchant Services, can manage up to 200 consecutive donations a second and, amazingly, was built in just three weeks - compared to a traditional turnaround of two months.

Kevin Cahill, Comic ReliefÍs CEO, believes its new system will change the whole process of "giving online". "The most exciting thing," he says, "is that it gives Comic Relief the potential to reach the hearts and minds of people not just in the UK but throughout the world. It's a tangible way of helping Comic Relief tackle poverty and promote social justice in the UK and Africa, not just for Red Nose Day but on an ongoing basis."

The internet has already opened up new avenues of fundraising in the charity sector. There are now dozens of ethical shopping sites which support good causes by guaranteeing a percentage of every transaction. Sites such as shop2give.com, free2give.co.uk and webcharity.com, which allows people to buy, sell or donate using the e-auction format and even boasts a virtual thrift shop - Oxfam in cyberspace.

Most sites, however, lack the expensive credit card payment systems which would make donating secure and seamless. The e-commerce solution also means that for the first time Comic Relief can sell noses, gimmicks, T-shirts and, significantly, two new Harry Potter adventures donated by JK Rowling, due for publication on March 12.

"For the first time, this means we had to think about designing the site for a global audience," says Horton-Mastin, "and being able to handle 13 different currencies."

But it's the good ideas in conjunction with the pride-and-joy payment systems which the organisers hope will make the campaign a success. Ideas like Pantasy Football (thought up by the lads at Cisco systems), an online game spoof of Fantasy Football launched on Valentine's Day with the Daily Star which allows wannabe football managers to create their dream team built from their 11 worst footballers, based on the performance of players in FA Cup, Premier League and Worthington Cup games. Entries start at £2 with 80% of fees being donated by the production company Dream League.

During the two day event itself (March 16-17), while the focus will be on televised events, Robbie Williams's "Bid it sum" live auction will be a strong contender for eyeballs. Game-as-ever Robbie, the nation's favourite cheeky chappie, is giving up his kingsize bed, Technics decks and a handwritten version of his hit single Angels to go under the hammer. The actual auction will take place at Sotheby's on April 10, highlighted at sothebys.com/robbie, but bidding will take place on the official site and at robbiewilliams.com.

Pop stars Westlife and Craig David have also hitched their fan sites up to the mother ship and will be offering free tickets and other paraphernalia. Other web attractions accessed in the "Have a laugh" channel include web casts of celebrity interviews (the marketing department cannot say who because it will be on an "on the hop" basis), stand-up shorts and video streaming. You can already view the likes of Davina McCall, Angus Deayton and Geri Halliwell doing have-a-go improvisations with pants, and play the boxers versus Y-fronts game.

Then there's the much-hyped Celebrity Big Brother (a joint venture between BBC, Endemol and Comic Relief), running from March 9-16, which will attempt to mimick the success of the Channel 4 gameshow, with telephone voting (25p a minute) and regular web bulletins to keep us up to date on which stars are killing who. According to reports, participants are rumoured to include Frank Skinner, Mariella Frostrup and Chris Evans, while Mel B has had to drop out due to exhaustion. The online voting mechanism which will connect you to a tariff line before reconnecting to your ISP, is apparently "the first of its kind", but only works from direct dial-up modems.

And when the stage is packed up and the whole stonking circus over for another two years, Comic Relief will live on in its new virtual form. With a database containing the details of all who have "given it sum", the charity hopes to keep the web community alive 365 days a year with email updates and online attractions such as comedy casts, news and a permanent resource for schools. The site is currently advertising something called Web Nose Day, a website design competition for schools. ItÍs the online donation mechanisms, however, which the organisers hope will become the "killer app" for charities.

Last year, Comic Relief raised a record £35m, which will be distributed among a host of causes in the UK, Africa and globally. This time around, with a bit of luck, it could make more than all the profits of all the dotcoms in the UK in 2000 put together. Just imagine.

The e-commerce solution also means that for the first time Comic Relief can sell noses, gimmicks, T-shirts and, significantly, two new Harry Potter adventures donated by JK Rowling, due for publication on March 12. "For the first time, this means we had to think about designing the site for a global audience," says Horton-Mastin, "and being able to handle 13 different currencies." But it's the good ideas in conjunction with the pride-and-joy payment systems which the organisers hope will make the campaign a success. Ideas like Pantasy Football (thought up by the lads at Cisco systems), an online game spoof of Fantasy Football launched on Valentine's Day with the Daily Star which allows wannabe football managers to create their dream team built from their 11 worst footballers, based on the performance of players in FA Cup, Premier League and Worthington Cup games. Entries start at £2 with 80% of fees being donated by the production company Dream League. During the two day event itself (March 16-17), while the focus will be on televised events, Robbie Williams's "Bid it sum" live auction will be a strong contender for eyeballs. Game-as-ever Robbie, the nation's favourite cheeky chappie, is giving up his kingsize bed, Technics decks and a handwritten version of his hit single Angels to go under the hammer. The actual auction will take place at Sotheby's on April 10, highlighted at sothebys.com/robbie, but bidding will take place on the official site and at robbiewilliams.com. Pop stars Westlife and Craig David have also hitched their fan sites up to the mother ship and will be offering free tickets and other paraphernalia. Other web attractions accessed in the "Have a laugh" channel include web casts of celebrity interviews (the marketing department cannot say who because it will be on an "on the hop" basis), stand-up shorts and video streaming. You can already view the likes of Davina McCall, Angus Deayton and Geri Halliwell doing have-a-go improvisations with pants, and play the boxers versus Y-fronts game. Then there's the much-hyped Celebrity Big Brother (a joint venture between BBC, Endemol and Comic Relief), running from March 9-16, which will attempt to mimick the success of the Channel 4 gameshow, with telephone voting (25p a minute) and regular web bulletins to keep us up to date on which stars are killing who. According to reports, participants are rumoured to include Frank Skinner, Mariella Frostrup and Chris Evans, while Mel B has had to drop out due to exhaustion. The online voting mechanism which will connect you to a tariff line before reconnecting to your ISP, is apparently "the first of its kind", but only works from direct dial-up modems. And when the stage is packed up and the whole stonking circus over for another two years, Comic Relief will live on in its new virtual form. With a database containing the details of all who have "given it sum", the charity hopes to keep the web community alive 365 days a year with email updates and online attractions such as comedy casts, news and a permanent resource for schools. The site is currently advertising something called Web Nose Day, a website design competition for schools. ItÍs the online donation mechanisms, however, which the organisers hope will become the "killer app" for charities. Last year, Comic Relief raised a record £35m, which will be distributed among a host of causes in the UK, Africa and globally. This time around, with a bit of luck, it could make more than all the profits of all the dotcoms in the UK in 2000 put together. Just imagine.

webTitle: Straw plan to seize criminals' cash

fields.headline: Straw plan to seize criminals' cash
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today outlined legislation that will make it easier for the police to seize cash and goods acquired through criminal activity by putting in place a scheme for recovering that money through civil proceedings rather than the criminal courts
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, today outlined legislation that will make it easier for the police to seize cash and goods acquired through criminal activity by putting in place a scheme for recovering that money through civil proceedings rather than the criminal courts.

The "Proceeds of Crime" bill would establish a Criminal Assets Recovery Agency (CARA) which would have powers to investigate and remove assets such as cash and cars that it suspects have been acquired illegally.

The proposals would give financial investigators greater powers than they have now, allowing them to take property at the start of a criminal investigation to avoid it being hidden or spent.

Civil liberties campaigners have questioned the legislation, saying money and property should not be confiscated before someone has been proven guilty.

Police chiefs have supplied the names of 39 alleged crime bosses who have assets of more than £200m between them and they want to follow the lead of the US, which raises millions of dollars every year by auctioning seized assets.

Mr Straw said: "Criminals are motivated by money and profit, and the fact that in many cases they appear to be 'untouchable', damages public confidence in the criminal justice system.

"Through a range of new measures, including civil recovery and taxation, we will target those individuals that benefit from crime, crippling their criminal enterprises and stripping them of the means to commit further offences.

"By removing the assets offenders have accumulated through criminality, we will deter others from following suit and send out a clear message to the public that nobody is beyond the reach of the law."

If the bill goes ahead, the director of CARA will also be able to carry out tax functions - for example income tax, capital gains, corporation and inheritance taxes - for individuals, companies and partnerships if he has reasonable grounds to suspect that the money was derived from crime.

Mr Straw announced money for CARA last July, setting aside a total of £54m for the programme over the next three years. Part of that budget will pay for the training and accreditation of financial investigators inside law enforcement and government.

fields.headline: Watson explains Lowe Live strategy
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Managing partner Tony Watson explains the reasons behind the creation of Lowe Live.
fields.body:
Lowe Direct, the Lowe Group's London direct marketing arm, is rebranding as Lowe Live.

It become the European headquarters of a new international marketing network as part of a global reorganisation.

Tony Watson, a managing partner, explains the reasons behind the creation of Lowe Live:

"This is really the culmination of a process that has been going on for several years.

"Direct marketing has been evolving as a discipline for many years - it began as direct response advertising, then moved towards database marketing, using computer databases of consumers to send out direct mail.

"But the explosion of digital marketing has changed the industry beyond all recognition.

"In the early days, it was very much a them-and-us attitude, with manufacturers saying 'I've got a product, I want people to buy it'.

"Now, it's much more about managing the relationship between consumer and supplier.

"To reflect modern communications, direct marketing has been focusing much more on things like SMS text messaging, Wap and interactive television.

"At Lowe Direct in London, it had got to the point where about a quarter of all our activity was based around digital communications.

"We could have renamed ourselves Lowe Interactive or Lowe Digital, but we think those titles will have become outdated in a few years.

"We chose Lowe Live because it implies something that is always on - it's a higher order that hopefully suggests something much broader.

"A lot of what we do already is internet related and that remains very important to us. But the rate of growth in internet access via PCs is slowing in Europe.

"People are starting to think differently about how they can use the internet. We are interested in looking at marketing via some of the other channels, like SMS and PDAs, which are growing much more quickly."

fields.headline: Mission impossible?
fields.standfirst: Today, Jeff Randall joins the BBC as its first business editor. But, asks  Emily Bell, can he balance the interests of companies with those of consumers?
fields.trailText: Today, Jeff Randall joins the BBC as its first business editor. But, asks Emily Bell, can he balance the interests of companies with those of consumers?
fields.body:
In the far-off days before Chris Woodhead was even invented, new teachers were told to stamp their authority on a class by picking on some unfortunate child, not necessarily the chief miscreant, and making a swift example out of them before the class started a full re-enactment of Lord of the Flies.

Greg Dyke's first year at the BBC has been notable for his remarkable lack of ear tweaking - he has shuffled schedules, buried Panorama and moved the news, but, in terms of BBC content, he has neither said or done anything contentious. In fact, the only area of direct criticism and intervention has been the corporation's financial coverage, which Dyke sent to stand in the corner for being too "anti-business".

Today, the Beeb's new business monitor arrives in the form of Jeff Randall, formerly of the Sunday Times and latterly of Sunday Business, with a brief sabbatical in financial PR, where they know all about being pro-business.

In terms of folding business journalism, the type you can wrap your chips in, Randall is pretty much without peer. But the BBC is a different kettle of fish. It has never had a business editor before, relying on the more cerebral discipline of economics editor to guide the corporation's coverage of all things monetary.

The recruitment of Randall and the imminent retirement of Peter Jay will change all that. For anyone watching closely, the anti-business broadside from Dyke had the immediate effect of bulletin editors on TV and radio scrambling to include "more business" in their coverage. But more didn't necessarily mean better. If the chief executive of BT caught a cold, there it was on the Ten O'Clock News.

In the meantime, economics has all but disappeared: Japan teeters on the brink of yet another recession and Alan Greenspan, the head of the Fed, worries about a lack of growth in the US, yet you have to either get up very early or stay up very late to be aware of it on the BBC.

Randall's appointment speaks volumes of the difference between John Birt and Greg Dyke in their approach to news. Birt was on a mission to inform, while Dyke seems to be on a mission to please - both valid exercises, but each throwing up different challenges when it comes to news.

You can make your information more entertaining but you cannot necessarily tell people what they want to hear and still retain the integrity of news. A case in point was the fuel crisis. Here we had lorry drivers essentially complaining about the price of fuel, and people who drive their kids to school or go to Tesco in the Focus twice a week agreeing with them. People loved the fuel protesters because people are greedy. In fact, the fuel protest showed that when it comes to the price of a tank of unleaded, rational thought disappears. The BBC's early coverage reflected this - saying that petrol is not really much more expensive than on the continent, that given the parlous state of our transport infrastructure money had to come from somewhere and if the Treasury was to cut fuel tax it would have to increase taxes elsewhere.

But the rumour goes that persons unknown were concerned that the coverage of the crisis was "not close enough to the people". If getting close to the people is what the BBC wants from its business news then is Jeff Randall the right man to do it? I would not for one moment suggest he starts taking the bus to work from Chiswick, but the truth is that the interests of big business are not in the short term the interests of the licence-fee payers.

After the recent closures of Corus steel plants in Wales, Randall made a brief guest appearance on the Today programme where he enunciated, very clearly, the correct business line, which is that no commercial operation can reasonably keep open inefficient and loss-making businesses. It is right, but it is not very close to the people.

This is the central conundrum for Randall, the bulletin editors and Dyke himself - that the kind of City-driven coverage provided by CNN and Bloomberg is ideal for businessmen, and if the BBC wants to serve the opinion-forming audience then this is what it must put on the Today programme and the Ten O'Clock News. But in being "pro-business", there is an inherent danger of becoming "anti-consumer", because the interests of Sainsbury's are not the interests of its customers, however much the company might protest otherwise.

After Jeff Randall finds his coatpeg, his wastepaper bin and the executive washroom, he needs to find the strategy for business coverage. And then he has to implement it with the editors of the 40-plus possible news outlets he has to service. Not so much mission to inform as mission impossible.
