webTitle: Chaotic rent patterns mean two beds are cheaper than one

fields.headline: Chaotic rent patterns mean two beds are cheaper than one
fields.trailText: The chaotic pattern of housing association rents has been graphically underlined by new figures showing that it is cheaper to rent two-bedroom homes than one-bedroom homes in 74 separate districts of the country.
fields.body:
The chaotic pattern of housing association rents has been graphically underlined by new figures showing that it is cheaper to rent two-bedroom homes than one-bedroom homes in 74 separate districts of the country.

The government is keen to rationalise rents so that tenants can make, what ministers hope, would be an informed choice about where they live.

Last year's housing green paper set out a 10-year programme for restructuring rents by forcing all housing associations to use some element of a house's capital value when setting rents.

But new figures released last week by the Housing Corporation show the scale of restructuring needed. Its guide to local rents shows that in 74 local authority areas two-bedroom homes are actually cheaper than one-bedroom homes. This trend is most prevalent in the West Midlands, Merseyside and the north-east. The figures also show that in 26 areas three-bedroom homes are cheaper than two-bedroom homes, including west Oxfordshire, south Somerset and north Hertfordshire.

A number of reasons have been put forward for the anomalous figures. Where one-bedroom homes are more expensive than two, the homes are likely to have been built under different funding regimes. The inclusion of bungalows in the one-bedroom category also skews the figures because these are likely to be more expensive than two-bedroom flats.

But the figures also illustrate housing association's lack of consideration of neighbouring landlord's rents, when setting their own rents. This is a practice the government wants to end so that tenants can make more consumer-style choices about where they live.

The figures also identify 15 areas where housing association flats are more expensive than private rented accommodation.

Danny Friedman, National Housing Federation head of research, said: "These figure confirm the need, as raised in the green paper, for more radical action to produce a coherent rent structure because there some definite anomalies across the country. However one should be wary of using average figures for regions because they can disguise as much as they reveal."

He added: "It illustrates the need for new deeper and clearer research to inform the rent restructuring process."

The National Housing Federation is currently negotiating with the environment department officials to persuade them to use a sophisticated way of recognising different property types in its rent reform plans.

fields.headline: Supermarkets welcome new slaughter scheme
fields.standfirst:
 Livestock ready to move
 Dartmoor's "nightmare scenario"
 Food sales up
 70 confirmed cases

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
 Livestock ready to move
 Dartmoor's "nightmare scenario"
 Food sales up
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.body:
Britain's livestock industry was today gearing up to start moving once again as farmers prepared to send thousands of animals for slaughter.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said measures were now in place to start moving cattle, sheep and pigs from areas unaffected by foot-and-mouth to slaughter houses.

Supermarkets welcomed the news and Safeway reported the crisis had led to an increase in demand for all food, although it denied an increase in sales of beef, lamb and pork of 70% amounted to panic buying.

Special trips were being made by customers to buy meat and this had led to an increase in sales of all goods including pasta and cereals, Safeway said.

Officials at the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food spent the weekend receiving hundreds of applications for temporary movement licences which will allow some animals to enter the human food chain despite the ongoing nationwide ban on transporting livestock.

Baroness Hayman, a junior agriculture minister, said 170 abattoirs had been approved for the scheme by yesterday evening, while one Scottish slaughterhouse in Banff started slaughtering animals yesterday.

Hundreds of farmers have also applied for the licences, which will allow cattle and sheep to be sent to special holding areas before being slaughtered.

"The scheme is up and running and should be widely in practise by tomorrow," said Baroness Hayman.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said the total number of outbreaks now stands at 70, with the latest confirmed case at a cattle and sheep farm in Bishop Auckland, Durham.

He said a total of 14,092 animals had been slaughtered so far while another 60,000 will also be culled in a bid to halt the disease's rapid progress.

The number of sheep affected is 62,306, while 10,493 cattle, 2,003 pigs and 13 goats have either been or are earmarked for slaughter.

Mr Brown refused to rule out government intervention on livestock prices following speculation that farmers would fail to get a fair price for animals in the wake of the current crisis.

Mr Brown said that the market may take some time to get back to normal, including prices to farmers.

Mr Scudamore reiterated that the relaxation on the nationwide ban to allow some livestock movements would not spread disease as all animals would come from uninfected areas. "The risk that these animals are incubating disease is pretty remote," he said.

Meanwhile, fears were growing that thousands of farm animals on Dartmoor may have to be slaughtered after an outbreak of the disease on one of the Prince of Wales's Duchy of Cornwall farms.

Around 46,000 cattle and sheep graze on the moor, which has already been declared a no-go area for walking, horse riding and other recreational uses. The National Farmers' Union described the Dartmoor outbreak as a "nightmare scenario".

The Duchy of Cornwall was "very concerned" about the outbreak at Dunna Bridge farm, near Two Bridges in the heart of the park, a Duchy spokesman said.

fields.headline: Moving to the private sector
fields.standfirst: What's it really like for public sector staff when transferred to the 'other side'?
fields.trailText: Read what it's really like for public sector staff when transferred to the 'other side'
fields.body:
"Productivity has risen by 110%, the residents are much happier and the workforce is pleased. You can't believe what you hear about the private sector. It's been much better."

William Sinfield is an area manager for street sweeping and refuse collection in the London borough of Islington.

Like many workers in that industry, Mr Sinfield does not work for the local authority but instead has been contracted out to the private sector, in his case, to a company called Accord.

Unlike many former employees transferred out into the big, bad world of the market, Mr Sinfield's experiences have been positive.

He says staff are generally much happier, more motivated and appreciated. Islington contracted out its refuse and cleaning services in June 1998 as part of a 15-year contract.

Mr Sinfield, 38, had worked for the council from May 1986 starting as a street sweeper before working his way up the administrative ladder. When news of the privatisation first emerged, he expected the worst.

"I was very pessimistic. I thought it would be six months then we would be ousted in some way or overburdened to make us look incompetent."

Instead, he says pay and conditions have improved, as have health and safety and his pension - transferred from the local government scheme - has been matched in the private sector.

But he is one of the lucky ones.

Many of the increasing number of staff forced out into the private sector have nothing but bad experiences.

Unison, which has almost a million members in local government, claims a two-tier system has developed where many staff transferred have been offered little protection in terms of pay and conditions.

New staff that join after a service has been privatised can find they get lower wages, worse working conditions and no access to a staff pension scheme. "There are unscrupulous employers who set about undermining wages and conditions," Margie Jaffe, a national officer with Unison said.

Legislation, especially the introduction of the Transfer of Undertaking Protection of Employment (TUPE) in 1999 that safeguards the rights of transferred workers, has improved things since the dark days of the 1980s where many staff were let without any protection. However, the unions remain convinced more can be done.

Mick Graham, national secretary at the GMB, said the quality of protection offered by the private sector is still too patchy. Pension provision remains a serious concern. The Office for Government Commerce, which looks at procurement across the state sector, is carrying out research into the provision of pensions under private finance initiative (PFI) schemes.

Some companies bidding for local government contracts privately admit they will not offer to meet pension costs, as it would be commercial suicide.

There is no exact total for the number of staff that have switched from the public to the private sector.

Unison calls this the "$64,000 question", although Office for National Statistics figures show that public sector workers made up just 17% of the national workforce in 1999. Twenty years previously they accounted for 27%.

Part of that is due to the increasing numbers of staff transferred to the private sector, something that will continue. The ever-popular use of PFI means more workers are likely to switch to the private sector. Best value will see even more private companies become involved in the delivery of services and increasingly cash-strapped councils will need to off load more services. This is starting to show itself among white collar workers - senior managers, IT staff and architects - as well as more traditionally among blue collar staff.

Private sector companies are queuing up to become involved in delivering public services. Some of the biggest involved so far are Capita, which provides IT and business services, Rentokil Initial and Sodexho specialising in catering, and the OCS Group concentrating on leisure services.

This could be bad news for those most badly hit by privatisations and the two-tier workforce: part-time, female workers.

Johanna Sweet is one such example. She worked for 18 years in local government, as a cleaner and swimming instructor, first for Buckinghamshire county council then for Milton Keynes.

In 1999, her job was put out to the private sector and Ms Sweet claims it has been a disaster. Her new employers have provided no pension, conditions have worsened - breaks and holidays have been slimmed down - morale is low and her hours, 18 each week, have been reduced.

"Everybody is looking over their shoulder. We don't know what's going on. With the council, the management was directly involved," said Ms Sweet, 50.

Of the seven cleaners who transferred across with her she is the only one left. But that could soon change.

"I'll probably give it up after Easter," she said.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: the front line

fields.headline: Foot and mouth: the front line
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited writer Derek Brown has assembled a panel of people, all from his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire, who are affected by the spreading virus. This is the first of his series of reports on what is happening at ground level.

Meet the panel
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited writer Derek Brown has assembled a panel of people, all from his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire, who are affected by the spreading virus. This is the first of his series of reports on what is happening at ground level
fields.body:
We have not, thank goodness, had an outbreak of the disease yet in our district. But it's creeping ever closer: cases have been confirmed east and west of Oxfordshire, in Northamptonshire and Warwickshire.

Today brought grim news of another suspected outbreak near Bicester, in our own county. It's a desperately worrying time for anyone involved in the food business, whether producing it, selling it or serving it.

Already, the first rippling effects of the crisis are visible to consumers: gaps are appearing on the meat counters, and prices are starting to move up. But the marginal inconvenience of shoppers is as nothing compared to the dark cloud hanging over farmers.

The farmers

Marilyn Ivings, with husband Ted, runs Mill Farm at Church Enstone, a few miles from Chipping Norton. It's a mixed arable and livestock operation of 220 acres, of which the Ivings own 165 acres, and this year has already seen profound changes.

The pigs have all gone - just before the first outbreak of foot and mouth - because they were just not profitable, and the planned winter sowing of crops has been severely disrupted because the ground is saturated.

Now Marilyn's worries are focused on her herd of 35 suckler cows. The farm, like so many others, is in something of a state of siege. None but the most urgent visits are allowed, in or out of the cordon of disinfected straw.

"I am not going to visit anybody on another farm. I am thinking before I go anywhere," said Marilyn today.

As yet, the crisis has not produced a financial squeeze on Mill Farm, because the animals there are not ready for market. For now, the economics of the crisis are a secondary consideration.

"People talk of the beasts as if they are a commodity, but it's so much more than that. We talk to them. They are our friends," said Marilyn. "We hear them all the time. If they were not there, it would be awful."

Talking to farmers these days, the sense of suspense and helplessness is palpable. Marilyn Ivings, a prominent member of the NFU, has done what she can to protect Mill Farm against the insidious disease, but knows the defences are vulnerable.

The farm is bounded by roads, for example, and there is no means of knowing if the vehicles passing along it have been in contact with the virus. At least the bridleway has now been closed - to the indignation of some horseowners - but walkers are still using nearby footpaths.

"It's very worrying. We are very aware of where we have been. We make sure that no-one comes in from another farm, and any visitors we can make sure are scrubbed up properly. But with people walking through, you just don't know where they have been," said Marilyn.

The butcher

While farmers fearfully watch and wait, others in the food business are already beginning to feel the effects of the crisis.

John Kench, who runs a high-class family butcher's shop in Chipping Norton, has not experienced any panic-buying yet, but says that the pattern of trade is changing.

"People are ordering four days' worth of stuff instead of two. They are more interested in where it is coming from and how supplies are likely to be affected," he said.

One of John's prime lines is premium Orkney beef. His good relations with the Scottish suppliers mean that he is confident his supply will be assured for the next two weeks. What happens then depends on whether the abattoirs reopen.

Pork, which he usually buys from Cheltenham, are less assured. Lamb too could be a problem - though there is always the option of buying New Zealand stock.

"I'm not happy about imported meat, because how can I rely on the quality? I think I would be happier to take pork off altogether. The thing is we just don't know how long this will last. Towards the end of this week we should have some good information to go on," he said.

Prices, by and large, have kept constant in John's shop, though as a curious side effect of the prices, wholesalers have slapped up the cost of poultry and New Zealand lamb - neither of which have any connection with foot and mouth.

"I'm worried that customers will blame me for taking advantage, but what can I do? I can't simply absorb the extra I am being charged," he said.

The caterers

One of the caterers in the town who regularly buys from Kench's is Brian Galbraith, who with partner Jan Blackburn runs the stylish bar-restaurant, Stones.

Recently opened, Stones has quickly built a reputation for its home-cooked meals, with most of the ingredients locally supplied. So far, there have been no alterations in the menu - but there has been a sudden worrying dip in trade, notably for the Sunday lunches in which the restaurant specialises.

"It was a very quiet Sunday for us. We normally get a lot of passing trade, people coming through the town on their way to the countryside. I get the impression that people are taking heed of the warnings and staying away," said Brian.

Other businesses which rely on tourist traffic in this edge-of-Cotswold town, notably the burgeoning antiques trade, have also reported a falling off in recent days.

The Co-op

There has been no such problem for the Oxford, Swindon and Gloucester Co-op, which runs one of the two supermarkets in Chipping Norton. Over the weekend the store's meat counter was stripped almost bare, and there was also heavy buying of frozen goods.

But manager Tony Hatch said there had been no real evidence of panic buying. "It's certainly not that way at the moment. Most of it we put down to the normal increase which follows half term. It was a healthy increase, but no more," he said.

The Co-op has for the time being dropped all special offers on meat, but Tony insisted that it has not raised prices, only "reverted" to the pre-offer ones. The organisation is already looking for imports, to ensure continuity of supply.

fields.headline: NUJ warned BBC of 'dangerous' building
fields.trailText:
2.30pm update: The union claims it warned the BBC five years ago a glass-fronted newsroom left staff vulnerable, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 5: BBC bomb rocks news operations
Mar 5: BBC bomb threatens peace process

'It was a fireball that seemed to fill the whole road'
Gallery: the blast in pictures
Comment: media explosion
fields.body:
The National Union of Journalists has slammed the corporation claiming it warned the BBC five years ago that a glass-fronted newsroom left staff vulnerable to attack.

"We told them when they were designing the building that it would be dangerous," said John Fray, the NUJ's deputy general secretary and former broadcast organiser.

"Any vehicle could be parked outside and this is just what has happened. It would also be easy to take a shot at the journalists from outside," he said.

The NUJ is requesting urgent talks with the BBC as it seeks further commitments on the safety of its members.

The union warned that plans by the BBC to open more of its buildings to the public, when it moves to Broadcasting House in 2006, could also be dangerous.

The blast follows security scares in 1999 following the death of BBC presenter Jill Dando and also after an intruder broke into the BBC newsroom later that year.

The bomb, which exploded outside BBC Television Centre in the small hours of Sunday morning, is thought to have been planted by the Real IRA.

webTitle: Pizzas and burgers turn Renee Zellweger off Bridget

fields.headline: Pizzas and burgers turn Renee Zellweger off Bridget
fields.trailText: The star of the much-anticipated Bridget Jones's Diary will not appear in the sequel as she didn't like having to put on extra weight to play the part and hated filming in London
fields.body:
With the release of the long-awaited Bridget Jones's Diary only one month away, the 3 am girls at the Daily Mirror report today that the film's star Renee Zellweger has refused point blank to sign up for a sequel.

The producers of the film, which is about a neurotic thirtysomething Londoner who is in a constant state of anxiety about her weight, looks and lack of boyfriend, were keen to sign up Zellweger for the sequel before the film comes out, but the Golden Globe-winning actress apparently hated the part so much that she has told them that nothing can persuade her to reprise the role

The 31-year-old Nurse Betty star's main gripe seems to have been the fact that she had to pile on the pounds and smoke cigarettes for the part, claiming it was the: "No-exercise part that killed me." She also apparently hated filming in London for eight months because of the cold and dark and would moan every day: "I'm so fat, I'm so fat."

Many film-watchers were surprised when the likes of Kate Winslet and Helena Bonham-Carter were overlooked in favour of the American actress, but Zellweger threw herself into the role by working in the Picador Publishing office in London to learn the British accent and gorging on a diet of hamburgers and pizzas to gain weight.

The film, which also stars Hugh Grant and Colin Firth, is being kept under wraps until its release but the few who have seen it have been pleasantly surprised. Nick Logan, editor of Sight and Sound, told the Observer yesterday that: "It was much more interesting than I thought it was going to be." Empire magazine's editor claims: "It's just really funny."

Bridget Jones's Diary is released on April 13.

fields.headline: Whither the NI peace process?
fields.standfirst: The bomb attack on the BBC has raised fears of a renewed offensive by militant Irish republicans, both in Northern Ireland and on the British mainland. It has also imposed new and dangerous pressures on the beleaguered peace process
fields.trailText: The issue explained: the bomb attack on the BBC has raised fears of a renewed offensive by militant Irish republicans, both in Northern Ireland and on the British mainland. It has also imposed new and dangerous pressures on the beleaguered peace process, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Who planted the bomb?
Nobody knows for sure, but suspicion points to the shadowy outfit calling itself the Real IRA. They are dissident former members of the Provisional republican movement, who disagree violently with that organisation's agreement, in principle, to "decommission" its arms as part of the peace process.

Is the Real IRA real? Certainly there is a small group of militants who support the hardline view of the 32-county Sovereignty Committee, that the armed struggle must continue until Ireland is united. The problem is that the more revanchist members of the Provisional IRA, who hold to the same view, may now be contributing to the new campaign.

Where are the weapons coming from?
That is the heart of the security and political issues. Last year, the Garda Siochana (the Irish police) let it be known that the Real IRA had acquired a consignment of arms, including rockets and commercial explosives, from a source in Croatia.

But there are growing fears that dissident republican groups are filtering off weapons from the well-established arms caches of the Provisional IRA. That suspicion infuriates Northern Ireland loyalists, who believe that the republicans, whatever they call themselves, have no intention of honouring their pledge to put their arms beyond use.

Will the new security alert damage the peace process?
It is already dangerously close to collapse, with the republicans and unionists at loggerheads. The republicans are deeply frustrated by the snail's pace of police reform, and the establishment of effective cross-border, all-Ireland, political institutions.

They also claim that the British government is dragging its feet over "demilitarisation" (army withdrawal) in the province. Meanwhile, unionists of various hues are getting more and more alarmed about the refusal of the Provisional IRA to cooperate with the official "decommissioning" body. The latest explosion in London will add new weight to their claim that the ceasefire is phoney.

What are the British and Irish governments doing?
They tried last month to inject new urgency into the endless negotiations, by setting yet another deadline for agreement on full implementation of the Good Friday peace accord. But the target date came and went without political progress, let alone agreement.

Now the British government is increasingly obsessed with the imminent general election, and has little taste for plunging into the quagmire of Northern Ireland negotiations. It also does not help that there is a new and untested Secretary of State, John Reid, in charge of the Northern Ireland Office, following the sensational resignation of Peter Mandelson.

Any other distractions?
For both governments - and for the struggling power-sharing administration in Belfast - dealing with the foot and mouth crisis is number one priority. In Britain, the disease has highly damaging economic and political implications. In both parts of Ireland, should it spread out of control, it would have a calamitous effect on the hugely important agricultural sector.

It also does not help that there is a new and untested Secretary of State, John Reid, in charge of the Northern Ireland Office, following the sensational resignation of Peter Mandelson. webTitle: 35 crushed to death in Holy Day stampede

fields.headline: 35 crushed to death in Holy Day stampede
fields.trailText: One of Islam's most important holy days, the Haj pilgrimage to the Saudi Arabian city of Mecca, turned to tragedy today as 35 worshippers died in a stampede.
fields.body:
One of Islam's most important holy days, the Haj pilgrimage to the Saudi Arabian city of Mecca, turned to tragedy today as 35 worshippers died in a stampede.

Saudi television reported that 23 women and 12 men, whose nationalities were not given, died as a huge crowd rushed toward one of the three giant pillars representing the devil in the Mina Valley near the holy city of Mecca, said to be the birthplace of the prophet Mohammed.

Every year tens of thousands of pilgrims travel to Mecca to cast seven pebbles at the stone columns. The 'stoning of the devil' ritual is part of a pilgrimage that must be performed once in a lifetime by every able Muslim.

An unspecified number of other pilgrims were slightly injured in the crush on the first day of the three-day ritual, the state-run television said, citing a report from the civil defence. It is the first such incident at the pilgrimage since 1998, when at least 118 pilgrims died and more than 180 were injured in a stampede on the final day of the stoning ritual at Mina.

"Because of heavy congestion and jostling, many pilgrims, especially the elderly, tripped and fell," the civil defence said.

Some of them suffocated to death while others were trampled before security forces restored order, it said, adding that the latest tragedy to hit the Haj occurred at around 8am local time (5am GMT).

The pillars symbolising the devil are at the centre of giant ramps built to accommodate the huge crowds of pilgrims who must complete the ritual by dusk. Muslim tradition says it was here that the devil tried to tempt the prophet Abraham to disobey God by refusing to sacrifice his son.

fields.headline: Government 'falls short of homes target'
fields.trailText: The number of affordable homes built each year is set to fall short of the number required by more than 50% despite an injection of government cash, new figures claim.
fields.body:
The number of affordable homes built each year is set to fall short of the number required by more than 50% despite an injection of government cash, new figures claim.

Last year's spending review increased the money available for new social housing from £750m to more than £1bn, and the amount is to increase further over the next few years. This extra cash is expected to help produce around 55,000 new affordable homes each year.

But new figures released by the National Housing Federation (NHF) and Town and Country Planning Association (TCPA) estimate that there is a need for up to 85,000 affordable homes a year over the next 15 years.

The research by former government statistician Alan Holmans, now a researcher at the University of Cambridge, points out that pressure will be most acute in London and the south-east. The analysis draws on the government's 1998 projection, but for the first time breaks down the projections by tenure and region. It also identifies a backlog of 650,000 families in temporary, overcrowded or poor housing.

The figures prompted warnings of increased overcrowding and spiralling house pricing if the new demand is not met.

Jim Coulter, NHF chief executive, said: "We have to address the increasing need for decent and affordable homes. The cost of not doing so will be an increase in house prices, overcrowding and poor homes. In the long run this means investing greater resources into affordable housing and making better use of planning laws."

Gideon Amos, director of the TCPA, claimed the report "uncovers a new scandal of housing need in England" since it comes after the government announced a cut in the number of homes to be provided in the south-east.

He added: "The homeless and the dispossessed can apparently no longer match up to the growing forces ranged against the creation of new housing. To meet this demand the next government - and society as a whole - must develop a new vision of how to create the homes and neighbourhoods we need."

fields.headline: 'All the cheaper cuts of meat have gone'
fields.standfirst:
'Prudence not panic' but the counters are looking bare

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Lee Watson's celebrated £5 meat pack will be missing from Bradford's New Rawson market today after scores of his regulars bought three of the bargains where one would normally do.
fields.body:
Lee Watson's celebrated £5 meat pack will be missing from Bradford's New Rawson market today after scores of his regulars bought three of the bargains where one would normally do.

Stocking up - "prudence not panic", insisted Ellie Thornton from behind two legs of lamb - has made the much-advertised price impossible to hold, as well as grating the nerves of the stall's usually chatty and cheerful customers.

"You're diddling us - you've had this stuff in the freezer for months," growled one burly man. Price jumps in the wholesale chain, triggered by foot and mouth restrictions on movement and slaughtering of animals, mean the pack (actually always fresh meat) could sell profitably only for £3 more.

"You can't have our £5 meat pack costing £8," said Mr Watson, conscious of the local landmark status of his product, which wraps 1lb each of economy mince, stewing meat, tenderising steak, diced chicken, lambs' liver and pork chops into a bargain few Yorkshire shoppers can refuse.

But the same nose for value has led to a run on the stall, as people watch the prices rise and monitor the foot and mouth news. Mr Watson will almost certainly close tomorrow and on Wednesday because sales will not pay staff wages at his company, D&M Meat.

"Forget the meat pack," he said, as business drew to a close at the weekend. "It's looking like we'll be mostly selling chicken on Monday." Stocks of everything else were running out, with beef already gone, and supply and demand was ratcheting up prices on everything else like a taxi meter.

"All the cheaper cuts have gone," said Mrs Thornton, who normally opts for lamp chops rather than a full leg. "And the bacon's getting very dear." Best rashers were priced at £2.25 a pound.

Mr Watson said: "It's hardly surprising that people are stocking up, when you think that this bacon cost 82p a pound before Christmas."

But panic buying was being sneered at by some shoppers over the weekend, who did their best to calm their fellow meat buyers and echo supermarket chain reassurances that meat was certainly not going to run out.

In Morrison's at Guiseley, Doreen Jordan admitted that she had brought two extra carrier bags but would not be using them, after chatting to friends in front of the sea of meat on the shelves.

It might be getting pricey, she said, passing over an £8.21 leg of lamb in favour of beef, but there was certainly plenty of it. Pensioner Jean Bradley was forthright, on her way home after her normal Saturday shop.

"It's just daft to buy extra now - the best way to send the prices silly and empty the shelves," she said. "Yesterday I saw this woman buying five or six lengths of pork like you usually only get at Christmas. When she sticks them in her freezer, God knows how much room she's going to have for anything else."

The big shopping chains warned yesterday that widespread ownership of home freezers has helped to take national retail stocks of meat to "significantly low" levels. But all emphasised that imports could cope with normal demand, and were optimistic about the suspension of stock movement and abattoirs ending soon.

Jill Rawlins of Somerfield said that meat sales were up by just over a half at the weekend and that some types of British meat would not be available in some stores today.

Poultry sales were up by 60%, but beef and some pork was arriving from Ireland and lamb from New Zealand.

Karen Marshall of Tesco said that more chicken had been sold in the past week than over Christmas. Beef sales were up 45%, lamb 65% and even fish 35%.

"People are stocking up, but it's not panic buying. It's just strong demand. If there is no more British slaughtering, at some point those supplies will run out.

"But that won't be before the middle of next week and by then we hope the new slaughtering licences will be operating to put new British stock into the system."

Supermarkets generally are holding prices of existing stocks, but they warned of possible price increases as imported meat came on to the shelves.

Safeway said that pork and lamb could go up by 15% this week and a spokesman for Asda, which is bringing in Irish beef, said: "Pricing is an issue we are looking into at the moment."

webTitle: Lowe Group launches direct marketing arm

fields.headline: Advertising giant unveils direct marketing arm
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The Lowe Group is launching an agency specialising in direct marketing. By Claire Cozens.

Useful link: lowelive.com
fields.body:
The Lowe Group, the global advertising giant whose clients include Unilever and Vauxhall, is today launching a new agency to specialise in internet, text messaging and other direct marketing.

Lowe Live will open with 400 employees with billings of £290m from clients including British Airways, Heineken, and the Times.

The agency brings together experts in so-called relationship marketing, which targets consumers directly via the internet, email and traditional mail, and digital marketing.

It will be made up of a number of existing agencies including Lowe Direct and Lowe Interactive.

The European headquarters of Lowe Live will be in London, where digital work already accounts for around 25% of the agency's work.

The agency will also have headquarters in New York and San Francisco as well as offices in Amsterdam, Paris and Stockholm.

"The foundation of communications has evolved with all the new digital technologies that have become part of our everyday lives," said Lowe Group chairman and chief executive Frank Lowe.

"Relationship marketing is simply a return to marketing fundamentals newly empowered by the information age and Lowe Live will extend our passion for creativity through all these new media."

Lowe Live will be headed by Floyd Miller, the 45-year-old president of the Lowe-owned agency Miller/Huber in San Francisco.

Mr Miller said the agency would specialise in "creating relationships with manufacturers' most valuable customers" with tools such as email and databases.

Dan Goodman, managing director of Lowe Direct in New York, becomes co-managing director of Lowe Live along with Paul Velardi, managing director of Lowe Direct.

The Lowe Group was founded in London in 1981 and ranks fourth among the world's marketing groups with billings of more than £8bn and offices in 80 countries.

fields.headline: How does it work?
fields.trailText: Websites differ slightly from bank to bank, but managing your finances online should be as simple as logging on to the bank's website and entering you user ID and password. The site will then guide you through the transactions you want to carry out.
fields.body:
Websites differ slightly from bank to bank, but managing your finances online should be as simple as logging on to the bank's website and entering you user ID and password. The site will then guide you through the transactions you want to carry out.

Some standalone banks, such as Smile and Egg prefer to communicate with you by email. They will, for example, send you an email when your statements are ready. And if you have an enquiry or want to order a statement, you are encouraged to email them.

Telephone support is likely to be expensive as the idea behind these banks is that by doing everything on the internet they dramatically reduce overheads and pass the savings on to you. Other standalone banks such as IF and Cahoot offer telephone support free of charge.

Other standalone banks such as IF and Cahoot offer telephone support free of charge.

fields.headline: The pros and the cons
fields.trailText: The most obvious benefit of internet banking is the convenience of being able to do your banking when you want to, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, saving time and effort.
fields.body:
The most obvious benefit of internet banking is the convenience of being able to do your banking when you want to, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, saving time and effort.

Internet banking should also help you keep more up to date with your finances because transactions are usually updated in real time. For example, if you pay in a cheque, the cleared funds will show on your computer at the same time as it shows on the bankÕs computer, usually within three to four days. If you have paid in money at your branch, this should be recorded instantly.

Transferring funds should be easy too. If youÕre overdrawn on your current account and the cash machines wonÕt give you any money, you can log into your savings account, transfer the required amount and then go straight back out to get it from the cash point.

With many banks you can pay bills online too, although you may have to let the bank know the details of bill payments you will usually be making from the account. However once this is done, simply logging on, selecting the correct supplier, and entering the amount you wish to pay will ensure your bills are paid on time. In many cases, you can select a date in the future that you wish the payment to be made, so you can go on holiday and not worry about getting your phone cut off.

Similarly, some banks let you download your account information from the internet into a number of financial software packages such as Microsoft Excel.

However, there can be drawbacks to online banking.

Security is by far the biggest concern surrounding internet banks, with consumers worrying that hackers will get into their account and spend their money.

Banks are adamant that the sites are secure, but while there have been no reports of large-scale theft, there have been plenty about unwitting surfers stumbling across other peoples financial details.

Consumer groups have asked the bank to provide a guarantee, similar to the Direct Debit guarantee, promising to return any funds straight away and investigate afterwards in the event that money does go missing from your account. Unfortunately, banks have refused, raising suspicions that they donÕt trust their own security systems. After all, if they did, they would have no qualms about providing the guarantee, the consumer groups say.

One of the biggest day to day problems with internet banking appears to be access. You might find it difficult to get on to the internet at certain times of day, especially during a weekday evening, when internet use is very high.

The speed with which you access your account will also depend on the amount of memory your computer has, or the speed of your modem connection. Also, if your computer develops a fault you will have to resort to the telephone or branch until it is fixed. The banks' computers themselves are also prone to failure and you could find yourself unable to access your account through no fault of your own. Sometimes your bank may need to shut down its website for maintenance from time to time, although this is usually carried out during the night.

fields.headline: Things to look out for
fields.trailText: Security
fields.body:
Security

The safety of financial information is one of the biggest concerns of online users, and there is still a lot of debate about the safety of using the internet for financial transactions.

Security systems are available, so check your bank uses one. Typical measures will include unique passwords, user identification names and encryption.

Deposit protection guarantee

Make sure your bank adheres to the UKÕs Deposit Protection Scheme, or the national equivalent, if your bankÕs parent company is not UK-based. Established under the 1987 Banking Act 1987, the scheme protects your money if the bank runs into problems.

Where is the bank registered

Check where the bank, or the bankÕs parent company is based. If it is based abroad - as is the case with French-owned First-E - consider what you will do and where you will go if something goes wrong or you need to make a complaint.

Technology

Check that your computer is compatible with the system your bank uses to run its internet operation.

The technology needed to run an internet bank account can vary from bank to bank. Most list the required hardware and software on their websites.

Typical requirements are a relevant operating system, Windows 95, 98 or NT, or MacOS, and the right system browser, usually Microsoft Internet Explorer 4 or above or Netscape Navigator 4 or above. However, some of the banks' websites are not compatible with Apple Macintosh computers.

fields.headline: What are internet banks?
fields.trailText: There are two types of internet bank which are referred to as standalone and cyberbranch.
fields.body:
There are two types of internet bank which are referred to as standalone and cyberbranch.

Standalone banks operate almost exclusively on the internet. Accounts are opened and transactions are conducted online. Non-internet communication with the bank is kept to a minimum. Telephone support is usually provided, but if you ask for information which is available via the internet you are likely to be charged - quite a lot in some cases. Items such as debit cards, cheque books and paying in slips can be ordered online and sent to you by standard mail.

Because these banks have dramatically reduced their overheads by operating online, their interest rates are often better than those offered by the high street banks.

The services offered by these banks varies. Some offer a whole range of banking services, from current and savings accounts to loans. Others have a more limited product range.

Egg, Smile, Cahoot, Intelligent Finance and First-E are all considered 'standalone' operations.

Cyberbranches are the online operations of existing high street banks and building societies. These banks offer online access as an additional service which supplements, rather than replaces, branch and telephone access.

As such, the products, rates and charges mirror those available through the traditional branch operation.

If you are an existing customer and your bank has an online operation, getting access should be as simple as registering for the internet service and being issued with an ID and password. It takes the banks around one week to process your registration.

The online service offered by the high street banks varies significantly. Some do not have an internet operation while others limit the service to viewing balance information. However, most have the facility to carry out simple banking transactions online.

webTitle: Say it loud - I'm bearded and proud

fields.headline: Say it loud - I'm bearded and proud
fields.standfirst: A Waitrose supermarket has won the right to sack a hirsute employee because it upset shoppers. Matthew Tempest stands up for his fuzzy-faced friends
fields.trailText: A Waitrose supermarket has won the right to sack a hirsute employee because it upset shoppers. Matthew Tempest stands up for his fuzzy-faced friends.
fields.body:
People will only tell you what they really think about your beard after you've shaved it off.

I first grew a beard (not a goatie, and certainly not a 'tash) aged 22 while revising for my finals. After four weeks out of circulation in the library, I turned up for our six-hour Shakespeare paper with a great big Chris Bonnington beard. It scared the hell out of my fellow undergraduates - a cunning tactic.

In the students' union bar that night, having shaved it off in the meantime, the comments ranged from "You look 10 years younger", to "Now we can see what an ugly bugger you really are."

Four years later, on a cycling holiday in Denmark I simply didn't shave for a fortnight out of laziness - and a lack of hot water.

Back in Britain I automatically reached for the razor for my first day back at the office - and paused.

"Hey, you look pretty distinguished," I thought. "Intellectual, even."

Hip bands such as the Beta Band and Grandaddy were also showing up in the papers looking coolly hirsute.

Then my boss settled it for me. Editor Craig McKenzie - brother of Kelvin - called me in. "Oi, whiskers, you can shave that fuzz off for starters," he growled. "Rupert Murdoch once told me 'Never trust a man in a beard - you can't see his face'."

Double whammy - if you can piss off Rupert Murdoch and one of the McKenzie clan at once, then the beard was definitely staying.

Now the beard works as a sort of litmus test - if people like it, they're cool. If they don't, I forgive them their ignorance. They're probably hairless eunuchs themselves. And that's just the women.

My girlfriend likes my beard, or at least claims to, and I've never had a problem getting food stuck in it, not that I've noticed. So really the only snag can be the velcro fastners on my jacket. Getting them stuck in your stubble is the equivalent of tearing your cheeks with cold wax strips.

I do have one beard philosophy though: beards on boys in their 20s; cool. Beards on geezers in their 50s; uncool. And goatees beyond the pale, on anybody. I shall be ceremoniously shaving my beard off on my 30th birthday.

Meanwhile, the way I look at it is this: I'm not the weirdie-beardie, it's you, the shaver-raver.

fields.headline: QXL promotes Mason to new role
fields.trailText:
2pm: Online auction company QXL has promoted Neil Mason into the new role of chief marketing officer, writes Wale Azeez.
Feb 22: QXL prospects dim as eBay prospers
fields.body:
Pan-European online auction company QXL has created the new role of chief marketing officer and promoted one of its own executives to the position.

Neil Mason's current role monitoring site statistics as "chief knowledge officer" will be phased out.

He will add the company's brand, marketing and product development strategies to his list of responsibilities.

In his expanded brief, he will supervise the integration of the company's customer and brand marketing function across the 13 European sites.

Since joining QXL in March last year, Mr Mason has been responsible for developing the company's marketing and management information systems.

He will continue to oversee these, as well as QXL's customer relationship management.

Prior to joining QXL, Mr Mason was a board director at WPP-owned Research International.

He began there as IT director and then as managing director of one of RI's operating divisions.

Related story

webTitle: Which type of internet bank is best?

fields.headline: Which type of internet bank is best?
fields.trailText: There is a debate as to which type of internet bank provides the best value.
fields.body:
There is a debate as to which type of internet bank provides the best value.

The high street banks, which provide online banking as an additional service, say standalone banks such as Smile and Egg are operating at loss creating rates.

They claim that, as more and more customers join these banks to take advantage of higher interest rates, the rates will become increasingly difficult to sustain and the banks will be paying out more than they expected.

Standard advice when buying any financial product is to check the financial history of the providers. Look at the long-term performance of the banks before choosing. Of course, as relatively new start-ups, the standalone banks will not have long term performance figures, but many are usually backed by more traditional companies so an investigation of their financial history may suffice.

In addition, consumer groups say it is very easy to make a mistake on the internet. For example, when transferring £1,000, you might press the 0 too many times and transfer £10,000. In this case, it is your responsibility to contact whoever the £10,000 was transferred to in order to get it back.

fields.headline: Media explosion: bombing your way into the headlines
fields.trailText:
Comment: Directly attacking the media is a tried and tested publicity-generating tactic, writes Julia Day.
Mar 5: BBC bomb rocks news operations

Mar 5: Bomb threatens peace process

Mar 5: 'A fireball filled the road' Gallery: the blast in pictures
fields.body:
Planting a car bomb outside BBC TV Centre guarantees blanket media coverage for terrorists wishing to up the ante of their campaign.

Directly attacking the media is a tried and tested publicity-generating tactic.

A militant lesbian protest would have passed unnoticed had the group concerned not famously invaded Television Centre during a Six O'Clock News bulletin only to be wrestled to the floor by Nicholas Witchell.

The Real IRA's audacious rocket-launcher attack on the M16 building in September generated huge publicity. Newspapers printed colour maps pinpointing the position the terrorist fired from to show exactly how it was done.

But attempting to blow up journalists assures the undivided attention of those who set the news agenda.

The result is apparent this morning. The story was splashed across the front page of every national newspaper - apart from the Daily Star.

The dramatic pictures of the blast contributed to double-page spreads in the tabloids while the Guardian, the Independent and Daily Telegraph ran the story to a second page. The Times had a second page of coverage and a leader column.

Yesterday the bomb attack took the top slot on radio and TV news bulletins throughout Sunday.

fields.headline: Labour defends waiting list rise
fields.trailText: The government has defended the rise in the number of people waiting for hospital treatment in England, claiming that the figures were better than expected.
fields.body:
The government has defended the rise in the number of people waiting for hospital treatment in England, claiming that the figures were better than expected.

Waiting lists rose by 4,500 to 1,039,000 in January, according to government figures published today.

Ministers said the increase had been kept to a minimum during one of the busiest periods of the year for the health service and pointed out that waiting lists rose by 11,000 in January last year.

But 1,880 more operations were cancelled during the last quarter of 2000, as hospitals scrapped routine surgery to deal with emergency cases.

Tory health spokesman Dr Liam Fox called on the government to scrap its waiting list initiative and instead treat patients according to clinical need.

He said: "These figures show that Tony Blair and Alan Milburn have completely failed to honour Labour's health promise to the electorate before the 1997 general election."

He claimed that rather than achieving a manifesto pledge to reduce waiting lists by 100,000, the queue for people waiting overall had risen.

The numbers of in-patients on waiting lists had come down by around 120,000 since 1997, he said. But the number of people waiting for an out-patient appointment had increased by 150,000 over the same period, making a net waiting list rise of 30,000.

Dr Fox said: "Alan Milburn seems to think that the latest figures are a cause for rejoicing. The atients whose operations were cancelled in the last month will tell him the exact opposite."

Mr Milburn said: "Waiting lists rose as we expected during January - but by a much smaller amount than we had thought.

"The fundamental reason is that the NHS has more beds and more staff and prepared better than ever before this winter.

"As a result, many patients whose operations would not have gone ahead in previous years, got the treatment they needed - but far too many had their operation cancelled.

"We are tackling waiting lists. Now we need to tackle cancelled operations head-on."

He today announced the first pilot schemes under which patients who have their operation cancelled at short notice will have to have another date within 28 days - or have their surgery done privately and paid for by the hospital trust. If the pilots are successful, the scheme will be rolled out to the rest of the country.

webTitle: Love and pain in John Diamond's last words

fields.headline: Love and pain in Diamond's last words
fields.standfirst: Mourners hear columnist's emotional farewell messages
fields.trailText: Thoughts and feelings written down by columnist and author John Diamond in his last days were shared with those who gathered yesterday at West London Crematorium to mourn his death. By Rebecca Allison.
fields.body:
The poignant words which echoed around the room were unmistakable in their honesty, wit and warmth. Read aloud, from laboured scribblings on the pages of a notebook, these sentences were the final few paragraphs in the remarkable chronicles of John Diamond.

Thoughts and feelings written down by the columnist and author in his last days were shared with his family, friends and colleagues who gathered yesterday at West London Crematorium to mourn his death.

Diamond, 47, who lost the ability to speak after having surgery on his tongue, continued to communicate vigorously through his writing until shortly before he died on Friday. He had been admitted to the Royal Marsden hospital in London on Wednesday.

More than 200 mourners attended the Jewish service led by Rabbi David Goldberg, to pay their last respects to a man who will be best remembered by many for his columns in the Times, which chronicled the course of his cancer, his treatment, and daily life with the terminal illness through all of its stages, with such honesty and candour.

His wife, the food writer Nigella Lawson, and the couple's two children Cosima, seven, and Bruno, four, listened as his last words were read aloud by her brother, Dominic Lawson, to a packed room and relayed to those outside through speakers.

The one-sided dialogue, a form of communication achingly familiar to those who were close to him, included moving messages of love for his wife.

He had written: "How proud I am of you and what you have become. The great thing about us is that we have made us who we are. Kiss the children for me. I love you all."

The unbearable pain he was experiencing was evident in the extracts which, in his customary direct manner stated: "Any chance of a little sedation? I feel a touch anxious. I want no more resuscitation. I can't take any more."

Later, he wrote: "Can you take me under to relieve the pain and waiting, please." It was underlined twice. Despite his continuing pain and the morphine-induced haze, Diamond, who had always insisted he was neither brave nor courageous, retained his humour and fortitude.

When asked how he was feeling, he replied: "Sort of OK, I suppose. Within the usual existential constraints." He also reserved a special thank you for the surgeon who had treated him after he had been diagnosed with cancer in 1997. He wrote: "Peter, thank you for everything, you have given me a wonderful extra three years."

Mr Lawson, editor of the Sunday Telegraph, went on to pay tribute to his brother-in-law's remarkable journalistic talent, as well as to his great kindness and warmth: "John was a brilliant writer long before he was a famous writer," he said.

Born in east London, in Hackney, Diamond's father was a biochemist, his mother an artist. He trained to be a teacher in English and drama and taught at a girls' school before switching to journalism. He met Nigella, his second wife, when they worked together at the Sunday Times, and they were married in Venice in 1992. It had been Diamond's unconditional love and support which had helped a shy, fragile Nigella to build up her confidence and self-belief, Mr Lawson added.

More than a touch of humour was injected into the service by Diamond himself, when his columns were read in part by Neil Pearson, the actor who is to star in a BBC adaptation of the play based on Diamond's experience of cancer. Also addressing the congregation, which included many famous faces from showbusiness and the media, was his younger brother Matthew, who spoke of the great bond he had shared with a man who was "kind, generous and brilliant".

Among those packed into the small crematorium were actor Alan Rickman, comedian David Baddiel, presenter Ruby Wax, writer Alan Coren, and Sasha Baron Cohen, better known as Ali G. Also present were Jon Snow, the newscaster, Alan Yentob, director of drama at the BBC, presenter Melvyn Bragg, and Elisabeth Murdoch, Rupert Murdoch's daughter.

Matthew Diamond told them: "I was lucky to have him as a friend. I was lucky to know him. I had him as my big brother. It was never dull."

Nigella had once summed it all up perfectly, continued Matthew, when she told him "I love a room with John in it". Summing it up for those who will miss Diamond, he added: "A lot of rooms we will have to love a little less, but we will never stop loving John."

fields.headline: Unilever puts TV adverts online
fields.trailText: 1pm: Unilever is planning to put its TV commercials on the internet, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Frustrated by the poor performance of the ubiquitous banner advert, the consumer products giant Unilever is planning to put its TV commercials on the internet.

The firm has designed a pilot project to show whether punters will stay logged on for long enough to watch a 30-second advert.

For the project, Unilever has hired a US internet company to put a campaign for its Salon Selectives haircare products on key internet portals.

The campaign will make its internet debut in May at the same time as it breaks on TV.

Web surfers will be wooed with incentives such as promotions and prizes to keep them watching for the duration of the commercial.

Unilever has already experimented with showing its commercials on the web as part of a deal with the internet company Excite@Home.

But whereas that required users to have access to broadband technology, the new arrangement will allow people to watch the adverts using a standard internet connection.

Unilever spends about £2.5bn a year to promote its 970 brands on worldwide TV.

fields.headline: Exorcist to make TV debut on C4
fields.trailText: 1pm: TV viewers will finally get to see the notorious horror movie 28 years after its release, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It has earned a reputation as one of the most terrifying films in TV history. When it was released it was branded sickening, gruesome, hateful and even blamed for mysterious deaths.

Now, 28 years after it was released under a strict X certificate, television viewers will have the chance to decide whether the Exorcist deserves its reputation.

It will appear on British terrestrial television for the first time on Channel 4.

The 1973 shocker about a young girl who becomes possessed by the devil, which was denied a video certificate in the UK until 1999, is being scheduled for Saturday March 17.

"The film is considered by many to be a classic of the horror genre," said a Channel 4 spokesman.

"It's notoriety precedes it and we are keen that viewers have a chance to decide for themselves."

The Exorcist, which has an 18 certificate, will be scheduled at 10.50pm.

It will be preceded by a short commentary by film critic and broadcaster Mark Kermode.

An Independent Television Commission spokeswoman said the regulator had no problem with Channel 4 showing the Exorcist, "provided the film has a certificate and is scheduled appropriately".

She said listings information and on-air trailers and warnings had an important role to play in alerting viewers to the film's content.

"Viewers are more likely to be offended if they are taken by surprise," she said.

When the Exorcist was rereleased in cinemas last year it attracted huge audiences for late-night showings, without any ill effects.

A statement from the British Board of Film Classification said: "The film was originally given an X certificate in 1974 and has been widely shown ever since.

"In the 1970s, however, incidents of hysteria involving young women led to some concern the film might cause severe emotional problems, particularly among those who believed in the reality of demonic possession."

The film fell foul of the Video Recordings Act in the 1980s and was denied a video certificate for more than a decade.

It finally received an 18 certificate from the British Board of Film Classification in 1999.

Channel 4 is also planning to give a terrestrial TV premiere to another controversial film, the Story of O, on Sunday March 18.

The Story of O tells of the sexual humiliation of a girl at the hands of a group of Parisian dilettantes and became a cause celebre when banned in the 1970s.

The censor considered it sadistic, while others defended it as an indictment of cruelty. It was finally passed uncut by the BBFC last year.

The Channel 4 spokesman said transmission of the film had yet to be confirmed, as the broadcaster's lawyers were examining its content.

"There are some potential legal issues because it features sexual scenes and we have to make sure they take place in the context of consensual sex," he said.

webTitle: Hague warns of Britain as a 'foreign land' under Labour

fields.headline: Hague warns of Britain as a 'foreign land' under Labour
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday upped the stakes in the pre-election battle when he came close to playing the race card with a provocative warning that Tony Blair wants to turn Britain into a "foreign land".
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday upped the stakes in the pre-election battle when he came close to playing the race card with a provocative warning that Tony Blair wants to turn Britain into a "foreign land".

To the fury of one nation Tories, Mr Hague reached out to the hard core on the right of the party to warn of the dangers of a second Labour term in office.

"Let me take you on a journey to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair," Mr Hague told the Tory spring conference in Harrogate as he warned of the prime minister's determination to destroy Britain by surrendering more powers to Brussels.

The use of such a loaded term, which was designed to appeal to grassroots Tories who appear to be growing increasingly disillusioned with his leadership, was condemned by Michael Heseltine.

The former deputy prime minister, who admitted over the weekend that he had faced a "dilemma" in deciding whether to vote Conservative, said he disagreed with the speech, which echoed a growing feeling of xenophobia in Britain.

Responding to Mr Hague's fear that Labour would turn Britain into a "foreign land", Mr Heseltine said: "We disagree. Does anyone seriously think that France is a 'foreign' country? Or that Germany is a 'foreign' country?

"These are great giant nation states fighting for their self-interest and they believe their self-interest is better sought and protected and advanced in concert with their neighbours than apart from them."

Mr Hague sparked the row during a hardline speech in which he pledged to lock up all asylum seekers and rounded on Mr Blair for destroying Britain.

To the delight of his audience, some of whom waved union flags, Mr Hague said a second Labour term would make Britain unrecognisable. Labour's Britain would lead to: "The Royal Mint melting down pound coins as the euro notes start to circulate. Our currency gone forever. The chancellor returning from Brussels carrying instructions to raise taxes still further."

He said: "It's your last chance to vote for a Britain that still controls its own destiny."

Mr Hague adopted a harsh tone on asylum seekers. He said: "The next Conservative government will assess the validity of asylum claims within weeks, not years. And, where applications are unfounded, immediate deportation will follow."

His remarks, which exasperated one nation Tories at the conference, were a clear attempt to enthuse hardcore Tories who appear to have given up on Mr Hague's leadership. A series of recent polls which have given Labour an emphatic lead over the Conservatives were reinforced yesterday by one showing that few Tories believe they can win the election.

The poll, carried out by YouGov Opinion Research for the Observer, found that more than three-quarters of Tory activists believe they will lose the election. More than a third believe Mr Hague should resign early in the next parliament.

He attempted to brush aside such gloom in Harrogate, insisting that he can win by appealing to Britain's "hard-working mainstream majority" who have been hit by Labour's "stealth taxes". Behind the spin, however, the Tory leadership knows it cannot win the election and should concentrate on drumming up support among grassroots supporters, 2m of whom stayed at home in 1997.

Under the influence of the Euro-MP Daniel Hannan, his new hardline Eurosceptic speech writer, Mr Hague is reverting to the tactics of last spring when he lurched to the right in the run-up to the local elections.

Cabinet ministers lined up last night to criticise Mr Hague. Jack Straw, the home secretary, condemned his pledge to lock up all asylum seekers while their claims are processed.

"It is difficult to know whether this is based on abject opportunism or deep-seated personal prejudice, which is worse," he said. "Locking up all asylum seekers while their claims are processed is inhuman and impractical and would cost billions and take years. What would he do meanwhile?"

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said Mr Hague's speech was "not common sense but complete nonsense".

"The last time William Hague let himself and his party run riot on this theme of so-called patriotism and defence of the nation, he lost the Romsey byelection. He should have learnt the lesson then that British people are not taken in by his thinly veiled little Englander sentiments and populist propaganda."

Even the outgoing US ambassador raised doubts about the wisdom of distancing Britain from the EU, saying such a move would damage Britain's relations with Washington. In an interview on Sky News, Philip Lader said: "For 50 years it has been the American government's policy that a Britain more deeply engaged in Europe is good for Europe, good for Britain, and good for America."

Haguespeak

Buzzwords and key phrases from yesterday's speech:

Common sense repeated 12 times

We will give you back your country eight times

I trust the people eight times

Values four times

fields.headline: No 7. Southampton
fields.trailText: Where Saints are at
fields.body:
Where Saints are at

Somewhere in the middle, with a rock on the left and a hard place on the right. Basically, you can never, ever, really know where you stand with Saints. One minute you're the laughing stock of the Premiership, losing to a team bottom of the First Division after being 3-0 up with 45 minutes to go. The next, you're pulling off an impressive away win against a Boro side unbeaten under Terry Venables. It's a rollercoaster ride, and you never know where you're going. Which for a rollercoaster is pretty hairy.

What makes us so different

What makes Southampton different to other clubs? Well, we play in the glamorous world of the Premiership, yet we're probably the least glamorous club you'll come up against. We play in a ground that takes you on a time warp back to the fifties, where you can smell the mixture of Brylcreem and Ralgex. We're a rarity in the Premier League: a small club swimming with sharks, feeding on plankton. As to whether we'll retain our charm in our new ground is the challenge we aim to succeed at.

The high points

An easy question to answer: beating the mighty Manchester United three years on the trot. Beating them 3-1 and having them blame it on their grey strip, beating them 6-3 and having them blame it on Roy Keane being sent off, bBeating them 1-0 and have them blame it on a full moon in the house of Scorpio.

Of course, beating Pompey 3-0 in 1996 was a high, an atmosphere that no Premiership opponent can generate. And perhaps surviving against all odds in 1999, what a ride that season was.

The low points

I wasn't able to make our 1988 defeat to Pompey, I would imagine that would be the worst defeat at the Dell. For me personally, losing 6-2 and 7-2 to Spurs was poor, as was the match in the 1998/99 season when we were trailing 3-1 at home to Blackburn. At that moment I swore we were going down. A miraculous recovery to draw 3-3, which spurred us to go on and survive, pretty much erased that pain.

Current position

At the moment Saints are flying high, playing good passing football and looking a good outside bet for Europe. It's been so long since Saints were in Europe, several countries don't exist anymore. Is Russia still a superpower? It was when I last went to Europe with Saints.

Our last fixture

Manchester City away. According to Joe Royle, we got lucky, committed a smash-and-grab, scored a goal against the run of play on a bobbly pitch and cheated City with a "blatant" penalty. It would be nice if someone actually remembered that sound defending is actually part of the game.

Our next fixtures

Everton at home, then Ipswich. God only knows how, but if we win those two games we could actually go third! How on earth can that happen? From relegation strugglers to European wannabes. If anything, the Tranmere game might just have done us a favour. With games like that you either sink or swim, and we're swimming along very well thank you. It might even have made our season.

Sore point

As a whole the board aren't that bad, and Saints are financially better off. But if I was to have one gripe, it would have to be the rise in prices for children in the new stadium. Children now face a massive hike in prices once they become "teenagers".

The chairman

After a shaky start, Rupert Lowe has come good, producing the new stadium and a club that is financially secure. He's also mature enough to actually talk to the fans.

Rivals

Pompey, but as rivals go they are piss-poor. Stuck in a time warp since the fifties, they constantly berate us for not having a glorious past like they had (ie: two championships, one FA Cup and nothing for the next 50 years). Three wins against us in the last 50 years, they still harp on about beating us in 1988. They named a fanzine after it.

Kit

I quite like the last one, though the one lined up for next season is a back-to-stripes basic. The worst one? The BLUE away kit, from about ten years ago. We looked like Pompey.

Most ridiculous piece of merchandise

A Nationwide Review CD-Rom. Just what interest is that to us?

Heroes

Currently, Dean Richards. The man is made of stone and only a fool wouldn't play him for England. The most popular ever? Le Tiss, quite simply the best player I've ever seen.

As for other teams? I'd have to say Michael Owen, the boy is a credit to his club and country. When he's on his feet that is.

Villians

Club villain? I don't think so. We love all our players. That said, Stuart Ripley isn't exactly Mr Congeniality. He was alleged to have slagged off Francis Benali and Matt Le Tiss, players who are much loved and respected here, to a fan in a local nightspot. Robbie Savage I'd have to say I hate: he can dish it out but can't take it. Oh, and Eyal Berkovic too. Fans never like players who slag their old team off. Eyal's parting shot - "I was never happy there, everyone was jealous of me" - didn't exactly endear him to the fans of the club that gave him his big break in the first place.

The ground

The Dell, it's a magical place. A throw back to a time when it was football that mattered not cash.

Local Knowledge

The Cricketers in Bedford Place and the Bevois Castle in Bevois Valley are recommended.

Links

Saintsforever, Marching In, Rick Throbber's Bogus Saints Page.

fields.headline: Cardinal damned for reviving Satan
fields.standfirst: Frontrunner for Pope writes 10 rules to resist temptation
fields.trailText: A leading contender to succeed the Pope has been accused of medieval mumbo-jumbo after publishing 10 rules on how to resist Satan's temptations.
fields.body:
A leading contender to succeed the Pope has been accused of medieval mumbo-jumbo after publishing 10 rules on how to resist Satan's temptations.

Cardinal Dionigi Tettamanzi, 66, the archbishop of Genoa, dedicated his lenten letter to combating the fascination of a devil who is charming, shrewd and very real.

Those who follow his 10-step programme are promised the ability to rebuff offers of forbidden fruit, unlike Adam and Eve.

First rule: "Do not forget that the devil exists."

Rule two: "Do not forget that the devil is a tempter."

Rule three: "Do not forget that the devil is very intelligent and astute."

Cardinal Tettamanzi, widely seen as a conservative frontrunner to succeed the Pope, urges permanent watchfulness. "Be vigilant in the eyes and the heart. Be strong in spirit and virtue."

Another five rules recommend tireless prayer, adoring God, listening to His words, remembering Christ's victory over temptation and man's sharing in that victory.

Obeying the tenth rule, though, should seal the devil's defeat: "Be humble and love mortification."

Cardinal Tettamanzi is a moral theologian who has helped the Pope write encyclicals. The pastoral letter raised his profile as the candidates jockey to replace the ailing pontiff, 81 in May.

The Milan-based Theological Studies Centre, which is independent of the Vatican, condemned the letter for bringing Satan back into the realm of human responsibility.

By raising the spectre of diabolical machinations rather than human evil, the cardinal was reaching back into the middle ages and ignoring scientific advances in psychology, the centre claimed.

"To attribute guilt to the devil could encourage people to be irresponsible," it said.

According to La Repubblica, the centre also accused the church of having exploited Satan in centuries past to persecute heretics and cultural minorities, such as gays.

In recent decades, the role of the devil has become a fraught topic in theology, splitting those who believe he is real and those who believe he symbolises mankind's capacity for evil.

Also known as Lucifer and Beelzebub, according to the Bible he is a fallen angel who sinned by pride and was banished from heaven.

He is allowed by God to exercise influence on living and inanimate creatures - tempting Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, and Jesus in the wilderness.

The Italian Bishops Conference has recently agonised about how to address the devil during exorcisms following a Vatican decision to translate into Italian the venerable Latin formula, Vade retro Satanas.

Bishops were unsure which form of "you" to use - the familiar "tu" or formal "lei".

fields.headline: Missing lottery jackpot winners
fields.standfirst: A £3m lottery prize went unclaimed until the last minute this week, and Camelot has questioned the validity of the alleged winning ticket. Here's our guide to the best sites on losing winners
fields.trailText: A £3m lottery prize went unclaimed until the last minute this week, and Camelot has questioned the validity of the alleged winning ticket. Here's our guide to the best sites on losing winners.
fields.body:
1. Someone in south Hertfordshire bought a winning ticket for the September 6 national lottery draw, but he or she nearly lost the lot by failing to claim the prize £3m prize until just before Monday's 11pm deadline.

2. Camelot, the company that manages the lottery, has a list of places that winners may want to look for lost tickets. Past winners have kept their tickets under the floorboards, taped to the body and under "m" for millionaire in the dictionary.

3. A quarter of female winners have kept their winning ticket in their bras.

4. The lottery operates strict guidelines about claiming prize money and locating winners. If no one had claimed the prize, it would have been the largest jackpot to be returned to the national lottery since £2m from a draw in May 1996 went unclaimed. Even now, Camelot has questions about the validity of the ticket finally produced on Monday.

5. By January, unclaimed lottery winnings donated to good causes totalled more than £303.9m and £38.2m in unclaimed prizes was within the 180-day deadline.

6. But the person who lost the most money on the lottery is probably still Richard Branson. He is seeking a reported £8m in compensation for his failed People's Lottery bid to run the game.

7. Lottery winners are not the only ones missing out on free money: individuals have left billions of pounds of unclaimed money languishing in corporate accounts, mostly from pensions, dormant bank accounts and life insurance policies. UK life insurance companies alone are estimated to hold £20bn in orphan assets.

8. You can search for lost money at sites such as Unclaimed Assets.

9. It is also worth searching through your own neglected paperwork to see if you have any forgotten accounts.

10. A case in point: in January, the Halifax put 145,000 former building society members on notice that they would lose unclaimed shares worth £170m if they did not claim them by April 7.
