webTitle: 10% of small bookshops forced out of business

fields.headline: 10% of small bookshops forced out of business
fields.standfirst: Matthew Engel: Bookshops are closing. Hurrah
fields.trailText: More than one in 10 of Britain's small independent bookshops have folded in the last five years, the Booksellers Association disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
More than one in 10 of Britain's small independent bookshops have folded in the last five years, the Booksellers Association disclosed yesterday.

Nearly 200 bookshops in high streets or suburbs have been killed by pressures including the explosion of price cuts on bestsellers by chains like WH Smith, Waterstone's and superstores, savage rent rises, and the internet.

The shops - seen until recently as integral to the heart and soul of British cultural life - fell in number from 1,894 in 1995 to 1,699 last year, a drop of 195.

The Booksellers Association issued the figures, which have not been announced before, after checking its membership records. It did so after being asked to shed light on a report in the Book Sales Yearbook showing that independent bookshops lost nearly 10% of the total book sales market last year. The closures were the main reason for this, it emerged.

"It has been a different industry in the last five years - much tougher," Tim Godfray, association chief executive, said yesterday.

Rent rises, which are squeezing all high street shops, have provoked the association to try to open talks with the government through the British Retail Consortium in an effort to reverse a contractual condition that reviews of shop rents can only be upwards. "The idea is to get the government to introduce legislation or a new code of practice", Mr Godfray said.

Warnings of dire effects on small bookshops were dismissed in 1995 when the book trade's net book agreement collapsed under pressure from big publishers and book chains.

The agreement, the last price-fixing measure left in British commerce, prevented big chains from using their financial clout to drive out street-corner shops by offering cut-price bestsellers.

Many small shops depended on revenue from the Christmas top sellers like Delia Smith's cookery series to stay in business.

The death of the agreement left them unable to match the chain discounts.

The 2001 Book Sales Yearbook shows that, six years later, the only outlets selling more books are superstores, book clubs through aggressive marketing, and internet bookshops like Amazon. Internet sales rose from 2.3% of the market to 5% last year, though this growth rate slipped in the second half of the year.

webTitle: Fair trade confectioners make everyone a winner

fields.headline: Fair trade confectioners make everyone a winner
fields.standfirst: Sophi Tranchell took on the ferociously competitive UK chocolate market when she started as managing director of the Day Chocolate Company. She markets fair trade Divine milk chocolate made from Kuapa's cocoa beans, and recently launched Dubble, a fair trade chocolate treat for children backed by Comic Relief. It's all tastebuds to the grindstone now, with her team currently hard at work taste-testing for a new chocolate bar
fields.trailText: Sophi Tranchell took on the ferociously competitive UK chocolate market when she started as managing director of the Day Chocolate Company. She markets fair trade Divine milk chocolate made from Kuapa's cocoa beans, and recently launched Dubble, a fair trade chocolate treat for children backed by Comic Relief. It's all tastebuds to the grindstone now, with her team currently hard at work taste-testing for a new chocolate bar.
fields.body:
'It is an enormously audacious proposition to launch a chocolate bar in Britain. The market here is very competitive and has so many established brands. When chocolate lovers hear how deeply fair trade impacts on farming communities in developing countries, and in particular the small-scale cocoa producers in Ghana who own the Day Chocolate Company, their response is incredibly warm. In my most optimistic dreams, that response could deliver a brand loyalty that would mean that Dubble, our new snack bar, could get into the chocolate top 20.

Obviously, the worry is that it won't happen - we are competing with multinationals which have sales teams of thousands.

When I started, Divine had just been launched and had a tremendous amount of press. But it wasn't on the shelf in many places so the first challenge was to get it into mainstream shops. I think we've done astoundingly well at that - most supermarkets now stock Divine, Dubble or both.

The value of a product is in the brand rather than in the commodity. By making their own fair trade chocolate bar aimed at the mainstream, cocoa farmers have a chance to gain some of the value in the huge confectionery market.

It's vitally important that fair trade works because many people's hopes and dreams are tied up with this. Divine and Dubble offer farmers who are the least powerful people in the market the chance to participate in a dignified trading chain that respects their skills and values their contribution. That goes for consumers in Britain as well - chocolate lovers are not only getting delicious chocolate, they know that their choice benefits the growers."

 Interviewed by Louise Tickle

webTitle: Tax breaks set to aid regeneration and urban renewal

fields.headline: Tax breaks set to aid regeneration and urban renewal
fields.trailText: The chancellor plans to revitalise the poorest areas through financial freedoms and tax relief
fields.body:
In January, chancellor Gordon Brown said this Budget would include measures designed to create an "enterprise culture" in those parts of the country with the highest levels of unemployment.

These areas needed more business start-ups and increased private sector investment, he said, and the government would present a range of new incentives to encourage both.

This means the Budget could include a package of targeted tax breaks, which Mr Brown said he would be consulting on in the run-up to this year's announcement. They include:

 Cuts in stamp duty.
November's pre-Budget report said the government would abolish this tax for all property transactions in the country's most deprived areas to stimulate the property market and encourage urban renewal.

 Reduced business rates.
A proposal suggested in last year's local government finance green paper that would cut overheads for small businesses throughout England.

 Changes in capital gains tax.
The Treasury has yet to release details of what these might be, but they will probably allow businesses to keep more of the profits from long-term investments in deprived areas.

Ultimately, Mr Brown hopes these measures will lead to an extra £1bn of private investment making its way into high unemployment areas of the country.

With the chancellor and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers convinced of the need to realise the economic potential of the English regions, Mr Brown might also unveil extra allowances and incentives to support this. The package could include a range of new freedoms for the regional development agencies to spend their funding, a move trailed in the pre-Budget report.

That report included several other regeneration measures due to be carried through to this year's announcement. Among them were:

 Accelerated tax credits for cleaning up contaminated land.
Aimed at encouraging land recycling by providing immediate tax relief for property investors' clean-up costs. Businesspeople will no longer have to wait until they sell to reap the tax rewards.

 Immediate tax relief for converting redundant space above shops into flats.
Aimed at making better use of urban space and bringing more life into commercial areas.

 Reduced VAT on converting residential properties into flats.
A 5% rate aimed at creating more homes in areas of high demand.

 Zero VAT on renovating residential property empty for 10 years or more.
Designed to encourage investors to bring derelict properties back onto the market.

The new VAT rates will be welcomed by social housing professionals, but bodies such as the Chartered Institute of Housing want to see the measures go further, and are hoping the chancellor will equalise the rates for building new properties and refurbishing old ones.

At present, new buildings attract no VAT, while refurbishment is charged at the full rate, a policy that flies in the face of the government's plans for urban renewal by discouraging the recycling of old homes and business premises. The equalised rate could be 5% or 7.5% for both types of work.

Mr Brown will probably have little to say about local government - councils have already had their finance settlement, with ministers delivering a funding increase of more than 7% plus an extra £190m to help keep down council tax levels.

Mr Brown can choose to add money in, and if he does decide to hand out funds from his pre-election war chest, some of it could end up in town and county hall coffers.

But the chancellor has set his face against "irresponsible pre-election giveaways", and promised to use this budget to lock in tough public sector spending rules, making any significant financial boost unlikely.

fields.headline: Nunavut hits money rut
fields.standfirst: Less than two years after Canada redrew its map to give the Inuit control over their vast land, the new northern territory of Nunavut is having financial problems, says Anne McIlroy in Ottawa
fields.trailText: Less than two years after Canada redrew its map to give the Inuit control over their vast land, the new northern territory of Nunavut is having financial problems, says Anne McIlroy in Ottawa.
fields.body:
Nunavut finance minister Kelvin Ng revealed last week that his fledgling government is heading for a serious financial crisis and will spend $12 million (about $18 million US) more than it brings in in revenue in the next fiscal year. About 90 per cent of its annual budget comes from the federal government.

Nunavut, which means "our land" in Inuktitut, the Inuit language, is the largest and most important experiment in aboriginal self government in Canadian history.

For the first time it gives the Inuit, known as Eskimos in the United States, control over their own economic and political affairs. About 85 per cent of the population of 27,000 are Inuit, people living in a vast frozen landscape more than 10 times the size of Britain.

There are more polar bears, caribou, seals and whales than humans in its 772,000 square miles of tundra, mountains and fjords. The preferred dish is raw meat.

After 20 years of negotiations, it became Canada's third official territory - like a province but with a few less powers - on April 1 1999.

Nunavut is off to a bad financial start because its government budgeted money allocated for hiring bureaucrats for a new public service to programs instead.

Now that positions are being filled in all the new departments, there isn't enough money to pay for everything. Mr Ng also says the level of initial funding was not high enough to meet the many needs of people in the territory.

The crisis is a sign of how difficult it can be to build a government from scratch, especially since years of neglect by the federal government have led to widespread poverty.

Nunavut has a birth rate more than twice the national average, which means there is enormous pressure for new schools and houses. The unemployment rate is 25 per cent. There is also a severe shortage of educated professionals to run the territory.

There is only one Inuit lawyer and that is premier Paul Okalik. He has budgeted a chunk of cash to establish a northern law school.

The birth of their own territory was a moment of extraordinary pride and hope for the Inuit people, and the federal government badly wants Nunavut to work.

Prime minister Jean Chrétien, a former native affairs minister who adopted an Indian son, has made it clear that programs to improve the lives of native peoples will be a priority in his third mandate.

That's why finance minister Paul Martin has agreed to review the level of federal funding for the territory, even though he has been tough on other provinces who have come to him looking for more money from Ottawa to keep their social programs afloat.

Ottawa already spends $21,500 Cdn for each person living in the territory. Nunavut received roughly $580 million a year from the federal government during its first two years, and is planning to spend $679 in 2001.

The Nunavut finance minister says its important to increase the funding before budget problems threaten the political and economic stability of the new territory.

It seems Ottawa, notoriously stingy with the provinces, will at least meet him halfway. Nobody is ready to declare Nunavut a failure just yet.

fields.headline: Pearson to cut back internet spending
fields.trailText: 11.30am: FT owner Pearson is to cut back its internet spending after a 17% fall in profits, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Financial Times owner Pearson is to cut back the internet spending which has eaten into the group's profits.

The UK media group reported a fall in its full-year figures after spending nearly £200m on internet projects last year.

But Pearson moved to ease City jitters over the damage to its top line by promising that the cost of developing its online education sites and putting the FT on the web will "decline significantly in 2001".

The group has joined the likes of Emap, United Business Media and Reuters in ploughing a significant amount of its capital into the internet.

As a result, pre-tax profits for last year fell 17% to £333m, although sales rose 16% to £3.8bn.

"This is another great set of results," said Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino.

"All the time, we are making the moves that enable Pearson to grow more quickly and more profitably," she said.

The Financial Times offset fears of a downturn in the financial advertising market by posting a 45% rise in operating profit to £81m.

However, Pearson admitted advertising growth had slumped from 34% last year to just 8% in the first two months of this year.

The education market is by far Pearson's biggest earner, contributing just over £2bn in turnover, with the FT group next on £800m.

Analysts will be eagerly awaiting US president Bush's education spending plans in the US.

Any rise in the budget will be a significant boost to Pearson's strong presence across the Atlantic.

The Financial Times Group is also teaming up with mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse to launch a "virtual" mobile phone network.

The service, which will launch in the spring, will offer business and financial content to consumers.

webTitle: Monica Bellucci is continuing a great Italian tradition

fields.headline: Part siren, part muse, all trouble
fields.standfirst: Laura Winters on how Monica Bellucci is continuing a great Italian tradition
fields.trailText: Laura Winters on how Monica Bellucci is continuing a great Italian tradition.
fields.body:
In Giuseppe Tornatore's new film, Malena, the Italian actress Monica Bellucci plays a heroine who is every man's dream and every woman's nightmare. The young and gorgeous Malena Scordia, who is marooned in her husband's village in Sicily when he goes off to the second world war, is an unwitting Circe, driving men to lust and their wives to plot revenge. Walking across the village square, Bellucci, with her sinuous curves and inimitable hauteur, evokes a grand tradition of Italian screen goddess: part siren, part muse and all trouble.

But she does not remain simply a glorious icon in the film. She also creates a subtle, wrenching portrait of a woman victimised by the society in which she lives as she struggles to maintain her dignity. "For me, Malena is a product of her era, in that she can't have an identity apart from men," Bellucci says. She smiles ruefully. "While I, of course, as a product of my era, have fought all my life to be free and independent."

It's a mark of Bellucci's talent that she has managed to incarnate a woman so different from herself. Bellucci, 29, began her professional life as a fashion model but has found wider celebrity in Europe as an actress, thanks to her striking presence in about a dozen Italian and French films, including two high-profile projects in France, L'Appartement (1996) and Dobermann (1997).

Her first English-language starring role came last year in Under Suspicion, in which she appeared opposite Morgan Freeman and Gene Hackman. In both that film and Malena, Bellucci plays enigmatic, alluring women who convey more with a glance than most people do with a diatribe. "Monica is mysterious: behind her beauty, there is a world you want to know," says Tornatore of his star. "But unlike so many beautiful women, she doesn't think her beauty is everything. She is intelligent and lends herself to the work in an extraordinary way, without limits."

In person, Bellucci speaks fluent English (she also speaks French) and comes across as warm, voluble and unpretentious. Recalling how she and Tornatore discussed Malena's inner life in each scene of the film, she says: "Because my character doesn't speak very much, I needed to show everything through my face and my body. It was as if we had a secret script, Giuseppe and I, where in each scene I had a big monologue in my mind."

Malena's story is revealed through the eyes of a 13-year-old boy (Giuseppe Sulfaro), who is captivated by her. He observes helplessly as her life unravels following her husband's death in the war. Alone and unable to find work, the young widow half-defiantly, half-desperately becomes a prostitute for the village's German occupiers.

Tornatore's evocation of Bellucci's charms doesn't prepare the viewer for the film's central scene, in which Malena is set upon by the village's jealous wives, who beat her and cut off her hair - a fate shared by many collaborating women at the end of the war. Tornatore and Bellucci decided that she, rather than a body double, would act that scene. "With someone as famous as she is, I couldn't risk doing a scene like this without its being realistic," Tornatore says. "If the scene is shocking, it's because it's true."

Bellucci agrees. "It was really important to me that you see it's me in the scene," she says, "that you see my face and my reactions, that you see the violence."

Throughout the film, Bellucci says, she tried to convey Malena's stifling lack of options. "She makes so many mistakes because she's a slave to her situation. This character was my way to fight, to say to everybody, 'This is where we used to be.' And yet there are still so many places in the world where women are oppressed by men."

She also understood Malena, she says, because of her own experience growing up in Citta di Castello, a small town in central Italy where her father has a trucking company. "I know what it means to be in a place where everybody knows everybody, where people try to invent things about you."

At the age of 18, she began studying law in the nearby city of Perugia but left her studies when she started modelling. For the next three years, she did both catwalk work and adverts for designers such as Dolce and Gabbana. When he met her to discuss the role of Chantal, a beauty who is consumed by jealousy of other women, Hopkins says: "She had known people like Chantal and had some great ideas about the character, so much so that I put them in the script."

She will also appear in a big French comedy, Asterix & Obelix: Mission Cléopatre, in which (no surprise) she plays what she calls an "over the top version" of the Egyptian queen.

"For me, Malena is a product of her era, in that she can't have an identity apart from men," Bellucci says. She smiles ruefully. fields.headline: Charity's great pantathon
fields.standfirst: Comic Relief 2001 may make more money for charity than the profits of all the dot.coms put together. Imogen O'Rorke looks at how the event's website will play a central role
fields.trailText: Comic Relief 2001 may make more money for charity than the profits of all the dot.coms put together. Imogen O'Rorke looks at how the event's website will play a central role
fields.body:
Due to the number of celebrities who will be taking them off, putting them on their heads or up for auction, Comic Relief 2001 will go down in the fundraising hall of fame as the "pants" year. "Pants to poverty", this year's slogan, will be up there with such corkers as Hale and Pace's "stonk" song (1991) and "the invasion of the comic tomatoes" (1993).

From a marketing perspective, however, 2001 will also be remembered as the year charity went high tech. For Comic Relief's new media strategy this year is anything but "pants". Cisco, Oracle, Energis, BT and Compaq make up the panoply of technology giants who have built the website - or online fundraising mall - at www.comicrelief.com.

With a new three-minute donation engine, a state-of-the-art database, e-commerce solutions, security firewalls, online tariff voting and 82 call centres (staffed by 15,000 volunteers), Comic Relief hopes to take fundraising to heights hitherto unknown. If 1999's bargain basement website collected £400,000, it will be interesting to see if it can exceed this figure with equipment worth at least £1m.

From PR to sheer pocket-emptying effectiveness, Red Nose Day has always been the king of charity showcases. It gets an enormous amount of airtime, celebrity support (200 stars already this year) and press coverage. In 1988, the experience of a red-carbuncled Lenny Henry encouraging us to "hit those phonelines" as we sat back and watched the grand total shooting up miraculously was an early taste of interactive TV.

From village cake stalls and sponsored streaks to 1999's successful campaign to "turn the web red" banner ad campaign, which is bigger this time, the organisers have had 13 years' experience in cross-platform interaction.This year, according to marketing director Amanda Horton-Mastin, new media technology is at the forefront of fundraising strategy. Only a month ago, you wouldnÍt have suspected it: a basic "coming soon" site with Henry inviting you to check out "one of the most crucial websites around" was all that was on show. Then on February 19, a handful of journalists were invited to the launch of a "new interactive donation experience", a live web event featuring Lenny Henry and Joanna Lumley, "taking you through the steps leading to the galaxy of stars" which boasts that it features the names of every person to make an online donation.

The idea is immediate gratification for anyone donating any amount of money (although sadly, due to a "software error", my name won't be joining the likes of Michael Barrymore). The network infrastructure and transaction system, designed by Cisco with NatWest Streamline Merchant Services, can manage up to 200 consecutive donations a second and, amazingly, was built in just three weeks - compared to a traditional turnaround of two months.

Kevin Cahill, Comic ReliefÍs CEO, believes its new system will change the whole process of "giving online". "The most exciting thing," he says, "is that it gives Comic Relief the potential to reach the hearts and minds of people not just in the UK but throughout the world. It's a tangible way of helping Comic Relief tackle poverty and promote social justice in the UK and Africa, not just for Red Nose Day but on an ongoing basis."

The internet has already opened up new avenues of fundraising in the charity sector. There are now dozens of ethical shopping sites which support good causes by guaranteeing a percentage of every transaction. Sites such as shop2give.com, free2give.co.uk and webcharity.com, which allows people to buy, sell or donate using the e-auction format and even boasts a virtual thrift shop - Oxfam in cyberspace.

Most sites, however, lack the expensive credit card payment systems which would make donating secure and seamless. The e-commerce solution also means that for the first time Comic Relief can sell noses, gimmicks, T-shirts and, significantly, two new Harry Potter adventures donated by JK Rowling, due for publication on March 12.

"For the first time, this means we had to think about designing the site for a global audience," says Horton-Mastin, "and being able to handle 13 different currencies."

But it's the good ideas in conjunction with the pride-and-joy payment systems which the organisers hope will make the campaign a success. Ideas like Pantasy Football (thought up by the lads at Cisco systems), an online game spoof of Fantasy Football launched on Valentine's Day with the Daily Star which allows wannabe football managers to create their dream team built from their 11 worst footballers, based on the performance of players in FA Cup, Premier League and Worthington Cup games. Entries start at £2 with 80% of fees being donated by the production company Dream League.

During the two day event itself (March 16-17), while the focus will be on televised events, Robbie Williams's "Bid it sum" live auction will be a strong contender for eyeballs. Game-as-ever Robbie, the nation's favourite cheeky chappie, is giving up his kingsize bed, Technics decks and a handwritten version of his hit single Angels to go under the hammer. The actual auction will take place at Sotheby's on April 10, highlighted at sothebys.com/robbie, but bidding will take place on the official site and at robbiewilliams.com.

Pop stars Westlife and Craig David have also hitched their fan sites up to the mother ship and will be offering free tickets and other paraphernalia. Other web attractions accessed in the "Have a laugh" channel include web casts of celebrity interviews (the marketing department cannot say who because it will be on an "on the hop" basis), stand-up shorts and video streaming. You can already view the likes of Davina McCall, Angus Deayton and Geri Halliwell doing have-a-go improvisations with pants, and play the boxers versus Y-fronts game.

Then there's the much-hyped Celebrity Big Brother (a joint venture between BBC, Endemol and Comic Relief), running from March 9-16, which will attempt to mimick the success of the Channel 4 gameshow, with telephone voting (25p a minute) and regular web bulletins to keep us up to date on which stars are killing who. According to reports, participants are rumoured to include Frank Skinner, Mariella Frostrup and Chris Evans, while Mel B has had to drop out due to exhaustion. The online voting mechanism which will connect you to a tariff line before reconnecting to your ISP, is apparently "the first of its kind", but only works from direct dial-up modems.

And when the stage is packed up and the whole stonking circus over for another two years, Comic Relief will live on in its new virtual form. With a database containing the details of all who have "given it sum", the charity hopes to keep the web community alive 365 days a year with email updates and online attractions such as comedy casts, news and a permanent resource for schools. The site is currently advertising something called Web Nose Day, a website design competition for schools. ItÍs the online donation mechanisms, however, which the organisers hope will become the "killer app" for charities.

Last year, Comic Relief raised a record £35m, which will be distributed among a host of causes in the UK, Africa and globally. This time around, with a bit of luck, it could make more than all the profits of all the dotcoms in the UK in 2000 put together. Just imagine.

webTitle: What, no sombrero? John Patterson on The Mexican

fields.headline: What, no sombreros?
fields.standfirst: Finally - a film about Mexico without the mescal and machismo.  John Patterson continues his look at the new US movies
fields.trailText: Finally - a film about Mexico without the mescal and machismo. John Patterson continues his look at the new US movies.
fields.body:
The Mexican is a shambling, shaggy-dog movie about how, for Americans, the world turns upside down once they leave the comforts of el norte, the first world, and become mere gringos in Mexico, the third. Brad Pitt is a small-time operator who has spent five years paying off a debt to a jailed American crime boss. The last service he must perform is to travel south of the border in search of a legendary hand-made pistol ("too beautiful to look at") known as "the Mexican", even if that means losing his bratty spitfire of a girlfriend, played by Julia Roberts.

This being Mexico, the pistol carries an ancient curse that afflicts all those who covet it. Almost everyone who picks up this gun - from the man who made it many years ago to the evil men who seek it now - will come to a sticky end.

For a movie billed as the first teaming of Pitt and Roberts, it's odd that they are rarely on screen together. Brad shambles around flyblown Mexican pueblos and cantinas in search of the gun as pastiches of Ennio Morricone fill the soundtrack. Meanwhile, Roberts is kidnapped by a gangland enforcer played by The Sopranos' James Gandolfini. And this is Gandolfini's movie all the way. The Mexican came out on Friday and a new season of The Sopranos kicked off on HBO last night, so you could say it's his weekend, too. He has been given equal billing in press stories and ads, and the marketing campaign for The Mexican has an admirable synergy with the blanket coverage that has been granted to the Sopranos.

Gandolfini's work here serves to efface for a moment the image of capo Tony Soprano. He is a curmudgeonly pug who, instead of spilling his guts to Lorraine Bracco's Dr Melfi, becomes Roberts's informal therapist, even as he holds her at gunpoint and ties her to hotel bedposts to stop her escaping. Oh, and he's gay, too, so prepare for your expectations to be defied at every turn.

What makes this rather slight movie so much fun is its gleeful, mordantly satirical take on the romantic cliches of Mexico as a place where the rule of law is replaced by notions of machismo, loyalty and honour, and death is arbitrarily distributed by a vengeful, jealous God. These stereotypes may be under siege in the new Mexico of Vicente Fox and the Zapatistas' Subcomandante Marcos, but the films of Sam Peckinpah and Alex Cox, and the novels of Graham Greene, Malcolm Lowry and Cormac McCarthy, still cast their spell.

The reality of Mexico - a poor, devout country with an oft-betrayed revolutionary tradition and a strong whiff of feudalism, yet no death penalty and the severest imaginable restrictions on gun possession - is often forgotten. The Mexican and a smaller, better movie from last year called La Cucaracha (The Cockroach), starring Eric Roberts, seem determined to highlight both the gringo's befuddled, fearful perspective and the eye-rolling annoyance of Mexicans confronted by people who see them as sombrero-wearing, mescal-fuelled, worm-chewing caricatures. With Traffic and now The Mexican, we are inching closer and closer to a new, potentially more illuminating set of myths and cliches - which is progress of a sort, I suppose.

webTitle: Muslims' kinder way of eating meat

fields.headline: Muslims' kinder way of eating meat
fields.standfirst: While Britain continues its mass cull of livestock, animals in the Middle East are slaughtered by the thousand for very different reasons, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: While Britain continues its mass cull of livestock, animals in the Middle East are slaughtered by the thousand for very different reasons, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Today in the Middle East, several million sheep will be slaughtered. No, this is not another outbreak of foot and mouth disease, it's 'Id al-Adha - the Feast of the Sacrifice.

This festival, the most important in the Muslim calendar marks the end of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. It also commemorates the story - found in Christian and Jewish scripture, too - of how the prophet Abraham was ordered to prove his love for God by sacrificing his son.

Abraham did as God commanded and prepared to kill the son. But once he had demonstrated his faith by the preparations, God spared the boy and allowed Abraham to sacrifice a lamb instead. In the Muslim version of this story the event took place at Mecca, in what is now Saudi Arabia. It was here that Abraham and his son built the Ka'ba - the square stone structure in Mecca which Muslims turn towards when praying.

As a reminder of this, pilgrims to Mecca make their own sacrifice - normally a sheep or a goat - though nowadays they can, if they prefer, simply purchase a certificate showing that an animal has been sacrificed on their behalf. The meat is not wasted, but frozen and shipped off as a gift to poor countries.

Elsewhere in the Muslim world, families gather together for the sacrifice and the meal that follows. It's not unlike the British ritual of the Christmas turkey - except that our turkeys come ready-plucked and gutted in a plastic bag, whereas Muslims usually buy live sheep. Even in some of the major cities, sheep are still bought a few days beforehand and kept in yards or on rooftops, where the children feed them, cuddle them and stare into their soulful eyes.

One year, I spent the 'Id with a Berber family in the Moroccan countryside. On the morning of the sacrifice the eldest son sharpened his knife, took the sheep by its horns, uttered the requisite prayer, and slit its throat. There was a spurt of blood, though less than I had expected. The animal's instinctive reaction was to run away, and for several seconds it struggled violently. Its breathing accelerated as the heart tried to pump more blood, then it slumped amid loud gurgling sounds.

Within a few minutes it was dead and strung up by its hind legs from the ceiling. The son cut a hole in its skin, inserted a wooden pipe and blew. Amazingly, the skin inflated, making it easier to peel off. Two hours later, lunch was served, and I can't say I enjoyed it. It was certainly an odd sensation to know that the food we were eating had, only that morning, been quietly munching straw in a shed.

For several days we ate nothing but lamb. On the third day, the mother set a large covered dish on the table. Lifting the lid with a flourish, she revealed the sheep's steaming head, with its shrunken eyes lying near their sockets. There were delighted cries of "Oooh!" from around the table but my own appetite vanished instantly.

For visiting foreigners, this sort of thing can make 'Id a slightly queasy experience. We are used to hamburgers and other processed meats that often give no hint at all of containing something that once lived.

Even in a butcher's shop, we're shielded from the more gory bits and the actual killing is kept well out of sight in the abattoir. For Muslims, on the other hand, this is just a normal part of life, nature and death. Animals are there to be eaten, provided they are killed in the proper way - so the 'Id is a joyful occasion. It is, in some ways, a more open and honest approach.

Travelling in Syria last week, I found people fascinated and appalled by Europe's foot and mouth crisis, not to mention mad cow disease. The general view was that Syrian farming may be less efficient but it's a lot healthier, because the distance from farm gate to plate is so much shorter. Also in Syria, I met - for the first time - an Arab who claimed to be vegetarian, though on further questioning it turned out that he occasionally eats fish and chicken.

The man, a government official in Damascus, told me that his 70-year-old father, who lives in the countryside, keeps himself fit and healthy on a diet of home-grown vegetables and tobacco which he grows himself and is so pungent that it would make most people choke.

Partly, that is a result of economic necessity. Meat may be desirable, but in poorer parts of the Arab world it's a rare luxury. The average British tourist on a two-week holiday in Tunisia, for instance, consumes as much meat as the average Tunisian eats in several months.

At a traditional Arab meal, eaten with the fingers from a communal dish, it's not polite to make straight for the meat. You're supposed to fill up with bread, rice and vegetables first - thus economising on both money and meat.

But the idea of being vegetarian on principle is totally foreign in the Arab world. Vegetarian tourists who order vegetable couscous in Tunisia or Morocco will find, almost certainly, that it has been cooked in meat stock.

The restaurant owner will assume they have ordered vegetables simply because they're short of money. And he may, if the vegetarians are really unlucky, take pity on them and throw in a few small pieces of meat as a gift.

fields.bodyText: Today in the Middle East, several million sheep will be slaughtered. No, this is not another outbreak of foot and mouth disease, it's 'Id al-Adha - the Feast of the Sacrifice. This festival, the most important in the Muslim calendar marks the end of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. It also commemorates the story - found in Christian and Jewish scripture, too - of how the prophet Abraham was ordered to prove his love for God by sacrificing his son. Abraham did as God commanded and prepared to kill the son. But once he had demonstrated his faith by the preparations, God spared the boy and allowed Abraham to sacrifice a lamb instead. In the Muslim version of this story the event took place at Mecca, in what is now Saudi Arabia. fields.headline: Beware the bedspread-and-pencil brigade
fields.standfirst: Beautiful South editor Daren Paul Wheeler on why a suddenly successful Southampton FC shouldn't forget the folk who kept them going through the dark years
fields.trailText: Beautiful South editor Daren Paul Wheeler on why a suddenly successful Southampton FC shouldn't forget the folk who kept them going through the dark years.
fields.body:
I can remember the day I found God. I wasn't on the road to Damascus, I wasn't one of the apostles and I don't think my name ever appeared in any of the testaments. No, I was at the Dell the day I found God, and he wore a number seven shirt.

It was a cold October night, it wasn't a particularly good game. In fact, despite Saints winning 2-1, they were often under the cosh and were in all honesty the lesser of the two teams. But in two moments of sublime, inspirational skill, the three points floated gently down the road to the FA Points Safe in the basement of the Dell.

Point number one, a pass to Le Tissier, who nonchalantly flicked over not one, but then two defenders, before calmly placing the ball past the oncoming keeper. Pure magic. Newcastle drew level. The game could have gone either way, until a hopeful cross drifted towards the Newcastle penalty box. Le Tissier trapped the ball of his thigh, swivelled and hit the ball on the volley unleashing an unstoppable shot into the top right-hand corner of the net. Truly unbelievable. That was the day I found God. It was a time where quality and style was a lost commodity, where work-rate and long-ball were preferred to skill and the passing game. It was an age of dour, passionless, skill-less, hit-and-hope football. It was a age the history books would eventually call the Branfoot era. But there was one shining light at the end of that tunnel, it was called Matthew Le Tissier.

At a time when Saints fans had very little to be upbeat about, Le Tissier gave the fans something they craved, style and class. In team full of what Mick Channon called "hod carriers and donkeys", Le Tissier stood head, shoulder, arms and elbows above the rest. Despite the fact that the football played at the Dell was so poor that if you called it abysmal, Branfoot and co would probably thank you for the compliment, you could always say that the best goals scored in the Premiership were scored there.

When Branfoot finally got the message and left the club in early 1994, Saints fans were thrilled at the prospect of having Le Tissier linking up with probably the one manager who could get the best out of him, Alan Ball. It was the dream ticket: Alan Ball reunited with Lawrie McMenemy, with probably the most talented player in the country to be given a free reign.

What a glorious time it was too. With Ronnie Ekelund up front with him, the following season Matt produced the best football in his illustrious career scoring thirty goals and creating just as many. To coin a phrase, that year Matt Le Tissier was truly unbelievable.

Alan Ball was to leave the next season, whether the board did enough to keep him or he simply wanted a the next bigger, better deal, who knows. One thing was for certain, that he was the last and only manager who knew how to handle Le Tiss. Dave Merrington promised so much for the Dell faithful, but sadly lacked the know-how or the motivational skills needed to bring the best of Matt. Subsequent managers also failed to find the qualities needed to see the bloody obvious. You give him the ball and let him do his thing. Obvious really.

One of the reasons why Matt struggles for fitness today is down to us, really. There was a time when, if Matt Le Tissier's name wasn't on the team-sheet, it was a portent of doom for all. Many's the time Matt was rushed back to the first team without really having time to get over his injuries. In effect, Matt paid a price for being too damn good.

But we seem to be forgetting one major point in all this. After the summer of Matt, every team wanted him. Chelsea, Tottenham, Liverpool all wanted him. Alex Ferguson was a massive fan of the Channel Islander. After Matt's last game for England against Italy, Ferguson devoted two whole pages in the Manchester United programme singing Le Tissier's praises . Who knows what direction Matt's career might have taken if he'd have played under the Scotsman?

It is, of course, a hypothetical argument, as Matt did what no-one thought a professional footballer would do. He turned down the big money in favour of staying where he was happy. He decided that the quality of his life here in Southampton was more important than doubling his money and moving to a more "glamorous" club. And we loved him for it.

With the end of the last season at the Dell fast approaching, Saints fans are left with the unbelievable prospect of Southampton's favourite son playing football next season for a team other than Saints, and I for one am appalled at the prospect.

But as bad as that may be, it pales into insignificance compared to the reaction of one section of the Southampton fan base, who seem not to care whether he goes or not. The phrases, "He has to play for his money," and, "He's past his prime," seem to come forth from certain quarters, mainly from people who should either (a) know better or (b) have a ridiculously short memory. For, if the truth be told, we owe Matthew Le Tissier far more than we could ever know.

It's hard to be objective at a time like this. A time where Saints are doing very nicely thank you without Matt in the side, a Saints side full of promising youngsters and international squad wannabes. Saints are in a better position than they have been in years, and with that it would seem that people such as Matt and Francis Benali are now forgotten people as the next generation of Saints heroes take the field.

It's easy to do so: Frannie hasn't played first-team football for a while, and Matt has had injury after injury impeding his bid for a first-team place. It would be so easy if they both just disappeared from sight so none of us could make a decision either way when it comes to their futures at the club.

With that in mind, allow me to put my two-penneth worth in. For me, if Benali and Le Tissier are allowed to leave this club, then we might as well pack up our stripes and become Man Utd fans. We might as well succumb to the Man Utd bedspread-and-pencil brigade right now, as it's obvious that we don't have the bottle or the sheer common decency to support a team like Saints.

For me, these two players represent everything good about this club, everything that I love about it. Good, decent men, who have put Southampton Football Club first and their purse strings second. You can say what you want about Matt earning good money anyway, as he could have tripled his money elsewhere. You can forget arguing about Francis Benali's ability, because when the chips were down, he never let his club down, never once flinched in putting himself in the line of fire. I've lost count of the amount of goal line clearances the man has made.

So what is my point exactly? A simple one. These two individuals are without doubt two of the nicest professional footballers you're likely to meet. Two people who are pretty much public property in terms of autograph hunters and fans, yet not once have I seen either of them project anything other than a friendly, approachable one. Two consummate professionals who are superb ambassadors for the club. Yet apparently disposable.

With Matt out of the team and Frannie at Forest, you have to ask yourself what you want out of this club, because make no bones about it, if it wasn't for the likes of these two there would be no Premier League Southampton. We constantly berate Man Utd fans as being soft in the head and valuing trophies more than supporting their local teams, yet once a local icon starts to hit a rough patch it's, "Well thanks a lot Matt, here's your cheque, now piss off to Fulham." Disgraceful. Up there with the Terry Paines, Mick Channons and Ron Davieses, this man is a Southampton legend and we're prepared to shove him in favour of our next Latvian/Moroccan/Norwegian idol.

This club owes both of these two players a huge amount and it's up to the club to get these contracts sorted out. The prospect of casting these two players out like used clothes for the Sally Army is appalling. With the clamour regarding Hassan Kachoul's wage demands, can we please remember one man who asked for little and gave so much. Time is running out. A big testimonial, a new contract and no more division amongst fans in regards to the man. Call me sentimental, but the sun does indeed shine out of his behind

Agree? Disagree? Send your opinions to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk and we'll publish 'em.

webTitle: In brief: Julia and Brad knock Hannibal off top in US

fields.headline: Julia and Brad knock Hannibal off top in US
fields.standfirst: Plus: British film-makers set for budget bonanza; Farrelly brothers to tackle Three Stooges; Nicole Kidman sought for Ned Kelly biopic; Hoffman and Sarandon to co-star
fields.trailText: Plus: British film-makers set for budget bonanza; Farrelly brothers to tackle Three Stooges; Nicole Kidman sought for Ned Kelly biopic; Hoffman and Sarandon to co-star
fields.body:
 The mega-star pairing of Julia Roberts and Brad Pitt in the comedy thriller The Mexican seems to have paid off as it has gone straight to the top at the US box office and taken an estimated $20.3m (£13.82m) over its opening weekend. Described by director Gore Verbinski as "a romantic comedy but with a little bit of Sam Peckinpah," the film also stars Sopranos star James Gandolfini. The canine comedy See Spot Run, starring David Arquette, made a surprisingly strong debut to take the number two position, with Hannibal dropping down to number three.

 The chief political commentator in the Daily Mirror this morning reports that chancellor Gordon Brown looks set to give British film-makers a £40m tax break in Wednesday's budget. Brown apparently wants to make permanent a trial programme of tax breaks which attracted a record £500m investment in UK Films. The system is credited with generating hits like Billy Elliot, Shakespeare in Love and The Full Monty .

 Peter and Bobby Farrelly, the writer-directors behind There's Something About Mary and Dumb & Dumber, are planning to make a film based on the veteran comedy trio, The Three Stooges, according to reports over the weekend. Although the film will not be a remake of any particular Stooges story, the characters will be inspired by the slapstick roles of Larry, Moe and Curly.

 Director Neil Jordan is keen to sign up Brad Pitt and Nicole Kidman for a film version of Peter Carey's bestseller The True Story of Kelly's Gang. The film which depicts the 19th-century bandit of the bush, Ned Kelly, as a Robin Hood-style folk hero who only stole from the rich, is reported to have a $60m (£40m) budget. If Kidman agrees to the role, it will mean she will be reunited with her family while lawyers thrash out a deal for her divorce from Tom Cruise. A senior source told Ananova: "She would love to return down under to film."

 Dustin Hoffman is in final negotiations to star alongside Susan Sarandon in the Walt Disney drama Baby's in Black for City of Angels director Brad Silberling, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Hoffman and Sarandon will play the parents of a young man (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) whose fiancee is killed in a restaurant where she was waiting tables. The film is expected to go into production in April.

webTitle: Brown's proposals herald benefits for charities

fields.headline: Brown's proposals herald benefits for charities
fields.trailText: A raft of pre-election sweetners look set to see charities reaping the rewards
fields.body:
In his pre-Budget report chancellor Gordon Brown said he planned to move forward with the government's three-year spending plans and double public investment.

This will affect many areas of concern to the voluntary sector: including education, health, transport and the environment. Mr Brown pledged to continue cutting debt interest and unemployment, and combine public spending with targeted tax cuts.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations is calling on the government to introduce measures to encourage business to give to charity. Although there has been no official confirmation of this happening, the chancellor is planning to create a better environment for business, which should have a knock on effect for charities.

Mr Brown said in his pre-Budget statement: "I am proposing to encourage entrepreneurship and expand investment."

Another measure that should have an impact on charities is the chancellor's drive to increase personal savings. Long term, this could result in a boost to the income charities receive from legacies.

Many voluntary organisations operating at a regional level will benefit from Mr Brown's aim to give regional development agencies more power.

"To build enterprise and balanced economic development across all the regions, public investment, including public/private partnerships, we are proposing today regional development agencies have greater freedom to decide locally how money is invested to meet local needs."

For charities working with unemployed people, the chancellor has proposed radical reform of tax incentives designed to raise business investment in areas with high unemployment by a billion pounds. He is proposing to introduce stamp duty exemption for all properties in our most disadvantaged communities, accelerated tax relief for cleaning up contaminated land; VAT cuts to reduce the costs of residential property conversions, and tax relief to bring empty flats over shops back into use.

Since the pre-Budget report, Mr Brown has been consulting on a new and generous tax credit for community investment and the creation of the first community development venture fund. These should benefit voluntary organisations working at a local level if they are confirmed in next week's Budget.

For charities working overseas the chancellor said: "We will not only continue to work for cuts in third world debt but now plan to do more to meet the international targets of cutting world poverty by half and cut by two-thirds infant mortality, which through preventible diseases carries off one in seven of the world's children before the age of five."

Mr Brown may announce a new tax incentive and spending measures to develop, cut the costs of production and ensure the supply of anti-tuberculosis, anti-malaria and anti-Aids drugs in poor countries.

In a further boost for charities working with the unemployed including disabled people, the chancellor plans to:

 Intensify coaching help for the 50,000 young people still out of work;
 Consult on introducing a new service that will help redundant workers move quickly into new jobs;
 Investigate how with tax-free and in some cases free adult learning the government can help upgrade fast changing workforce skills;
 Extend the New Deal for lone parents with the government's nationwide programme of choices starting next April and extend to a further 150,000 lone parents not on income support the opportunity to get back to work;
 Agree a new partnership with the voluntary sector to help those with disabilities who want work to get it;
 For each area drawing up local full employment plans addressing all barriers to full employment in local areas.

Environmental charities will be encouraged by the chancellor's plans to cut the excise duty for ultra low sulphur petrol so it replaces unleaded petrol in every petrol station in Britain and at a lower excise duty.

fields.headline: Canadian firm cashes in on tobacco legislation
fields.trailText:
11.30am: A Quebec-based company is to bring its decorative cigarette packet covers to Europe, reports Julia Day.
Mar 1: EU plans fresh curbs on tobacco merchandising
Feb 15: Clampdown on e-marketing loopholes in tobacco bill
Jan 24: Government urged to stop 'invisible' marketing of cigarettes
fields.body:
Pictures of cancer-ridden lungs on cigarette packets - to be allowed under new EU legislation - are set to spawn a new product category: cigarette packet covers.

A Canadian company is planning to bring its cardboard covers, which can be slipped over a packet of cigarettes, to Europe in the light of the new rules on marketing tobacco.

The manufacturers hope to cash in on smokers' embarrassment at being faced with horrifying images every time they light up.

The covers, which cost about 40p, carry pictures such as a skull and crossbones, sunflowers, tattoos or cannabis leaves.

One has a smiley face and the caption, "It's cool".

Quebec-based company Cigarette Cover launched the disposable covers in response to Canadian laws to boost the size of the health warnings - including images - that appear on cigarette packets.

In the EU, from 2003, health warnings must cover 30% of a packet and individual countries can decide whether to introduce pictorial warnings.

Cigarette Cover spokesman Luc Renaud said the company had plans to introduce the covers in Europe and elsewhere.

"We are planning to launch our covers internationally," he said. "We are just starting to manufacture a new size of cover for packs of 20 cigarettes because in Canada we have packs of 25.

"The new size could be used in Europe," he explained.

The covers are distributed by Quebec magazine distributor Benjamin News, which delivers to 10,000 stores.

In the past month, it has distributed 900 racks containing 144 covers per rack.

Benjamin News distribution manager Marie Labrecques said: "Sales are amazing - a lot better than we expected - and there is demand from all over Canada. This is a new product category."

Three or four other companies are manufacturing similar covers.

UK anti-smoking group Action on Smoking and Health spokeswoman Amanda Sandford said: "These covers show that the health warnings are effective.

"As the smokers themselves have reported, they are put off by grisly images.

"I don't think it will negate the graphic warnings - on the contrary, the publicity around it will raise awareness even more," she said.

www.cigarettecover.com

webTitle: Priceline hires Mills as marketing chief

fields.headline: Priceline hires Mills as marketing chief
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The man behind the Spice Girls' Pepsi promo is to be marketing chief of Priceline, the US answer to Lastminute.com. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
The man responsible for hiring the Spice Girls to promote Pepsi is to be the new marketing chief of Priceline, the US answer to Lastminute.com.

Former Pepsi International marketing director Soren Mills joins Priceline Europe as vice-president marketing, responsible for implementing pan-European marketing and promotional campaigns.

Lowe Lintas and online marketing agency Organic were appointed last November to launch a £2m advertising campaign in the UK.

Priceline allows internet users to name their own price for goods and services including airline tickets, hotel rooms and car hire, taking advantage of companies' unsold inventory.

American Mr Mills first came to the UK in 1994 as marketing manager for Walkers and Pepsi UK before being promoted to Pepsi International as marketing director - Europe and Africa

He led Pepsi's return to global music promotions including the Spice Girls tie-in.

Returning to the US, Mr Mills worked for e-commerce company PacificCoast.com and small business e-marketplace Onvia.com during the company's floatation on Nasdaq. In London last year he led Onvia.com's European launch.

Priceline Europe is a private company, backed by priceline.com and private equity firm General Atlantic Partners.

webTitle: You can't please all of the women all of the time

fields.headline: You can't please all of the women all of the time
fields.standfirst: If Glamour is to survive in the very crowded market of women's glossies, it must make up its mind about exactly who it's aimed at - and stick to it - warns  Hadley Freeman
fields.trailText: If Glamour is to survive in the very crowded market of women's glossies, it must make up its mind about exactly who it's aimed at - and stick to it - warns Hadley Freeman
fields.body:
Minx. Frank. Those are just two words that Nicholas Coleridge will not want to hear this week, for they were two women's magazines which, although laudable in many ways, failed to survive today's almost impossibly cutthroat publishing market. A few other dreaded words are: "What, another women's magazine?", a question he and the rest of Condé Nast have heard several times in the past few months, and one they have probably asked themselves a couple of times as well. Adding to the gloom caused by the deaths of Frank and Minx, the latest six-monthly average sales figures show declines for almost every women's magazine.

Yet just two weeks after the launch of InStyle UK, here comes Glamour. There is undoubtedly a kind of competition going on here between publishing houses, Time-Life and Condé Nast, but, looking at the women's magazine market today, are they running a futile lose-lose race?

Coleridge is quite right when he describes Glamour as one of the most successful women's magazines in the United States. But it has always been more like the wallpaper in the US magazine world than an essential piece of furniture: it's there, it's nice, readers appreciate it as a piece of decor, but it has never felt essential. It has not achieved central cult status in the way that magazines such as Cosmopolitan or Vogue have, which probably explains why few British readers have heard of it before. Yet its impressive circulation figures are a testament to Glamour's very simple formula: it wants to make its readers feel good. Whereas the far more elitist Vogue is about people who are more in vogue than you are, Glamour's potentially equally elitist title is simply about making its readers feel glamorous.

Preppy, sunny, girlish smiles radiate from every one of its pages. In this month's issue there are features on what your man loves about your body, how to have more confidence in bed, stilettos that won't hurt your feet and "I Nailed My Rapist". So far, so happy. There is none of that body fascism or other similar feel-bad features ("Lose five inches off your thighs - IN TEN MINUTES!!!") so beloved of other women's magazines, particularly American ones. The usual effortlessly readable quizzes and surveys abound, as do their fashion equivalents, photo-spreads of this month's accessories and make-up.

There is a relaxed mix of the silly and the serious (on one page, a feature on how to dye your pubic hair rests unapologetically above a piece on fertility myths), so unlike Marie Claire, for example, which cordons off its "healthy" features (death in Rwanda, biographies of forgotten artists, etc) from its more indulgent spreads, like a clucking mother making you eat your broccoli before you can start on dessert.

Condé Nast is clearly, and understandably, a little nervous about launching its baby into such an unstable market, as is apparent in this gimmick of making the magazine pocketbook size. It is unlikely that this will be a big plus to potential readers, and I'd be surprised if it stays that size for more than six months. However, it will give Glamour a stand-out identity amid the sea of other competing women's titles. The real test, as ever, will lie in the way the magazine targets its readers.

The reason so many British women's glossy magazines fail is because they try to appeal to as many as women as possible, across the age and social brackets. The result is a magazine that does not seem to be aimed at any one person in particular, one that falls back on Ally McBeal (the so-called Everywoman of television, although many would beg to differ) cliches and fashion shoots that appeal to no one - too dowdy for the under 35s, too bright for the older age brackets.

American women's magazines are able to avoid this, partly because they have a larger market and thus have the confidence to target certain pockets, rather than trying to cast too wide a net, and therefore garner more readers in specific age brackets than less-focused magazines do from across the spectra.

Cliched, All-Bar-One images of young women abound in British Glamour's press release ("Flat- sharing urbanites who work to live and love fashion, friends and the famous"), but generalisations are the grist of such publicity announcements; let's just hope they are not translated into editorial content.

American Glamour is unashamedly fun, without resorting to too much fluffy ditziness, or ever feeling the need to justify itself, or trying to be too inclusive to too many readers. British Glamour will need to have similar confidence if it still wants to be on UK newsagents' shelves in 12 months' time.

webTitle: 'Good care for the elderly does not come cheap'

fields.headline: 'Good care for the elderly does not come cheap'
fields.trailText: Analysis: Nadra Ahmed has come to London with grim determination. She's worried about the future of her residential home. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
Nadra Ahmed has come to London with grim determination. She's worried about the future of her residential home, Headcorn Hall in Kent. She won't talk about closures - she points out that any bad news would affect her residents - but she does talk obliquely about "diversifying".

"I need to look at diversifying, which is heartbreaking, as I've worked for 20 years with the elderly," she said.

She is joining up to 1,000 other residential and nursing care home owners, members of the National Care Home Association (NCHA), on a parliamentary lobby. The association says its members' businesses are going to the wall.

Currently, Ms Ahmed's business offers a home to 19 elderly residents, all over 65. And she claims it's a good example of the high-quality end of the residential care market. "We have Investors in People, which is a nationally accredited system of acknowledging training and staffing needs, and we meet all the contract compliance requirements of council."

For Ms Ahmed, there is big pressure looming in the form of new government standards covering matters such as the amount of space each resident must have and staff training. "I have to look very carefully at where I can make more beds to make it viable. We will lose two beds under the new standards, so, unless we have the money to invest, that's an issue."

There are other problems, too - nowadays, residents are older and more frail than a decade or two ago, thanks in part to people living longer and the trend towards supporting people in their own homes. Good care for the frail elderly doesn't come cheap, says Ms Ahmed.

Her worry is that "big conglomerates" will be able to make economies of scale and "sweep up the market". Meanwhile, small, local homes will go bust. "The funding of the beds in the smaller units is becoming acute," she said. The result, she believes, will be large, 60-bed homes, akin to the old long-stay geriatric wards that were shut under community care policies. "The small units are the ones that will be destabilised, and residents will suffer as they're moved around and homes close."

But the issue that has been making care home owners angry for some time is the fees they receive from local authorities. The state - local and central - funds something like seven in 10 of residential and nursing care home places. That, argue the owners, puts councils in an enviable position when it comes to determining the amount they will pay for places.

"Local authorities, as a 70% purchaser don't really enter into negotiations, so home owners have to take it or leave it," said Sheila Scott, chief executive of the National Care Homes Association.

Ms Ahmed said: "At my home, we get approximately £240 per person per week. When you look at the impact of the minimum wage and working time regulations, that's put around £6,000 on my wages' bill in a year. But the income has not gone up. Local authority funding is going up by around 2%."

Because care homes are short of money, it's hard for them to recruit nurses and other care staff, they argue.

And they are in a competitive market. Ms Ahmed has higher paying shopping malls and supermarkets on her doorstep. "A new Sainsbury's opened up paying £5.50 an hour and we struggle at £4.60 an hour. It doesn't take a mathematician to work out the figures don't add up."

Unison national social services officer Owen Davies agreed: "If we are really going to raise standards, then the people who work in homes are going to have to be paid greatly improved wage levels."

However, there's a sense that care home owners have only themselves to blame. "Unison's experience was that, when old people's homes were privatised, the people who ran them put in very low bids in order to win business away from local government and were forced, as a result, to pay very low wages to their employees."

Unison doesn't dispute there's a crisis, however. "There's no doubt that the result of the privatisation of the care of old people has now led to a crisis and it's also obviously the case that more public money needs to be invested in the care of our old people," said Mr Davies.

But the union's solution is a different one from Ms Ahmed's. Mr Owen said: "There are a lot of elderly people who cannot pay for their care and we, as a society, have to pay that. But the best way is through council-run homes or support in their own homes."

webTitle: Care home owners lobby for more cash

fields.headline: Care home owners lobby for more cash
fields.trailText: Care home owners have called on the government for extra money to head off a "growing funding crisis" and have asked for an extra £50 per resident per week.Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
Care home owners have called on the government for extra money to head off a "growing funding crisis".

The National Care Homes Association (NCHA), which will lobby parliament today, wants the government to stump up an extra £50 per resident per week. It wants central government to ensure that extra money ends up in the care homes' coffers - either through ringfencing or paying service users directly.

Residential and nursing home owners are complaining that homes are going out of business, in part because local authorities are squeezing the fees they pay for places. In 1999, there were 800 home closures and 15,000 beds lost.

"The government says it gives increases to local government to fund care - local government says it doesn't have enough money. No one's taking responsibility," said NCHA chief executive Sheila Scott.

Around 70% of all nursing and care home residents are state funded. As a major purchaser, councils tend impose prices rather than negotiate, claims the NCHA. "The fee levels are being kept artificially low by local government - they don't even keep up with inflation," said Ms Scott.

The campaigners also claim that new standards for care homes, covering the physical environment and training and staffing levels will just add to the financial burden. Last Friday, the government published national minimum standards as part of the implementation of the Care Standards Act.

"We are very aware of, and are listening to, the views of the care home sector," said a spokeswoman for the Department of Health.

The new standards gave providers "a reasonable time to adapt", she said. "In particular, changes to the physical environment of existing care homes will not take effect until 2007 and will not apply on the sale or transfer of an existing home to a new owner during the transitional period 2002 to 2007."

Care home owners would also be involved helping local authorities determine what nursing and residential beds might be required in future, she said.

Moreover, funding had increased by 12% in real terms since 1997. But, she added: "It is for care home owners and local councils to agree on the appropriate fee levels for services provided."

No one's taking responsibility," said NCHA chief executive Sheila Scott. Around 70% of all nursing and care home residents are state funded. As a major purchaser, councils tend impose prices rather than negotiate, claims the NCHA. "The fee levels are being kept artificially low by local government - they don't even keep up with inflation," said Ms Scott. The campaigners also claim that new standards for care homes, covering the physical environment and training and staffing levels will just add to the financial burden. Last Friday, the government published national minimum standards as part of the implementation of the Care Standards Act. "We are very aware of, and are listening to, the views of the care home sector," said a spokeswoman for the Department of Health. The new standards gave providers "a reasonable time to adapt", she said. "In particular, changes to the physical environment of existing care homes will not take effect until 2007 and will not apply on the sale or transfer of an existing home to a new owner during the transitional period 2002 to 2007." Care home owners would also be involved helping local authorities determine what nursing and residential beds might be required in future, she said. Moreover, funding had increased by 12% in real terms since 1997. But, she added: "It is for care home owners and local councils to agree on the appropriate fee levels for services provided."

webTitle: New bridge in Australia opens old wounds

fields.headline: New bridge in Australia opens old wounds
fields.standfirst: The opening of a bridge in south Australia has reignited a 10-year conflict between Aborigines, white Australians and academics, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The opening of a bridge in south Australia has reignited a 10-year conflict between Aborigines, white Australians and academics, writes Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
A group of 100 Aborigines and their supporters stood in silent protest as several thousand people streamed across a new bridge in south Australia yesterday.

The local Ngarrindjeri people said the official opening of Hindmarsh Island bridge was a giant step back for the reconciliation of black and white Australia. The bitter, 10-year battle of the bridge has belittled Aboriginal spirituality, almost bankrupted developers and ruined the careers of academics and politicians.

The bridge was first mooted back in the late 80s to connect Hindmarsh, a small island at the mouth of the Murray River, 50 miles south of Adelaide, to the Australian mainland. White developers and the owners of a marina stood to make huge profits from it.

A group of Aborigines led protests against the bridge and in 1994 the federal government stepped in and banned its construction for 25 years under a law to protect Aboriginal heritage, declaring that the bridge threatened to desecrate a significant indigenous site. The marina went into receivership.

A group of anthropologists collected crucial evidence to stop the bridge's construction from a group of Ngarrindjeri women who said the bridge violated "secret women's business". Many Aboriginal groups use the terms "men's business" and "women's business" to denote their spiritual activities.

Hindmarsh Island, they argued, was a sacred Aboriginal site and to reveal its secrets would be traumatic and damaging. Robert Tickner, the Labor minister for Aboriginal affairs, respected these wishes and stopped the bridge being built without opening two envelopes of evidence listing the "secret women's business", which were meant to be read by women only.

Then the whispers started. Other Ngarrindjeri men and women said there was no such thing as "secret women's business" on the island. Dissenting anthropologists argued that the Ngarrindjeri were characterised by an absence of such spiritual practices. The Labor foreign minister at the time, Gareth Evans, privately called the secret women's business "bullshit on stilts".

Two years later, a federal court overturned the ban on the bridge. A royal commission ruled that the "secret women's business" at Hindmarsh was a fabrication. In a scathing judgment, the commissioner said Aboriginal women had been encouraged to invent it by sympathetic feminist anthropologists, part of a large, politically correct lobby against the bridge.

One anthropologist in particular, Dr Lindy Warrell, was reported to have said to the Aboriginal women: "It would be nice if there was some women's business." Dr Warrell later claimed she had been misrepresented, but the phrase stuck and one sceptical journalist wrote a book with her comment as his title.

Most of Australia's press heralded the verdict, along with the developers. It was a vindication of transparent and rational western law, they argued, a victory for progress, and a damning indictment of gullible and self-interested academics.

Many anthropologists hit back. The divisions among the Ngarrindjeri over the truth of the "women's business" did not necessarily affect its credibility, they argued, just as in western societies not everyone believes in god and those excluded from secret belief systems may refute their existence.

Australian law, they also pointed out, has often failed to account for the importance of Aborigines' oral traditions in assessing land disputes. One internationally renowned anthropologist, Diane Bell, wrote an award-winning account of the controversy, citing new evidence unavailable to the royal commission who supported the Ngarrindjeri's oral evidence that the island was a sacred site.

But the bridge got built, and the scars from the battle still remain. Doris Kartinyeri, the younger sister of the Ngarrindjeri custodian of the secret women's business, believes her current sickness is some kind of punishment for the exposure of too many of the women's secrets.

Plots of land are now making hefty profits for private developers, thanks to improved access created by the publicly funded bridge (which ballooned in cost to more than $A30m). Hindmarsh's developers, who nearly went bankrupt when construction was delayed, are currently seeking a further windfall by suing the former Aboriginal affairs minister and academics for more than $A20m in damages.

After the ban on the bridge was lifted, one of the developers, Wendy Chapman, said: "Give us back our possessions, give us back control of our destiny and allow us to get on with the development." They got back what they claimed they owned, unlike the group of Ngarrindjeri women.
