fields.headline: Von Mensch und Mais
fields.standfirst: The recent discovery that humans  possess the same number of genes as sweetcorn has been a surprise to many. Nichole Prestle asks what young people think
fields.trailText: The recent discovery that humans possess the same number of genes as sweetcorn has been a surprise to many. Nichole Prestle asks what young people think
fields.body:
Der Mensch, die Krone der Schöpfung. Was haben wir uns immer darauf eingebildet, die am weitesten entwickelte Spezies zu sein. Und jetzt das: Nur 30.000 Gene bestimmen über unser Aussehen, über unseren Körper, seine Krankheiten, seine Eigenheiten. 30.000 Gene. Das sind gerade mal doppelt so viele wie die einer Fruchtfliege. Und wenn man uns - genetisch gesehen - auf eine Ebene mit Gemüse stellen will, dann ist der Vergleich mit Mais angebracht. Der hat nämlich genau so viele Gene wie der Mensch.

Zwei unabhängige wissenschaftliche Teams haben in den vergangenen Wochen die Ergebnisse ihrer Forschungen veröffentlicht. Und wer bisher dachte, der Mensch sei allen anderen Lebewesen nur deshalb überlegen, weil er viel mehr Gene hat als sie, der wird bitter enttäuscht sein.

Und dennoch: Die Forschungsergebnisse haben die Wissenschaft vorangebracht. Ist der genetische Code erst entschlüsselt, könnten Krankheiten geheilt oder sogar vermieden werden. Doch für euphorische Zukunftsplanungen ist es, warnen Wissenschaftler, bei weitem zu früh. Es könnte Jahrzehnte dauern, bis das Rätsel um das Zusammenspiel der genetischen Bausteine gelüftet ist. Besteht dennoch Hoffnung auf ein Leben ohne Krankheiten? Und wenn ja: Wie weit dürfen Wissenschaftler gehen, um einen für immer gesunden Menschen zu "schaffen"?

30.000 Gene machen einen Menschen aus. Rund 70.000 weniger, als man bisher angenommen hatte. Hat euch dieses Forschungsergebnis überrascht?

Michael (19) : Bis ich von dem Ergebnis gehört habe, hatte ich mir eigentlich nie Gedanken gemacht, wie viele Gene ein Mensch haben könnte. Ist ja eigentlich auch egal, wenn alles funktioniert, oder?

Martina (17) : Wir haben uns in Biologie darüber unterhalten. Eigentlich war aber niemand geschockt, dass der Mensch "nur" aus 30.000 Genen besteht. Was soll auch diese Rechnerei. Wir wissen ja, was Menschen können und wie sie aussehen.

Mirjam (15) : Geschockt nicht. Ich fand es eher witzig. Da bildet man sich immer ein, so etwas besonderes zu sein. Und dann erfährt man auf einmal, dass Mais uns rein von der Anzahl der Gene her in nichts nachsteht.

Ist das menschliche Erbgut erst entschlüsselt, könnten Krankheiten geheilt, besser erkannt oder sogar vermieden werden...

Anton (16) : Das mag schon sein. Ich glaube aber, dass es noch lange dauern wird, bis man tatsächlich alle Kräfte, die im Körper zusammenspielen, richtig einordnen kann. Wahrscheinlich wird nicht einmal mehr meine Generation davon profitieren.

Mirjam: Ich stelle mir das gigantisch vor, ein Leben ohne Krankheiten... Man muss aber auch daran denken, dass es immer noch Krankheiten gibt, die nicht vom Erbmaterial abhängen. Ganz ohne gesundheitliche Probleme wird der Mensch also wohl nie leben können.

Seht ihr Gefahren auf die Menschheit zukommen, wenn erst alle Geheimnisse des Erbmaterials erforscht sind?

Martina: Ehrlich gesagt: Ja. Ich habe ein bisschen Angst davor, dass man sich den perfekten Menschen züchten will, dass Mütter Kinder abtreiben, nur weil sie vorher wissen, dass sie krank sein werden. Ich denke, man sollte der Natur in gewissen Dingen ihren Lauf lassen, sich nicht überall einmischen.

Anton: Der Mensch ist doch gebildet genug, um mit diesem Wissen umzugehen. Es wird mit Sicherheit keine Auswahl der Stärksten, Gesündesten und Schönsten geben. Diese Wahnvorstellungen hatten wir schon einmal in Deutschland und wir haben gesehen, wo sie hinführen können. Ich bin mir sicher, dass wir daraus gelernt haben.

Michael: Vielleicht wird das Gesetz Vorschriften machen müssen, wann und wie wir unser Wissen einsetzen dürfen. Wenn einem Menschen geholfen werden könnte, weil man Gene sozusagen "reparieren" kann, fände ich das in Ordnung. Wenn man aber Lebewesen klont, sie also als Ersatzteillager züchtet, um anderen zu helfen, widerspricht das meinen moralischen Vorstellungen.
Mirjam: Diese Gefahr sehe ich bereits viel früher und in einem anderen Punkt: Das "Wettrüsten" zwischen den einzelnen Forschungsteams hat doch bereits begonnen. Wer hat die besseren Ergebnisse, wer kann das Erbmaterial schneller entschlüsseln. Ich finde, in solch wichtigen Dingen sollten alle zusammenarbeiten und sich nicht gegenseitig ausboten.

angebracht sein reasonable, advisable

sich gegenseitig ausboten to play one (person, team) off against another

sich etw. einbilden to be conceited

einsetzen to use sth. (eg knowledge)

entschlüsseln to decipher, decode

enttäuscht sein to be disappointed

die Schöpfung creation

die Wahnvorstellung illusion, mania

fields.headline: Monday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are backing William Hague to preserve the best of British
fields.trailText: John Gregory has admitted his job at Aston Villa is not safe. Villa are 15th in the Premiership and Gregory tells the Mirror: "Let's face it - that's exactly where we were when I took over three years ago. The one lesson we can learn from history is that no manager can survive purely on past deeds."
fields.body:
John Gregory has admitted his job at Aston Villa is not safe. Villa are 15th in the Premiership and Gregory tells the Mirror: "Let's face it - that's exactly where we were when I took over three years ago. The one lesson we can learn from history is that no manager can survive purely on past deeds."

Another day, another potential new home for Sol Campbell. The Mirror believes that Liverpool are favourites to sign the Spurs captain, with a contract offer worth £100,000-a-week to the England man.

Tottenham are keeping an eye on the best-named Dutch striker ever. Jan Vennegoor of Hesselink has scored 13 goals for FC Twente this season, and was watched by George Graham this weekend according to Teamtalk. The Dutch international would cost Spurs around £5m.

Ruud van Nistelrooy made his return for PSV Eindhoven this weekend, according to the Sun, and his move to Manchester United could now be back on. According to van Nistelrooy's agent Rodger Lindse: "It was like he had never been out when he played again. The situation can now be changed if there is initiative from Manchester United."

Dean Windass will complete a £1m move from Bradford to Middlesbrough today. "I told Dean about the offer and he said he wanted to leave," Bradford boss Jim Jefferies admitted. "It is a chance for him to earn a big contract and even though I don't want to sell him, I can't stand in his way."

Arsenal have stepped up their interest in Hertha Berlin's Marko Rehmer. The Daily Mail reports that the Gunners want to tie up a £5m move by the end of the week.

Chelsea have played down reports suggesting they are looking to sign Pavel Nedved and Marcelo Salas from Lazio this summer. "We are always interested in quality players," said managing director Colin Hutchinson. "But clubs are not going to get too interested in deals when they are still fighting for honours."

fields.headline: Vying for VIPs
fields.standfirst: Last week, ITV claimed it was attracting more upmarket viewers than BBC1. But trends in TV viewing are never as simple as we are led to believe, says  Maggie Brown
fields.trailText: Last week, ITV claimed it was attracting more upmarket viewers than BBC1. But trends in TV viewing are never as simple as we are led to believe, says Maggie Brown
fields.body:
A private cinema in Soho, a smattering of celebrities and a clutch of cooing publicists - yes, another TV drama launch. But the benign smiles of Ricky Tomlinson masked behind-the-scenes tension: the BBC drama ship is in trouble, and there are fears that the new series of Clocking Off will not be enough to save it.

Series one of the Paul Abbott drama was one of BBC1's most successful Sunday night hits last year, achieving the key combination of critical acclaim and popular success, with up to 11m viewers.

Series two was due to start on Sunday, but a debate, as yet unresolved, is raging at BBC1 about where to place the seven-parter. The BBC is getting a hammering on Sundays, and executives feel Clocking Off could follow Rebel Heart and Take a Girl Like You down the ratings plughole. They want to move it from the killing fields to somewhere safer.

Abbott said he and the producer, Nicola Shindler, discussed the BBC's plans, but had reservations. "We felt the audience would stick with it on a Sunday. But they still might move it."

The Sunday night ratings slaughter has shaken BBC drama. Since the autumn, BBC1's average audience share has fallen to 26.1% from 28.3%. Its prize post-9pm Sunday night dramas have been mown down, one after another, by a lethal mix of long-running stock ITV series, such as Heartbeat and London's Burning, and two-part specials, such as The Innocent. Ambitious, expensive pieces such as Take a Girl Like You, Rebel Heart, Love in a Cold Climate and now, most recently and shockingly, Best of Both Worlds, the contemporary drama about an air hostess's bigamy, have all fared badly.

The BBC1 tradition of classic drama on Sunday nights is going up in smoke. Abbott, who wrote Best of Both Worlds, is used to success - his previous work includes Cracker, Reckless and Touching Evil - so he found the 21% share gained by the second episode sobering. "Yeah, we didn't pull the audience in. And it wasn't for lack of press coverage, we got loads." He suggests that Alice Evans, who played the lead, was not a familiar face, and that too much comedy was edited out.

Perhaps audiences are getting lazier, refusing to commit time to unknown properties. "I don't know what the answer is," Abbott says. "The BBC may have lost its way over the years, so they've got to do a very strong climb back. But it hard to see, when you're not bringing the audience to you, how you're going to effect that. To reclaim Sunday nights they'll have to throw bigger and bigger stuff at it. Over the years, the BBC must have let that go. I'm sure the new team will pull that audience back. But they've got to hit higher: Take a Girl Like You - my dad wouldn't watch it. It appeals to a very specialised audience."

But ITV has been "very consistent in plying its two-part trade," says Abbott, in a reference to the special dramas that break up the standard fare of Heartbeat and Peak Practice and, crucially, attract upmarket viewers. "Fragile Heart - superb; The Innocent - fantastic. They've upped the stakes. ITV audiences know what to expect."

BBC1's Sunday night dilemma is just part of the ongoing problems facing the channel's new-ish controller, Lorraine Heggessey. Heavily promoted comedies such as Office Gossip and Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years have flopped in her new Friday night comedy zone.

The issue, say her supporters, is how to identify programmes and ideas which retain BBC1's diverse mix, have an inclusive, collective spirit, but also respond to a big cultural shift among audiences, who seem to prefer the predictable.

A BBC insider blames the current poor showing on decisions taken before Heggessey took up her post. "It stems back to two years ago, when, in a state of angst the BBC said, 'Let's take a risk, go with the creative people and give them leeway.' But they are coming back with programmes that are not ideal, there's been no reality check. Lorraine has inherited a lot of wrong programmes, nor are they the right length now that the news has moved. It will be autumn before the new stuff starts feeding through."

The BBC's preoccupations may explain its failure to rebut last week's reports that ITV is usurping Auntie's natural heartland and gaining more upmarket and younger viewers.

ITV's figures were questionable, because they excluded the GMTV effect - the breakfast broadcaster attracts a more downmarket audience profile. A cynic might also suggest that, with Carlton last week confirming TV advertising revenue is down by about 5%, talking up the value of your audiences makes perfect business sense.

The truth is that the BBC is more in sync with the nation's white-collar, middle-class social make up. But the trend is interesting: ITV is closing the gap by selectively targeting ABC1s, while benefiting from what researchers identify as a general easing of middle-class snobbery towards entertainment TV.

The research consultant Colin Macleod says, "ITV is probably better at promotion of its programmes, and at cross marketing. But that apart, tastes are dumbing down, upmarket people want to be entertained with stuff that's not too demanding or too provocative, that is simple to absorb, and which they don't have to work too hard to take in. That is different from 10 years ago."

The main channels agree that viewers are increasingly unwilling to try out unfamiliar programmes with unfamiliar faces - the BBC's Sunday night problem affects them all to a greater or lesser extent.

ITV, in any case, must move with the times to keep the advertisers happy. The population, as defined by the audience researchers Barb, is now composed of 45% ABC1s, compared with 32% in 1980. This is a massive shift for a medium which has always appealed to most of the poorer, older, less mobile groups. BBC1 remains most upmarket, with 45.8% of its audience classified as ABC1, with Channel 4 next at 44.6% then BBC2 at 44%. ITV, at 38%, still trails. But it is moving up, albeit slowly, by one percentage point a year.

It is a BBC1 programme, EastEnders, which perfectly encapsulates a mass market channel's aims: 45% of its audience is ABC1, exactly matching the social map of Britain, which makes the decision to show a fourth episode entirely understandable.

BBC1's disappointment over the flop of so many expensive, hand crafted dramas is shared by Channel 4's disppointment over the poor showing last year for its lengthy legal drama series, North Square: only three dramas, Queer as Folk, Kid in the Corner and Never Never really gained impact and attention in the past year.

But ITV is proving, through a clearly devised strategy, that it can supplement a strong basic raft of mass-market programmes with premium plums. Channel 4 snorts with derision, however, at ITV's claim to be plundering its hold on prized younger adults: ITV's share of under 34s is reported by Channel 4 to be down 5% year on year.

ITV demonstrates that it pays to target certain groups with programmes which gain a more upmarket profile: A Touch of Frost gained a 48% share of ABC1s, The Innocent 41%. Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? gained 42% share of 16 to 34 year olds; Popstars got 50%, Tarrant on TV 46%, Blind Date 45%, SMtv/CDUK 48%, An Audience with Ricky Martin 48%. Yet the evidence that differences are eroding, that "upmarket" and "downmarket" people watch the same programmes as everyone else, is not conclusive.

True, last Friday a group of media companies unveiled research into the media habits of "VIP-ers" - members of the elite AB social groups - to see what motivates them to switch on. Watching TV is their favourite way to de-stress: 22% turn on the TV every day with this in mind, compared with 13% who read and 8% who listen to music. It bears out the view that television is there principally to entertain and keep them up to date.

Yet at the same time Channel 4 has found that top social groups specifically seek out its programmes: Channel 4 News attracts a 55% ABC1 audience, up from 52% last year. The Kama Sutra got 54% of ABC1s, The 1940s House got 53%, and The Real Stephen Hawking scored 56%. A consumer study by Carat Insight does not overturn the view that we are all Millionaire watchers now, but it does suggest that differences persist some of the time and that news and information do matter.

For ABC1s, 14 of their favourite programmes are on BBC1, three on ITV, three on Channel 4 and none on Channel 5 - the performer with the most upmarket appeal would seem to be Rory Bremner. For the bottom social groups, D and E, only two programmes are on BBC1, nine are on ITV, four on Channel 4 and five Channel 5. Their heroes are Jim Davidson and Michael Barrymore.

Trends in television, as in life, are never as simple as we're led to believe.

fields.headline: The learning curve
fields.standfirst: At launch, Network of the World was trumpeted as a global interactive TV and web player, but since then this most ambitious of dot.com enterprises is finding you can't rely on the web alone to make money.  Jason Deans  reports
fields.trailText: At launch, Network of the World was trumpeted as a global interactive TV and web player, but since then this most ambitious of dot.com enterprises is finding you can't rely on the web alone to make money. Jason Deans reports
fields.body:
These are dark days in the new media world, with dot.gone burnouts and fatalities virtually every week. But while the general picture across the sector is one of gloom and financial failure, at London-based internet and TV convergence outfit Network of the World (NOW), one of the most ambitious dot.com enterprises, the emphasis is very much on business as usual.

NOW launched last June, offering five themed web portals alongside a TV channel, based around the same five content genres, which is beamed to 130m homes in Asia via satellite and is available as a streamed video service to internet users elsewhere.

The operation is a joint venture between Trans World International (TWI) and Pacific Century Cyber Works (PCCW). TWI, the TV rights management and production arm of sports marketing giant IMG, provides the content; and PCCW, founded by Hong Kong new media mogul Richard Li, brings the cash.

When NOW launched, there was a considerable fanfare about the project's ambition to become a global interactive TV and web entertainment player once broadband arrived, and about the $1.5bn Li planned to invest in the service over five years.

Then, towards the end of last year, PCCW ran into financial difficulties. The global sell-off of technology stocks, along with concerns about the level of debt Li took on to buy Hong Kong Telecom, began to bite. PCCW's Hong Kong-listed share price collapsed.

In October PCCW announced a $200m annual cap on its investment in all narrowband and broadband pro jects, including NOW, until market conditions improved. Then last month the firm announced it was axing 30 of the 50 London-based staff working on NOW. Following these developments, all eyes have been on NOW, to see if the reversal in PCCW's fortunes would hit the service and its content production operation, which is run by TWI.

However, NOW head of service Rick Thomas is keen to stress that no redundancies are planned among the 400-odd content staff he oversees, and that work is continuing on developing and improving the offering. "TWI has an agreement with PCCW to produce content that runs for some years and that has not been affected at the moment," says Thomas, who continues to executive produce TV shows for TWI, in addition to his NOW role. "We're here and we're carrying on."

The business-as-usual line is reinforced by deputy head of service Patrick Walker, who was working in Asia as a BBC journalist before joining NOW. "What's been going on at PCCW is just the reality of the market right now," he says. "They have given figures for what they're willing to commit on an annual basis and Richard Li is still very committed to the business-to-consumer side of the business."

Thomas adds that he has always been working to a timetable that assumed an 18-month period after the June 2000 soft launch to develop NOW and roll it out globally, before moving to a hard launch. This is still the goal.

NOW's other deputy head of service, Sarah Hicks, says one priority in the first six months since the service went live has been building the infrastructure behind it. This has included developing a dedicated NOW operating system for web and TV content production, which Hicks says combines the best elements of the ENPS TV newsroom system and Dreamweaver website building software.

Another key development has been creating software that synchronises NOW's TV and web content, allowing users to click on a "trigger page" embedded in the video stream they are watching that takes them to the relevant page in one of NOW's web portals.

In other areas of NOW's operation there has been a sharp learning curve. Hicks, a launch veteran who was in at the start of now established TV news services Sky News, BBC World and BBC News 24, admits that early plans for a multiskilled workforce who could all shoot and edit their own video footage, as well as writing accompanying scripts and web copy, have been scaled back.

She adds that some individuals have taken to multiskilling. NOW sports reporter David McGrath, for instance, operates as a one-man TV production team, covering events overseas armed with a digital camera, laptop editor and two satellite dishes.

But in general NOW has moved towards hiring people with good old-fashioned specialisms. Subs have been brought in to cast a beady eye over web copy, and yachting journalists have been hired to report on round-the-world catamaran event The Race for the NOW website established to cover the event.

The NOW management team has also spent the past few months refining and improving the TV and internet content offerings. NOW launched with five individually branded web portals and complimentary TV programming strands themed around sport, gaming, film and art, earth and space, and cutting- edge music.

The daily block of TV output broadcast from 4pm London time, which consists of 15- and 30-minute programmes, was increased from two-and-a-half to four hours a day in mid November. A sixth technology themed programming strand, Tech, was launched at the same time and the Tech website went live last week.

Two of the portals have been rebranded, with Emage relaunched as Film and Art, and Mothership transformed into Earth and Space. Explaining the rebranding, Walker says: "On TV you try and find funky names that hint at what a show's about. But on the web you've got to be much more specific, otherwise people just click away."

NOW has also been targeting events around the world that will appeal to the communities it is looking to serve, either picking up internet rights for video streaming or providing other types of coverage in cases where footage of the event itself is not available.

Last month NOW signed a deal with Mean Fiddler, which will allow the outfit to webcast gigs from the music event organiser's 12 UK venues. Thomas reveals that NOW is also talking to Mean Fiddler about coverage of the Reading rock festival later in the year.

As for how much traffic the NOW service gets, Walker says PCCW is not revealing full figures. But he adds: "Traffic has more than doubled since we relaunched the look and feel of the website on December 8", and it is now hundreds of thousands of page views per day and millions of page views per month.

The NOW management team is also encouraged by the email response from users, with 200 in the last week alone. "The average time spent on the site is around 20 minutes per user," Walker says. "There are real communities being built, which is encouraging from a business point of view."

On the even thornier issue of how NOW will make money, Thomas says it will be looking for everything from online advertising and sponsorship to syndicating the outfit's TV content to traditional broadcasters through the PCCW and TWI sales teams. He also expects to have more TV distribution deals in place by the time of NOW's hard launch, which will provide extra potential for generating advertising and sponsorship revenue.

"It will be a mix of old and new economy revenue models," adds Walker. "Because you can't rely on the web alone."

fields.headline: The mag in a bag
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Coleridge  explains why the women's magazine that he launches this week into an already saturated market is destined to be a winner - it's slightly smaller than usual so that it fits into your handbag (if you have one, that is)
fields.trailText: Nicholas Coleridge explains why the women's magazine that he launches this week into an already saturated market is destined to be a winner - it's slightly smaller than usual so that it fits into your handbag (if you have one, that is)
fields.body:
This Thursday we are unveiling what is, without question, the most ambitious and controversial magazine project of my 12 years at Condé Nast. If it works - and we are pretty sure that it will - we will all be covered in glory, and the world will ask, "Why didn't anyone think of that before? It's such an obvious idea." If it fails, you can depend on it that wise heads will shake sorrowfully and declare: "It was never going to work in that format. Never had a hope. They must have gone crazy."

As I write, 647,000 copies of our new magazine, Glamour, are being trucked from the printers in Tewkesbury to wholesalers and retailers, for what is the boldest and most expensive launch into the women's market since Marie Claire 11 years ago. What is revolutionary about Glamour, however, is its physical page size. Instead of the customary A4 format, the magazine is an inch and a half trimmer all round: handbag-sized.

At a time when everything from mobile phones to Walkmans is progressively becoming miniaturised, we are banking on the appeal of a handbag-size glossy. It has exactly the same amount of content as a regular magazine, but it's much handier to read. With luck, modern young women travelling into work by tube and bus, and ricocheting between gym and cocktail bar, will appreciate the innovation.

We have been considering launching Glamour in Britain for as long as I can remember. Glamour is Condé Nast's largest title in America, even bigger than our flagship, Vogue. Founded in 1937, with a monthly circulation of 2.2m, Glamour is second in size only to Cosmopolitan, but its image is sassier and less murky. Somebody once defined for me the difference between a Cosmo girl and a Glamour girl. The Cosmo girl, they suggested, usually goes to bed on the first date and probably can't remember the bloke's name the following morning. The Glamour girl makes him wait until the third date and insists he takes her shopping the next morning.

For various reasons, we launched GQ, Vanity Fair and Traveller before Glamour, but it was always lurking in the wings - the grand slam challenge awaiting the perfect moment and a clever idea to give us market differentiation.

The idea for a handbag-size Glamour wasn't, in fact, invented by us in Britain. It was a stroke of genius by my counterpart at Italian Condé Nast, Giampaolo Grandi. Glamour was launched in Italy seven years ago, initially in a conventional for mat. The title flourished but, in an intensely crowded middle market, never quite reached its potential.

On a hunch, Grandi tested the smaller format in two of Italy's regions, Umbria and Calabria. Sales rocketed and they took the hint. Within a year, circulation had climbed by 60% and the pocket-sized Glamour was a runaway success. Readers declared it to be more accessible and, significantly, more chic. Advertisers bought into the novelty and doubled their investment.

But would the small format play in Britain? We still weren't sure. There were numerous good reasons not to take the risk. How, we wondered, would newsagents react, and how would they display it? Would advertisers complain that a smaller page packed less punch, or expect to pay less for their space?

"It will fit in my handbag with my mobile," exclaimed person after person in Newcastle, right on cue. It was obvious that format alone wouldn't do the trick and I set about searching for an editor and a publisher. One early potential candidate I talked to was Jo Elvin, then editor of Emap's New Woman. She is a bright, streetwise Australian with an impressive track record and a certain sunny toughness I admire.

We met for breakfast at the Halkin hotel and, about half way through the second poached egg, I had a strong instinct she was going to be the one. As a true Glamour girl, she waited until the third date, of course, before succumbing. We were having dinner in a fish restaurant called Sheekey's by this time. webTitle: Keith Allen over the moon about football film

fields.headline: Keith Allen over the moon about football film
fields.trailText: The comedian and actor is planning to make a film which will pay tribute to the uselessness of England's football managers
fields.body:
British comedian and actor Keith Allen is planning to make a new film about the fate of British football managers, according to peoplenews. Allen says the film will: "Explore the multi-faceted amalgam of all useless England managers."

Mike Basset - England Manager, which has been described by Allen as: "Spinal Tap meets Match of the Day," will star Royle Family actor Ricky Tomlinson in the leading role. It is also expected to feature cameo appearances from all of Allen's usual collaborators, including bad-boy British artist Damien Hirst and Alex James from the pop-group Blur. British girl-band Atomic Kitten are expected to perform on the soundtrack.

Although Allen is best known for his TV work, he had small film parts in Shallow Grave and Trainspotting and appeared in last year's much slated Rancid Aluminium, alongside Joseph Fiennes and Sadie Frost. As well as being an actor and comedian he has also released a couple of football-related songs along with Hirst and James, including the lager-lout anthem Vindaloo for the 1998 World Cup and a rendition of Jerusalem for Euro 2000.

The film is due to go into production next week.

fields.headline: Politics with no 'p' at all
fields.standfirst: Radio 1 listeners like FHM and the Sun. They don't like politicians. Which makes election coverage a tad difficult for the station's political reporter Polly Billington, says  John Kampfner
fields.trailText: Radio 1 listeners like FHM and the Sun. They don't like politicians. Which makes election coverage a tad difficult for the station's political reporter Polly Billington, says John Kampfner
fields.body:
How do you cover politics for readers, listeners and viewers who have no interest in politics and politicians? The problem has exercised media strategists for years. It was a big challenge for Channel 5, and to a certain extent for Channel 4. It has never been felt more acutely than in the run-up to the coming election - and never more acutely than on Radio 1.

The latest batch of audience research, commissioned last October by the station's controller, Andy Parfitt, is revealing. Asked which newspapers or magazines they read, Radio 1 listeners listed, in order of preference: FHM, the News of the World, the Sun, Loaded and Sky TV Guide. Asked whether they listen to any other news radio, such as Radio 5 or Radio 4, 87% of them said they didn't. In other words, their opinions are not influenced by what the political classes would call conventional media or conventional debate.

This is the first time that the station has made a concerted effort to address the problem. It should matter to politicians because they need to reach an audience of several million people (average age 16-25), many of whom can't be bothered to vote. And it matters to the BBC because it sees making politics interesting as part of its public service remit.

The solution Radio 1 has come up with is "politics without the politicians". In November, the station seconded Polly Billington, a political reporter from the BBC's Westminster headquarters, to work exclusively for the twice-daily Newsbeat programmes.

Billington, who has done the rounds from local radio to political producer to reporter for On the Record, describes herself as a "nerdy, geeky person, interested in politics at far too young an age". Now she talks the Radio 1 talk.

"Our listeners hate the 'p' word, they like to say that it's all bollocks. If you ask them whether they're interested in politics, they'll say no. But if you ask them whether the minimum wage has helped them, or whether they're angry about the trains, or whether they're happy with a law that allows their boss to snoop on their emails, they have opinions, loads of them."

Much has been written about the issues that most exercise first-time voters. Billington has a stab: "everything to do with work and play - that means sex, buying cars, and having enough money to spend on things like drink and drugs." A recent Radio 1 survey suggested 84% of its listeners wanted soft drugs legalised; 97% said they took drugs such as ecstasy when going to clubs.

So how do you separate issues (not "policies") from politicians? You write stories differently. Newsbeat has an edict to avoid using parliamentary terms such as "select committee" or "front bench". "We never start by saying 'minister X announced today'. That turns people off," says Billington. "We talk about what the announcement is, and only if we feel we really have to do we mention the politician."

The trouble is that the BBC's own rulebook requires it to use "three-party-synch" during election campaigns - that means using a representative of equal weight from each of the three main parties (or the SNP, or other parties where appropriate). In a package of less than two minutes, even with the shortest of sound bites, that makes for deadly dull listening. The Newsbeat solution is: if you're not allowed to select, it's best to have none at all - have young people, pop stars, experts, anyone but a politician.

Exceptions will be made. Each of the main party leaders has committed himself to a 30-minute interview with Newsbeat (they did the same last time). The parties have also been asked to submit three one-minute mini-manifestos, voiced by their top figures.

But, for all the hard sell, this experiment will surely go through the BBC grinder and end up as po-faced as so much of BBC political output? "If we end up sounding like everyone else, we'll have failed," says Rod McKenzie, Newsbeat's editor. "We do have a fairly long leash, probably because we're not listened to as much by the suits."

He says that Radio 1 suffered in the past by having to rely on political correspondents at Westminster on the "taxi-rank" basis - ready to serve any outlet at the drop of a hat. "We asked for people who sounded young, but - it wasn't their fault - they were more used to Radio 4." McKenzie is looking for budgeting that would allow the experiment with a dedicated political reporter to become permanent.

At 33, Billington is somewhat outside the Radio 1 catchment area. I asked her what gigs she'd been to recently. Answer: Dido and Coldplay. What CDs had she bought in the past six months? Madonna, Fatboy Slim, Moby and - she was thinking hard - Pulp.

As for the politicians, she says they are beginning to understand the need to tailor the agenda. But only to a point: all cliches from politicians will be banned. "They have this strange idea that the more they repeat things, the more they think they'll sink in with voters. What they don't realise is that our people zone out."

So Radio 1 listeners will not be hearing talk of Britain being "in Europe but not run by Europe", or promises for an "end to boom and bust". That's advice the chancellor, apparently, should heed. "We regularly turn Gordon Brown down at budget time," Billington says. "He's too dull."

webTitle: A safe pair of hands for cocoa collective

fields.headline: A safe pair of hands for cocoa collective
fields.standfirst: Improving the options for marginalised cocoa producers in Ghana is Kwabena Ohemeng-Tinyase, who heads up the trading arm of Kuapa Kokoo, a cooperative with more than 35,000 members. Kuapa sells its members' cocoa on the conventional and fair trade markets, and also owns a stake in the UK-based Day Chocolate Company
fields.trailText: Improving the options for marginalised cocoa producers in Ghana is Kwabena Ohemeng-Tinyase , who heads up the trading arm of Kuapa Kokoo, a cooperative with more than 35,000 members. Kuapa sells its members' cocoa on the conventional and fair trade markets, and also owns a stake in the UK-based Day Chocolate Company.
fields.body:
"My priority is to help cocoa farmers organise their trading, because in conventional trading, a poor farmer is at the mercy of market mechanisms. When we see the farmer in this weak position, the big-time manufacturers and the multinationals tend to pay the farmers very little.

The biggest challenge that we face in the cooperative is our growth - more and more farmers are getting interested in our activities and want to join us. The financial backbone of Kuapa Kokoo worries me because I have to raise the money for the trading at village level and for the infrastructure that will allow us to grow.

We need reliable weighing scales, tarpaulins, sacks and trucks. We then need the resources for our education outreach programme, so the farmers understand how the cooperative system works and how to manage it for themselves - the book-keeping, the village elections for their Kuapa representatives - so that they will really see the vision of Kuapa in terms of empowering the farmers.

Before the season starts, I have to go around the banks, raising the loans and the guarantees to trade. I also have to get the logistics in place - Ghana's cocoa growing area is very large, and we need to journey far to get the sacks and twine to the villages, ensure that their scales are working correctly, and, because we don't ask the farmers to wait for payment, we need to make sure that the cash is there to pay them immediately when they have their stocks to deliver.

The we have to deliver the cocoa to our warehouse very quickly, so we can sell it on, and then get the money back that we have paid out. This keeps the money turning around, using it as many times as possible to make it work hard, because it is expensive to take out loans from the banks.

In my wildest imagination, I see Kuapa being a giant cooperative, with the farmers being empowered and taking trading activity into their own hands, so they become a force to be reckoned with and being traded with more fairly."

 Interview by Louise Tickle

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • Astrological warfare has broken out on the internet, and the object of everyone's affection curiously happens to be the larger-than-life astrologer Russell Grant. Grant has been wooed by Questico and UK newcomer Keen to join their competitive lists of "experts", but Grant is not fussy - he'll work with anyone. Already segments of Grant's "Astrological Universe" appear on MSN and Excite, and a staggering 5m people a month are said to visit RussellGrant.com. But even though Keen.co.uk is talking up its ties with said astro-guru, Grant's picture on its front page links to, er, nothing whatsoever to do with him. In fact, a search of the site led to abject disappointment: "Sorry, your search on 'Russell Grant' has returned no results." So, it's one nil to Questico already.
fields.body:
 Astrological warfare has broken out on the internet, and the object of everyone's affection curiously happens to be the larger-than-life astrologer Russell Grant. Grant has been wooed by Questico and UK newcomer Keen to join their competitive lists of "experts", but Grant is not fussy - he'll work with anyone. Already segments of Grant's "Astrological Universe" appear on MSN and Excite, and a staggering 5m people a month are said to visit RussellGrant.com. But even though Keen.co.uk is talking up its ties with said astro-guru, Grant's picture on its front page links to, er, nothing whatsoever to do with him. In fact, a search of the site led to abject disappointment: "Sorry, your search on 'Russell Grant' has returned no results." So, it's one nil to Questico already.

 Who would have thought that PR virtuoso Matthew Freud would choose his moment so well to finally wield the scythe at Toyzone.co.uk? As soon as eToys told the world it had no choice but to file for bankruptcy last Monday, it was just a matter of hours before Toyzone, Freud's baby, pulled down its site. Was this just a bizarre coincidence? No, of course not. Toyzone has been biding its time for months, and the shock news of eToys pulling the plug was just the cover it needed. If only those pesky journalists hadn't noticed!

 Hapless individual of the week is Geoff Inns, business development director at Questico, who not only lost his mobile phone in a Berlin nightclub, but also spent the early hours wandering the streets of Berlin trying to remember the name of his hotel and - even though he now works for a German company - struggling to ask directions. A few hours later, he managed to catch his flight back to London with just minutes to spare, only to arrive home and find his parents sitting on his doorstep (having turned up on the wrong day), expecting to spend some time with their bedraggled son. It never rains...

 Once upon a time there was a massive media company; a household name no less, that caught the dot.com wave and embarked on a massive internet expansion plan. This was Disney, that was then, and layoffs and cutbacks are now. Curious then that its corporate website has not changed a jot: "WDIG [Walt Disney Internet Group] is taking the internet by storm... it's certain that WDIG will be blowing the socks off the internet world for years to come... there's never a dull moment." And there's more: "That's the kind of atmosphere that WDIG people thrive in. It's an atmosphere of constant challenge and change - where self-starters and self-motivators are richly rewarded. In ALL areas of compensation. Including that all-important pat on the back for a job well done." Hindsight kind of sours the hyperbole.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Credit union for Kuapa Kokoo cooperative

fields.headline: Credit union for Kuapa Kokoo cooperative
fields.standfirst: There are now 35,000 members of the Kuapa Kokoo collective in Ghana which guarantees cocoa growers a good price for their crops. Now the farmers' cooperative wants to set up a credit union
fields.trailText: There are now 35,000 members of the Kuapa Kokoo in Ghana which guarantees cocoa growers a good price for their crops. Now the farmers' cooperative wants to set up a credit union. Louise Tickle reports
fields.body:
Hundreds of cocoa farmers are flocking towards a vast hall in central Kumasi, Ghana's second city, in the heart of the Ashanti cocoa growing region. Delegates wearing colourful traditional dress sashay along to boisterous band music as they filter in to the AGM of Ghana's biggest farmer-owned cooperative, Kuapa Kokoo. Despite the party atmosphere, there is serious business to be done.

Established seven years ago with the aim of empowering small-scale cocoa farmers to get a better deal from the volatile world commodities market. Kuapa Kokoo (the name means "good cocoa farmer") now has more than 35,000 members. The cooperative is using the AGM to gather support for its latest project - the piloting of a credit union.

Patricia Appiahgyei, the credit union's new managing director, is convinced of the need for the scheme.

"Here in Ghana the farmers find it very difficult to access credit in the normal banking sector," she says. "Often they have been resorting to the use of money-lenders at an incredible rate of interest - sometimes 100% or even 500%, and farmers can stand to lose their farms to these money lenders. As well, illiterate and semi-literate farmers lack the confidence to approach a banker to ask for a credit facility, and of course, any financial institution will require statements and records of business which are not available to the farmer."

Asking vulnerable farming communities to hand over hard-earned cash to a brand new financial institution requires a lot of trust. Kuapa Kokoo's members cannot afford to risk losing even a small proportion of their income.

The managing director of Kuapa's trading company, Kwabena Ohemeng-Tinyase, acknowledges that these concerns must be addressed for the credit union to flourish.

"Sometimes the farmers raise questions about whether their money will be safe, because with other cooperatives that their monies had been with, they ended up not getting their money back. But with this system, they see that it is the people from their own village who are collecting the money and depositing it. The records are well kept so they know that their money is safe, they can get hold of it when they want it, and even, with the interest paid, get more."

But can the union retain members' confidence over the long term? Albert Tucker, head of the alternative trading organisation, Twin, has worked with Kuapa to shape the credit union, and explains that it is now on course for its first big test.

"At the end of this cocoa harvest, the fund will start lending to farmers, and we are hoping that the farmers will feel secure enough not to just withdraw all the money at the first opportunity. If we have been successful, then more and more growers will come on board. The education outreach is vital to help them understand how leaving their savings in the union has benefits for everyone. With Kuapa's membership growing fast, this could even become a huge financial service, not just a credit and savings scheme. That would give the farmers a fair bit of negotiating power."

Patricia Appiahgyei is determined that as the union develops it will enable farmers to improve their livelihoods. "We have various types of loans that we want to sell to the farmers," she says. "We are talking about development loans, group loans for the whole village and also individual loans. Loans will be given at reasonable interest rates, and over a much longer period than normal. I believe this will help farmers to be more confident. It is also going to improve their production capacity, lifestyle, and altogether, financial wellbeing."

webTitle: Sweet success: fair trade for cocoa farmers

fields.headline: Sweet success: fair trade for cocoa farmers
fields.standfirst: Thanks to a local cooperative initiative in Ghana, cocoa growers are finally getting a fair deal. But its success depends on the chocolate we choose to buy in Britain
fields.trailText: Thanks to a local cooperative initiative in Ghana, cocoa growers are finally getting a fair deal. But its success depends on the chocolate we choose to buy in Britain, writes Louise Tickle
fields.body:
At the edge of a dusty village two hours' hard drive down a dirt track in central Ghana, a farmer waits to sell his cocoa crop - and for an agent who can be bothered to navigate the potholed road to buy it.

This is a typical start to the conventional chocolate chain, and the farmer is not in a good bargaining position. If he doesn't like the price or method of payment, there is not likely to be any other market where he can sell.

Kuapa Kokoo is a Ghanaian co-operative that was set up seven years ago to give cocoa producers a better deal. It has grown fast and now has 35,000 members. That's a lot of cocoa. And Kuapa's operation aims to empower farmers from the grass roots up.

Instead of individual farmers in isolated villages being at the mercy of dealers, Kuapa works with village societies so that the cocoa is weighed accurately by an elected local recorder, cash payment is made immediately, and the cocoa is then collected by the co-op's trucks and delivered efficiently for export. This means that even though the world cocoa price remains extremely low, Kuapa farmers get a higher proportion of what is available.

Cocoa is a vulnerable, risky crop, and yet hundreds of thousands of Ghanaians rely on it. To produce high quality cocoa - and Ghana's beans are recognised as the best - requires skill and hours of labour.

In the village of Dadease in Ghana's Ashanti region, Isaac Nkroumah leads the way down a winding path into the cocoa forest.

Glowing yellow cocoa pods hang from every tree under the shady canopy. Shaped like mini rugby balls, a few pods sprout oddly from the trunks; hundreds of others gleam high up in the branches, swollen hard with their hoards of cocoa beans tucked tightly inside.

With a swift "thwack" of his machete, Nkroumah splits a pod precisely down its middle, levering the husk open and digging out the beans with his hands. Each cocoa bean is covered in a sweet wet jelly. Sucking one, it tastes like lychees.

The harvest is done collectively by the villagers, and it's hard, hot work. Nkruoumah has a group of about 20 neighbours working with him this afternoon to gather the pods, extract the beans, then cover the cocoa heap in banana leaves to ferment in the sun.

Several days later the beans are loaded in great piles into baskets, and lifted onto people's heads for the journey back to the village. The final stage is a careful sorting and drying on bamboo tables.

At Kuapa's central warehouse in the city of Kumasi, rows of hessian sacks full of cocoa are piled high on pallets reaching almost to the ceiling. There is a prevailing smell of fermentation and a chocolaty whiff in the air, although these beans are still a long way from their final scrumptious destiny.

Most cocoa is sold to confectionery multinationals at the going world rate. Despite a recent rise, this price is still extremely low, and often not enough to cover the farmers' costs. The rest is sold on the fair trade market, and is then made into fairly traded chocolate products now available in most supermarkets.

Currently, fair trade sales of the raw cocoa alone give Kuapa approaching double the world price at $1,150 (£780) per tonne. The cooperative also has shares in its own chocolate bar sold in the UK called Divine. But fair trade means more to farming communities than just money - it means the price is guaranteed, and that farmers can rely on long-term trading contracts so they can plan ahead. Clearly, Kuapa would prefer to sell to fair traders - and that depends on what chocolate lovers of the world choose to put in their shopping trolley.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Emma Jones
fields.trailText: Sun journalist Emma Jones who has just been appointed editor of Smash Hits.
fields.body:
Newspapers:

Every day I start with the tabloids and then leisurely read all the heavies. I like the Observer's Life magazine and the Sunday Telegraph magazine. Also read the Evening Leader online, which is my local paper in North Wales.

Magazines:

I like magazines like wallpaper*, which look good. Visually, it's a new direction for magazines, which will feed into pop mags. I still like girlie mags, they've come such a long way, things like Sugar are so glossy now. I read all the pop mags plus Music Week and Campaign, Vogue and Tatler for fashion and Hello! if I was near death or coming round from an operation.

Television:

Spaced, The League Of Gentlemen and Two Pints Of Lager was quite good. I like Sex and the City for a bit of glamour. Mark Thomas is good.

Books:

I've been doing some stories on the James Bulger case and have been reading Gitta Sereny's book, Cries Unheard. I think it's important people take another look at it because it paints an important picture of a very sad situation, but in a reasoned and dignified way. Also just finished Grit by Irvine Welsh. It's set in Wales but I didn't really identify with it. It didn't have the humour and that's what I think you should take out of Wales.

Radio:

London is great for radio; it gives you a good overall feel for what's going on. I listen to XFM in the morning and get all I need to know about pop from Capital and Kiss FM.

Films:

Central Station was a brilliant, human film. I liked The Lowdown and Some Voices, and I loved All About My Mother.

Adverts:

The best one at the moment is for MTV with the guy in a kebab shop singing Britney Spears's Hit Me Baby One More Time.

New Media:

The internet is vital for anyone in the media or pop industry. I use it day to day to get stories and ideas from but I'd still rather read a book.

 Sun journalist Emma Jones has just been appointed editor of Smash Hits.

webTitle: Internet lectures on groundbreaking new site

fields.headline: Star thinkers in 'e-learning' launch
fields.standfirst:
Brief free taste for public but internet expositions by top academics such as Richard Dawkins and Niall Ferguson will then be licensed

More net news
fields.trailText: Three eminent dons will deliver interactive, online lectures on a ground breaking internet site to be launched today. By Stuart Millar.
fields.body:
They are among the greatest thinkers of the day, driving forward an understanding in a range of disciplines from the origins of the cosmos to the nature of consciousness. But from today, 12 of the world's leading academics will be available to expound on their latest theories at the touch of a button.

Richard Dawkins, evolutionary biologist, Niall Ferguson, controversial history professor and the media's current academic favourite, and Sir Martin Rees, the astronomer royal, are three of the eminent dons who will deliver interactive, online lectures on a ground breaking internet site to be launched today.

In a development which may herald the web's coming of age as a powerful educational tool, the series of "e-lectures" will cover topics as diverse as the human genome project, Shakespeare's Othello and the relationship between power and money.

Alongside the eminent British contingent, will be three leading American academics, including Steven Pinker, the world-renowned professor of brain and cognitive sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

His lecture, the Ingredients of Language, poses some fundamental questions. "How does language work?" he asks. "What is the trick behind our ability to share so many different kinds of ideas, merely by making noise as we exhale? ... the prediction that regular forms are generated by rule whenever memory fails helps to make sense of the many puzzles of language, such as how children learn their mother tongue, where language resides in the brain and why no one really seems to know the plural of Walkman."

Richard Halkett, who set up Boxmind - the company producing the e-lectures - with two fellow Oxford graduates three years ago, said: "Everybody has heard of Richard Dawkins, Niall Ferguson and the others. They might have heard them on the radio or seen them on television but very few will ever have had the chance to hear them deliver a lecture. Now they can log on and see them put forward their greatest theories."

Boxmind claims the site will blow apart traditional approaches to study. Because the lectures are not delivered by a live webcast but by a broadcast of filmed material, users can stop the action at any point and follow the extensive links on each page for in-depth background information on specific points. The lectures can also be rewound and examined line by line for weaknesses in the argument.

The technology used for the site - www.boxmind.com - is as inventive as the concept. Each lecture screen is split into four. In the top left, a talking head delivers the lecture, while synchronised slides run in the top right. In the bottom right there is a synchronised transcript of the entire lecture - complete with embedded footnotes - next to the relevant web links.

The 12 lectures will form the foundations of a growing archive. But there is one drawback: the resource is open to members of the public only until the end of the month. After that, the lectures will be licensed for use by individual universities, which will also be able to have their own academic staff delivering lectures in the same way.

"It is a pity that the public won't be able to access them," said Mr Halkett. "But the reality of internet businesses since the dot.com collapse is that we have to make real money."

The technology driving the site has potential far beyond academia. One option already under discussion is a deal with publishers for similar sites to tie in with new book releases, especially in the booming popular science market. That opens the possibility of readers being able to log on and have ready access to leading authors - Stephen Hawking, for example - to take them through their latest work.

The launch of the e-lectures is also likely to intensify demands for high quality online learning. So far the internet's potential as an educational resource has been limited by the sheer volume of information it carries.

In February last year, David Blunkett, the education secretary, announced plans for the world's first national e-university, offering a "British university education" worldwide.

But since then the grand plan has foundered, with many sceptics dubbing it an irrelevant white elephant on a par with the Millennium Dome. The government itself admits that the project is at least four years from fruition.

But Mr Halkett said the new e-lectures were proof that the internet could be made to deliver. "We started off building an online library but we quickly realised how scarce decent material is out there. We decided to produce our own and now we have a lecture series which offers dynamic, unrivalled access to the most persuasive thinkers of the day."

Heavy hitters in the groves of academe

The site's first 12 lecturers are:

Richard Dawkins
Fellow of New College, Oxford, and Charles Simonyi, professor of the public understanding of science. Lecture title: Survival of the Fittest - the Fittest What?

Niall Ferguson
Professor of political and financial history, at Oxford. Lecture title: The Cash Nexus - Money and Power in the Modern World.

Sir Martin Rees
Astronomer Royal and Royal Society professor at Kings College, Cambridge. Lecture title: Cosmic Evolution.

Daniel Dennett
Professor of philosophy, and director of the Center for Cognitive Studies at Tufts University, Massachusetts. Lecture title: Consciousness: More Like Fame Than Television.

Peter Atkins
SmithKline Beecham fellow and tutor in physical chemistry at Lincoln College, Oxford. Lecture title: The Second Law.

John Kay
Fellow of St John's College, Oxford, and visiting professor of economics at the London School of Economics. Lecture title: The Foundations of Corporate Success.

David Womersley
Fellow and tutor in English literature and senior tutor of Jesus College, Oxford. Lecture title: Tragedy and Individuality in Othello.

John Searle
Mills professor of the philosophy of mind and language, University of California at Berkeley. Lecture title: Consciousness, Free Will and the Brain.

Sir David Weatherall
Regius professor of medicine at Oxford. Lecture title: The Human Genome Project and the Future of Medical Practice.

Ian Stewart
Professor of mathematics at Warwick University. Lecture title: Order and Chaos in Mathematics and Nature.

Nicola Lacey
Professor of criminal law at LSE. Lecture title: Criminal Law and Modern Society.

Steven Pinker
Peter de Florez professor in the department of brain and cognitive sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Lecture title: The Ingredients of Language.

webTitle: How the Real IRA was born

fields.headline: How the Real IRA was born
fields.trailText:
Who belongs to the Real IRA?
According to defence analysts, the Real IRA is a hardline group of between 70 and 170 members dedicated to an armed campaign aimed at driving the British out of Ireland. Its members see themselves as Irish republican purists, accusing the Provisional IRA of selling short republican ideals.
fields.body:
Who belongs to the Real IRA?
According to defence analysts, the Real IRA is a hardline group of between 70 and 170 members dedicated to an armed campaign aimed at driving the British out of Ireland. Its members see themselves as Irish republican purists, accusing the Provisional IRA of selling short republican ideals.

When was the group formed?
The Real IRA emerged out of a row in 1997 over a ceasefire called by the Provisional IRA to get Sinn Fein involved in talks which eventually led to the signing of the Good Friday agreement.

The dispute came to a head at a convention of Provisional IRA leaders in Gweedore, Co Donegal and led to the resignation of its quartermaster general. He left to form the new group and was joined by other disaffected Provisional members.

How is the Real IRA run?
The Real IRA follows the same embryonic command structure as the Provisionals with an army executive and council, with the former quartermaster general assuming the role of chief of staff in the new organisation.

Where are their strongholds?
The Real IRA made its biggest inroads into the Provisionals's southern command in the Irish Republic, with Janes's Intelligence Review reporting in October 1998 that up to 30 experienced Provisional IRA operators had joined its ranks.

Concentrated in border counties like Louth in the Irish Republic, the group drew support north of the border in areas like South Armagh and have made their presence felt in other parts of Northern Ireland in west Belfast and Newry.

The group is also believed to have recruited top Provisional bombmakers in Dublin, Monaghan and South Armagh. But it also succeeded in bringing new faces into its ranks.

The Provisional IRA continues to command more support in republican areas than the dissident group but there are concerns that the longer the Northern Ireland peace process remains deadlocked, the more support the dissidents will attract.

What has the Real IRA been involved in?
The organisation has continued the Provisionals's pre-ceasefire tactic of bomb attacks on security and commercial targets but the latter backfired badly in 1998 with the Omagh atrocity. The Real IRA was forced to declare a ceasefire in the wake of Omagh.

But despite overwhelming public anger, it managed to survive. As the peace process stumbled in the wake of the power sharing executive's formation in December 1999, the Real IRA has managed to re-establish itself and has returned with attacks in Northern Ireland and London designed to destabilise the peace process.

fields.headline: Cows week
fields.standfirst: Is it the sign of a government contemptuous of Britain's farming community? Or perhaps the finest hour of a forgotten minister who rose to the occasion?  Roy Greenslade  on the press stampede to put a spin on the foot and mouth outbreak
fields.trailText: Is it the sign of a government contemptuous of Britain's farming community? Or perhaps the finest hour of a forgotten minister who rose to the occasion? Roy Greenslade on the press stampede to put a spin on the foot and mouth outbreak
fields.body:
William Hague announced in the Commons that he was declaring a truce with the government because of the foot and mouth crisis. Unable to grasp the meaning of ceasefire, he rather spoiled it by immediately furling his white flag and trying to extract a pledge from Tony Blair about delaying the bill to outlaw fox-hunting.

But Hague had no real need to worry about the political consequences of a temporary suspension of hostilities. He knew he could sit back and let the government's real opposition, the Tory press, do the job for him.

Between them, the Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph tried every conceivable trick to disrupt all hopes of a genuine bipartisan understanding in the face of a national catastrophe.

Given the apolitical nature of an animal virus, and the fact that no amount of parliamentary probing had managed to lay the blame for its arrival on the government, it required an unusual degree of subtlety to besmirch Blair's government.

What these papers sought to create was a public perception, regardless of the facts, that Blair's cabinet was somehow guilty of causing and then mishandling the outbreak. In other words, they indulged in their favourite pastime: journalistic spin.

The other, quite separate, underlying strand to their arguments was fascinating too because these ideologues of monopoly capital found themselves questioning the concept of modern food production dictated by the free market they so revere.

The Mail began the week with a splash headlined: "The Great Burning Begins But Is It Too Late?". This rhetorical question was not a direct assault on the government, of course, but the suggestion was obvious. Inside, an editorial page feature by an academic laid into everyone connected to "the commercial policies that rule the farming world", including "the government, the European Commission, the supermarkets" and "globalisation".

He was exercised by the fact that "farming is geared unswervingly to profit" and made an excellent case against it. Noticeably, though, having taken a swipe at the government, he offered not the slightest clue about how Blair could do a blind thing to interfere with the market.

Next day came another ambiguous front-page headline, "The Pariahs of Europe", which seemed to suggest that Germany and France were misbehaving by banning British meat imports, a neat way of using the crisis to take another xenophobic rap at Blair's European sympathies.

The main features slot was given to Edward Heathcoat-Amory, the nephew of MP David who, the Times's William Rees-Mogg informed us, "has a real loyalty to the land". He unleashed a blistering attack on the ministry of agriculture for turning "a crisis into a catastrophe".

Again, the central thrust of his argument had some merit, but the anti-Labour political message - with a childish joke about Nick "Newcastle" Brown - was insistent. (It was a busy day for Mr H-A. On another page he was damning Blair for his commitment to the Euro army, a familiar Mail beef, so to speak).

The Mail, an overwhelmingly metropolitan paper, also taunted Labour for being an "overwhelmingly metropolitan party" guilty of "indifference, sometimes bordering on contempt" for rural communities.

On Wednesday, the Mail's leader writer was apoplectic at the government insistence on debating a hunting bill, while refusing "to find time to discuss the most devastating threat to the countryside in a generation". The paper screamed: "This is the true voice of New Labour - a party that holds parliamentary democracy in contempt."

It also took Brown to task for "scurrying off to Brussels and his tours of broadcasting studios" and concluded: "No wonder millions of country dwellers have lost all faith in New Labour."

The following day the Mail's news story - the bit where the paper supposedly relays impartial information - began: "MPs showed astonishing contempt for Britain's farming community last night when only a handful of them took part in a debate on the foot-and-mouth catastrophe."

The headline referred to "just 13 Labour MPs" being in the chamber while the story revealed that the Tories, who we might note are an overwhelmingly rural party and who had demanded the debate in the first place, fielded only 48.

On Friday, the Mail found yet another way to attack Blair. At a time of national emergency, it said, ministers were "spending an inordinate amount of time on New Labour's [election] campaign strategy". It was therefore important for the prime minister to "announce that there will be no early election".

Over a period of five days, the Mail had succeeded in pouring a huge amount of manure over Blair and his government. It wasn't the only muck-spreader, of course, with the Daily Telegraph enthusiastically shovelling the same stuff too.

It slammed the agriculture min istry for culling abattoirs on Monday; asserted in its supposed news splash on Tuesday that Blair was relieved by the postponement of the Countryside Alliance march; questioned the need for an election on Wednesday; and reinforced that point with a Boris Johnson column on Thursday.

The Telegraph's most tendentious assault on the government came from Tom Utley who argued that it was "totally out of control of the crisis. Much of what it is doing is plainly fatuous, and done just for show".

He thought the measures adopted by the government "frighteningly authoritarian and hopelessly ineffective" and advocated instead a policy of doing nothing. "There is damn all that the government can do now to stop it, until it has run its course."

I just wonder how sympathetic the Telegraph would have been if Blair had greeted the original news of the outbreak in an Essex slaughterhouse by announcing that there was nothing to be done and we should go about our business as normal. It doesn't take a minute to imagine headlines such as "Crisis, What Crisis?" and editorials about Blair's contempt for the problems of the countryside. The Utley article was a piece of maverick nonsense.

I also suspect that Nick Garland's cartoon in Friday's Telegraph, casting Nick Brown as Hercules struggling to conquer the Hydra, which grew two heads in place of any one chopped off, was meant to suggest the minister was facing an impossible task. But he, and Utley, would do well to remember that Hercules eventually killed the beast.

The Mail and Telegraph were not entirely alone in their criticisms of Brown. Two parliamentary sketch-writers, Simon Hoggart of the Guardian and Matthew Parris of the Times, lampooned his Commons performance. Hoggart thought him "a drizzlingly depressing fellow" while Parris accused him of flying into "a massive sulk".

None of this mattered to the Independent which next day talked of him as the "forgotten minister" who "rose to a crisis". The Mirror's Paul Routledge also praised Brown's impressive coolness and the wisdom of his "judicious measures".

These two papers are largely sympathetic to the government, but it's always difficult to gauge how the Sun will react. This time, it accomplished a neat hat-trick, giving Blair unqualified support, taking a pot-shot at the Mail for referring to Britain as Europe's pariahs and then playing a familiar xenophobic card.

"Our standards of animal husbandry and food hygiene are a match for anywhere in the world," said the Sun. "The trouble is that Britain is more honest than most other countries. When we have a problem, we don't try to hide it."

Isn't journalistic spin a wonder to behold?

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Henrietta Morrison
fields.trailText: Henrietta Morrison, co-founder and joint-CEO of queercompany.com
fields.body:
Favourite websites?

bbc.co.uk is one of the most comprehensive websites. One of the best things about it is the kids' stuff which you can print off such as colouring pictures and dot-to-dot drawings. It's great for my daughter if she comes into the office.

Last online purchase?

Air tickets to Madrid from buzzaway.com. The internet is the only place I'll buy them; it's instant, you can check availability and the whole transaction can take 10 minutes.

Most recent technological faux pas?

Sending an email to a group of people about a surprise birthday party when I was just trying to tell one other person. I was using Microsoft Entourage which I hadn't really sussed.

Ever been in a chat room?

Yes. My first experience, and probably my last, was on an American website for leather fans called dykes delight or something. I was quite surprised at how explicit it was and I went bright red in the cafe.

Main news source on the web?

ft.com.

Most useful site on the web?

bargainholidays.com. It's really quite tacky but useful for finding out what the weather's going to be like, currency conversion and when is a good time to visit places.

Which site is least likely to succeed?

The ground rules for success are; hold on to your money and run a tight ship. You need people to multitask for you and be flexible so you can manage your funds effectively. Also, you need to charge for areas of your site. You can't keep on offering website usage for free. E-commerce figures just don't add up and you need to operate some kind of subscription service.

Time spent on the web?

Far too much! Probably seven or eight hours a day.

Least useful site on the web?

areyouhotornot.com is quite funny but totally inane. It's the ultimate waste of time and resources.

Screensaver?

Don't use them. By the time I'd seen it half a dozen times I'd be bored of it.

Most irritating thing about the web?

Sites which make your computer crash. This has happened loads of times with one particular business site called tornado.com. My system crashes every time I try to delete their emails. I've contacted them hundreds of times to get taken off their list, but it hasn't happened yet.

Do you still bother with old media?

Yes, but I'm more selective because I have so little reading capacity left after the time I spend on the web. I buy a Sunday paper and the Guardian on a Monday but I'm not a daily newspaper reader anymore.

 Henrietta Morrison is co-founder and joint-CEO of queercompany.com

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: John Kampfner
fields.trailText: John Kampfner
fields.body:
News is relative. Political news is very relative. In the silly seasons of August and Christmas, any low-grade Westminster gossip story will make it on to the news or into the papers. The same applies throughout the year to Sunday stories for Monday's editions. Editors, if they have nothing else for the splash, will call the political team. Politics, in other words, is journalistic Polyfilla.

When a big, unplanned story breaks - abroad or at home - the reverse applies. Policy launches are postponed, initiatives are dropped, and political hacks have to sit on a juicy titbit they gleaned from a minister over lunch that in normal times they could turn into a half-decent front page item.

Rarely has this rule been so true than over the past week as the foot and mouth crisis developed. Until then, the SW1 set had been whipping itself up into general election fever. The talk had been of Tony Blair going to the country early, in April. And then suddenly, the same people were warning that it might not be able to go ahead even in May.

Normal politics was put on hold. The Westminster week should have got off to a busy start with the launch of the government's latest crackdown on crime. The prime minister's picture at Pentonville prison was emblazoned in many a daily on Tuesday, and there was decent coverage on the news and comment pages - generally mixed - but the story died more quickly than it would normally have done. Even Jack Straw's propensity to court controversy wasn't quite what it should have been. His attack on lawyers on the make, in a speech to lawyers on Tuesday, might have infuriated them, but it didn't get the nation going.

Other problems were sidestepped. Robin Cook's signing of the Treaty of Nice on Monday was confined to a short 'blob' in most papers, even though Downing Street had been preparing itself for a Eurosceptic onslaught; criticism by the IMF of Gordon Brown's approach to public spending made it to the splash of the FT on Wednesday, and was followed up by the Mail the next day, but - especially in the week before the budget - that was the least flak he could have expected. As for usual budget speculation, there was virtually none.

Would any punter have noticed government figures showing a sharp decline in the use of stop-and-search powers by police? These post-Macpherson data could have been very difficult for ministers. The story made it to the bottom of page 10 in Thursday's Mail, but not many other places. And what happened to those speculative stories about the impending Hammond report in the Mandelson-Hinduja affair? The Sundays had had some fun, but they weren't followed up.

The biggest escape of all, though, was the downpage treatment given to Chris Woodhead's attack on Labour education policy. After signing up the former chief inspector of schools several months ago, Charles Moore, the Telegraph editor, had had a long time to ensure his revelations would have maximum impact and wreak maximum damage. Woodhead's "breaking of silence" was flagged prominently several days ahead, but in the ultimate example of Sod's law, Thursday was absolutely the worst possible choice. The Telegraph itself managed only seven paragraphs on page one, in its basement slot; others followed to an extent, and the next day's television and radio bulletins covered it, but only after long sequences on the two main running stories.

As for the Tories, they felt obliged to postpone a press briefing on their latest policy announcement on Wednesday - which was probably just as well as it constituted yet another u-turn, this time on Tube privatisation. They were also spared more stories about jockeying for William Hague's job.

So who benefited most from the jettisoning of normal politics? Both sides avoided various pitfalls. The biggest relief for ministers was the decision of the Countryside Alliance to call off its march. And what of that other date, May 3? In spite of the dire warnings by several commentators to push back the election, Downing Street officials insisted there were no logistical reasons for doing so. Their concerns lie elsewhere, in a phenomenon encapsulated by a piece in Thursday's Sun.

Columnist Jane Moore provided a snapshot of everything that was wrong in Britain - the highest rate of teenage pregnancies, "bog standard" schools, decrepit hospitals, terrible public transport, a culture of criminality . . . and now foot and mouth and Selby. "Whichever way you look at it, this country is in chaos," she wrote. It's what aides call "the national mood swing", and it's this that will swing Blair's decision.
