fields.headline: Obituary: Archie Ammons
fields.standfirst: Poet engaged with the minutiae of daily life
fields.trailText: Poet engaged with the minutiae of daily life.
fields.body:
The American poet, Archie Ammons, who has died aged 75, wanted a poetry "plain as day, exact and bright," in which things like saliva, the weekly waste collection, the weather forecast, and his backache were equally at home. Published in prestigious quarterlies, taken up by powerful professors, employed at an elite university, laurelled with awards and fellowships, only one element was missing in his stellar career. He never found a reading public.

Ammons wrote every day in his study in Ithaca, New York, where he taught poetry at Cornell University, his daily routine providing the subject and occasion of his writing. He belonged to the generation of postwar writers for whom the cultural megalomania of a figure like Ezra Pound, and the theological and cultural agenda of TS Eliot, had little appeal. He lacked the pizzazz and showmanship from which public careers in poetry are built.

Ammons was not interested in ideas, politics, civic life or cultural heritage - because he did not engage with such things, he was literally, as a poet, speaking to no one. "I don't address an already defined stratum of society or a particular cause," he told an interviewer. "I think of the hermit lark, a shy bird with an unlocatable, indescribable sound."

In 1971, Harold Bloom published an essay in which he placed Ammons in the line of descent from Emerson, Whitman and Wallace Stevens. With Bloom's patronage, critics could see how Ammons's meditations upon landscape and the weather were firmly within the tradition of American transcendentalism.

He preferred open forms, unrhymed short lines, short paragraphs, and a personal tone. Closure, formal intricacy, sensual delight in verbal dexterity, or even "meaning", were not his strongpoint. Buying a roll of adding-machine tape on im pulse in 1963, he fed it into his typewriter and began a poem:

6 Dec:

today I

decided to write

a long

thin

poem

By the time he had finished 13 months later (he used a wastebasket to hold the completed text), he had a verse journal, a record of dailiness, weather reports and reflections upon the ordinary business of writing verse.

Tape For The Turn Of The Year, published in 1965, 200 pages long and consisting of a single sentence, bemused reviewers, and beguiled some by its plain, unfeigning tone:

the reason I write so much

is

that I can't do anything

else:

poem must be now

close to 40 feet long:

He meant this quite literally. By that point, the tape was too long to be removed from his typewriter. He was a prisoner of his poem, and had to go until the tape was done.

Ammons came from the poor-white, southern world photographed by Walker Evans and Dorothea Lange during the depression. He grew up on a farm in Columbus County, North Carolina, miles from the nearest paved road. His father grew tobacco and corn, and raised chickens, cows and pigs. There was no one to tell his family that they were white trash - civilisation was too far away.

As the depression hit subsistence farmers, the Ammons family sank deeper into debt. He himself felt his grade school was strange; it was painted inside, and there were electric lights and a flushing toilet. At high school, he was poorer than the other students, and felt excluded from the world of "town kids".

The second world war opened up new opportunities. After graduating from high school, Ammons got a job in the shipyards at Wilmington. The family farm was sold, debts paid off. At the age of 18, he joined the US naval reserve, and served on a ship in the Pacific. He began to write poetry during quiet moments at sea. Taking advantage of the GI Bill, he studied biology at Wake Forest College. After graduating in 1949, he married Phyllis Plumbo, who shared his interest in poetry.

In the early 1950s, Ammons went to the University of California, Berkeley, where he was encouraged by the poet Josephine Miles. He continued to write poems while working for a decade as an executive of a biological glass manufacturing company in New Jersey. His first book, Ommateum, appeared in 1955, to be followed by Expressions Of Sea Level (1964) and Corson's Inlet (1965), which established a reputation. In 1964, he began teaching poetry writing at Cornell, and spent the remainder of his career as a poet-teacher.

Ammons went on to publish nearly 30 books, winning nearly every major American award for poetry, including the National Book Award for his Collected Poems in 1973, and, in 1993, for Garbage, a long meditation upon a smouldering mountain of trash in Florida. His last book, Glare, appeared in 1997.

He is survived by his wife and a son, John.

Archie Randolph Ammons, poet, born February 18 1926; died February 25 2001

webTitle: The hallmarks of the Real IRA

fields.headline: The hallmarks of the Real IRA
fields.trailText: The Real IRA, considered by security chiefs as the main dissident threat to the peace process, is most notorious for the Omagh bombing in August 1998.
fields.body:
The Real IRA, considered by security chiefs as the main dissident threat to the peace process, is most notorious for the Omagh bombing in August 1998.

It is also believed to be responsible for a number of other recent attacks on the British mainland.

  • On August 15 1998, the Real IRA carried out the Omagh bombing, killing 29 people in a busy town in Co Tyrone.
  • It was the worst atrocity in 30 years of violence, killing more people in a single explosion than any other.
  • One of the dead was a mother expecting twins - and 370 were injured. Another 2,000 people, many of them suffering mental trauma, have also needed medical treatment.

    Since Omagh, the group is believed to have been responsible for a number of incidents, including:

  • February 6 2000: Bomb attack on Mahon Hotel, Irvinestown, Co Fermanagh.
  • February 25 2000: A device found at a perimeter fence at Ebrington Barracks, Londonderry.
  • February 29 2000: Fully primed rocket launcher found close to military base in Dungannon, Co Tyrone.
  • June 1 2000: Bomb attack on Hammersmith Bridge, the first by the Real IRA on the British mainland.
  • June 20 2000: Explosives found in the grounds of Northern Ireland Secretary's residence at Hillsborough, Co Down.
  • July 9 2000: A 250lb car bomb attack on Stewartstown RUC station.
  • July 19 2000: Bomb attack on railway line near Ealing Broadway station, west London.
  • September 12 2000: Soldier escapes unhurt when an 80lb bomb fails to explode at a military site at Magilligan, Co Londonderry.
  • September 20 2000: ROG-22 rocket attack on MI6 headquarters in London.

fields.headline: Consuming passions
fields.standfirst: As John Brown lands the contract to publish the listings supplement for Hello!,  Jessica Hodgson looks at the way contract publishing has developed from dowdy throwaways to lucrative lifestyle titles
fields.trailText: As John Brown lands the contract to publish the listings supplement for Hello!, Jessica Hodgson looks at the way contract publishing has developed from dowdy throwaways to lucrative lifestyle titles
fields.body:
There's a delicious irony in John Brown Publishing - the company that steered Viz from Newcastle-based bedroom industry to publishing sensation - being handed the contract to publish Seven Days, the new entertainment and listings supplement for Phil Hall's revamped "hip" Hello!.

Although it's not the first example of contract publishing for a consumer magazine client, it's the first time a high-profile magazine has farmed out a whole section of its editorial to a contract publisher on an ongoing, weekly basis.

Both Hall and Brown say the decision to outsource was a logistical one: Hello! simply didn't have the resources to churn out a 56-page weekly supplement in-house. Brown is confident that the relationship will be exactly the same as any other contract deal. Hello! is the client and the brief is to reflect its brand values. The fact that the client is another magazine makes little difference. "In some ways it's easier," says Brown. "We're both in the business of publishing, so we don't have to explain things to them."

The deal follows another less glamorous but far more lucrative deal for Brown; the contract for a whole clutch of aspirational lifestyle magazines for WH Smith. Four of these - Buying a New Home, Fit and Healthy, Improving Your Career and Getting Married - come out this week.

It's the biggest single-contract publishing deal ever, and emphasises the extent to which contract publishing is emerging from the shadow of its glamorous older sister, consumer magazines. The fact that Seven Days is being edited by an experienced women's magazine journalist, ex-Cosmo deputy editor Leah Hardy, as well as the fact that Hall is confident that the brand values of Hello! will not be tarnished by outsourcing, reveals the growing confidence of the sector.

Contract publishing (or "partnership publishing"), has come of age from its inauspicious beginnings in the 1970s. The sector was developed to provide vehicles for duty-free advertising by airlines, and the first years of its life were characterised by subbing errors, bad design and sycophantic interviews with middle-managers.

Brown recalls his first forays into the world of contract publishing, with Hot Air, the in-flight magazine he produced for Virgin in the 80s. "The early mags didn't have to make an effort. They had a captive audience, the readers were strapped into their seats - and the advertising was on a plate. There was a culture of absolute dross."

Redwood Publishing's twin founders, former journalists Christopher Ward and Mike Potter, are credited by many of their peers with transforming the industry from a dowdy publishing services sector to an increasingly dynamic new group of companies.

Redwood won the contract to publish magazines for the BBC in 1988 - a turning point for contract magazines. The success of the company in handling the BBC's Top Gear, BBC Good Food and BBC Gardeners' World established that contract magazines could have high publishing values and quality editorial. Redwood also made substantial advertising revenue.

Redwood published the first in-store magazine for Marks & Spencer in 1987, which spawned a generation of upmarket "gastroporn" titles such as New Crane Publishing's award-winning magazine for Sainsbury's and Brown's Waitrose Food Illustrated. Last year, the customer magazine market was calculated to be worth £227m annually, having increased by 15% from its value of £197m in 1999, with a combined target audience of more than a billion consumers, according to analyst Mintel. Of the 20 highest circulation magazines at the last ABCs, only five were non-contract.

Contract magazines' targeted demographics have also made them increasingly interesting to media agencies, who value them for building the kind of databases that marketers dream of. This has led marketing services group Omnicom to buy three contract publishers in the UK: Redwood, Premier Media Partners and Specialist Magazines.

Slick production values and high budgets have also attracted good journalists. Sainsbury's magazine recently pulled the long-term Radio Times editor Sue Robinson and Hot Air is edited by the former Arena editor Ekow Eshun.

Brown says that the increasing sophistication of media consumers means that blatant company advertorial just won't wash. "Hot Air needs to reflect the ethos of Virgin. It doesn't need to tell you much about flying in an aeroplane. Similarly, Waitrose don't want a magazine about Waitrose, they want one about good food."

fields.headline: Magazine launch targets self-employed
fields.trailText: 10.30am: A new magazine launches this week targeted at self-employed professionals, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A new magazine launches this week targeted at self-employed professionals.

Alodis magazine is a joint venture by a company called Mongrels World - a company targeting people from "unrepresented groups" - and John Brown Publishing.

webTitle: Reds' light flickers in shadow of past

fields.headline: Reds' light flickers in shadow of past
fields.trailText: Compared with recent barren years, Liverpool are having a successful season yet even now they are apt to cower before the memories of things past and forget the basics, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Compared with recent barren years, Liverpool are having a successful season. One trophy has been won, another is a possibility and a Champions League place is well within reach.

Yet even now the best team so far produced by Gérard Houllier are apt to cower before the memories of things past. It is as if the ghosts of the great Liverpool sides of Bill Shankly, Bob Paisley and Kenny Dalglish choose the most inauspicious moments to haunt the present players.

The power cut in extra-time of the Worthington Cup final, when Birmingham City briefly ran the game, was followed by this 2-0 defeat at Filbert Street which again found Houllier's side flickering like a faulty light bulb, only this time the filament failed altogether.

Ade Akinbiyi's strike shortly after half-time put the hosts infront and Muzzy Izzet flicked the switch by doubling the margin in injury time.

But Peter Taylor, the Leicester City manager, is among the more fair-minded of his kind and readily conceded that having a dozen players absent on international duty three days earlier could not have helped Liverpool's cause.

"If someone offered me the choice, I'd always play Liverpool when they've had 12 players away," he admitted.

But Houllier did not hide behind excuses: "It was not good enough. We just have to look at ourselves and realise that this is not acceptable."

Alternatively they could look at Leicester and remind themselves that strengths of character and desire are as important as sound technique and tactical awareness. Leicester, first under Martin O'Neill and now Peter Taylor, operate in the knowledge that hard work and concentration will often bridge any gaps in ability between themselves and more vaunted opponents.

So faithfully did Leicester follow this creed on Saturday that for the last hour they not only exceeded Liverpool in terms of work rate, they were the better side all round. Nobody personified this aspect of the game more than Robbie Savage, who since Neil Lennon departed for Celtic in December has become the fulcrum of a team that utilises a solid defensive platform for counter-attacks using the pace Leicester possess on their wings.

Opponents must find Savage as irksome as a Welsh corgi, forever snapping at the postman's heels. "We have to calm him down because sometimes he runs all over the place," said Taylor, as if to support the comparison. But on Saturday Savage was in the right place at the right moment to help turn the match Leicester's way.

The first half having been largely devoted to the spectacle of each set of centre-backs heading hopeful crosses away, the second was quickly redeemed by an aberration on the part of Robbie Fowler. Gaining possession deep in his own half, he brought the ball under control and glanced up before laying it carefully across the left-hand corner of his own penalty area straight to Savage. He quickly found Izzet who fed a short ball to Dean Sturridge, before the striker's low, square pass was turned in by Akinbiyi.

Thereafter Liverpool attacked steadily but untidily, until a long clearance from Andrew Impey, who had replaced the injured Frank Sinclair before half-time, dropped to another Leicester substitute, Arnar Gunnlaugsson, and with the Liverpool defence caught square the Icelander sent in Izzet to complete a notable victory that keeps Leicester's hopes of European football next season very much alive.

Houllier was convinced that Liverpool should have had a penalty in the 68th minute when Emile Heskey went down after tangling with Gerry Taggart. True, Taggart, in falling, did grab his old team-mate around the waist but not before Heskey had caught his face with a flailing arm.

Heskey, as Houllier was saying before the match, has become a better player since moving to Anfield from Filbert Street, but on Saturday Liverpool did not provide the service to allow him to prove as much to his former colleagues.

Meanwhile, Craig Brown will ask Liverpool's Gary McAllister to return to the Scotland squad for the two World Cup qualifiers against Belgium and San Marino later this month.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-seven, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-seven, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: With all the latest bets losing, has new Blue Square expert The Camel got the hump? Last week's bets
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £170.54
Paul MacInnes = £25.01
Sean Ingle = £24.82
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £14.08
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £170.54
Paul MacInnes = £25.01
Sean Ingle = £24.82
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £14.08

Scott Murray: Manchester City v Southampton - James Beattie to score first goal £5 @ 13/2
Bet lost; Beattie went off injured after 30 minutes, Dan Petrescu scored first goal after 55

I will reveal my true colours immediately. I detest first-scorer betting: with the exception of no goalscorer, I see no virtue in it. Bookmakers give themselves big margins on this particular market, and the appearance of substitutes before a goal is scored just adds to their edge. It is very rare to be able to try and buck percentages of 150 or more profitably. As a general rule, I would avoid this option.

Having said all that, with my hand tied behind my back and a gun pointed to my head, your selection of James Beattie was a logical one. It could easily be envisaged that he would give the ancient Manchester City central defence a nightmarish day: he is big, strong, quick and mobile - just the sort of striker the Blues have struggled with all season. Unfortunately, he was replaced after 30 minutes following a clash with Richard Dunne, thus ending all hopes of a winning bet. Not getting 90 minutes for your money hmm perhaps I should have included that in my anti-first goalscorer diatribe. In fact, the Saints, second behind only Manchester United in the six-match form table, were perhaps the best betting option in this match at a best price of 7/4.

Your alternative bet, Dundee to be leading at St Johnstone at the interval, certainly had some merit. St Johnstone have the poorest home record in the Premiership, and Dundee's away record is far superior to their home form. Although hindsight is a valuable tool for the fledgling betting analyst, I would always prefer betting on a 90-minute outcome, as half-time betting is altogether too random for my taste. But St Johnstone's abysmal form since the return from the mid-season break made them poor favourites at around 11/10, and Dundee had to be considered at a best-priced 2/1. (Dundee won 3-2.)

Sean Ingle: £10 treble - Celta Vigo v Real Oviedo: Celta to win @ 4/7; Stockport v Wimbledon: Wimbledon to win @ 11/8; Bristol City v Oxford: Bristol City to win @ 1/3
Bet lost; Celta beat Oviedo 1-0, Stockport drew 2-2 with Wimbledon and Oxford held Bristol City to a 0-0 draw

Thank you for your kind welcome. But as for your value treble, I think you were treading on very unsafe territory. I did like the Celta Vigo selection: BlueSq were best price at 4/7 and that certainly looked value. Ovideo are certainly a different proposition at home, but they are truly woeful on their travels; and with Celta's recent improvement, this certainly had the look of a home banker.

And Bristol City should certainly have beaten a very poor Oxford side. But whether they were value at 1/3 is a moot point. I rate City's strikeforce of Tony Thorpe and Lee Peacock very highly, but they haven't been scoring as frequently as I would have expected, and their recent form has left a lot to be desired of a team with play-off pretensions. Their previous two games saw defeats at the hands of Colchester (4-0!) and Brentford. Backing any team who could lose to such moderate opposition is clearly a risky venture, particularly at such prohibitive odds.

I certainly could not have made a selection in the Stockport v Wimbledon clash. While agreeing that the Dons are certainly a better proposition on their travels than at a sparsely attended Selhurst Park, I personally think they are flattered by their mid-table position in the First Division. Their form rarely rises above mediocre, and although they have been impressive recently in dispatching very poor sides in the shape of Sheffield Wednesday and Queen's Park Rangers, their overall profile is of a team that may struggle to survive in the First Division next term. Especially, as seems likely, their remaining Premiership-standard players, Jason Euell and Marcus Gayle depart in the summer.

When you add Stockport's dire need for a good result in this match and Aaron Wilbrahim's recent upturn in form, I would have more tempted to include Stockport at 7/4 than Wimbledon at 11/8.

The Prince of Punts: Parma to beat AC Milan £5 @ 11/4
Bet lost; the match ended in a 2-2 draw

Milan against Parma had all the hallmarks of a low-scoring, dour affair. Parma have indeed been in excellent recent form, as you mention - thumping two poor sides, in the shape of Peruigia and Brescia, at home in recent outings.

But away from home, they are a different proposition. They play a very defensive, cagey strategy, often leaving the admirable Sergio Conceicao on the bench. They are very strong at the back, with the towering Fabio Cannavaro and the excellent Lilian Thuram often starring. So from my point of view, the outcome of this match depended on whether Oliver Bierhoff and Andriy Shevchenko could get the better of a rearguard which had only conceded nine goals away from home prior to this match.

Milan are formidable at home, only having lost one of their 10 outings thus far. I would have expected a low-scoring affair to be settled by one goal, if at all. The value option to me was 0 or 1 goals at 5/2. But the no goalscorer bet available at 13/2 was also appealing.

Martin Lawson of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Derby to draw with Tottenham - £5 @ 9/4
Bet lost; Derby beat Spurs 2-1

Tottenham's away travails of this season have been well documented. True, they managed to beat a very poor Manchester City team on their last outing, but all season they have been one to oppose away from White Hart Lane. They show little enterprise, and regularly concede all hope at the concession of an early goal.

The surprise absence of Sergei Rebrov, which you could not have forseen, meant Spurs would be playing with Les Ferdinand and Andy Booth as their strikeforce, and while individually they are both very good players, their style is too similar to be a frightening proposition for the home defence.

Derby's home form is the reason they are still odds-on to remain in the Premiership next season. Malcolm Christie and Branko Strupar have provided more than their fair share of goals, and Seth Johnson and Craig Burley are a very effective midfield combination.

On the whole, I prefer to oppose teams who seem to have given up on their league season, into which category Spurs almost certainly fall. Safely above the relegation zone, yet surely too far away to challenge for a European place, Spurs look all set to concentrate on their FA Cup challenge, while Derby need to pick up every point available at Pride Park. This would have been a home win selection for me.

webTitle: Murdoch 'will not bid for DirecTV rival'

fields.headline: Murdoch 'will not bid for DirecTV rival'
fields.trailText:
10am: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation will not bid for US satellite broadcaster EchoStar, writes Dan Milmo .
Mar 2: News Corp denies DirecTV takeover crisis
Mar 2: Merger on verge of collapse
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation will not bid for US satellite broadcaster EchoStar, even though its takeover of DirecTV appears to be doomed.

Sources close to the media group said a bid for the company was "far down the track", even though DirecTV owner General Motors has effectively told News Corp to rethink its offer.

"A bid for EchoStar has never been off the cards, but it is far down the track. At the moment, News Corp is completely intent on DirecTV," said the source.

The source said that News Corp's interest in EchoStar is no great surprise, as Mr Murdoch has always talked about being interested in more than one US satellite broadcaster.

"I don't see News Corp moving. Its talks are with General Motors, [DirecTV holding company] Hughes Electronics and no one else," added the source.

Analysts are already downgrading News Corp's shares amid mounting speculation that the £49bn bid to merge the company's satellite assets with DirecTV will fail.

GM is unhappy with an all-share deal which has no cash component and is understood to be offering DirecTV and Hughes Electronics to other potential bidders.

GM is desperate for cash as it experiences a slump in car sales due to a downturn in the US economy and it sees market share slipping away in the European market.

But News Corp insiders said that companies such as Disney and Comcast have already looked at DirecTV and have decided not to join the fray.

News that EchoStar is being lined up as a safety net will be given a subdued reception, as it has 4m subscribers against DirecTV's 9m and it does not have the technological backing of Hughes Electronics.

Echostar is a privately owned company, controlled by chairman Charles Ergen who owns 90% of the stock.

webTitle: TV doc explores war and media

fields.headline: TV series turns guns on war and media
fields.trailText: 9.30am: A new documentary will lift the lid on the relationship between war and the media, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A new documentary in development backed by some of the biggest names from international newsgathering will lift the lid on the relationship between war and the media.

The Eyes of War, a six-part series, has been made by Mercury Media, a four-man team of former APTN journalists who have set up as an international production company.

The project, which has been in gestation for two or three years, was created "to ask journalists questions that they wouldn't normally ask themselves".

"If you look at the history of war, you can trace certain military actions to certain pictures, like the end of the Gulf War to the pictures of the road to Basra," said Tim Sparke of Mercury.

"Pictures resonate with people in positions of power but the media sometimes don't ask enough questions about their relationships with those pictures."

The series, which has yet to secure a terrestrial commission, features interviews with senior TV newsgathering industry figures, including CNN's Chris Cramer, ITN's Richard Tait, and Richard Sambrook and Tim Orchard from the BBC.

It will also feature unreleased interviews with Miguel Gil Moreno de Mora, the APTN cameraman shot dead last year during a gun battle in Sierra Leone, and the Russian media magnate Boris Berezovsky.

The series will look closely at the increasingly powerful military PR machines, with the first-ever filming of an off-the-record military briefing given by the Ministry of Defence.

The series, which has yet to secure a terrestrial commission, features interviews with senior TV newsgathering industry figures, including CNN's Chris Cramer, ITN's Richard Tait, and Richard Sambrook and Tim Orchard from the BBC. It will also feature unreleased interviews with Miguel Gil Moreno de Mora, the APTN cameraman shot dead last year during a gun battle in Sierra Leone, and the Russian media magnate Boris Berezovsky. The series will look closely at the increasingly powerful military PR machines, with the first-ever filming of an off-the-record military briefing given by the Ministry of Defence.

webTitle: Internet twins could return to US within weeks

fields.headline: Internet twins could return to US within weeks
fields.trailText: The custody battle for the twins at the heart of the internet adoption scandal was mired in new controversy last night when it emerged that they could be sent back to authorities in the US within weeks.
fields.body:
The custody battle for the twins at the heart of the internet adoption scandal was mired in new controversy last night when it emerged that they could be sent back to authorities in the US within weeks.

Legal experts believe that continued court battles in the US will force British authorities to pass judgment on the twins' case within weeks, handing them to American officials "within a month".

The Welsh couple Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who claim they rightfully bought the twins from an American internet adoption agency, await the judgment of Birmingham high court over their application to become the twins' guardians.

But last week a court in St Louis, Missouri, ruled that the twins should be returned to the country of their birth where two court battles - in Arkansas and Missouri - over their adoption are continuing. It is now up to the judge in Birmingham to send the twins back.

'The likelihood is that they will return to the US,' said Deborah Cullen, an adoption lawyer and legal spokeswoman for British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering. 'Unless there is some subtle argument for the the Kilshaws being granted custody, Birmingham High Court will hear the case within weeks and you could see them move to the US within a month.'

Judith Kilshaw admitted yesterday that she and her husband were not going to win the Birmingham court case, the next hearing of which is scheduled for 19 March, adding that the decision had, in her opinion, already been taken against them at 'higher levels'.

'There's a political agenda' she said. 'If I won, it would say that it is all right to adopt from the US.

'I wouldn't call [the latest] US court decision a judgment - it's more a request. I think the twins should be sent back to Arkansas - that's where the paperwork and the judges are. I don't want them to go back to Tranda [Wecker, their birth mother]. [She made] allegations that I smell. I put perfume on and we bathe like normal people.'

The likelihood of yet another move for the twins will anger campaigners who believe that their repeated moving between foster parents and social services has unnecessarily added to the disruption the eight-month-old girls have experienced. The twins could leave the care of British social services, to be passed to another temporary foster family in the US, before being found a final foster home.

This would give the girls five sets of foster parents in a matter of months.

Recriminations and controversy continue to surround the battle for the twins. Judith Kilshaw claimed that Tina Johnson, who sold the girls to both the Kilshaws and another couple in California - Richard and Vicky Allen - through her internet adoption agency, was now being offered film and book deals for her story.

Richard Allen has subsequently been charged with sexually abusing two other girls. He denies the charges.

webTitle: More cash and time off for mothers

fields.headline: More cash and time off for mothers
fields.trailText: New mothers are to be given a significant boost in maternity pay and the right to take six months off work as the government directs the last Budget before the general election towards wooing women voters.
fields.body:
New mothers are to be given a significant boost in maternity pay and the right to take six months off work as the government directs the last Budget before the general election towards wooing women voters.

As a war on tax erupted between the two main parties yesterday, government sources revealed that a central part of the chancellor, Gordon Brown's, £4 billion giveaway, to be announced on Wednesday, will be an expected increase in the flat rate of maternity pay from £60 a week to £100 a week. The present 18 weeks' maternity leave will be extended to 26 weeks.

The chancellor is using the Budget to respond to concerns that women voters are turning away from the government, which they believe has not been as radical as expected and has failed to modernise Britain's struggling public services.

The new maternity package will be bolstered by allowing mothers to claim the new working families tax credit - cash back through the pay packet - from the birth of the baby onwards, effectively targeting most help on those who are least well-off.

Previously it could take up to six months before women could get the extra money.

'We hope this is going to be a very, very good package for women,' said one senior source. 'Our absolute determination has been that the greatest help should be for the poorest women. The aim is that women can have long enough to get to know their new babies, which up until now has been the prerogative of the better-off.'

However, the chancellor is understood to have rejected demands from unions and other campaigners for a major extension of earnings-related maternity pay.

At the moment women get 90% of their usual earnings paid by the state for the first six weeks, then go on to a much lower flat rate for the rest of their time off.

The maternity pay will be one of a package of measures aimed at making the Budget as 'family friendly' as possible, a move which the prime minister has told colleagues is vital to winning the election.

Brown will also announce a large extension of the 10p tax band which will be trumpeted as a 'tax cut for all'. Although he is thought to have rejected an across the board 1p cut in income tax as appearing too profligate, he will say that from April families on average earnings of £25,000 will be £370 a year better off. He will also claim that poorer families on £12,500 a year will be £2,600 a year better off and will have the lowest direct tax burden since 1972.

Yesterday, Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, upped the war on tax by pledging that he would match any tax cuts announced in the Budget.

Speaking at the Conservatives spring conference in Harrogate, Portillo said the promise came on top of £8 billion of cuts the Tories have already said they can achieve.

He also said that indirect taxes, so-called 'stealth taxes', meant that everyone was now paying the equivalent of 10p extra on the basic rate of income tax.

Labour dismissed the claims, saying Portillo had a black hole in his spending plans which could only be filled by increasing national borrowing and pushing up interest rates.

The Treasury had initially balked at increasing maternity leave, concerned that it would mainly benefit wealthier high-flyers who are keenest to return to work.

But it has been persuaded by arguments that having a child is the single biggest strain on family incomes - and that if women are allowed to take long enough off to bond with their babies and return only when they are ready, they are less likely to drop out of the labour market. The children's tax credit, which will be given to parents earning up to £40,000, is also likely to be introduced at a higher than expected rate of £10 a week from April.

fields.headline: Bomb threatens peace process
fields.standfirst:
• Real IRA blast rocks BBC studios
• Warning of more attacks
• Police fear two terror campaigns on mainland
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch warned that yesterday's bomb blast outside BBC Television Centre in west London was almost certainly the work of the dissident group, Real IRA, write Nick Hopkins and Rosie Cowan.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process was put in further jeopardy last night when security sources revealed that members of the Provisional IRA have been conducting reconnaissance missions in England, raising fears of a two-pronged terrorist threat to Britain that could shatter the Good Friday accord.

The revelations came as Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch warned that a bomb blast early yesterday morning outside the BBC Television Centre in Shepherd's Bush, west London, was almost certainly the work of the dissident group, Real IRA, and is likely to be followed by further attacks in "the coming days and weeks".

The bomb, which had been hidden in a London taxi bought on Saturday, exploded at 12.30am.

One railway worker at the White City tube station opposite was slightly injured. Windows in nearby buildings were shattered and homes up to 100 yards away were showered with debris.

The bomb was packed with up to 20lb of high explosive and may have been planted at the BBC in revenge for a Panorama programme which named Real IRA members suspected of detonating the bomb in Omagh that killed 29 people.

Scotland Yard, MI5 and the RUC are now aware that members of the Provisional IRA, which has observed the ceasefire, have been actively involved in reconnaissance activities for several months.

The Northern Ireland Office was informed on Saturday that a 23-year-old man arrested last Tuesday by police near Colchester Garrison in Essex - a Parachute Regiment base and one of the army's biggest barracks - is a suspected Provisional IRA quartermaster from Derry. He is still being questioned under the terms of the Terrorism Act 2000.

Essex police are also looking for an accomplice, who is thought to be a Provisional IRA terrorist released from jail under the provisions of the Good Friday agreement.

"The RUC is positive they are Provisional IRA, not dissidents," said a source. "We don't know exactly what they were up to. It looks as if it was some kind of a reconnaissance. We have found no weapons or explosives. It was preparation for something."

Though the Provisional IRA has supported the political initiative, it is understood senior figures in the movement have been privately briefing the "war is not over" to ensure few members are tempted to join the dissident ranks.

Security sources said the Provisional IRA might want to show that "at the appropriate time, they would be prepared to go back to the business of war."

Whatever the intentions of Provisional IRA gunmen, Scotland Yard warned yesterday that there was a growing and continuous threat posed by dissidents whose bomb at the BBC was designed to "maim, injure and kill".

Deputy assistant commissioner Alan Fry, head of the anti-terrorist branch, said nobody had claimed responsibility for the blast, but confirmed that a secret codeword used in a telephone warning to a hospital was recognised as the Real IRA.

He said: "It is quite clear that we are dealing with ruthless terrorists who are prepared to use ruthless tactics without any care for the consequences of their actions."

Although it is thought this is the first attack in England since last September, Real IRA has been active in Northern Ireland, recruiting and training "cleanskins" as well as disaffected provisionals.

First Minister David Trimble said he believed the dissidents targeted London because of recent failed attacks at Ebrington barracks in Derry and Claudy RUC station.

"[Among] the reasons why it may be trying to pull off a spec tacular is because of the efforts the government is making to persuade the mainstream IRA to honour its obligations on decommissioning and the fact that an election may be coming up shortly.

"These actions may be designed to try to destabilise and frustrate the efforts of the government to secure the peace process," Mr Trimble said.

Downing Street called the bombing "a cowardly act". A spokesman said: "There are those outside the peace process who are set on trying to turn the clock back to the days before the Good Friday agreement."

Intensive talks to salvage Northern Ireland's faltering political process have been continuing between the British and Irish governments and all the main parties since before Christmas.

Republicans want further guarantees on policing reform and substantial scaling down of military operations, especially in south Armagh, but in return, Tony Blair wants to see real progress on IRA decommissioning.

Mr Trimble, whose Ulster Unionist party is bitterly divided over whether it should quit the power-sharing government with Sinn Fein if the IRA does not give up its arms, will be under huge pressure in the general election if he stays at Stormont without a significant new move from the Provisionals.

Scotland Yard has appealed for anyone with information about the BBC bomb, or any other suspicious activity, to call the Anti-Terrorist Hotline on 0800 789321.

webTitle: Budget to give public jobs boost

fields.headline: Budget to give public jobs boost
fields.trailText: An extra £500m-£800m to help teacher and police recruitment and ease bed blocking in the NHS is expected to be a surprise element in Gordon Brown's pre-election Budget on Wednesday.
fields.body:
An extra £500m-£800m to help teacher and police recruitment and ease bed blocking in the NHS is expected to be a surprise element in Gordon Brown's pre-election Budget on Wednesday.

The extra spending for 2001-02 is on top of the generous allocations set out in last summer's spending review. The cash, currently being negotiated by the Treasury, Downing Street and spending departments, is seen as a high-profile commitment to public services.

The package, likely to be finalised in meetings tonight, would be used to fund a pay scheme to encourage retired teachers to return to work, or to encourage supply teachers to work permanently.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, believes levels of teacher training are acceptable, but there is a serious problem of teacher shortages in classrooms.

Jack Straw also wants extra cash to fund his package to recruit extra police and ease housing problems. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is looking for money to ease continuing bed blocking in the NHS and meet targets for reducing cancelled operations.

Tony Blair is understood to be supporting the key workers package, partly because he believes it will be attractive to middle income, middle-aged Britain.

Some Labour strategists believe Mr Brown's Budget is excessively targeted at welfare benefit reforms to help the poor, many of whom do not bother to vote.

The package can in part be funded from £2.8bn savings in the social security budget generated by lower than predicted unemployment.

The extra cash for health is despite figures due to be published today showing NHS waiting lists rose by little over 5,000 in January, ensuring the government will meet its target to cut waiting lists by 100,000 at the time of a May election. Waiting lists are 120,000 below the figure at the time of the 1997 election. If the waiting lists had risen by as much as 11,000 - in line with January 2000 - the government's flagship pledge would have been in serious danger. The number of operations cancelled in January was 0.8%.

The bulk of the chancellor's measures will be aimed at cutting fuel duty and increasing the basic rate for pensioners by £5 for single people and £8 for couples and offering respite in fuel duty. In last December's pre-budget report he earmarked £1.75bn for pensions and fuel.

But the Budget will also contain a populist commitment to remove betting tax, replacing it with profits tax on the betting firms.

The new children's credit, available to 5m poorer families, is to be set at a maximum £520 - £10 a week.

In an attempt to broaden the Budget's appeal, Mr Brown is also expected to bow to pressure from Tony Blair and offer a token income tax cut for the middle classes. He will enlarge the slice of income covered by the 10p starting rate of tax by an extra £500, a move that would save the average household £60 a year.

He has rejected calls from within the Downing Street policy unit for a 1p cut in the basic rate of tax, which would cost almost £3bn.

Although Mr Brown is on course to chalk up a record £18bn government surplus this fiscal year, he has consistently ruled out a giveaway budget that might prevent the Bank of England from cutting interest rates again.

Thanks to a buoyant economy which has boosted tax revenues and kept spending on unemployment low, Mr Brown should still be able to announce that he is banking £16bn of his surplus.

The Bank's monetary policy committee starts its two-day meeting on Wednesday, as Mr Brown delivers his Budget. Some City analysts believe it might announce another rate cut when the meeting ends.

webTitle: Help at last for suicidal young men

fields.headline: Help at last for suicidal young men
fields.trailText: More males in their 20s die by their own hand than in car crashes. MPs are demanding action to stem the tide. Anthony Browne reports.
fields.body:
The soaring suicide rate among young men, which means they are now more likely to die by their own hand than be killed in a car crash, will this week be confronted by a new parliamentary committee set up to investigate the scale of the tragedy.

The suicide rate for young men has doubled since the early 80s, while for women it has almost halved. Suicide is now the biggest single cause of death of men aged 25 to 34, who are more than five times likely to take their lives as women of the same age, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics. The all party group on men's health is so alarmed that in its inaugural meeting it will press for measures to ensure that suicidal young men can find help. The launch is being supported by public health minister Yvette Cooper. Howard Stoate, chairman of the men's health group, said: 'It's the commonest cause of death among young men. It's an important issue and is under-recognised - most people have no idea it is so high - but the statistics are shocking.'

Overall, suicide has overtaken car accidents as a cause of death among men. Each year about 3,600 men take their lives, compared to 1,200 women. Dr Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, which advises the government, said: 'If this rate of death among young men was an infection, there would have been a lot more attention paid to it.'

The new measures will come too late to help Mike Whitaker, who seemed to have everything to live for. He was in his last year of a chemistry degree at Bath University and was expected to get a first. He had a job lined up, a girlfriend and was captain of the clay pigeon shooting team. "He was very successful at whatever he did," said his mother, Jenny Whitaker.

But one morning at the end of the Christmas break, Jenny awoke to find the car gone, while her husband found the back door open. Then they saw a one-line handwritten note against the bedroom door of Mark's younger brother:"'Sorry bro - look after Mum and Dad." Half an hour later the police found him in the car with a pipe from the exhaust to the window.

"We were astounded. We knew he was upset about a university project, but we had no idea he was that ill.' said his mother. "He was a perfectionist and did keep things to himself. He hadn't spoken to anyone about being desperately distressed."

Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans, said that this refusal to talk about problems is a key reason why men are more likely to kill themselves than women. "They are more likely to internalise feelings until it gets too big a burden to bear, and then it leads to self-destruction. The British culture of stiff upper lip still reigns supreme," he said. The Samaritans has tried to target men by advertisements on beer mats and in changing rooms.

Declan Curran, 13, hanged himself from a door with a guitar strap. He had been sexually abused and had no one he could talk to. "As a lad you have to be tough, and if you're not you're a bit of an outcast," said his brother Liam. There is a huge range in suicide rates among different groups of men. It is far higher - and rising - among unskilled men than among professional men. Men are more likely to kill themselves if they are from ethnic minorities, unmarried or gay.

Psycholgists say that the rise in suicide among men is a result of their loss of a role in society. Dale Peters, a market trader selling plants and flowers, hanged himself at 25 after splitting up with his girlfriend. "He found it difficult to see where he was going. He was ticking over with a small business, but he wasn't doing particularly well - he didn't see a future for himself," said his father, John Peters, who teaches psychology and works for the self-help group Survivors of Bereavement by Suicide. "Many men have expectations they should be providers, and for a small percentage they don't live up to it."

Males are falling behind females at school and university. The loss of unskilled jobs has hit men with few educational qualifications particularly hard. "Young men cannot see what their role is, and often their parents cannot see what their role is," said Peters. "The men can be perfectly sane in coming to that decision. For so many it is a very determined act."

More women than men attempt suicide each year, but are less likely to succeed. They usually choose methods such as an overdose of pills which can often be tackled in casualty wards, and are often seen as pleas for help. Men tend to choose violent, decisive methods, such as hanging, jumping off buildings, crashing a car or shooting themselves.

"There's fatalism about the whole thing. People say they're going to do it anyway, but that's just not true,' said Banks. 'There are many practical things we can do. Changing men's attitudes to themselves is a long-term job, but it's not impossible."

 Samaritans helpline: 08457 90 90 90

 Survivors of Bereavement by Suicide helpline: 0870 241 3337

 Shadow of Suicide helpline for bereaved parents: 0117 953 9639

fields.headline: Causes and effects of a deadly virus
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Why do we need to slaughter infected animals?
fields.body:
Why do we need to slaughter infected animals?

The first reason is to stop the disease spreading, the second is economic. The virus is virulent and would spread through the entire population of cloven-hoof animals. Although nearly 50,000 animals, mostly sheep, have already been killed in this outbreak to prevent an epidemic, millions more would eventually be infected. There are 40m sheep and 10m cattle in Britain, plus domestic and wild pigs, deer and goats. Normally live animals are exported for breeding, and thousands of sheep for slaughter, but all this trade has been stopped and could never resume to countries free of foot and mouth if we did not eradicate this disease.

What effect does foot and mouth have on animals?

Although most animals do recover, about 5% of young and older animals die. Animals get sore mouths and feet, and stop eating as much, and so do not gain weight; cows' milk yield goes down. Animals go lame and in some cases get severe foot infections which would lead to slaughter to prevent suffering. These losses could make farms uneconomic.

How long would it last if allowed to run its course?

Each outbreak would last only a few weeks in each farm before the animals appeared well. Vaccination of other herds and flocks which had not had the disease would protect them against infection and illness. Millions of shots of vaccine are in stock. The problem is that this accepts the disease is here to stay. Foot and mouth in the national herd bars animal exports to "clean" countries because of fear of infection. Slaughter is a controversial policy but kept the UK foot and mouth-free for 20 years. It remains British and EU policy, although it could be reviewed once the outbreak is over, or if the disease keeps recurring in Europe. Greece has had outbreaks twice in five years.

What happened in the last outbreaks?

In 1967 400,000 animals were slaughtered and the disease took six months to get under control. In 1981 there was one outbreak in the Isle of Wight.

Why has it arrived after 20 years?

There is a worldwide epidemic of a virulent virus of foot and mouth called Type O which reached 60 countries in 1999. South America, South Africa and Asia have all had outbreaks. The immense increase in free trade - making import restrictions more difficult - means infected meat is traded round the world. That makes more countries vulnerable to outbreaks. Once present it spreads very quickly and can travel more than 100 miles as an airborne infection.

Can humans catch the disease from animals?

Yes, but very rarely and only thought to be by direct handling of sick animals. There were cases in the 1960s epidemic and children under 10 are most likely to suffer. In humans it is like flu but with an added sore mouth. People must be kept in quarantine until they have recovered.

Would the meat of animals with foot and mouth be infected?

Yes. This is the most likely way the infection came to Britain in the first case. Imports of meat from countries with foot and mouth are banned but infected meat fed to pigs in Northumberland in swill is regarded as the most likely cause of the outbreak, although the cause is still under investigation. Food containing the virus brought in from another country and carelessly thrown away in Britain is another possible cause. Countries must be disease-free for six months before exports are allowed. For infected meat to have reached Britain some illegal practice must have occurred.

What would the effect on humans be from eating infected meat?

None. Properly cooked meat kills the virus and it would not be in sufficient quantities to get past the human defence system. Animals are far more susceptible.

What about wild animals?

These are far less likely than farm animals to catch foot and mouth because they have less contact with infected animals. The rapid spread of infection so far has been caused by the mixing of sheep in markets and transporting them long distances crowded in lorries. If wild boar did get foot and mouth they would be the most likely wild animal to spread the disease because, like domestic pigs, they "shed" large quantities of virus . But experts think infection of wild animals is unlikely. Culling poses difficulties because frightened animals are likely to disperse, spreading the infection further than leaving them alone would do.

fields.headline: SurfControl bucks tech trend
fields.standfirst:
SurfControl
More net news
fields.trailText: SurfControl, whose products enable the surveillance of web surfing habits, has not been affected by the US economic slowdown, reports Neil Hume.
fields.body:
Internet software company SurfControl, whose products enable the surveillance of web surfing habits, will today surprise its critics by revealing that it has not been affected by the US economic slowdown.

Lifted by strong demand for its internet filtering products, SurfControl, which makes about 70% of its sales in North America, will tell shareholders that its third-quarter figures will be in line with market expectations. It will also say that it is confident of achieving its full year forecasts.

Last week SurfControl shares dropped 19% on rumours of tough trading in its key North American market. On Friday, the shares fell 11% following reports that the company was about to issue a negative trading update.

However, demand for SurfControl's products, which helps firms block employees' access to offensive websites and emails, is understood to have remained strong.

Unlike software used to encrypt messages and transac tions sent across the internet, it appears that SurfControl's products are seen by corporates as a must have product.

The problem of internet abuse in the workplace is growing, highlighted by a number of high profile cases in which employees at firms such as Merrill Lynch, Orange and Royal & Sun Alliance have been fired for misusing the web.

SurfControl is also said to be benefiting from the pricing of its products. Where as encryption software such as public key infrastructure, or PKI, has an average order price of $150,000 (£103,000), SurfControl's price is nearer $4,000.

SurfControl's broker, UBS Warburg, expects the company to post $9.55m of revenues in its third-quarter results, compared with $3.68m in the same period last year. For the full year UBS is forecasting $36.5m of revenue. SurfControl is not expected to break even until 2003.

Although listed in London, the company formerly known as JSB Software, is now based in Silicon Valley.

fields.headline: BBC news is top people's choice
fields.trailText: 8.30am: When the nation's wealthiest demographic group want to relax, they switch on BBC1's 10 O'Clock News, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The nation's wealthiest demographic group, the ABs, have found a novel way to de-stress: they settle down in front of BBC1's 10 O'Clock News.

When they want to chill out they also watch Have I Got News For You, Friends, Frost, Frasier, Match of the Day, Inspector Morse, ER and Ally McBeal.

The media habits of 1,000 ABs have been revealed in the latest VIPer survey carried on behalf of Channel 4, Classic FM, Conde Nast, Times Newspapers, More Group and Media Planning Group.

The research reveals 79% of respondents have a computer with a CD-rom drive, 29% have a laptop, 6% use a Wap phone and 5% own a PDA.

Pay-per-view TV is by far the most popular use for digital TV - 52% order PPV movies - while some 36% listen to radio through digital TV.

Sky Sports Interactive and Sky New Interactive are accessed by 31% and 25% of ABs respectively.

Just 5% use digital TV to access the internet and 9% use it to access interactive advertising

The Daily Mail, Daily Telegraph, the Times and the Guardian are ABs' favourite daily papers.

The Sunday Times and Mail on Sunday are the favoured weekend reads.

The ABs clearly enjoy celebrity gossip, reading Hello! more than any other magazine. This is followed closely by Good Housekeeping, Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire and FHM.

Radio listening habits have altered since the first VIPer research was carried out a year ago.

Radio 4, Radio 5 Live and Radio 2 have all increased their share of AB listening, while Radio 1 and local BBC radio have lost out.

As 76% of the group use cars as their main method of transport, they see a lot of poster advertising and 75% say they notice posters more if they are amusing.

ABs are more likely to own Ford and Rover cars.

Other VIPer statistics offer a glimpse into the lifestyle of the top demographic group.

Online banking is used by nearly one in five of the group, 95% buy wine (in comparison with 64% of the UK population) and Jacob's Creek is their favourite brand.

Some stereotypes are also confirmed: 62% drink champagne, compared with 24% of the population and, on average, ABs take an impressive nine holidays a year.

fields.headline: Que Pasa Media launches online sales house
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Online media company Que Pasa Media has launched a specialist online advertising sales house, reports Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Online media company Que Pasa Media has used its understanding of the youth entertainment market to launch a specialist online advertising sales house.

This follows the launch of its dance music website in December.

Que Pasa Media Network professes to be the only youth-oriented music and entertainment third-party ad sales house on the web.

It has signed up 20 music, clubbing, community and student websites. Together they boast of over 1m unique users and up to 30m page impressions per month.

One such site is iCrunch, a digital download and streaming website with rights from over 55 UK dance and alternative music labels.

According to Que Pasa founder and chief executive Mark Maddox, the company has identified a gap in the market.

Mr Maddox claimed it has the potential to provide advertisers with a single point of access to sought-after 16 to 34-year-olds.

The network was established following the launch of Burnitblue.com, a dance music website that provides news, reviews, features and listings across 11 genres.

Que Pasa was established by three former youth magazine publishers, including creative director Nick Green, who was previously at the Guardian New Media Lab before it became Guardian Unlimited.

The commercial director is Hugh Burrows, a former music advertising director at Emap.

fields.headline: Analysing the allure of orange
fields.trailText:
8.30am: An increasing number of companies are choosing orange as their corporate colour, writes Julia Day.
Is orange hot? Have your say
fields.body:
The colour red conjures up undeniably strong images - danger, love and sex. Green is equally provocative - safety, envy and nature all come to mind.

Orange, on the other hand, struggles to say anything specific. It strikes a halfway house between the fiercely strong emotions aroused by red and the cowardly, sometimes sickly, images associated with yellow.

In the past five years, however, it seems to have become one of the most popular corporate colours.

EasyJet, Sainsbury's, Orange and, indeed, MediaGuardian.co.uk have all chosen the hue for their branding.

However, just what it signifies is a matter of dispute that has divided MediaGuardian.co.uk users .

Click on our Talk pages to find out why the colour is considered a no-no for prestigious companies in America but is thought to be a reassuring hue in the UK.

"Is it just me, or is there a proliferation of the colour orange on everything new, forward thinking and revamped at the moment? "Why have we collectively decided this is the hue to be?" asked Jenechka.

Here, the UK's foremost branding experts explain the allure of orange.

Michael Wolff, founder of brand consultant Fourth Room and co-founder of Wolff Olins, the company behind the Orange mobile phone brand, said he first used the colour in a big way in 1965 for Camden council.

"People were unaware of what the council was doing for them but once we'd put orange branding on meals on wheels vans and dust carts, people noticed," he said.

"Orange is a way of using red without its stridency, urgency and alarm - it keeps the vibrancy but is warm and cheery.

"Tesco's red means cheap but Sainsbury's orange is red, but not quite," he added.

"Orange is attention-grabbing without being aggressive," explained Marksteen Adamson, international creative director of Interbrand.

"It can be calm, warm and rich as well as fresh and healthy."

Robbie Lawson, Wolff Olins creative director said: "Orange is warm and friendly as opposed to the cold, blue tones used by telecoms companies and banks."

In the past five years, however, it seems to have become one of the most popular corporate colours. EasyJet, Sainsbury's, Orange and, indeed, MediaGuardian.co.uk have all chosen the hue for their branding. However, just what it signifies is a matter of dispute that has divided MediaGuardian.co.uk users . Click on our Talk pages to find out why the colour is considered a no-no for prestigious companies in America but is thought to be a reassuring hue in the UK. "Is it just me, or is there a proliferation of the colour orange on everything new, forward thinking and revamped at the moment? "Why have we collectively decided this is the hue to be?" asked Jenechka. Here, the UK's foremost branding experts explain the allure of orange. Michael Wolff, founder of brand consultant Fourth Room and co-founder of Wolff Olins, the company behind the Orange mobile phone brand, said he first used the colour in a big way in 1965 for Camden council. "People were unaware of what the council was doing for them but once we'd put orange branding on meals on wheels vans and dust carts, people noticed," he said. "Orange is a way of using red without its stridency, urgency and alarm - it keeps the vibrancy but is warm and cheery. "Tesco's red means cheap but Sainsbury's orange is red, but not quite," he added. "Orange is attention-grabbing without being aggressive," explained Marksteen Adamson, international creative director of Interbrand. "It can be calm, warm and rich as well as fresh and healthy." Robbie Lawson, Wolff Olins creative director said: "Orange is warm and friendly as opposed to the cold, blue tones used by telecoms companies and banks." Talkboard Is orange hot? Have your say

webTitle: Business: Telewest in £15m bid for live auction channel

fields.headline: Telewest in £15m bid for live auction channel
fields.trailText: Telewest has agreed a deal to take a significant stake in Sit-up, the digital TV outfit run by Ashley Faull and John Egan, two of the founders of ONdigital. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Telewest has agreed a deal to take a significant stake in Sit-up, the digital television outfit run by Ashley Faull and John Egan, two of the founders of ONdigital.

The cable company is injecting £14.8m into Sit-up which launched a live auction TV channel, Bid-up.tv, last October. At the same time, Sit-up will pay £10m for Screenshop, Telewest's home shopping channel to create a larger business focused on interactive TV. The transactions will leave Telewest with a 38% stake in the enlarged company.

Mr Faull said Sit-up had enough financing in place to see Bid-up.tv and Screenshop through to profitability, but that further cash would be needed to meet the aim of launching more channels.

"We are in the fortunate position now of not needing further cash but we do have high ambitions for this company which are shared by Telewest," he said.

"It will be very useful to have a strategic shareholder."

The company is considering a stock market flotation later this year. Mr Faull and Mr Egan together own around 30% of the business.

Bid-up.tv has featured items ranging from a Renault Clio which sold for £14,000 to the shirt worn by Anthony Hopkins in the Mask of Zorro. The company claims to be attracting 5,000 bids a day which are made through an automated system by using the keypad on a phone.

fields.headline: 'It was a fireball that seemed to fill the whole road'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: By Jamie Wilson.
fields.body:
The usually immaculate facade of Studio 6, the home of television and radio news, was a mess of twisted metal and broken glass yesterday morning. The cross on the T of Television Centre had fallen off, while the BBC logo had disappeared, ripped off the building by the force of the blast.

All that remained of the red London taxi that lit up the night sky of west London when it exploded in the early hours of yesterday was a pile of charred and twisted wreckage. Fragments of its bodywork and the robot that bomb disposal experts had used to try to defuse the device were scattered up and down Wood Lane.

"It was a fireball that seemed to fill the whole road between BBC TV Centre and White City tube station," said Laurie Margolis, a BBC news editor who was watching from the top of a nearby multi-storey car park. "We knew from the police activity something was going to happen, but the actual force of the explosion was very substantial. It was followed by what looked like quite an intense fire on the ground which was the vehicle burning up."

Mr Margolis had made his way to the car park with a cameraman after staff inside Television Centre were evacuated or moved further inside the complex soon after a London hospital received a coded warning at 11.30pm that a maroon hackney cab containing a bomb was parked near the corporation's main building.

"At about 12.15am a bomb disposal vehicle drove up and the robot stayed up close to the taxi. It fired something into the taxi, I think to open it up to see what was inside.

"Whether it was triggered by another round being blasted in by the robot or whether the bomb exploded early, I don't know. But it was a spectacular fireball and there was a physical force to the blast. The car park we were in shook. A bit of the robot flew about 80 yards away."

Staff inside the complex, who had moved to other studios, reported that the windows and walls had shaken.

In nearby houses and flats on the Wood Lane estate double-glazed windows were blown out and pictures fell off walls.

Penny Jones, 49, who lives nearby, said she heard a small bang followed by a larger bang. "I didn't really take any notice of the first one because it sounded like a car backfiring but the second one was a massive explosion. I screamed and was absolutely terrified."

Trevell Archer, 16, who lives about 100 yards from the scene of the explosion in Exhibition Close, heard the bomb from Acton, a couple of miles up the road.

When he got home, he found the front windows in the house where he lives with his parents had shattered. A small piece of twisted metal with debris, almost certainly from the bodywork of the taxi, was lying in the yard.

It was the second bomb to go off off within 100 yards of Trevell's house in the space of a month. His friend, the Territorial Army cadet Stephen Murphy, lost a hand and was blinded when a torch bomb he had picked up in South Africa Row exploded.

webTitle: TV: No news is bad news. David Hencke on small-screen investigative journalism.

fields.headline: No news is bad news
fields.trailText: David Hencke on small-screen investigative journalism.
fields.body:
It would take a hard-nosed and dedicated reporter to get television executives to admit it, but small-screen investigative journalism is in its most parlous state since John Logie Baird invented the box. The reason is simple: it's far better to spend millions on simple formula game shows than risk the uncertainty and wrath of highly paid TV moguls by commissioning a documentary that might fall down at the last moment.

So it should have been refreshing to see that both BBC1 and BBC2 have invested cash in two new investigative programmes on the box, one of them aimed at prime-time viewers, and the other in the "serious" slot following Newsnight. But don't get too excited. One is effectively just a transplantation to the BBC of that old ITV tabloid warhorse, Roger Cook; the other is really insider reportage, with one man and a camcorder, rather than real investigative TV.

Both, in different ways, follow a classic formula. How many times have I, for example, heard commissioning editors (to declare an interest, I am also a director of an obscure semi-professional outfit called Brown Envelope TV) say, "we've got to have secret filming" or "think there's any chance of some violence?" They want this kind of material regardless of the content or even the need to do it. They're also in love with MacIntyre Undercover-style TV - the reporter as the hard man exposing the truth with no regard for his safety or sometimes even his life.

Paul Kenyon on BBC1 on Mondays gives you the lot. Barely have the credits rolled on tonight's programme on bogus doctors, for example, when the fists are flying, with the subject trying to jam shut a loo door to escape from our Paul and his camera team. Secret filming takes up a good half of the programme, and each disclosure is delivered with breathless intensity. Every classic line is there. The duped patients are "disgusted" and "shocked" when the reporter tells them they have been conned. The bogus medics get their comeuppance, the obligatory expert is there to say they have sinned, and even the reporter shows how he can pose as a bogus doctor complete with stethoscope and surgery skeleton and get away with it. By the end, as with a John Wayne movie, we can safely go to our beds, knowing that all the villains have had their just deserts and that our hero has fought his way through, against the odds, and emerged victorious.

Sean Langan is an altogether different character. His late-night BBC2 series, Langan Behind The Lines, shown over five nights last week, explored the hidden and dangerous world of Muslim Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq and the Gaza Strip. It was very personal TV - and the initial scene of him going across the Afghan border seemed too indulgent for words. But unlike Paul Kenyon, people can warm to Sean. His filming in Afghanistan - particularly the episode called Tea With The Taliban - provided amazing insights behind the Muslim veil. The fact that filming is banned in Afghanistan justified the approach. His open filming of the Taliban on the front line showed how the fighters actually love the cameras they outlaw. Many seemed surprised by how handsome they looked.

His decision to film women illegally educating their daughters helped bring out the hidden side of the country. Langan's camera also brought home the horrors of the regime - for example, the atmosphere inside a football stadium where they kill transgressors of the faith. And his points hit home more often than not - such as his observation that, horrible as the deaths of the unbelievers were, they were hardly a million miles from the death penalties routinely meted out in George Bush's home state of Texas.

Langan's film of life in the Gaza Strip brought home the crowded lifestyle of the Palestinians, trapped in permanent refugee camps, surrounded by the occasional spacious and green Israeli settlement. And he highlighted the fact that teenagers are the same anywhere - the rush to appear on film, "to attract a foreign girl", and antics on the beach. He also brought out a telling general ignorance that could only hearten Holocaust deniers - most young Palestinians thought the gassing of six million Jews was a Western myth put about by Zionists. "Perhaps 1,000 died", said one young Palestinian confidently.

But none of the episodes could reasonably be called investigative journalism - even if they did challenge some of the myths about the Muslim world portrayed in the tabloids. Sadly, Langan's late-night series will not have been seen by a wide enough audience to change minds. (It must have been cheap - a hand-held camera, air fares and a number of inexpensive rooms in hotels, and BBC2 have a series all lined up.) But it was worthwhile, and something that could be developped.

What on earth has happened to the real investigations? Even John Ware's recent semi-exposure of Railtrack on Panorama was a disappointment when compared to, for example, his monumental investigation into the "home for votes" scandal in Westminster a decade ago. It is certain that there are as many scandals that would make a big political impact lurking out there. But TV does not want to make the commitment and pay reporters for the many months it would take to amass sufficient evidence. We're left with fascinating but cheap reportage like Sean Langan's series, or the exposure of small to medium-size crooks in Harley Street, just as Roger Cook turned over the small-time villains a year ago. And when the Cook report did get its big chance - to expose the network behind former Tory minister Neil Hamilton and the "cash for questions" scandal involving lobbyist Ian Greer - they fluffed it. The programme was never finished or broadcast. Until TV does go for the "big game" again, we will have to be content with a rogues' gallery of small mammals exposed by the likes of Paul Kenyon.

 Kenyon Confronts, 7.30pm, BBC1

webTitle: Drama crisis at BBC as blockbusters nosedive

fields.headline: Drama crisis at BBC as blockbusters nosedive
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Television drama is in crisis as BBC blockbusters plunge in the ratings, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Television drama is in crisis as BBC blockbusters plunge in the ratings and writers complain of being treated like "ventriloquists' dummies".

Four successive Sunday night BBC dramas have bombed, and executives have ordered an urgent rethink. And writers say their ideas are being ignored.

The BBC is so concerned about the performance of previous Sunday night offerings that it had second thoughts about scheduling one of its most successful series, Clocking Off, on Sundays. Its creator, Paul Abbot, lobbied hard to keep it in the planned slot.

Sunday nights have become the "killing fields" of TV drama, say BBC executives: Take a Girl Like You, Rebel Heart, Love in a Cold Climate, and, most recently, Best of Both Worlds have all performed poorly.

There is trouble elsewhere in BBC entertainment: a Friday night sitcom, Office Gossip, has been universally derided, and Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years, has also nosedived.

ITV is having problems too - it pulled Big Bad World, a comedy starring Ardal O'Hanlon, halfway through its run after poor reviews and low ratings.

The BBC's new head of drama, Jane Tranter, has been given an extra £100m to sort out the situation.
