webTitle: Business: UK mints lion's share of euros

fields.headline: UK mints lion's share of euros
fields.standfirst: Llantrisant plant spits out 700 coins a minute
fields.trailText: In south Wales, they are well prepared for the introduction of the euro. The Royal Mint's plant in Llantrisant has been spitting out 700 euro coins a minute for nearly a year, as part of the preparation for E-day - January 1 - when the first notes and coins of the new currency go into circulation.
fields.body:
In south Wales, they are well prepared for the introduction of the euro. The Royal Mint's plant in Llantrisant has been spitting out 700 euro coins a minute for nearly a year, as part of the preparation for E-day - January 1 - when the first notes and coins of the new currency go into circulation.

Britain may not be a member of the eurozone, but that did not stop the mint - the world's largest producer of copper blanks - winning the lion's share of the contract to produce the 50bn coins which must be ready by E-day. Nine out of 12 euro members have used the mint to produce their new coins.

The scale of the task is underlined by the fact that the euro coins being issued will in total weigh some 250,000 tonnes - enough to fill 15,000 fully loaded trucks.

Strangely enough, the European Central Bank's official website preserves a discreet silence over the British involvement in the production of the euro coins. A helpful map illustrates where the euro notes were printed, but no details are available on the mint's involvement.

While the coins and bank- notes will be ready, with less than 10 months until E-day, policymakers in Europe are becoming increasingly concerned the public will not. There will be a brief changeover period when both national currencies and euros will be legal tender, and thenfrancs, marks and all the other familiar notes and coins will disappear at the end of next February. Several countries are aiming to effect the changeover even more quickly.

Many small firms appear to be leaving it to the last minute to convert their systems to euros. The European Union's lat est survey showed that so far, only 15% of small businesses were prepared for the new currency. Half reported that they would not be ready until 2002.

The European commission fears a surge in demand for accountants and IT specialists to help the changeover could cause bottlenecks, making some firms miss the deadline.

The prospect of paychecks failing to make it into bank accounts is not a happy one, on top of the disruption the new currency is already likely to cause.

Big queues at banks, railway stations and shops are expected as customers and firms struggle with the unfamiliar currency. A simulation by the Dutch national railways suggested the situation on January 1 could be outright chaos, with queues of more than 1,000 at main terminals.

Nobody expects a wholesale rejection of the new currency - even though only 55% of the public actively supports the euro - but a bumpy transition could increase public hostility at a potentially tricky time. Retail sales are expected to plum met in January as some consumers decide to avoid doing the maths involved in calculating prices in the new currency by staying at home.

Last week, the European Central Bank launched a public information campaign to overcome consumer resistance. Although the bulk of its advertising spending will be in the final months before the switch to the euro, the ECB is already targeting those areas - banks, retailers, public and private institutions - which it believes will be well placed to spread the euro message.

fields.headline: New milestone for US executioners
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Antonio Richardson will today become the 700th person to be executed since the death penalty was reintroduced in the United States.
fields.body:
Antonio Richardson will today become the 700th person to be executed since the death penalty was reintroduced in the United States.

The case of the 26-year-old is remarkable on several counts: Richardson is on the border of mental incapacity; he was only 16 at the time of his crime; he was persuaded to turn down a deal that would have kept him off death row; and the parents of his victims are divided on what should happen to him.

"Given the circumstances of his age and his background, this just isn't a case that cries out for giving him death," said Larry Denk, one of his lawyers.

Richardson and three others raped Robin Kerry, 19, and her sister Julie, 20, before pushing them to their deaths into the Mississippi river in St Louis.

Richardson, who has brain damage and an IQ of about 70, called police the next day to tell them of the crimes. All four confessed: one agreed to testify against the others in return for his life, and the other two were sentenced to die.

In the light of his cooperation, Richardson was offered a deal that would have given him a life sentence if he pleaded guilty. He intended to do so until he was visited in jail by a member of a group called the Coalition for Justice, which was trying to portray the case as an anti-black frame-up.

They persuaded Richardson to change his plea and the boy, whose inexperienced lawyer failed to tell the court about his client's mental state, was sentenced to death.

Mr Denk said: "He was offered the opportunity to accept life in prison without parole. He turned that down, we submit, because of the intervention by certain activists whose interests were not compatible with Tony's.

"All we can say is that he's very remorseful about what happened. He's not asking for anything more than the state was prepared to offer him just before his trial."

Richardson will avoid the death penalty only in the unlikely event of late legal appeals succeeding or Missouri's governor granting clemency.

Organisations opposing the sentence include Amnesty International, the American Bar Association and the National Mental Health Association.

They are joined by Ginny Kerry, mother of the dead sisters. "I think that Antonio Richardson is responsible for what he did," she said. "But I requested clemency for him because of his youth and his diminished mental capacity."

Her ex-husband, Richard, takes a different view. "The governor knows that I'm for the death penalty and hopefully he'll do what's right."

"Given the circumstances of his age and his background, this just isn't a case that cries out for giving him death," said Larry Denk, one of his lawyers. Richardson and three others raped Robin Kerry, 19, and her sister Julie, 20, before pushing them to their deaths into the Mississippi river in St Louis. Richardson, who has brain damage and an IQ of about 70, called police the next day to tell them of the crimes. All four confessed: one agreed to testify against the others in return for his life, and the other two were sentenced to die. In the light of his cooperation, Richardson was offered a deal that would have given him a life sentence if he pleaded guilty. He intended to do so until he was visited in jail by a member of a group called the Coalition for Justice, which was trying to portray the case as an anti-black frame-up. They persuaded Richardson to change his plea and the boy, whose inexperienced lawyer failed to tell the court about his client's mental state, was sentenced to death. Mr Denk said: "He was offered the opportunity to accept life in prison without parole. He turned that down, we submit, because of the intervention by certain activists whose interests were not compatible with Tony's. "All we can say is that he's very remorseful about what happened. He's not asking for anything more than the state was prepared to offer him just before his trial." Richardson will avoid the death penalty only in the unlikely event of late legal appeals succeeding or Missouri's governor granting clemency. Organisations opposing the sentence include Amnesty International, the American Bar Association and the National Mental Health Association. They are joined by Ginny Kerry, mother of the dead sisters. "I think that Antonio Richardson is responsible for what he did," she said. "But I requested clemency for him because of his youth and his diminished mental capacity." Her ex-husband, Richard, takes a different view. "The governor knows that I'm for the death penalty and hopefully he'll do what's right."

webTitle: Ransom haggle sets scene for Briton's release

fields.headline: Ransom haggle sets scene for Briton's release
fields.trailText: The British hostage, Tim Selby, was last night on the brink of freedom after a secret ransom deal was apparently agreed between his Danish employers and the kidnappers who have held him for 18 days in the Bangladeshi jungle.
fields.body:
The British hostage, Tim Selby, was last night on the brink of freedom after a secret ransom deal was apparently agreed between his Danish employers and the kidnappers who have held him for 18 days in the Bangladeshi jungle.

Sources said that the construction firm Kampsax was preparing to hand over a ransom of around £200,000 in exchange for Mr Selby's release and that of two Danish colleagues.

The three were kidnapped by tribal bandits on February 16 while on a road-surveying trip in the remote Chittagong hills in south-east Bangladesh.

The Bangladeshi military withdrew an earlier threat to storm the kidnappers' hideout after intermediaries had been given assurances that the three Europeans would be released later today.

"They [the kidnappers] have agreed to set the hostages free and asked for safe passage .. which we have agreed to provide," Colonel Munirul Islam said.

The kidnappers would be allowed to escape by road to the nearby hill station of Rangamati, he added.

Officials have publicly denied that any money was being paid to the bandits. The kidnappers at first demanded 90m taka (£1.2m) in ransom. But sources have privately confirmed that a deal was struck at the end of last week after days of "haggling". "The kidnappers dropped at first to 50%. The price eventually came down to 15m taka," one source said.

Kampsax representatives have not been available for comment.

The apparent deal follows two weeks of mostly frustrated attempts by intermediaries to make contact with the kidnappers. British diplomats have had little choice but to sit in a wooden hut close to the spot where Mr Selby was seized, and await developments.

The 28-year-old Briton is likely to be evacuated by military helicopter to the capital, Dhaka, once he is freed, and then be flown back toBritain.

In a letter written soon after he was abducted at gunpoint, Mr Selby - whose family are from Oldham, Greater Manchester - complained that he and his fellow hostages were in poor health.

More recent reports suggested that they were bearing up reasonably well. The hostages have been surviving on a diet of bananas, coconuts and rice. It is not clear whether they are being held in a village or sleeping out in the jungle.

The Bangladeshi military has closed off a 30sq km area of dense teak and banana forest where the hostages have been kept.Officers have refused demands to lift their troop cordon but have now released relatives of the kidnappers, whom they had earlier rounded up. The kidnappers' identity remains a mystery, but they are believed to belong to a faction opposed to a peace accord four years ago that ended a 20-year-old tribal insurgency.

Civilian officials have criticised Mr Selby and his two colleagues for failing to take a police escort with them when they visited the dangerous forest region.

Some 57 locals have been kidnapped in the area over the past three years. Most were released unharmed after payment of ransom.

The Kampsax group took an escort with them when they visited the same road three days earlier - but they had no guard with them when the armed gang stopped their car and took them hostage.

webTitle: Leader: Labour's lack of women candidates

fields.headline: Favourite daughters
fields.standfirst:
Parachute women into unfilled seats

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: It was one of the iconic images of May 1997: Tony Blair surrounded by more than a hundred women MPs. Activists hoped it was a first step towards the day when the Westminster parliament would reflect the true balance of the nation. It has not quite worked out that way.
fields.body:
It was one of the iconic images of May 1997: Tony Blair surrounded by more than a hundred women MPs. Activists hoped it was a first step towards the day when the Westminster parliament would reflect the true balance of the nation, boasting the same proportion of women in the Commons as there are women in the population: exactly half.

It has not quite worked out that way. Labour has not matched the huge advance of 1997 with an equal leap forward for the next election (whenever that day comes). Of the 600-plus candidates named so far, only 142 are women. Of course, 300 should be the very minimum an egalitarian party aims for - but even 200 would have been an advance. To have selected only 142 is not even to have stood still: in fact, it means there are 16 fewer women candidates for Labour this time than four years ago.

Party officials says the legal ban on all-women shortlists is to blame, but that prompts a sad conclusion. It suggests that, when not forced to choose women, Labour activists tend to pick men. Still, there is a solution at hand. Twenty seven seats remain unfilled; picking women for those would bump up the numbers. Besides, insiders knowingly speak of the last-minute "retirements", often prompted by the offer of a cosy peerage, which suddenly materialise as an election is called. Those instant vacancies are not decided by the local party, but usually settled by the national executive. The past habit has been to fill these openings by parachuting in favoured sons of the high command. High on the parachute list this time would be the likes of Gordon Brown's right-hand man, Ed Balls, or the Tory defector Shaun Woodward. There are also some Downing Street aides with an eye on seats kept warm by aged MPs in Wales and the English north-east. But a more imaginative response might be to replace the old men not with favourite sons - but rather find 27 favoured daughters.

webTitle: Tate Britain recreats Turner's picture gallery

fields.headline: Home from home with Turner ... more or less
fields.standfirst: Tate's anniversary gallery leaves out the wreckage and the 30 cats
fields.trailText: Tate Britain has recreated JMW Turner's own picture gallery to mark the 150th anniversary of the artist's death. However, the features that horrified 19th-century visitors have been omitted.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Tate Britain has recreated JMW Turner's own picture gallery to mark the 150th anniversary of the artist's death. However, the features that horrified 19th-century visitors - leaking roof, sinister housekeeper swathed in bandages and stalked by dozens of Manx cats, paintings blocking a broken window or used as a cat flap - have been omitted.

The Tate usually displays a mixture of the 300 oil paintings and 20,000 watercolours and drawings, including unfinished works from his studio, which it received as part of the Turner bequest. The anniversary exhibition, opening today, collects together only the pictures, many imposing but rather conventional history paintings, which Turner himself chose to keep and display as a testimonial to his own powers as an artist.

The walls have been repainted a dark red, to suggest the colour Turner chose for his own walls.

"We know from a visitor's account that the gallery had red walls, but he rather unhelpfully described it as 'Indian red, neither pale nor dark'," curator David Blayney Brown said. "The paintings are transformed by being hung on it - you can almost hear the pictures sighing with relief." The paintings that can be identified from two tiny, murky contemporary views, done from memory by George Jones, including a view of Richmond and the Battle of Trafalgar, have been hung at the Tate in the positions shown.

"It seemed an interesting way of looking at the collection to display only those works which Turner himself valued most highly, and consciously saw as his own lasting memorial," said Dr Blayney Brown.

Turner, a barber's son, built on a gallery when he acquired his London house in the early 19th century. He bought back some earlier canvases and refused to sell others - including one believed to show his two illegitimate daughters - to add to the collection.

The gallery became his mausoleum in 1851, when his coffin was laid out among the pictures before his burial at St Paul's. The grimly severe facade of the house, designed by Turner himself, was recorded in a Victorian photograph before its demolition. In the last decades of his life many were shocked by their visit. By then the reclusive Turner had a tiny cottage on Chelsea Embankment, and lived there as "Captain Booth", rarely visiting his house and gallery.

Visitors to Harley Street would have made an appointment, knocked on the door and been reluctantly admitted by the alarming figure of the housekeeper, who had a skin disease which meant her entire head was bandaged apart from her eyes. She also collected Manx cats, and up to 30 are believed to have had the run of the house. The exhibition also has objects from the house and library, including a sheet of drawings for a lecture on perspectives, covered in little black paw prints.

Turner permitted his housekeeper to block a broken window with an Italian landscape watercolour - a star exhibit at the recent Academy exhibition of his major watercolours - and to use an early canvas of the Thames foreshore as a cat flap.

His will left the 300 canvases from his gallery to the National Gallery, provided that a special gallery was built for them, and most of his £140,000 fortune to create a hospice for decayed artists. The will was overturned in the high court, with the result that distant relatives got most of the money and the nation got not just his chosen paintings but everything in his studio, including thousands of watercolours, sketches and working drawings.

The Turner bequest - which was transferred to the new Tate Gallery early in the 20th century - has been condemned by some art historians as a betrayal of the artist's intentions.

Dr Blayney Brown said: "Say what you like about the Tate, we have never used a Turner as a cat flap."

webTitle: 'Designer baby' parents give away male embryo

fields.headline: 'Designer baby' parents give away male embryo
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The couple at the centre of a "designer baby" controversy have given away a male embryo after their quest to have a daughter by in vitro fertilisation failed.
fields.body:
The couple at the centre of a "designer baby" controversy have given away a male embryo after their quest to have a daughter by in vitro fertilisation failed.

Alan and Louise Masterton travelled to Italy for treatment which they hoped would allow them to chose the sex of their baby, a practice forbidden in Britain in all but a handful of cases for ethical reasons.

However, the pre-gender diagnosis (PGD) treatment failed to produce a female embryo, and the Mastertons, from Dundee, decided to donate their male embryo to a couple with no children of their own. It is now in cold storage in a Rome clinic, awaiting a suitable recipient.

The Mastertons turned to Italy after every suitable clinic in Britain refused to allow them to chose the sex of their child. Although they have four sons, their daughter, Nicole, died aged three in an accident and the couple want to have another girl to give their family a "female dimension" again.

They are adamant that they are not trying to replace Nicole but the case sparked national debate last October when they tried, unsuccessfully, to overturn the British ban on sex selection.

In July, three months before their case became public, and having already undergone protracted argument with the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), the Mastertons travelled to the private Biogenesi clinic in Rome for the PGD treatment.

Clinicians there said they would go ahead with the treatment because the Mastertons had a special medical need to have a girl.

Mr Masterton, 43, discovered the clinic after looking on the internet and checking in a hospital library. He is unemployed and a family friend lent the couple the £6,000 needed for the treatment.

"PGD was being denied to us in Britain for the most absurd reason and it would have been intolerable for us to live the rest of our lives knowing that there was treatment out there which could help us," said Mr Masterton.

The couple knew they would have only a slim chance of producing a female embryo - the success rate in PGD procedures drops to around 17% compared with around 23% in standard IVF - and they decided they would give away any male embryo before they embarked on the treatment.

"As responsible and intelligent adults we tried to think about all the various outcomes of the treatment," said Mr Masterton. "If the embryo was male we would donate it to a childless couple as our need is for a daughter. We hope this will allow someone else to know the joy of having children."

Mrs Masterton, 42, underwent hormone treatment with Simon Fishel, director of the Centre for Assisted Reproduction in Nottingham, before travelling to Italy.

In Rome, doctors removed three eggs from her ovaries, but two were too immature to use and when the one mature egg was fertilised the embryo was found to be male.

Mrs Masterton was sterilised a year after Nicole's birth, but the HFEA has refused to amend its rules to allow the Mastertons to undergo treatment here.

Its decision is now being scrutinised by the ombudsman and a report is expected in July. After that, the Mastertons are expected to take the HFEA to court under new human rights law.

fields.headline: Mansur Hoda
fields.standfirst: Champion of small enterprises for India's poor
fields.trailText: Champion of small enterprises for India's poor.
fields.body:
With the death of Mansur Hoda at the age of 70, the rural poor of India have lost one of their most effective champions. For more than 30 years, he advanced the cause of small-scale technology, advocating tools and equipment suited to the rural needs and resources of the sub-continent, and working on the research, development and training needed to devise low-cost agricultural tools to help small farmers work themselves out of poverty.

Hoda's great influence was Fritz Schumacher, who wrote Small Is Beautiful. The two first met in 1968, and Hoda was convinced by Schumacher's concept of intermediate technology - something between the sickle and the combine harvester, the hoe and the tractor - as the only feasible solution to the problems of massive unemployment that haunted India and other developing countries.

Born in the Bihar village of Chapra, he looked on his education, which included a science degree from India's Aligarh University, an MSc from Surrey University and a mechanical engineering qualification, as a launching pad to help in this work.

Hoda, who, as a student, had worked as a research volunteer for the Intermediate Technology Group, had 10 years' experience with Indian railways and 10 years as a factory inspector in Bihar. In 1968, along with his brother Surur, and helped by Schumacher, he formed the India Development Group UK, which runs rural development programmes in India with the help of the Indian business community in Britain.

In 1972, Hoda was invited by Jayaprakash Narayan, the leading Gandhian in India, to run the appropriate technology unit at the Gandhian Institute in Varanasi. Schu- macher travelled with him to deliver a series of lectures, and, in 1976, the unit was enlarged and moved to Luck- now, with Hoda as its first director.

It worked on a number of rural technologies, including cotton spinning, renewable energy (solar cooker and biogas) and cycle ricksaw transport. It became internation- ally known for its development of improved mini sugar factories, and an efficient 20-ton-a-day cement plant, using local raw material and making high-quality Portland cement.

In 1983 Hoda returned to Britain to help set up the Gandhi Foundation in London. He returned to Lucknow to set up the Schumacher Institute of Appropriate Technology, training young people from the villages in the management of micro-enterprises and rural skills, such as primary healthcare, maintenance and the repair of scooters, farm equipment and pumps. This work continues to be supported by British and European Union aid.

When Hoda first started work on appropriate technologies, it met opposition from the Indian government. But his approach is now accepted on a state-wide basis.

He is survived by his wife, Khaleda, and his two sons, Faiz and Shuja.

Mansur Hoda, engineer, born April 22 1930; died February 10 2001

webTitle: Mother killed on same Zimbabwe farm as her son

fields.headline: Mother killed on same Zimbabwe farm as her son
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's escalating crisis of lawlessness continued yesterday when gunmen shot dead Gloria Olds, the 68-year-old mother who refused to leave the family farm after her son Martin was murdered there a year ago.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's escalating crisis of lawlessness continued yesterday when gunmen shot dead Gloria Olds, the 68-year-old mother who refused to leave the family farm after her son Martin was murdered there a year ago.

Her surviving son, David, barricaded himself in the farmhouse with his mother's body, shooting at anyone who approached. His shots forced police investigating the murder to flee the scene.

Neighbouring farmers and a Catholic priest later entered the house and convinced Mr Olds to release his mother's body. Negotiations continued last night to persuade the distraught son to put down his weapons.

The killing of Mrs Olds will fuel the controversy surrounding President Robert Mugabe's visit to Paris and Brussels today.

The flinty Mrs Olds had refused to leave the family farm in Nyamandlovu, 25 miles west of Bulawayo, despite the hit-squad killing of her son, Martin, on April 18. She refused to be frightened into moving off the farm by the self-styled "war veterans" loyal to President Mugabe who took over her son's adjacent farm.

Mrs Olds was ambushed at dawn as she opened the farm gates. She died in a hail of automatic gunfire from an AK-47 assault rifle, the weapon associated with Mr Mugabe's "war veterans". Her three dogs were also killed.

Her killers stole her truck but did not take other property, according to family sources. Neighbouring farmers using a light aircraft have tracked down the truck, and police are said to be in pursuit.

fields.headline: Joseph Bamford
fields.standfirst: Engineer who gave his name to a machine on every building site - the JCB digger
fields.trailText: Engineer who gave his name to a machine on every building site - the JCB digger.
fields.body:
Joseph Cyril Bamford, who has died aged 84, founded the hugely successful construction equipment company that bears his initials, JCB. The letters themselves have become a word in their own right, defined in the Oxford English Dictionary as "a type of mechanical excavator with a shovel at the front and a digging arm at the rear". The vivid colour that they always display has become a standard paint, known as "JCB yellow".

From modest beginnings at the end of the second world war, Bamford began developing agricultural trailers. At his death, JCB was the largest privately-owned engineering company in Britain, employing 4,500 people and manufacturing 30,000 machines a year in 12 factories on three continents. It had revenues of £850m in 1999, earned from 140 countries.

Joe Bamford, or Mr JCB as he was known by the construction equipment industry, was the great-grandson of the founder of Bamfords Ltd, the agricultural engineering company based in Uttoxeter, where he was born. On leaving Stonyhurst College, Lancashire, he set out to pursue his own engineering goals, working with several Midlands engineering firms, and serving in Africa as a diesel engineer.

During the second world war, he worked with the Ministry of Aircraft Production and English Electric, where he learned valuable lessons about welding techniques. After the war, Bamford joined the family firm, only to be released by his Uncle Henry, who thought Joe had "little future ahead of him".

So, in 1945, Bamford started building agricultural trailers in a lock-up garage rented for 30 shillings a week - opening for business on the day his first son, Anthony, was born. Demand in the late 1940s was brisk, and the agricultural trailer business prospered. A family and no money "tended to concentrate my mind", he said later.

However, it was his diversification into hydraulics in 1948 that proved to be the turning point, with the launch of the major loader, the first European hydraulic loader, whose availability of double acting rams and a variety of attachments became a driving force behind postwar agricultural mechanisation. JCB's first excavator (or backhoe) was launched in 1953, with the revolutionary JCB MK1, an excavator with a 180- degree slew fitted to a tractor.

In 1957, the first backhoe loader was launched as the hydra-digga, incorporating the excavator and the major loader as a single, all-purpose tool. Without abandoning his agricultural roots, Bamford had moved into the rapidly-expanding construction industry; even today, both sectors remain crucial to the company's success.

Few people excel either at engineering or marketing, but Bamford was among a handful of postwar engineers who successfully combined both skills. His engineering abilities, and passion for creating problem-solving machinery, enabled JCB to grow quickly. His philosophy was "simplicate, don't complicate", while being dubbed "jamais content B" by French colleagues summed up much of his approach to engineering.

He will, however, be rem- embered by the industry as much for his marketing skills - some would say pranks - as for his engineering prowess. After scouring Eur- ope for a 12-volt socket, he incorporated a kettle into the driver's cab, and presented the machine personally to the first 100 owners, arriving in his Rolls-Royce, with JCB1 on the nameplate. He purchased a corporate aircraft to fly in foreign customers, who were met by a Cadillac with the same number of seats as the aircraft. He also built an award-winning factory that became a key marketing tool, and launched the "dancing diggers", whose parade down Las Vegas's main street in 1999 stopped the gamblers.

Bamford ran his company according to trenchant guiding principles: don't borrow money; plough profits back into research and manufacturing; create a healthy working environment, and work hard. As he said: "The problem with the competition is that they get up late and go to bed early." In 1969, he was appointed a CBE, and in 1993 became the first - and only - Briton to be honoured in the American Construction Equipment Hall of Fame.

Mr JCB retired in 1975, leaving the business under the chairmanship of his elder son, now Sir Anthony. He went to live in Switzerland to pursue his interests of yacht design and landscape design. His passion for engineering continued, with the development of a diesel engine being a consuming interest.

He is survived by his wife Marjorie, whom he married in 1942, and their two sons.

Joseph Cyril Bamford, engineer, born June 21 1916; died on March 1 2001

fields.headline: Arlene Mundle
fields.standfirst: Brixton leader building bridges between the black community and the police
fields.trailText: Brixton leader building bridges between the black community and the police.
fields.body:
Arlene Mundle, who has died of cancer aged 47, was a campaigner for social justice and a fearsome adversary to anyone who stood in her way. She was a crucial figure in reshaping relations between the black community and the police in south London, but her influence stretched far wider, touching at the very heart of national policing policy.

Born in Portland, Jamaica, Arlene was the granddaughter of a prosperous businessman and the daughter of an RAF warrant officer. When she was two, her family moved to Hong Kong, where her earliest memories were of life on the military base as the only black family. She recalled no overt racism, just a sense of being different and special, qualities which continued to set her apart.

In the late 1950s, her grand- father brought the family to Brixton, south London, where she and her sisters went to the Dick Sheppard school. At the age of 16, she began work as a secretary and switchboard operator. In her early 20s, she married Lascelves Mundle and had two children, Rascelles and Acqua, though the marriage broke up shortly afterwards. Later, she met Cecil "Junior" Williams, with whom she had a daughter, Cassandra. Attracted by his sense of life's possibilities, she recalled this as her happiest period.

By the mid 1980s, Arlene was enjoying the showy affluence of the times, earning good money as an escort in West End clubs. It was also the period in which crack- cocaine started appearing in Britain, and Arlene and Junior's lives took a downward turn as they became sucked into the world of drugs and crime. By the mid-90s, rather than continue to drag each other down, Junior left. Arlene knew it was time to turn her life around.

There was another blow when her friend, Brian Douglas, died in police custody in 1995. His family mounted a campaign to press for justice, and Arlene threw herself into this activity with a passion and fury. This was her first encounter with the community police consultative group in Lambeth, which was to become the platform from which she launched her public career.

Arlene's temper was legendary, and, at first, her anger at the racism and injustice she perceived as endemic in police relations with black people boiled at an almost uncontrollable pitch. But she harnessed that energy, in particular working with Lee Jasper's 1990 Trust, motivating others and engaging her organisational skills to huge effect. She met Stephen Lawrence's parents and, through various campaigns, started to understand more about police work.

Arlene saw how black victims of crime were being poorly served by the police, but, more controversially, believed change would only come if the black community engaged with the authorities to push for it. No one pushed harder than she did.

Her direct approach and unorthox methods - telephone calls in the early hours, even to senior officers, were her trademark - came as a culture shock to the Metropolitan police. But at a time when the police needed to listen, she had plenty to say, so she was employed to provide a much-needed community perspective for senior officers on training exercises, and to advise an operation tackling drug-related gun crime, codenamed Trident.

At times, Arlene jeopardised her own safety, but she was never afraid to speak out against the villains on her doorstep, and took the lead in promoting a highly successful firarms amnesty in Lambeth. During the tension that followed the Brixton nailbombing in 1999, she was a conduit of understanding between grassroots black feeling and the police investigation.

When her cancer was diagnosed just before Christmas last year, messages of support came in from chief constables and from public figures such Neville Lawrence, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the former football star, Ian Wright. Two months ago, she received a Metropolitan police commissioner's commendation.

Everything Arlene achieved was done through her own efforts. Tragically, her illness struck just as she was to embark on a law degree at Southampton University. Her life was about transforma tion and she would have become a fine lawyer. She is survived by her three children and her mother.
Lee Jasper writes: Arlene Mundle was the kind of person whom you felt you had known for years. In that sense she was an "old soul". I first met her through my association with the Brian Douglas Family Campaign in 1995.

Working for me at the 1990 Trust, she had convinced me of the need to speak publicly about how the black community could work with the police to tackle crack-cocaine gun violence. It was a difficult position to take. Nevertheless, she worked hard to ensure I spoke about these issues publicly. Make no mistake, Arlene gave me the confidence to speak out. Her enthusiasm was infectious.

Over the years, she developed leadership skills and became a figure in her own right. To me, she was my sister and confidant. In Jamaican terms, she was my key spar. Her work will remain a shining testimony to her selfless dedication.

Arlene Mundle, community leader and police adviser, born August 17 1953; died March 2 2001

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: G8 progress on global warming
fields.body:
G8 progress on global warming

The G8 countries yesterday renewed promises to tackle global warming after the US hinted it would honour commitments made by Bill Clinton.

A summit of environment ministers in Trieste ended in cautious optimism that the Kyoto accord, threatened by the collapse of a UN conference last year, would be finalised this summer.

Environmentalists wel- comed a pledge to resolve disputes on gas emissions. Rory Carroll, Rome14

Macedonia rebellion grows

Macedonia's ethnic Albanian insurgency spread in size and intensity yesterday as troops fought hundreds of guerrillas in two villages and on a mountain top near the Kosovo border.

Two soldiers died when their vehicle hit a landmine. A third was killed by sniper fire. AP, Skopje

Khatami ally facing prison

An Iranian court yesterday sentenced the deputy interior minister, an ally of President Mohammed Khatami, to a year's jail for vote-rigging in last year's parliamentary elections.

The ruling by the conservative-dominated court would bar Mostafa Tajzadeh, from organising presidential elections in June. He is free pending appeal. Reuters, Tehran

No late reprieve for Tolstoy

The leader of the Russian Orthodox church, Patriarch Alexei II, said yesterday he did not believe the church could lift the excommunication of Leo Tolstoy, as the author's great-great-great grandson had requested, according to a news report. AP, Moscow

webTitle: Bomb was meant for me, says Thai prime minister

fields.headline: Bomb was meant for me, says Thai prime minister
fields.trailText: The new prime minister of Thailand, Thaksin Shinawatra, said yesterday that an explosion on Saturday on a Thai Airways jet at Bangkok's Don Muang airport minutes before he was due to board it was probably an assassination attempt and an inside job.
fields.body:
The new prime minister of Thailand, Thaksin Shinawatra, said yesterday that an explosion on Saturday on a Thai Airways jet at Bangkok's Don Muang airport minutes before he was due to board it was probably an assassination attempt and an inside job.

Mr Sinawatra was in a nearby VIP lounge when the explosion occurred in the front section of the Boeing 737-400 near where he was scheduled to sit. One member of the cabin crew was killed.

The prime minister's life was thought to have been saved by a half-hour departure delay.

"It is clear now that it [the explosion] was not caused by the engine, but involved explosives," he said in the northern city of Chiang Mai, where he eventually arrived by military plane.

"This is an attempt to hurt somebody. I don't know whether I was the target or somebody else but, as far as I know, there were no other important people on the flight."

Mr Shinawatra refused to speculate about who might have been responsible for the blast, but one of his security advisers, Police General Prasarn Wongwai, said the billionaire telecoms tycoon had his suspicions.

"I have already talked to the prime minister and he seems to have a clue who did it. But he wouldn't want to talk too much because it might pressure the investigation officials."

Thailand's air investigation agency, which is leading the investigation, has yet to comment officially on what caused the explosion. But, as the engines were not switched on at the time of the explosion, a mechanical malfunction is expected to be ruled out.

Thailand is no stranger to coup attempts, but no prime minister in this constitutional monarchy has faced an assassination attempt.

Last night Mr Shinawatra suggested that someone close to him must have been involved in the explosion; he had originally planned to go to Chiang Mai yesterday but told his secretary on Friday to change the flight to Saturday afternoon.

"If I was a target of the explosion, the one who placed the bomb should have had access to my schedule," he said.

Local media are speculating that the most likely perpetrator is someone with links to the extremely lucrative drugs trade in the Golden Triangle, the region where Thailand, Burma and Laos meet.

Mr Shinawatra made repeated promises during the election campaign to crack down hard on drug traffickers, particularly drug lords in Burma moving their wares through Thailand. He reiterated that promise yesterday, vowing to eradicate the "rampant" drugs trade that is blighting the region.

The manifest showed that 149 passengers, including the prime minister and his son, were booked to be on flight TG114 to Chiang Mai.

Mr Shinawatra's Thai Rak Thai (Thai Love Thai) party swept to power largely on the back of the leader's personal popularity, bolstered by campaign promises of tens of thousands of pounds for every village, and tax cuts.

Despite his party's landslide victory the prime minister might be out of office in a couple of months if a corruption indictment against him is upheld by the constitutional court.

He is accused of hiding assets while serving in a previous administration. His defence could include the fact thatthat Thais knew of the scandal well before polling day but still voted for him in record numbers.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed Fruitful fare, page 12, Society, February 28, we attributed to its author, a voluntary neighbourhood worker in Easterhouse, Glasgow, the following: "I met lone parents who, after deductions, had a weekly cash income of less than £7." It should have been "less than £73".
fields.body:
In an article headed Fruitful fare, page 12, Society, February 28, we attributed to its author, a voluntary neighbourhood worker in Easterhouse, Glasgow, the following: "I met lone parents who, after deductions, had a weekly cash income of less than £7." It should have been "less than £73".

An article on pages 14 and 15 (Arts), G2, February 13, about the box office fortunes of the film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, should have acknowledged the magazine Variety as a source of information and the stimulus for the Guardian piece. Sorry that it did not do that.

The Children's Trust, based at Tadworth in Surrey, which has a fundraising appeal called the Hand of Hope appeal, has asked us to point out that it is in no way connected with the Hands of Hope Children's Cancer Fund, two trustees of which were convicted of stealing about £250,000 from street collections (a brief item, page 11, March 2).

In an article headed Lie back and think of England, page 2, Office Hours, February 26, we described Paul Kinsella as the former UK manager of World Online. In fact, he was the chief executive officer.

Correction to a correction, in this column February 28. We said Arsenal lost at home 2-6 to Manchester United in the 1991-92 season. We should have said in the 1990-91 season (November 28, 1990, in fact).

In a piece headed The perils of loyalty, page 22 (Comment), March 1, we referred to "the moral satin of Clinton's career". That should have read "the moral stain" etc.

webTitle: US sub trip was only put on for VIPs

fields.headline: US sub trip was only put on for VIPs
fields.trailText: The US navy submarine which accidentally sank a Japanese fishing vessel last month was carrying out an exercise purely for the entertainment of civilians aboard, it has emerged.
fields.body:
The US navy submarine which accidentally sank a Japanese fishing vessel last month was carrying out an exercise purely for the entertainment of civilians aboard, it has emerged.

The submarine's captain had been ordered by senior officers to accommodate visiting VIPs as a public relations exercise for the navy, which wanted to increase the size of its nuclear submarine fleet.

The revelations about the tragedy which claimed the lives of nine people, including four school students, aboard the Ehime Maru, come as an inquiry begins today.15

The inquiry into the sinking will fuel anger in Japan, where suspicions have already been aired that the fatal trip was just a "joy ride" and not a necessary naval exercise.

Navy officials now say that had it not been for the civilians, who included influential Texas businessmen in the oil and gas industries, the trip would not have taken place. "There was no other reason to be out there," an official told the New York Times.

The captain of USS Greenville, Commander Scott Waddle, had not intended to take his vessel out of Pearl Harbour on February 9. However, a party of 16 civilians, including the businessmen, a journalist and people involved with fundraising for a navy memorial, had been due to take a trip with the sub. Senior officers asked Waddle to accommodate them.

What has emerged since the accident is the large number of PR trips laid on by the armed forces at a time when they feared budget cuts.

Those invited usually include "influencers" who might be able to promote the armed forces' case with politicians. In 1999, there were 54 trips laid on for civilians on US navy submarines and a further 50 last year. Last summer, USS Greenville gave a ride to James Cameron, director of the film Titanic, picking him up in California.

It has already emerged that some crew members felt the presence of 16 civilians in the control room distracted them, and that a civilian's hands were on the controls at the time the submarine surfaced.

fields.headline: Better sources for organs
fields.trailText: Six weeks ago, I underwent surgery to donate one of my kidneys to my wife (£3m drive to double organ donor cards, February 28). Although we are told this operation is becoming more common, the bureaucratic hoops that we had to jump through to get consent would have put less determined people off.
fields.body:
Six weeks ago, I underwent surgery to donate one of my kidneys to my wife (£3m drive to double organ donor cards, February 28). Although we are told this operation is becoming more common and has a greater success rate than that for a cadaveric transplant, the bureaucratic hoops that we had to jump through to get consent would have put less determined people off.

Such processes exist to eliminate the chance of human organs being sold, but a fresh approach to this issue could lead to a good number of the 5,000 people on the list getting their transplant. Having met dialysis patients who are waiting for a cadaveric transplant, I know many of them will have a friend or relative willing to step forward, if only encouraged to do so. It is a myth that precise compatibility is a prerequisite for a transplant - in our case being the same blood group seemed to be good enough.

Unblocking this route could substantially reduce waiting lists, lead to more successful outcomes, and ease the expensive burden dialysis places on the NHS.
Chris Hurdle
Address supplied

 I hold an organ donor's card, but this is an expression of intent rather than anything binding on my immediate relative after my death. In the US, you are asked to opt into the local scheme when you first get a driver's licence and to confirm on renewal. State law, at least in Virginia where I hold a driver's licence, is binding.
Dominic Pinto
London

webTitle: Swiss vote heavily to stay out of EU

fields.headline: Swiss vote heavily to stay out of EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Swiss voters yesterday scuppered any chance of bringing their country into the EU within the next ten years after an overwhelming majority rejected a referendum proposal that would have triggered membership negotiations.
fields.body:
Swiss voters yesterday scuppered any chance of bringing their country into the EU within the next ten years after an overwhelming majority rejected a referendum proposal that would have triggered membership negotiations.

The "yes to Europe" proposal, brought by a private group of pro-European campaigners who successfully petitioned for the referendum in 1996, was rejected by 77% to 23%.

In addition to the unsettling changes the prosperous Swiss fear they would need to make to their coveted institutions, the unexpectedly wide margin of defeat signalled a no-confidence vote in the workings of the 15-member EU.

Barely two months ago, polls indicated a close result which largely reflected the state of public opinion in recent years.

The major surprise was the rejection by western regions, where the minority French-speaking community is normally supportive of closer EU ties. Even in the canton of Geneva, an internationalist bastion, 58.9% said No. In some Swiss-German rural areas, more than 90% rejected the step.

"We lost the vote very clearly, but what's not so clear is who won it - our government which said not now but later, or those who say the EU never?" said Marc Suter, an MP of the conservative Radical Party and leader of the pro-EU campaign.

Despite its stated long-term aim of seeking EU membership, the Swiss government had campaigned against the proposal, arguing that the country was not ready for such a step.

Privately, however, most ministers had counted on a smaller margin of defeat, fearing that a sweeping outcome would play into the hands of the dominant isolationist trend among rightwing parties and majority Swiss-German areas.

The government said the result was largely about procedure and should not be interpreted as a rejection of membership. But the rightwing Swiss People's Party, the second largest in parliament, welcomed the outcome as a clear sign of disapproval.

Traditionally, most Swiss have feared that outside ties, even with the UN, of which they are not a member, would jeopardise their sovereignty. Brussels is perceived as a threat both to neutrality and to a thriving strong currency, the Swiss franc.

After a setback in 1992 when an association agreement with the EU was rejected, the Swiss approved a series of bilateral economic accords with Brussels last year.

But the four-party government won over Eurosceptics with a promise that the agreements on areas such as transport and labour would benefit the Swiss economy without being a stepping stone for membership.

Negotiations on further piecemeal accords are due to begin on Thursday.

fields.headline: The Tories' dilemma
fields.trailText: You suggest that the UK Independence party is doing a deal with the Tories not to stand in certain constituencies ('£2m deal' to shield Tory marginals, March 3). As chairman of the eastern region of the UKIP, and a prospective candidate at the next election, I believe that the days of Euroscepticism are long over.
fields.body:
You suggest that the UK Independence party is doing a deal with the Tories not to stand in certain constituencies ('£2m deal' to shield Tory marginals, March 3). As chairman of the eastern region of the UKIP, and a prospective candidate at the next election, I believe that the days of Euroscepticism are long over. You either support the EU or you are against it. The Tory party supports the EU, therefore any candidate who wants to be elected for that party is by definition a supporter of the EU.

The allegiance to the EU, and to Britain eventually joining the Emu, is virtually the same in the Tory, Labour and Lib Dem parties, yet the Tory party continues to promote the deception with slogans like "In Europe, not run by Europe". It is also cynically promoting itself as the party that will save the pound, when it has no such intention.

William Hague claims that, if elected, his party will successfully negotiate major changes to the operation of the EU. He may well obtain some concessions, but he is deluding himself, and the country, if he thinks he can change the essence of the EU without the overwhelming support of other countries. He would need to get this support before the next general election, and this is not very likely.

I cannot imagine the leaders of UKIP doing a deal with the Tories, even though we are sorely in need of funds. However, if they do take the money, that will be the end of UKIP.
Brian Lee
Hadleigh, Essex
brianlee@ukipsouthend.freeserve.co.uk

 Your leader (March 2), displays a disturbing lack of knowledge of electioneering. Will you allow a Tory to trespass on your pages? Campaigning from a safe distance by phone and email may well suit Labour canvassers, who are as welcome in the countryside as the foot and mouth virus. The Conservative campaign, however, is based almost entirely on door-to-door canvassing, which had already started in some areas. Posters are to be displayed alongside main roads and people without transport conveyed to the polling stations. Livestock markets and country fairs (currently suspended) provide candidates with opportunities to meet the electorate; and a programme of public question and answer sessions in village halls was scheduled.

It would obviously be to Labour's advantage to hold elections while their opponents' campaigns are effectively banned. Faced with the near certainty of rejection in country seats, the foot and mouth crisis must have seemed to be heavensent and it comes as no surprise that they should exploit it to the full.
Peter Lally
Broseley, Shropshire

webTitle: Letters: Take the theatre out to the people

fields.headline: Take the theatre out to the people
fields.trailText: In your report of the theatre conference (Theatre world backs 'ball-breaker' attack, March 3) all the theatre practitioners mentioned have one thing in common: they have a building to fill. The most exciting pieces of theatre I have seen in the last year have not taken place in theatre buildings.
fields.body:
In your report of the theatre conference (Theatre world backs 'ball-breaker' attack, March 3) all the theatre practitioners mentioned have one thing in common: they have a building to fill. The most exciting pieces of theatre I have seen in the last year have not taken place in theatre buildings: Foursight Theatre in a school hall and Brioni Lavery's site-specific piece for Pentabus in and around Ludlow Castle.

Performances in theatres dully fulfil expectations, - "Yes, that was Hamlet, alright" - while theatre in unexpected places has much more capacity to delight and excite.

A few building-based companies make a token recognition of this: Birmingham Rep's community tours, the RSC taking The Tempest to sports halls. But the amount of subsidy that goes on these projects is absolutely minimal compared with what is eaten up finding product for a boring building. If people won't come to the theatre, perhaps the theatre ought to come to the people.
Robert Petty
Coalbrookdale, Salop
rscpetty@aol.com

 Of course theatre companies "spend so much on development, marketing, infrastructure and admin". Has Richard Eyre ever tried asking for subsidy for anything else?

In my experience it simply hasn't been possible. And as the artistic director of a company that really has dedicated the past 23 years to making "theatre accessible to a wider range of people", what do you get for your troubles? Being told that your real subsidy needs can't be taken seriously because no one's heard of you. No one no doubt meaning those "leading members in the theatre world" that "queued up to endorse" Eyre's speech.
Bob Frith
Rossendale, Lancs
hb@compnet.co.uk

 Every empty seat at a performance is a missed opportunity to attract a wider audience who can't afford full prices. There is a need for more creative pricing policies, such as the splendid "Pay What You Can" schemes run by the Tricycle, Donmar and Almeida theatres, for example.
Peter Croft
London Free List
peter@londonfreelist.com

Great Missenden, Bucks

webTitle: Letters: Too fast - and too slow

fields.headline: Too fast - and too slow
fields.trailText: The Selby rail crash shows that a dedicated high-speed rail network, as exists in Japan and France, is needed (Land Rover went through safety barrier gap, March 3).
fields.body:
The Selby rail crash shows that a dedicated high-speed rail network, as exists in Japan and France, is needed (Land Rover went through safety barrier gap, March 3). Britain is trying to mix high-speed with other trains and with points, crossings, bridges, that came into existence about 150 years ago, when trains weighed about 50 tons and did 50mph.
AJ Hollis
Letchworth, Herts

 It is ironic for the government to now start complaining that judicial review of its privatisation plans may cause a delay to tube improvements (Prescott 'at compromise limit' March 2). Labour has been in power for nearly four years already - why hasn't anything been done before now?
Mark Pack
London

 There is a Scouse analogy to Afro-Caribbeans' use of "bitch" for any woman, from the Queen down (Letters, March 3). Here in Liverpool, when men speak of "me tart" (pronounced "tsaaht", with drawn-back lips), they do not mean a prostitute but, affectionately, their girlfriend or partner - more rarely wife. But I doubt whether the Duke of Edinburgh has much use for either expression.
Fritz Spiegl
Compiler, Lern Yerself Scouse

 I feel complimented when my Glaswegian friend (in his fifties) calls me a "bright wee bitch". Then again, when he refers to a male colleague as a "daft bugger", I doubt he is dismissing the man as a mentally deficient homosexual.
Helene Parry
Twickenham, Middx

 To explain to our younger children what is happening on farms perhaps the government could rewrite some of our old nursery rhymes for distribution to schools, eg Baa Baa Burnt Sheep, Old MacDonald Had a Pyre, Mary Torched Her Little Lamb etc.
Steve Little
Lytham St Annes, Lancs

fields.headline: The same old song
fields.standfirst:
For the Tories it is bash the foreigners

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday confirmed that while his Tory party would never be at the heart of Europe, Europe will be at the heart of his election campaign. So much, so predictable.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday confirmed that while his Tory party would never be at the heart of Europe, Europe will be at the heart of his election campaign. So much, so predictable. There was not much else on offer in the leader's peroration yesterday to feed the faithful. In a speech as dispiriting as it was dispirited, the Tory leader appealed to the baser instincts - to punish, to expel, sadly even to hate, for what else was his repeated incantation about "foreign" all about? The pro-Tory noise made on a daily basis by our politicised and biased press, so influential in setting broadcasters' agendas also, often leads us to forget how narrow the social and ideological base of the post-Major party has become. Token children had been marooned on the Harrogate platform, coached to applaud even Mr Hague's insistence on harsher discipline - classroom traitors! - but they could not reduce the wrinkle count in the auditorium. In an ageing society there is of course nothing disreputable in basing partisan appeal on the elderly as an interest group. But not all the old are reactionary or xenophobic - words Mr Hague dislikes, but which are often apt to characterise his cry - and not all the old command the savings from which Michael Portillo proposes to lift income tax.

Mr Hague begged the non-Tory public to "lend" him its vote so that, as he put it, it would have the chance to exercise it in some future contest - Brussels having evacuated the content of UK democracy in the mean time. But on Europe, Hagueite populism is far from consistent. Trust the people, but not to vote in a referendum on entry to the single currency. Trust the people, but not to confide in them that the clear logic of Tory policy is exit from the European Union into a state of permanent commercial and diplomatic friction with our neighbours. If the purpose of never saying "never" to joining the euro is to keep the Tory party's big beasts in the zoo, Michael Heseltine's twitch at the weekend came close to making it redundant. Increasingly, the presence in Tory ranks of the likes of Kenneth Clarke is what keeps the party from becoming an honest party of EU withdrawal.

And if the Tory party acknowledged that openly, surely some permanent change in the political disposition of British business would follow. The discomfort of the corporate class with really existing Conservatism has been evident since the early 80s. Perhaps if we had proportional representation at Westminster and party lines blew up, business would find a new sweetheart - for the affair with Labour has never really been consummated, despite Tony Blair's seductive smiling. Both the objective and self-perceived interests of a wide swathe of private companies are completely now out of sync with what the Tories threaten to do in power.

The party faithful at Harrogate applauded like automata but under the cover of anonymity told pollsters of their belief in the next leader of the Tory party. Will they happily applaud, say Michael Portillo, if he were to offer them a kinder, gentler and more winning formula? Like Labour in the 80s and 90s, the return of the Tories from the uplands of electoral exclusion will have to take Mosaic form, that is to say it will have to be a revolution from above. But the analogy is limited. Unlike Labour the Tory transformation will have to be accomplished in the face of vociferous and influential newspapers which may not like Mr Hague much but are certainly no friends of a more liberal-minded or internationally responsible set of policies.

But not all the old are reactionary or xenophobic - words Mr Hague dislikes, but which are often apt to characterise his cry - and not all the old command the savings from which Michael Portillo proposes to lift income tax. Mr Hague begged the non-Tory public to "lend" him its vote so that, as he put it, it would have the chance to exercise it in some future contest - Brussels having evacuated the content of UK democracy in the mean time. But on Europe, Hagueite populism is far from consistent. Trust the people, but not to vote in a referendum on entry to the single currency. Trust the people, but not to confide in them that the clear logic of Tory policy is exit from the European Union into a state of permanent commercial and diplomatic friction with our neighbours. If the purpose of never saying "never" to joining the euro is to keep the Tory party's big beasts in the zoo, Michael Heseltine's twitch at the weekend came close to making it redundant. Increasingly, the presence in Tory ranks of the likes of Kenneth Clarke is what keeps the party from becoming an honest party of EU withdrawal. And if the Tory party acknowledged that openly, surely some permanent change in the political disposition of British business would follow. The discomfort of the corporate class with really existing Conservatism has been evident since the early 80s. Perhaps if we had proportional representation at Westminster and party lines blew up, business would find a new sweetheart - for the affair with Labour has never really been consummated, despite Tony Blair's seductive smiling. Both the objective and self-perceived interests of a wide swathe of private companies are completely now out of sync with what the Tories threaten to do in power. The party faithful at Harrogate applauded like automata but under the cover of anonymity told pollsters of their belief in the next leader of the Tory party. Will they happily applaud, say Michael Portillo, if he were to offer them a kinder, gentler and more winning formula? Like Labour in the 80s and 90s, the return of the Tories from the uplands of electoral exclusion will have to take Mosaic form, that is to say it will have to be a revolution from above. But the analogy is limited. Unlike Labour the Tory transformation will have to be accomplished in the face of vociferous and influential newspapers which may not like Mr Hague much but are certainly no friends of a more liberal-minded or internationally responsible set of policies.

fields.headline: Political dreamers reply
fields.trailText: I am pleased Polly Toynbee went to Socialist Alliance's press conference and yet she seems to have missed the point (Coalition of dreamers, March 2).
fields.body:
I am pleased Polly Toynbee went to Socialist Alliance's press conference and yet she seems to have missed the point (Coalition of dreamers, March 2). The Socialist Alliance is not a coalition of Militant and the Socialist Workers party. Many of us in the SA would never join either of these organisations.

The Socialist Alliance is not there to poke and prod Mr Blair to throw a few more scraps to the poor. Rather, it is that Labour has ceased to represent working people. Labour has been transformed from a party which demanded concessions from business to a party that directly represents business. If it offers a few concessions to some poorer voters, this is not because the poor are part of the project, but because they are needed for Blair to win office. This is no different from the other parties offering something to the poor.

Yes socialists dream. And so they should - to hell with the stuffy accountants asking of every policy, "will our friends in business be happy with this"? The Socialist Alliance will get a lot of policies wrong, it will be vague and muddled (just like the other parties). However, for the first time for a long while, ordinary people will have a party in which they are members and the subjects of policy, not objects to be treated with Alastair Campbell's contempt.
Geoff Barr
Exeter

 It is precisely the jaded cynicism displayed by Polly Toynbee that is turning people, especially young voters, off politics. If we cannot aim for a better society - yes, to dream of a new sort of world - then our political views descend into those of the "old troupers" abandoning the "romance" of fighting for a just society. Politics becomes the vehicle of cynical manipulation, not of hope, justice and freedom. Would Polly Toynbee condemn Martin Luther King for having a dream?
Marcus Larsen
Chair, London Socialist Alliance
marcus.larsen@lineone.net

 Polly Toynbee fails to acknowledge both the number of supporters who have spent decades within the Labour party - John Mulrenan, standing against Harriet Harman, was her election agent in the 1982 election which first brought her into parliament - and those who, like myself, have never previously been members of any political party. Labour's self-reinvention as a "pro-business" party has created a vacuum on the left, and someone's got to fill it. What have the Romans done for us? Not nearly as much as they've done for the Romans.
Charles Shaar Murray
London
csm@angels.demon.co.uk

 Of course the left can be quixotic and frustrating. But at least it sees Blairite New Labour for the entryism it is. An evangelical, middle-class concern for the deserving poor, it has no philosophical basis in socialism and seemingly less and less with liberal democracy. It's still a damn sight better than Toryism, but Polly is going to be disappointed.
Chris Walker
Woking, Surrey

 I am fortunate in that I chose to move to south Wales 23 years ago. My wife and I are now active members of a genuinely modern, socialist party: Plaid Cymru. In its manifesto the party says what Labour should be saying. I only hope that socialists in the regions of England can take a lesson from us and establish not separatist, but potentially British federalist political organisations.
Philip D Whitehead
Neath, Glamorgan.

 Whingeing lawyers, whining academics and pretend politicians write to the Guardian on matters of little import, while ordinary people tell opinion pollsters (including me) that life is now much better and most of them will vote Labour.
Charles Smith
Chesterfield

webTitle: Leader: admitting medical errors is the first step

fields.headline: Medical massacre
fields.standfirst: Admitting error is the first step to reform
fields.trailText: Twenty-five years after Ivan Illich first highlighted the problem in the United States, the first hospital-based study measuring medical mistakes in this country has been published in the British Medical Journal (BMJ).
fields.body:
Twenty-five years after Ivan Illich first highlighted the problem in the United States, the first hospital-based study measuring medical mistakes in this country has been published in the British Medical Journal (BMJ). In Medical Nemesis, a philippic against doctors, Illich used statistics on American medical error to suggest hospitals were more dangerous than all industrial sites except mines and high-rise construction. The BMJ study, based on two London hospitals, estimated one in ten admissions suffers some form of harm. With 8.5m hospital admissions a year, this confirms an estimate made by a working party for the chief medical officer last year which suggested there are 850,000 "adverse incidents" in the NHS every year.

The study said that in one-third of cases there was serious harm and in 8% the error contributed to the patient's death. Extrapolated these figures suggest medical errors in NHS hospitals in England contribute to 68,000 patient deaths and 200,000 permanent or moderate injuries. In the same issue of the BMJ, Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, said that although it was only based on 1,000 case records "there is no reason to believe the results are unrepresentative". Can the medical profession, already reeling from scandals in Bristol, Liverpool and Kent, take any more punishment? Ironically, this study ought to help not harm. It coincides with a new push by the medical establishment, including the chief medical officer, the British Medical Association and the royal colleges, to move to a more open system of reporting error. Like other professions, medicine has been in the grip of a "blame culture" that has deterred people from reporting error. Worse, medicine has helped perpetuate the myth that doctors never make mistakes, which has reinforced reluctance to report adverse events.

The good news about errors is that about half are preventable. One ambition is to copy the aviation industry, which by encouraging the reporting of errors by pilots and air traffic controllers, systematically studies "near misses" to reduce risk and make air travel safer. George Alberti wants a national study of NHS error. But we do not need to wait. The road to remedy is now clear. Last June the health secretary promised an open reporting system by the end of 2000. He has not yet delivered and needs to correct his error.

webTitle: Suicide bomb is new blow to peace

fields.headline: Suicide bomb is new blow to peace
fields.standfirst:
The latest attack underlines Israeli vulnerability to Palestinian militants and deepens the sense of crisis
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Palestinian wearing a backpack containing explosives blew himself up in this Israeli coastal town yesterday, killing three passers-by and injuring more than 60 others in an attack that could signal a vicious upswing in the five-month uprising.
fields.body:
A Palestinian wearing a backpack containing explosives blew himself up in this Israeli coastal town yesterday, killing three passers-by and injuring more than 60 others in an attack that could signal a vicious upswing in the five-month uprising.

The suicide mission was the first inside Israel since the start of the uprising, and the third bombing within the borders of the Jewish state in five days. Both facts underlined Israel's vulnerability to attacks by dedicated Palestinian militants despite its overwhelming military might, and its siege of the West Bank and Gaza.

Israelis began their working week yesterday struggling with the images of horror visited on a seaside town north of Tel Aviv during the morning rush hour.

Minutes after the attack, onlookers rounded on an Arab man, and beat him unconscious. He was taken to hospital in critical condition.

Even with the resort to such drastic measures as the construction of an 11-mile trench around the town of Jericho, yesterday's bombing makes it clear that no Israeli can ever feel completely safe while the uprising continues.

"There is no such thing as 100% security," Israel's police chief, Shlomo Aharonisky, said.

Other police officers warned of more suicide missions in the coastal heartland a day after the armed wing of the militant group, Hamas, warned that it had signed up 10 bombers willing to die to launch attacks inside Israel.

The Hamas threat deepens the sense of crisis and dread awaiting the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, whose government could be sworn in as early as Wednesday.

Mr Sharon has vowed to hold no negotiations with the Palestinians until such attacks end. At the same time, he is facing mounting pressure to live up to his reputation as a warrior and exact harsh reprisals against the Palestinian Authority of Yasser Arafat.

On Saturday, Israel's army chief, Shaul Mofaz, said Israel was "obliged to raise the threshold in our amount of action and our pressure on the terrorists, and those who send them".

Yesterday, Rehavam Ze'evi, a far-right minister in the incoming cabinet, called for Israel to re-occupy tranches of the West Bank under Palestinian rule. The president, Moshe Katzav, warned that now Israel would be forced to take harsher measures.

Mr Sharon appeared to be heeding their demands. He told reporters in Tel Aviv yesterday: "The government which I hope will be formed in a very short time will be able to find appropriate answers that will return security to the citizens of Israel".

He seconded the accusations from Gen Mofaz, and from the chief of Israeli intelligence yesterday, that the "most trusted forces" in Mr Arafat's administration participated directly in the recent bombings.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, and Hamas claimed no knowledge of the bombing. All but one of the earlier bombings inside Israel during the last five months have been linked to the rival Islamic Jihad militant group, or to previously unknown organisations.

However, Hamas did claim a January 1 bombing on the same road in Netanya, which injured 40 people.

Amid the rhetoric on both sides, the stage appears set for a new escalation in the uprising to mark the installation of Mr Sharon's government, and the Jewish festival of Purim later this week, which has often been marred by violence.

Police said yesterday's bomb was a relatively small device, but they believe the Palestinian militant had been in the Netanya area for several days, waiting for his moment. It was not immediately clear whether he was part of the cell behind two bombings last week, in Tel Aviv and in northern Galilee.

Yesterday's suicide bomber struck just before 9am with lethal effect, killing two women and a man. "I saw hands and legs all over the street. It looked like a butcher's shop," said Israel Aaron, a traffic policeman.

Mr Aaron said he held out little hope that Mr Sharon could end the violence with strong-arm tactics. "We tried strong, but I do not think it is a good solution. We kill some Palestinians, and then they kill some of us. We score a goal, and then they score a goal, and it goes on and on. It is like ping-pong. We have to stop it, and sit down and talk."

A Palestinian man suspected of collaborating with the Israeli intelligence services was stabbed to death in a village near the West Bank town of Jenin, Israel Radio reported yesterday.

In recent months, there has been a series of vigilante killings as Mr Arafat's administration conducts a manhunt for suspected collaborators.

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: No 23. Salary issues
fields.trailText: No 23. Salary issues
fields.body:
Feeling undervalued - particularly in the pay-packet department? Considering a career move to boost your earning power? Before you burn your bridges, think carefully.

 Friends may tell you that they earn big bucks, but bear in mind that they could be exaggerating a tad. So take wild salary claims with a pinch of salt.

 Take a good look at your current package. Write down your "base pay" (your basic salary), your "indirect pay" (benefits such as healthcare and travel allowances), and "variable pay" (Christmas bonus, etc). Then examine the hidden benefits - company parties, lunches, free parking, etc. Be aware of the little extras you receive - you might not get them elsewhere.

 Next, research the market and find out what you're worth. Get hold of salary surveys from Adecco, Select Appointments or Gordon Yates Recruitment and see how you compare. Salaries differ widely according to region, industry and the seniority of your job.

 If you're still convinced you could earn more by moving to new pastures, keep your list of salary, benefits and perks handy. Find out as much as possible about any prospective jobs, and see if their packages stack up. Would you be travelling further (and spending more); is the dress code more formal (more outlay on workwear); do all company social events come out of your pocket? If money is your main criterion for moving, consider where you'll be spending it, as well as where you'll be earning it.

 Don't divulge your current salary before your interview. If asked to submit it on your covering letter, be evasive, saying you'd be happy to discuss it when you meet to talk about the job. Should a company offer you the job, knowing already what your salary is, it will destroy your negotiating position. If pressured to reveal it, offer a band only (eg, £12K to £15K).

 If, however, you decide the pros of your present job outweigh the cons, you can always negotiate an increase with your boss. Justifications for more money should always be based on the value you bring the organisation (not on your new mortgage payments). Your efforts to save company money, improve systems and efficiency, and better oil the wheels of the business, will argue your case for you.

 Whichever way you jump, never forget the benefits of fun colleagues, stimulating work, and an atmosphere of respect - these are priceless in any market.
