fields.headline: Chancellor 'to back Myners'
fields.standfirst: Inquiry calls for investment management reform  Inflation target likely to be met
fields.trailText: A code of conduct for City pension fund managers will be proposed tomorrow as the centrepiece of a sweeping package of reforms aimed at combating the "herd-like" nature of investment decisions.
fields.body:
A code of conduct for City pension fund managers will be proposed tomorrow as the centrepiece of a sweeping package of reforms aimed at combating the "herd-like" nature of investment decisions.

Industry sources said the long-awaited Paul Myners report was expected to be sharply critical of actuaries, pension fund trustees and fund managers, singling out a lack of transparency and unclear lines of accountability as the key failings in the system.

It is believed Mr Myners, the chairman of the Gartmore fund management group and also of Guardian Media Group, will urge the chancellor to back a code of principles for pension fund managers along the lines of the Cadbury code for corporate governance.

But the City fears Labour would resort to statutory limitations if necessary - unlike the Cadbury code.

The chancellor, briefed on the contents of the report at the end of last week, is expected to largely endorse its recommendations in his Budget speech on Wednesday.

He has been concerned for some time that long-term flows of savings, such as contributions to pension funds, are not being allocated efficiently as a result of the need for quick, short-term results.

The publication of the Myners code comes at the end of a nine-month inquiry instigated by Gordon Brown into why such a small proportion of pension fund assets - which make up more than a third of the entire stock market - are invested in start-up businesses. This lack of investment - less than 5% of the entire pool of assets - is stalling the chancellor's attempt to foster an "enterprise" economy.

The City believes Mr Myners has concluded that the actuarial profession, pension fund trustees and major City invest ment firms combine to invest the assets of pension funds in a very similar way - leading to the "herd-like" behaviour.

The aim of the code is to break the stranglehold enjoyed by the actuarial profession, which advises pension fund trustees on which firm of fund managers to employ to manage their funds. The actuaries - of which there fewer than a half a dozen firms - are also influential in determining how long the management firm should be employed and against which benchmark its performance should be measured.

The Myners code also tackles the pension funds themselves and the trustees who are elected by the members of the pension funds to look after their investments.

Industry sources believe the trustees are often too cautious in their outlook and too easily swayed by their advisers. The "time horizon" used to measure performance - often as little as three years - is also said by some to be too short for a pool of assets often invested for at least five times as long.

In his interim report, published in November, Mr Myners proposed initial changes to the regime governing the investment of pensions.

He called for legal changes to investment restrictions on pension funds, making it easier for them to invest in so-called private equity limited partnerships which foster start-up businesses.

He also called for the abolition of the minimum funding requirement, or MFR, introduced after the Maxwell scandal to prevent employees raiding employees' pension funds. Mr Myners suggested the MFR should be replaced by more stringent checks on fraud and better disclosure from trustees and managers about their decisions.

webTitle: Foot and Mouth could cause inflation rise

fields.headline: Outbreak to spare Bank's blushes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Higher prices at supermarket meat counters as a result of the foot and mouth crisis could spare the Bank of England the embarrassment of writing to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to explain why it has undershot the government's 2.5% inflation target.
fields.body:
Higher prices at supermarket meat counters as a result of the foot and mouth crisis could spare the Bank of England the embarrassment of writing to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to explain why it has undershot the government's 2.5% inflation target.

Underlying inflation has been below target for 22 months, and in January it fell to 1.8%, the lowest since records began in the 1970s. Many City analysts had expected it to break the 1.5% level which would require Sir Eddie George to write a letter of explanation to Mr Brown.

But rising meat prices could send inflation back up above 2%, according to Danny Gabay, an economist with JP Morgan.

"Initial reports from the supermarket chains suggest that wholesale meat prices may have already risen by 20%," said Mr Gabay. "If the full cost was passed on, it would imply a jump of 0.5% in the retail price index in March."

Meat and dairy products make up 4% of the basket of goods which government statisticians use to measure changing price pressures.

Supermarkets are expected to pass cost increases to their customers, although they are aware that it could put them back in the political firing line. Last week, prime minister Tony Blair attacked the big supermarket chains, which he said had "an armlock" on the food producing industry.

Safeway said yesterday that pork and lamb prices could rise by up to 15%. It said it had enough home reared beef to last "several weeks," but a spokeswoman said: "We will be importing pork and lamb from next week and will try to keep prices as low as we can."

A spokesman for Sainsbury's said: "We still have UK stock on our shelves, so prices have stayed the same. But we will have to import, and pricing is an issue we are looking at at the moment."

webTitle: Scientists create killer moth to control pests

fields.headline: Scientists create killer moth to control pests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists are preparing to start trials of the world's first genetically modified insect, an unnatural born killer moth that will fly over cotton fields, passing a deadly gene on to its pestilent kin as an alternative to pesticide.
fields.body:
Scientists are preparing to start trials of the world's first genetically modified insect, an unnatural born killer moth that will fly over cotton fields, passing a deadly gene on to its pestilent kin as an alternative to pesticide.

Although the GM moth will be released in Arizona, the technology used to create the killer gene has been developed by a British team led by Luke Alphey, of Oxford University. The scientists believe that the chances of the killer gene spreading beyond the species it is intended to harm, the pink bollworm, is very small, and would do no harm if it did.

But the US department of agriculture still has to give consent for the first part of the trial, which would involve a tightly controlled release of moths with another gene inserted to track any possible cross-species transfer.

Scientists need to target the bollworm larvae, which feed on cotton plants, before developing into moths. The idea is to take insect eggs in the lab and insert into their DNA a gene from a fruit fly which would normally damage their metabolism so badly that they would die.

In the lab, however, the larvae survive, because they are dosed with an antidote to the effects of the killer gene. They will grow into adult moths, which are naturally immune to the effects of the gene, and will then be released over the cotton fields in huge numbers.

Unaware that by mating they are both creating and assassinating the next generation, the GM moths will mate with wild moths and each other. The female moths will lay their eggs as normal. But their offspring will have inherited the killer gene. In the wild, the larvae will find no antidote and will die.

In the initial trial, which could take place next year, 3,600 moths will be given a jellyfish gene that glows under special light instead of the killer gene. This will show what happens to GM insects when they encounter their wild counterparts and other species.

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst:
Wonder: De La Warr pavilion
Blunder: Building site, London
fields.trailText:
Wonder: De La Warr pavilion
Blunder: Building site, London
fields.body:
The De La Warr pavilion in Bexhill-on-Sea is one of the best modernist buildings in Britain. Erich Mendelson's design has a simple grace and is still in very good condition. Built in the 1930s, it was the first building in the UK to have a steel structure. Bexhill-on-Sea is an unusual setting for such a modernist building. The pavilion looks like a spaceship landing on the seafront. The staircase inside is wonderful and the furniture has been gloriously restored.

Unlike so many other modernist buildings, the pavilion is still used by the public, especially in summer. Mendelson achieved and put into practice what modernism was all about: the idea of democratising urban spaces and making the best of architecture available to the people is perfectly summed up in this beautiful structure. I see it as quite an idealistic, almost socialist building that shows us something we can aspire to.

My least favourite building is not a building but a building site about 50ft from my flat near Shoreditch High Street in east London. At the moment the site is a huge hole in the ground, but a 400-room generic chain hotel is planned. It is a perfect example of the dubious regeneration of the Shoreditch area, which is happening after little consultation with people living there. I don't think this kind of redevelopment does the local people any good, especially in terms of increasing noise levels.

This feels like the second wave of construction - after the new flats and bars were built the hotels started moving in. I have lived here for three years and I suppose, as an artist, I may have contributed to the whole Shoreditch myth. The area is little more than an entertainment centre: it is becoming more like Old Compton Street every day. Shoreditch is going downhill and is getting a little laddish. I suppose being so close to the City it was waiting to happen but I am surprised that it happened so quickly.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: War killings denied | £15m fund for technology | More Britons killed abroad | Signed book 'a bargain' | Eight share Lottery jackpot
fields.body:
War killings denied

An Edinburgh man yesterday denied killing civilians during the second world war while in a Nazi police battalion based in Lithuania, which wants him extradited to stand trial. Anton Gecas, 85, told the Mail on Sunday: "It makes me very cross that I am being accused of murdering all these people. I never did those terrible things."

£15m fund for technology

Materials to repair skin, bones or damaged organs are among the technologies to benefit from a £15m government fund launched today. Grants to companies and researchers will focus on biomaterials, sustainable energy, nanotechnology and mobile wireless communications.

More Britons killed abroad

The number of Britons murdered in foreign countries rose by seven to 44 last year, according to Foreign Office figures. Robberies fell from 190 to 116, rapes from 117 to 79, and abductions from 29 to 22.

Signed book 'a bargain'

A rare 1924 signed copy of a book by H G Wells, The Story of a Great Schoolmaster, was sold yesterday for what auctioneers at Worksop in Nottinghamshire described as a "bargain" £400.

Eight share Lottery jackpot

Eight ticket holders shared the £6.6m Lottery jackpot on Saturday with numbers 7, 14, 20, 24, 38 and 48, bonus 17. There was no Lottery Extra winner - numbers 1, 6, 7, 11, 12, 42, while one ticket took the £250,000 Thunderball top prize, with 8, 14, 21, 22, 28, Thunderball number 12.

fields.headline: People come before profit
fields.standfirst:
The drug companies' litigation against South Africa is immoral
Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: When Nelson Mandela took over as president of South Africa in 1994 he inherited a profoundly unequal society - but also a terribly unhealthy one. Multiple epidemics existed among the majority of the population that apartheid had left marginalised and poor. While the white population had access to the best of modern health services, for poor (mostly black) people there were not enough hospitals, doctors or clinics and the price of medicines - which had never been subject to regulation -was inordinately high.
fields.body:
When Nelson Mandela took over as president of South Africa in 1994 he inherited a profoundly unequal society - but also a terribly unhealthy one. Multiple epidemics existed among the majority of the population that apartheid had left marginalised and poor. While the white population had access to the best of modern health services, for poor (mostly black) people there were not enough hospitals, doctors or clinics and the price of medicines - which had never been subject to regulation -was inordinately high.

In 1996 the government set out a far-sighted vision for health service transformation. This involved shifting resources from tertiary to primary care, changing the law to prevent medical insurance schemes from excluding the people most in need of medical care and preventative measures such as drastic anti-smoking laws. However, preventing ill-health will take decades, while the need to treat illness is enormous and immediate. Hundreds of thousands of adults die of malaria, TB and respiratory illnesses every year. Nearly 5m people have HIV, and the government estimates that this year there will be 200,000 HIV-related deaths.

Many people die because they live too far from health services, but very large numbers die in the shadow of hospitals and clinics, clutching prescriptions for life-saving medicines that they cannot afford.

P fizer's anti-fungal drug Diflucan offers a case in point. Diflucan effectively treats severe forms of oral and oesophageal thrush. These are common illnesses in people with Aids, and frequently lead to painful death by dehydration, because of the difficulty of swallowing. Several pills must be taken every day, but at a cost of £3-12 per pill, most can't afford them. Effective generic versions, which cost less than 17p per pill, cannot be imported legally because Diflucan is under patent. Thus people die because of Pfizer's unflinching defence of market exclusivity for a drug that has sales of more than $1bn per annum, almost all in developed countries.

The high price of Aids drugs provides the most extreme example of the dilemmas faced by the South African government, but the problem applies also to other medicines. In 1997, the government amended the Medicines Act to bring down the cost of medicines to the government as well as to individuals. The changes to the law were premised on the notion that medicines (however profitable to their manufacturers) are not ordinary commodities, and their affordability affects the ability of millions of people to live productive and dignified lives.

Powers were given to the minister of health to buy a medicine from another country if a company or its licensee sold it there at a cheaper price. The law made it compulsory for pharmacists to substitute off-patent but expensive brand-name medicines with cheaper generics that had the same ingredients and efficacy. It also proposed a pricing committee to monitor the price of medicines and that a medicine should have a "single exit price" when sold to the private sector.

These reforms attracted the wrath of multinational pharmaceutical companies and their South African subsidiaries, who huddle under an umbrella called the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. Although the act was passed by parliament, PMA litigation has meant that it has not been implemented, so many medicines remain extremely expensive and people continue to die of market failure.

Much of the PMA's case is based upon a wholly unjustified assumption that the government will use the law for holus-bolus infringements of patents on medicines. This is despite repeated explanations that the South African government can derive no benefit from doing to medicines what the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, is doing to land. South Africa is not anti-patent. It ratified the Agreement on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property the same year that the Medicines Act was passed.

The litigation which begins in Pretoria today is immoral. Millions of pounds are being spent on legal costs and no good can come of it - except, perhaps, to focus the attention of the world on the excesses of pharmaceutical companies. South Africa and the rest of the developing world are being failed by these companies.

Mark Heywood is head of the Aids Law Project at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg

webTitle: Office hours: Interview with a reps manager

fields.headline: Snow business
fields.standfirst: Claire Ryan is responsible for reps at the Ski Club of Great Britain. As she tells  Tom Twentyman, despite the job's obvious advantages, it's no easy task
fields.trailText: Claire Ryan is responsible for reps at the Ski Club of Great Britain. As she tells Tom Twentyman, despite the job's obvious advantages, it's no easy task.
fields.body:
As reps manager for the Ski Club of Great Britain, Claire Ryan is straightforward about her role. "Good reps are an asset to us, and that's what I aim to achieve," she says.

The club operates skiing and snowboarding holidays in Europe, the US and Canada, and Ryan acts as a "roving rep", with a brief to ensure that the necessary standards are being maintained. It will involve making three journeys this season - the first, a few weeks ago, saw her shuttling between Flaine, Chamonix and Grenoble in France, in just 72 hours.

"I talked to our people, checked their paperwork, and skied with them," says Ryan. "When I wasn't doing that, I met ski school contacts and the holiday groups, or looked at potential accommodation for the future. There wasn't time to swan around, believe me."

Ryan, 27, has a degree in languages and business, for which she studied French and German, and she was torn between either "a serious City-type role, earning lots of money, or a bit of fun which was interesting". A former rep herself, she had been running an Alpine hotel before joining the Ski Club at its Wimbledon base in November 1999.

Her linguistic skills are put to regular use. "I often deal with hoteliers and tourist offices, and in the summer, I negotiate bed, board and lift pass packages for the reps. The French seem genuinely surprised that I actually understand what they're saying. That's quite noticeable. I haven't got any Italian - although my assistant has, fortunately."

She also organises pre-season training in Tignes, France. This involves tuition in mountaincraft by qualified guides, and Ryan talking her charges through the finer points of maintaining efficient records.

"They're tired out after a day on the snow, and I'm saying to them, 'Right, get your pencils. Here's how you fill in your returns sheets and resort diaries.' But the admin is important, and without it, my whole system would fall apart."

Delivering a presentation holds no fears for her. "Initially, it was intimidating," she admits. "With experience, I've found it's not a problem." And in that sort of environment, she adds, it is possible to have a laugh and a joke.

Thanks to her background, Ryan knows a thing or two about being the life and soul of the slopes. There is a social aspect to the course - positively heroic amounts of après-ski lie ahead - and it lets her see for herself how these prospective party animals shape up. "Yes, a certain amount of research is done at the bar," she says, dead-pan.

The fact that the reps are volunteers - shop assistants and helicopter pilots feature in the current crop - means they won't all be present for the entire season. (The majority can spare less than a month, anyway). So Ryan's biggest challenge is to find cover when someone cries off. If she's told early enough, it isn't a major issue. However, she sometimes gets just one or two weeks' notice (and it can be less). "They'll say, 'Look, I'm sorry, but I've got to work instead'."

Ryan's opinions vary at this stage. "Part of me wants to make them feel as guilty as possible, so I'll reply, 'Well, my boss will probably tell me to take a hike, and to take my P45, too'." And on the other hand? "This is a difficult situation - they haven't signed a legally binding contract, just a repping agreement, and I can't demand anything, which is a pain."

Even the boxes of chocolates sent in apology fail to ease the situation. Her solution is a "long, long list" of those who could be available at the last minute, "and I phone around like a madwoman".

Ryan calls each rep on a weekly basis - she likes to be kept informed about what's happening, and occasionally, information overload sets in. "One guy was bursting to tell his news about the couple who had a daughter, and how she went to the same school as his little girl. Rather nice for him, but I was more interested in finding out where they were going skiing."

Asked what it takes to forge a career in the travel trade, Ryan says: "Stamina helps. I've been in the office as late as 11pm, and working at home at weekends is common. In return, there's probably more variety and greater job satisfaction than in other industries, but you have got to be totally committed. It can take over."

webTitle: Tunnel let US spy on Soviet embassy

fields.headline: Tunnel let US spy on Soviet embassy
fields.trailText: The US built a secret tunnel under the Soviet Union's embassy in Washington to spy on its rival superpower, it has emerged in the wake of the arrest of an FBI agent for spying.
fields.body:
The US built a secret tunnel under the Soviet Union's embassy in Washington to spy on its rival superpower, it has emerged in the wake of the arrest of an FBI agent for spying.

The agent, Robert Hanssen, who was arrested last month, is believed to have disclosed the existence of the tunnel to his Soviet contacts years ago.

The vice president, Dick Cheney, said in a radio interview yesterday that, if the story about the tunnel was true, he could not comment on it.

The construction of the tunnel and related intelligence-gathering facilities is estimated to have cost the US government several hundred million dollars, according to yesterday's New York Times. Its aim was to create a method of eavesdropping on the Soviet Union's embassy. It was built during the 70s and 80s, according to former agents, and did not become properly functional until the early 90s.

Mr Hanssen has maintained his innocence and commentators speculate that the leaking of the details of the tunnel may be a way of letting him know that everything is known about the information he supplied.

The FBI court papers state merely that Mr Hanssen "compromised an entire technical programme of enormous value, expense and importance to the United States government" and this is understood to be a reference to the tunnel.

It is alleged that Mr Hanssen, who was arrested on February 15, was spying for the Soviet Union, and later the Russians,for 25 years.

The tunnel was built under the Soviet embassy complex, as it then was, on Wisconsin Avenue in Washington. The embassy was not fully occupied for a number of years because of a dispute over US claims that its Moscow embassy had been bugged.

According to former intelligence agents, there is no evidence that the tunnel ever produced any useful information, an indication that the Soviet Union knew of its existence.

If convicted on the spying charges, Hanssen could face the death penalty, not least because he is alleged to have passed on information that led to the deaths of US agents.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • You can always spot heavy email users from the way their fingers flutter when they talk. And, of course, their annoying habit of missing out vowels. Regus, the "instant office provider" (presumably one just adds water) recently commissioned a survey (sometimes WPM wonders what all these people do when they're not surveying things. She has recurrent nightmares of being stuck in a public house with a bevy of slavering young office researchers, all commenting on how 78% of the table are drinking gin and tonic, and quizzing her about pork scratchings) which has revealed that office employees in the south and London (which the keen-eyed among you will have spotted is the capital), are more inclined to email their colleagues and clients than those in the north and Scotland.
fields.body:
 You can always spot heavy email users from the way their fingers flutter when they talk. And, of course, their annoying habit of missing out vowels. Regus, the "instant office provider" (presumably one just adds water) recently commissioned a survey (sometimes WPM wonders what all these people do when they're not surveying things. She has recurrent nightmares of being stuck in a public house with a bevy of slavering young office researchers, all commenting on how 78% of the table are drinking gin and tonic, and quizzing her about pork scratchings) which has revealed that office employees in the south and London (which the keen-eyed among you will have spotted is the capital), are more inclined to email their colleagues and clients than those in the north and Scotland.

In London, 11% of office workers send between 91 and 100 work-related emails every day. WPM would dearly love to know how many of these are those bloody fwd fwd fwds of "98 things which were absolutely genuinely written in job applications - no really!", or indeed that hil-ar-i-ous graphic of a gentleman pulling his trousers down. No please, send me that one again.

What really riles WPM is that every single one of these wretched things is prefaced by one of your mild acquaintances saying, "i don't normally forward these things . . ." at which point WPM is gripped by the almost uncontrollable urge to march across the office and scrawl over her workmate's face in neon highlighter pen "YES YOU DO!" Indeed, what gets her goat more than anything is that said email pest then has the audacity to add ". . . but i thought you might find this amusing!" Why? Why did you think I, of all the people in your miserable address book, would find "39 things to do with your stapler" even remotely smirkable? Especially when it has been forwarded all over Britain since some unknown data analyst called Simon Partridge first received it from his American cousin back in August, and it now has all the limp appeal of the tea-towel festering in the office kitchen. I think you know where I'm coming from.

Anyway, back to the survey. Regus found that in the north, 76% of office workers sent fewer than 10 business emails during the day. As any fool will tell you, this is because there is no electricity in the north, and they are all forced to communicate via carrier-pigeon, and the archaic method of communication known as "speaking".

Readers in the south may like to take the opportunity to wreak merry havoc in the office today, by trotting over to their colleagues' desks and actually telling them those "72 rib-tickling facsimile anecdotes" one by one. Anyone who succeeds in ending this performance with a cheeky ;-) will win a prize.

 As you may have gathered, WPM is not having a particularly good day. This may well have something to do with the fact that her handbag broke on the way to work this morning. Or it could perhaps be related to the vast quantities of superstrength coffee she has consumed today. More likely is the fact that she was in the office for 16 and a half hours the other day, and is still feeling a little frazzled by thoughts of word-counts and rudimentary spelling errors. However WPM is not alone. A report by Office Angels (ah, right, I see, when they're not surveying, they're reporting) tells us that two-thirds of us spend 20 hours a week worrying about work when we should be relaxing.

Using a complex method of mathematical calculation, which probably involved a lot of pie-charts and Venn diagrams, Office Angels has concluded that this translates as about three working days, which, it claims, a little dubiously, means we are working eight days a week.

But before you rush off to the accounts department bellowing the word "overtime!", you should probably ponder the question: "How much time do we think about relaxing when we should be working? WPM, for example, would be the first to admit that she spends a sizeable part of her day wondering whether she can really justify buying that asymmetric top she saw in Top Shop, and considering what she might have for lunch. Cheese and pickle sandwiches or a great big pie are her current options. I'm sure that for every moment WPM spends worrying over the Monday morning filing, she spends at least five deciding which shoes she would wear if ever she had the good fortune to meet John Cusak.

webTitle: Racing: Club still pin hopes on Lingfield

fields.headline: Club still pin hopes on Lingfield
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Jockey Club and British Horseracing Board were still determined last night that racing should resume at Lingfield on Wednesday despite the continued increase in the number of foot and mouth outbreaks over the weekend.
fields.body:
The Jockey Club and British Horseracing Board were still determined last night that racing should resume at Lingfield on Wednesday despite the continued increase in the number of foot and mouth outbreaks over the weekend.

However, there is likely to be only a handful of race meetings this week even if the sport should resume as planned.

All eyes at first will be on Lingfield and while the all-weather Flat card may not be particularly mouthwatering in normal circumstances, it is sure to attract plenty of attention provided it gets the go-ahead.

Lingfield's clerk of the course Chris Stickels said: "As far as I'm aware we pass all the relevant guidelines issued by the Jockey Club and racing should go ahead. Hopefully there will be plenty of runners as people will want to get a run into their horses."

However, the two other meetings set for Wednesday at Bangor and Catterick have already been cancelled because of the foot and mouth crisis and a similar fate has befallen all Thursday's scheduled meetings at Carlisle, Towcester and Wincanton.

The British Horseracing Board will make a decision today on a replacement fixture to avoid Thursday being a blank day.

There is better news later in the week with officials at Sandown Park satisfied at this stage that their two-day meeting for Friday and Saturday can go ahead.

Ayr, where racing is also due to take place on those two days are expected to make a decision today. Friday's third meeting is at Hereford where racing was said to be doubtful yesterday. webTitle: Rugby Union: Clubs in threat to keep back players

fields.headline: Clubs in threat to keep back players
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Rugby Football Union is to appeal to its leading clubs to accept an 11th-hour restructuring of the Premiership season to avoid English rugby descending into chaos if its two remaining Six Nations fixtures against Ireland and France have to be postponed.
fields.body:
The Rugby Football Union is to appeal to its leading clubs to accept an 11th-hour restructuring of the Premiership season to avoid English rugby descending into chaos if its two remaining Six Nations fixtures against Ireland and France have to be postponed.

With talks set to commence today between RFU officials and their Irish counterparts to determine whether the foot and mouth outbreak will permit the English to travel to Dublin on March 24 as scheduled, the RFU is all too aware the alternative date of May 4 proposed by the Six Nations committee clashes with the end-of-season Zurich Championship, vital in determining the English qualifiers for next season's Heineken Cup.

With Newcastle and Saracens, for example, threatening to take a stand over the looming prospect of being without several leading England players and with pressure mounting from sponsors and broadcasters, the RFU has drawn up a contingency plan based on switching the final round of Premiership fixtures from Easter weekend to March 24, which will be free if, as expected, the Dublin game is postponed.

The next step would be to reschedule the quarter-final play-offs for the holiday weekend of April 14-15, a fortnight earlier than planned, and stage the semi-finals on April 28 instead of a week later. Ireland are due to play Saturday's postponed game in Wales on April 29 but only a handful of English club players such as Wasps' Irish centre Rob Henderson and Wales's Alan Bateman would be involved in Cardiff. Keith Wood's Harlequins are unlikely to make the play-offs.

According to RFU sources, the Zurich Championship grand final would still be played as scheduled on Sunday May 13, although fresh headaches would arise if the final round of Six Nations games, notably England v France and Scotland v Ireland, also needed to be moved. The Six Nations committee is adamant that Test rugby takes precedence over anything else but the leading English clubs are in mutinous mood.

The RFU's chief executive Francis Baron was sufficiently concerned over the weekend to phone the Gloucester owner Tom Walkinshaw, chairman of English First Division Rugby, at the Australian grand prix in Melbourne and apologise for last week's breakdown in peace talks between the RFU and the clubs.

Walkinshaw, also in charge of the Arrows formula one team, returns to the country today and will hold immediate talks with the club owners to discuss EFDR's next move.

Baron, who was away on holiday in Aspen when 40 amendments to the supposed final agreement were mysteriously tabled, remains hopeful the deal can be salvaged, insisting last night: "The agreement will be signed this week."

The clubs, though, believe the time has come to sort out the unholy political mess still afflicting English rugby six years after the start of professionalism. "The clubs are going to go their own way now," said Newcastle's Rob Andrew. "It doesn't matter if the RFU expel us, in my opinion, because we're going bust anyway."

webTitle: Starting up: Survival of fittest dot.coms

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
Survival of fittest as dot.coms nosedive

More net news
fields.trailText: Survival of fittest as dot.coms nosedive.
fields.body:
This week sees us in New York. As well as neatly avoiding the meat crisis in Britain, we have a series of meetings and are attending a leading US internet technology conference.

While our meetings have gone well, there is a smell of fear about almost every company we have encountered. The US has led the internet revolution, and appears to be leading the downturn too.

We have heard of several companies that were valued at more than $100m (£69m) last year being sold off for less than $1m.

There are horror stories in Britain, too, and this year is going to see some more very high profile business failures.

The Rools team has had contact with two businesses whose figures suggest they are struggling. Both are burning around $1m in cash each month, with revenues only a meagre $20,000. It is interesting that these businesses are seen by their respective investors in a relatively positive light - an indication perhaps of the overall health of the investors' portfolios.

But we have heard of companies changing hands very quietly for $1 as investors seek to dispose of poorer performing companies.

Last year's ambitious pan-European plans, including our own, have been shelved as the focus moves from customer acquisition to sustained profitability.

The last six months have been very painful for anyone in the dot.com industry. From our perspective, the recent shakeup has been unpleasant - and there is more to come.

It is to be hoped that firms which survive will be stronger and be around for the long term. Meanwhile investors, the markets and the public at large should be prepared for more high profile internet failures.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com a service that enables teenagers to shop online

webTitle: Fate of ancient statues in balance as talks with Taliban continue

fields.headline: Fate of ancient statues in balance as talks with Taliban continue
fields.trailText: The fate of Afghanistan's two towering Buddha statues was unclear last night as last-minute negotiations began to reverse a Taliban decree ordering their destruction.
fields.body:
The fate of Afghanistan's two towering Buddha statues was unclear last night as last-minute negotiations began to reverse a Taliban decree ordering their destruction.

One Taliban source said the statues had not yet been damaged but the work could start at any time. The regime's information minister, Qudratullah Jamal, said the statues and scores of other artefacts across the country were gradually being dismantled.

Residents of central Bamiyan, where the two ancient statues of Buddha hewn from a cliff face in the third and fifth centuries are located, said they had seen soldiers firing anti-aircraft weapons at the two statues three days ago.

The statues stand as evidence of the Greek and Buddhist cultures that flourished in Afghanistan centuries before the arrival of Islam. But a week ago the Taliban's leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, declared that they were the "shrines of infidels" and should be torn down.

Analysts said the edict might be an attempt to bargain with the west. The Taliban have come under strong pressure from UN sanctions, which were tightened in January to punish the regime for not handing over the Saudi-born terrorist Osama bin Laden.

In addition, drought and civil war have forced 500,000 Afghans to flee their homes. More than a million are facing starvation but international aid has slowed to a trickle.

"This may be an attempt to blackmail the international community into giving them some money or some kind of relief," said Rifaat Hussain, who heads the department of defence and strategic studies at Islamabad's Quaid-i-Azam University. "Afghans are very smart traders."

The regime's ruling has sparked international condemnation and has created the first rift with the Taliban's hardline Islamic mentors in Pakistan.

Sami-ul Haq, a cleric who runs one of Asia's most influential Islamic schools and who is highly regarded by the Taliban, said the regime was wrong to begin destroying the ancient Buddhist monuments.

"The worship places of the idolaters were preserved so the people could learn a lesson from them," said Mr Haq.

Many of the most senior Taliban ministers studied as children at his madrassah in Akora Khattak, two hours' drive from the Afghan border. He has sent hundreds of his students to fight alongside Taliban soldiers in their civil war.

"The statues should be locked in a museum or sold because there are infidels who are interested in buying them," he said. "Then the money should be used for the people of Afghanistan who have been affected by drought and war."

The G8 industrial nations, meeting in Trieste, said the ruling was "deeply tragic" and pressed the Taliban to reverse the edict.

A Unesco special envoy, Pierre Lafrance, met Mr Haq yesterday before flying to Afghanistan for talks with senior Taliban ministers in a last-ditch effort to reverse the ruling.

Mr Lafrance came out of a meeting with the Taliban's ambassador to Pakistan on Saturday and said he believed there was "a faint glimmer of hope" but it was unclear how much had been destroyed.

Mullah Omar's latest ruling will serve as a warning to the Taliban's allies, particularly Pakistan, that the regime will not easily be tamed.

webTitle: Police fear Real IRA bomb blitz

fields.headline: Police fear Real IRA bomb blitz
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch had been bracing itself for a strike in the capital since last autumn, with senior officers nervously predicting that at least one dissident terrorist cell was operating in London.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch had been bracing itself for a strike in the capital since last autumn, with senior officers nervously predicting that at least one dissident terrorist cell was operating in London.

"We've had three attacks from the Real IRA already," said one detective recently. "We're expecting a fourth." The waiting ended early yesterday.

A D-registered red and black taxi parked outside the main entrance of BBC Television Centre in Wood Lane at 11pm on Saturday, its headlights blazing.

Twelve hours earlier the cab had been sold to an Irishman from a used car yard in Picketts Lock, Edmonton, north-east London, half an hour after it had been put on sale. "A taxi's good," the buyer remarked, as he paid £300 in cash. "You never get stopped in a taxi." The man, described as white, 30, and wearing a baseball cap, was right.

At 11.22pm, someone rang a hospital in London and said: "There is a maroon taxi parked outside the BBC. And there is a bomb in the taxi to go off any minute." The caller gave a recognised codeword. Two minutes later a similar message was received at a charity in London.

Significantly, the codeword mentioned was also used to warn police about an explosion by a railway line in Acton, west London, last July. TNT, the explosive used at Acton, matched the type packed into a device which damaged Hammersmith Bridge in June last year.

The gut instinct of officers is that the man who abandoned the taxi in Shepherd's Bush was the person who fired a rocket-propelled grenade at the secret intelligence service building, commonly known as MI6, in Vauxhall, London, last September. "The guy's obviously got loads of bottle," said a source. "We're linking all of these attacks to dissidents."

Revenge

The size and style of yesterday's bomb, which contained between 10lb and 20lb of high explosive, and the choice of target have particularly worried detectives. Intelligence sources knew the Real IRA wanted to strike in London, probably with a car bomb, but believed the terrorists had been thwarted by undercover operations conducted by the RUC; in October, a 500lb fertiliser device was discovered in a horsebox in west Belfast, which may have been bound for London.

Yesterday's bomb was the biggest detonated by dissidents on this side of the Irish sea, and may have been planted at the BBC in revenge for a Panorama programme which named four members of the Real IRA who were allegedly responsible for the Omagh bomb that killed 29 people, including a woman pregnant with twins, in 1998. Last week, the BBC team won several top awards for the documentary, which was presented by John Ware.

"Panorama definitely caused the dissidents some pain," said a security source. "It put pressure on the Gardai and the attorney general who were seen to be allowing these people to carry on normal lives when a reporter from the BBC was going around calling them terrorists."

Security personnel believe there are up to 10 Real IRA terrorists working in London, and that their bomb-making equipment seems to be hidden in the city rather than in Ireland. Of even greater concern to Scotland Yard, MI5 and the RUC is evidence that suggests the Provisional IRA, which is observing the ceasefire, has also been involved in reconnaissance missions in England, as well as attempting to procure weapons from the US.

Although there is thought to be some dialogue between low-ranking members of both terrorist groups, security sources believe Provisional and Real IRA are conducting separate campaigns, raising fears that London is facing a twin threat.

Renegade

At the moment, though, police are concentrating on the danger posed by the Real IRA, the largest renegade republican group opposed to the Good Friday agreement. Its membership is estimated at between 200 and 400 members, north and south of the Irish border, and it is particularly strong in south Armagh/north Louth and parts of west Belfast.

Its political wing, the 32-County Sovereignty Committee, is fronted by Bernadette Sands-McKevitt, sister of the hunger striker Bobby Sands, and her husband, Michael McKevitt, who were run out of their printing business in Dundalk in the Irish Republic by local people after the Omagh bomb.

Sources believe the Real IRA is stepping up efforts to destabilise the peace process in an attempt to put pressure on Sinn Fein not to make a deal on paramilitary disarmament. There has been a steady drift of disaffected provisionals to the Real IRA; others have threatened to defect, especially in hardline south Armagh, if any weapons are decommissioned.

The group is believed to have secured some Provisional IRA arms and has also tried to buy weapons from eastern Europe, in particular the Balkans, with money from armed robberies and fund-raising in the US.

Sources believe up to a dozen of the Provisional IRA's top bomb-makers are now Real IRA members. "You don't need thousands of footsoldiers if you have the brains," said one source.

Its membership is estimated at between 200 and 400 members, north and south of the Irish border, and it is particularly strong in south Armagh/north Louth and parts of west Belfast. Its political wing, the 32-County Sovereignty Committee, is fronted by Bernadette Sands-McKevitt, sister of the hunger striker Bobby Sands, and her husband, Michael McKevitt, who were run out of their printing business in Dundalk in the Irish Republic by local people after the Omagh bomb. Sources believe the Real IRA is stepping up efforts to destabilise the peace process in an attempt to put pressure on Sinn Fein not to make a deal on paramilitary disarmament. There has been a steady drift of disaffected provisionals to the Real IRA; others have threatened to defect, especially in hardline south Armagh, if any weapons are decommissioned. The group is believed to have secured some Provisional IRA arms and has also tried to buy weapons from eastern Europe, in particular the Balkans, with money from armed robberies and fund-raising in the US. Sources believe up to a dozen of the Provisional IRA's top bomb-makers are now Real IRA members. "You don't need thousands of footsoldiers if you have the brains," said one source.

fields.headline: Brown caught on the inside looking out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Budgets are a peculiarly British phenomenon. And when the chancellor is banging away at the despatch box about the cyclically adjusted budget deficit, it is easy to believe that nothing much has changed since Gladstone's day.
fields.body:
Budgets are a peculiarly British phenomenon. All the paraphernalia - the Budget box, the peck on the cheek outside 11 Downing Street, the obsessive secrecy - mark out the occasion as a big day in the nation's calendar. And when the chancellor is banging away at the despatch box about the cyclically adjusted budget deficit, it is easy to believe that nothing much has changed since Gladstone's day, and that the world is still run from the mother of parliaments.

Of course, buried away in the speech, there is recognition that there is an international dimension to tax and spending decisions. But the moment Gordon Brown says, "the global outlook is less promising than it was in November", is the moment 99% of those listening hit the snooze button.

Yet this year, even more than most, the world matters. Indeed, what is going on in the United States and Japan, the two biggest economies, will have a bigger impact on our lives than anything Brown has up his sleeve. This, for those who are interested, will be the usual four-stage affair - prudence for the City, a few goodies for business, redistribution through his plethora of tax credits and something for old Labour at the end.

Brown's strategy is for his package to have minimum impact on the markets and maximum impact on the voters, and he will almost certainly succeed. The Treasury's deliberate policy of underestimating the size of the budget surplus means that the chancellor can stick to his plans for repaying debt while having a few more billions to spare for tax cuts and spending increases. There is not much chance that the Bank of England will respond to the Budget by putting up interest rates in the foreseeable future; the only question is whether it might be deterred from cutting them by too much generosity from the chancellor. Given the present level of inflation, the answer is probably not.

By contrast, external events look far more threatening to Brown's economic forecasts and fiscal arithmetic. First, there is the US, a country which could be almost a textbook case of Brown's warnings about boom and bust. The lights went out for the US in November last year, and if the markets are anything to go by, may not come on again for some time. This week will see the anniversary of the day when the Nasdaq index peaked at just over 5,000 points. In the subsequent 12 months it has lost 60% of its value and, with the profits warnings rolling in relentlessly, may still have further to fall. Indicators of both business and consumer confidence have fallen sharply in recent months, and there is a risk that an increase in consumer saving, savage cutbacks in the corporate sector and the falling stock market will create a vicious downward spiral. Policymakers have a considerable degree of flexibility, with scope for both fiscal and monetary easing, but once an economy is heading down it is hard to turn it around. The real question for the US this year is whether Greenspan's rate cuts and Bush's tax cuts get to the economy before confidence really cracks.

Lesson from the past

Interestingly, some analysts are now drawing parallels with what happened after the Japanese bubble burst a decade ago. This is premature, but it does highlight the extent to which Japan has blundered its way through the 1990s and still lacks a coherent recovery strategy. If Japan were as close geographically to Britain as Germany or France, we would be hearing about its economic woes every day. As it is, the fact that it stands to be the first leading developed nation since the war to replicate the conditions of the 1930s has escaped attention. Last week, for example, there was news that industrial production had fallen by almost 4% in January, that core prices in Tokyo were falling at an annual rate of 1.1%, and unemployment was nudging 5%. The Nikkei Dow index ended the week at its lowest level for 15 years, and some 60% below its peak level. There are those who believe that Japan is essentially a strong economy which is poised to be a world leader in the next phase of the internet revolution. But while it was true that parts of its economy are incredibly efficient and are at the cutting edge of scientific advance, the same could be said of the Soviet Union in the 1950s.

After months in which it had boasted that the country had at last turned the corner, Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party said it would come up with an emergency package of measures to boost the stock market and boost the liquidity of the real estate market. The fact that Japan's government has removed its head from the sand is certainly welcome, although it has yet to provide a shred of evidence that it knows how to get the country out of its mess. One idea floated last week - that banks should be encouraged to get rid of their bad loans - sounds like the sort of structural reform that might help transform Japan into a vibrant American-style economy, but in the circumstances pulling the plug on debtors and creating a fresh wave of bankruptcies is the last thing the country needs. The result would be a further downward lurch in land prices, which have fallen in tandem with the stock market, but are seven times as important to the Japanese personal sector. Putting a floor under land prices is the key to stabilising the economy and creating the conditions for stronger growth.

Blunt weapons

The problem for the Japanese authorities is that they appear to have exhausted all the normal policy options. For an economy as moribund as Japan's, the classic remedy would be zero or even negative real interest rates, but this is impossible when inflation is negative. However low nominal rates of interest go, they still remain positive in real terms. For much of the 1990s, Japan tried stimulatory fiscal policies, and the Keynesian approach worked up to a point, in that things would now be a lot worse had the government not spent trillions of yen on infrastructure projects. But with public debt exploding, fiscal policy is now the bluntest of policy weapons, because the private sector is well aware that the price of higher borrowing now will be higher taxes later.

In the light of all this, unorthodox remedies are now being suggested. Paul Krugman thinks the Japanese should print money as a way of pushing inflation into positive territory, thereby making it possible for the authorities to engineer zero real rates of interest. Variations of the Krugman thesis include setting an inflation target of 2.5%, thereby massaging expectations, and the approach used by Roosevelt when he arrived in office in 1933 - printing money and a devaluation. One particularly radical solution floated is that Japan should nationalised the banks and the even more sickly life insurers and impose a moratorium on interest repayments for three years.

Such a move, it is argued, would stem the rising tide of bankruptcies, put a brake on falling land prices and restore confidence. Certainly, something drastic is needed because the rest of Asia is already feeling the backwash from Japan's latest travails. The UK economy at present seems reasonably healthy, and managed - just - to ride out the last Asian crisis in 1998. But that was when the US was in the last heady days of the boom that was never supposed to end. It will not be nearly so comfortable here if the US, Japan and the rest of the Pacific Rim all go down the tubes.

webTitle: Business: Odds on Tax-free betting pioneer dismisses Brown plan

fields.headline: Odds on Tax-free betting pioneer dismisses Brown plan
fields.trailText: Victor Chandler, the pioneer of tax-free offshore betting, has dismissed government plans to lure bookmakers back to Britain - which are expected to be announced in the Budget on Wednesday - as unworkable.
fields.body:
Victor Chandler, the pioneer of tax-free offshore betting, has dismissed government plans to lure bookmakers back to Britain - which are expected to be announced in the Budget on Wednesday - as unworkable.

Mr Chandler, right, chairman of Victor Chandler International, said the proposed scrapping of the 9% duty on winnings in favour of a tax on bookmakers' gross profits would not deter punters from looking to offshore websites and call centres for more attractive odds rather than using local bookmakers such as that pictured above.

Mr Chandler, who triggered an industry-wide rush to establish offshore operations when he set up business in Gibraltar in 1997, said: "The stable door has been opened and the horse has bolted."

He also attacked proposals from five leading British bookmakers - Ladbrokes, Coral, William Hill, Stanley Leisure and the Tote - to abandon their offshore operations if Gordon Brown sets the rate of tax on bookmakers' profits at 15%. "It equates to a 3% betting duty - and that will be passed on to the punter," he said. "The punter will always suffer. Meanwhile, VCI offers as good a service but with better odds. People are still going to find us, even if government restricts our advertising."

Last year, advertisements on Teletext for odds offered by VCI were banned by the court of appeal.

According to analysts at Datamonitor, online betting in Europe could be worth as much as as £3.5bn by 2004. "You have to remember, we are not as Anglo-centric as the big three [Ladbrokes, William Hill and Coral]," Mr Chandler said.

The Gibraltar-based operation has successfully wooed high rollers in Hong Kong and Singapore with the prospect of tax-free bets on football matches and other sporting events. As a result, the company that was founded by Mr Chandler's grandfather - also named Victor Chandler - has been transformed from a track-side bookmaker into an international business.

webTitle: Business: Railtrack fails to find a chairman

fields.headline: Railtrack fails to find a chairman
fields.standfirst: Blair's hopes of pre-election solution dashed
fields.trailText: Railtrack has been forced back to first base in trying to find a chairman to take over the onerous task of running a company that is close to bankruptcy, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack has been forced back to first base in trying to find a chairman to take over the onerous task of running a company that is close to bankruptcy, industry sources said last night.

The new chairman's name should have emerged by the end of last month, but candidates are being frightened away by the possibility of being associated with potential corporate manslaughter charges following the Hatfield rail crash last October.

Railtrack's board was told last week that the hunt for a new chairman to succeed Sir Philip Beck - who is ready to stand down as soon as his successor is appointed - is still on, but that it would be several months before a decision could be made.

The task of finding somebody to head one of Britain's most unpopular companies is proving to be more difficult than the headhunters scouring the City and industry have found. The person will have to be prepared to work a five-day week - almost unheard of in a comparable position - and will be responsible for appointing a new board.

Potential recruits have been frightened off by suggestions that they might have to bear corporate responsibility for the Hatfield crash.

Although it may not be possible for the crown prosecution service to prefer corporate manslaughter charges against Railtrack and several of its contractors closely involved in Hatfield, the company has been advised that it will inevitably face swingeing fines for incompetence and for runing an unsafe railway.

It closed large sections of the network after the Hatfield crash in order to repair hundreds of cracked rails, and the system will not return to normal operation until summer.

The government's hope of finding a new chairman and changing the look of Railtrack before the election appear to have been stymied.

The prime minister has been pressing for dramatic changes at the top of the industry and has approached several key businessmen to see whether they would be interested in the chairmanship. Ministers want to influence key appointments within the company, but Sir Philip has angrily rejected any suggestion of interference.

Railtrack sources said last night that the new chairman would be in place before the company's annual meeting of shareholders in July. This gives Railtrack a substantial breathing space to find another candidate, but the delay will infuriate ministers.

The prime minister is known to be becoming increasingly exasperated at the way Railtrack is managed. He was appalled by what he saw as unnecessary passenger chaos after Hatfield and is determined to resist further financial demands from Railtrack unless properly monitored, with interest paid.

One government source said: "If the company goes bust, then so be it. At least we will know where we stand."

Ministers are also thought to be concerned at the failure of the strategic rail authority to get on with its job. Chairman Sir Alastair Morton and Mike Grant, the SRA's franchising director, could be sacked if they fail to deliver on key issues.

fields.headline: Media monkey's diary
fields.trailText: • The BBC seems to have a surfeit of stars whose salaries seem not entirely matched by their output: so it was with pleasure that we welcomed Kate Adie back to our screens last week. But it was only a flying visit - the rarely seen chief news correspondent, covering the Selby train disaster, left Yorkshire after a day. Would her brief sojourn back in the field have been anything to do with the BBC's £55 cap on hotel bills, Monkey wonders?
fields.body:
 The BBC seems to have a surfeit of stars whose salaries seem not entirely matched by their output: so it was with pleasure that we welcomed Kate Adie back to our screens last week. But it was only a flying visit - the rarely seen chief news correspondent, covering the Selby train disaster, left Yorkshire after a day. Would her brief sojourn back in the field have been anything to do with the BBC's £55 cap on hotel bills, Monkey wonders?

 Talking about stars with fat salaries, speculation is rife about the future of the BBC's economics editor, Peter Jay. He was stripped of his business brief when Jeff Randall - who starts work today - was appointed: now insiders say he may retire sooner than planned. Newsnight's chirpy economics man, Evan Davis, is regarded as an ideal replacement.

 By the slightest of margins, Davis must take second place to the garrulous Richard Quest in Monkey's top ten of business hacks. In his 15 years at the BBC, he has shown more enthusiasm for the Dow Jones than is good for the health: now he has taken his populist style to CNN. Sitting at the CNN table at the Royal Television Society journalism awards this week, Monkey took the opportunity to alert his new bosses to a rather intriguing episode in the Quest files: the platinum blond era. When questioned, Quest said it was something to do with Sydney Mardi Gras. We felt it best not to inquire further.

 There was far too little bad behaviour at the RTS awards this year: only one lady fell over, and no one punched Peter Horrocks on the nose. Which is just as well for the BBC current affairs chief, whose Panorama team dominated the ceremony. While the awards for John Ware's Who Bombed Omagh? were clearly deserved, Mark Austin's memorable ITN report from the Mozambique floods only got a technician's award. Some observers wondered how long the industry snobbery towards ITV's news coverage can continue.

 To the delight of Richard Sambrook, the new director of BBC news and a News 24 champion, the rolling news channel took a number of gongs, while Sky News failed to land a single award. The disappointed satellite contingent muttered darkly that its head of news, Nick Pollard, would have some serious questions to answer back at the office - he chaired this year's judges. But there is a positive side to Sky's failure: at least its impartiality can't be questioned.

 Just in case his 30-something wife hasn't worked it out herself, Rupert Murdoch has helpfully calculated just how long he will grace the world with his presence. Asked, at a conference in New York, how he felt about turning 70 next month, he joked: "Bad", quickly adding he had approximately 175,000 hours left, after factoring out sleeping, family time and "other useless meetings". Since Murdoch is trying to pull off a £43bn merger with a car company that has satellite interests, he added: "I just hope that not too many of them are taken up by negotiations with General Motors."

 One presenter who can say goodbye to his chances of anchoring ITV's election night - he hosted poll coverage back in 1992, but then fell out of favour - is Jon Snow. Replying to his attack on ITV current affairs, a menacing network statement said Snow and his C4 News team would be "out of a job" without ITN's ITV contract. Yesterday, news 'n' current affairs nabob Steve Anderson sneered that Snow's own "most recent foray" into gritty journalism was his Monica Lewinsky interview. Seconds out! Both men work in "Liddy's Lubianka", the ITV/ITN glass palace on Gray's Inn Road, so hiring minders could be advisable.

 Thanks, Virgin, for your cheery postcard bragging that Chris Evans hosts the most-listened-to "national commercial breakfast show". As it's the only pop-based national commercial breakfast show, however, Monkey suspects this may not be a significant achievement.

 Overheard from a sulking top Sky exec at last week's RTS journalism awards (where the BBC garnered most of the gongs): "What's the point of having [Sky News head] Nick Pollard as awards chair, if this is the outcome?"

 Scuttlebutt at the RTS ceremony suggested that BBC biz boss Jeff Randall's arrival at TV Centre will shortly be followed by rarely-sighted (but formerly Birt-protected) economics editor Peter Jay finally converting inactivity into formal retirement - with Newsnight's Evan Davis a possible replacement. Talked of as in line for promotion too is World Service chief Mark Byford, the Beeb's sole surviving Birtist. Supporters tip him to take over Margaret Salmon's job at BBC Resources. But is that promotion?

 Also rarely glimpsed is BBC chief news correspondent Kate "Angel of Death" Adie, but she covered the Selby rail crash. Why was her Yorkshire sojourn limited to a single day, though? Anything to do with the Beeb's £55 cap on hotel bills?

* Good to see adland responding swiftly to last year's IPA report on women in advertising, which slammed the industry's laddish sexism. A graduate recruitment ad last week for top media agency Carat featured a bosomy babe clad in hot-pants and stilettos, blowing a kiss. The headline? "Where's the best place to touch her?"

*Newsdesks including the Times, Telegraph and Mail eagerly followed up last week's Indy piece on Shakespeare and dope. But were they suffering from the effects of waccy baccy themselves when the same correspondent filed essentially the same story ("The Bard and Dope", Sindy 5/11/2000) four months ago?

 Asked in New York how he felt about turning 70, Rupert Murdoch joked "bad", and revealed that he has helpfully calculated his remaining active hours - around 175,000, after factoring out sleeping, family time and "useless meetings". With haggling over the DirecTV deal continuing, he added: "I just hope that not too many of them are taken up by negotiations with General Motors." Two days later, a possibly pissed-off GM indicated that it was also talking to Disney, General Electric and Comcast.

Since Murdoch is trying to pull off a £43bn merger with a car company that has satellite interests, he added: "I just hope that not too many of them are taken up by negotiations with General Motors."  One presenter who can say goodbye to his chances of anchoring ITV's election night - he hosted poll coverage back in 1992, but then fell out of favour - is Jon Snow. Replying to his attack on ITV current affairs, a menacing network statement said Snow and his C4 News team would be "out of a job" without ITN's ITV contract. Yesterday, news 'n' current affairs nabob Steve Anderson sneered that Snow's own "most recent foray" into gritty journalism was his Monica Lewinsky interview. Seconds out! Both men work in "Liddy's Lubianka", the ITV/ITN glass palace on Gray's Inn Road, so hiring minders could be advisable.  Thanks, Virgin, for your cheery postcard bragging that Chris Evans hosts the most-listened-to "national commercial breakfast show". As it's the only pop-based national commercial breakfast show, however, Monkey suspects this may not be a significant achievement.  Overheard from a sulking top Sky exec at last week's RTS journalism awards (where the BBC garnered most of the gongs): "What's the point of having [Sky News head] Nick Pollard as awards chair, if this is the outcome?"  Scuttlebutt at the RTS ceremony suggested that BBC biz boss Jeff Randall's arrival at TV Centre will shortly be followed by rarely-sighted (but formerly Birt-protected) economics editor Peter Jay finally converting inactivity into formal retirement - with Newsnight's Evan Davis a possible replacement. Talked of as in line for promotion too is World Service chief Mark Byford, the Beeb's sole surviving Birtist. Supporters tip him to take over Margaret Salmon's job at BBC Resources. But is that promotion?  Also rarely glimpsed is BBC chief news correspondent Kate "Angel of Death" Adie, but she covered the Selby rail crash. Why was her Yorkshire sojourn limited to a single day, though? Anything to do with the Beeb's £55 cap on hotel bills? * Good to see adland responding swiftly to last year's IPA report on women in advertising, which slammed the industry's laddish sexism. A graduate recruitment ad last week for top media agency Carat featured a bosomy babe clad in hot-pants and stilettos, blowing a kiss. The headline? "Where's the best place to touch her?" *Newsdesks including the Times, Telegraph and Mail eagerly followed up last week's Indy piece on Shakespeare and dope. But were they suffering from the effects of waccy baccy themselves when the same correspondent filed essentially the same story ("The Bard and Dope", Sindy 5/11/2000) four months ago?  Asked in New York how he felt about turning 70, Rupert Murdoch joked "bad", and revealed that he has helpfully calculated his remaining active hours - around 175,000, after factoring out sleeping, family time and "useless meetings". With haggling over the DirecTV deal continuing, he added: "I just hope that not too many of them are taken up by negotiations with General Motors." Two days later, a possibly pissed-off GM indicated that it was also talking to Disney, General Electric and Comcast.

fields.headline: We have lift-off
fields.standfirst: The Midlands' place at the heart of interplanetary exploration is now assured.  Jonathan Glancey  pays a visit to mission control, north Leicester
fields.trailText: The Midlands' place at the heart of interplanetary exploration is now assured. Jonathan Glancey pays a visit to mission control, north Leicester.
fields.body:
As children my friends and I used to point at the Albert Memorial in London's Kensington Gardens and say it was Britain's entry into the space race. We Brits chose to live in neo-Georgian homes and drive mock-Tudor cars (even the Pop-era Mini estate was framed, like its automotive auntie the Morris Minor Traveller, in timber beams), so a neo-Gothic rocket was just the sort of contraption we would come up with to challenge the Soviets and Americans.

These memories orbited my mind as I travelled through the outskirts of north Leicester, a bleak industrial wasteland of Victorian red brick and inter-war factories and warehouses. Would anyone really expect to find the new heart - or brain - of Britain's space challenge here, in the flattest part of the Midlands? It's not exactly Cape Kennedy. And there's not a hint here of the gleaming white imagery of Stanley Kubrick's magisterial 2001: A Space Odyssey.

But then the tower of the new lottery-fuelled National Space Centre launches into view, rising above the factory roofs and the sodden banks of the River Soar like some giant prop from a 1950s sci-fi film. The very nearly completed building is glamorous in a Boy's Own, Dan Dare, Pilot of the Future, way. Unlike some other over-optimistic millennium museums and galleries in regional towns and cities, this one seems bound to draw the audience it needs to make it a success. The centre aims to attract no more than 300,000 visitors a year, mostly children on school trips, although it should do better than that.

Why the confidence? First, because this is not just another museum dedicated to showing a few exhausted rockets and redundant satellites, but a live space centre, connected via the University of Leicester to real space exploration. Satellites will be controlled from here, and if all goes to plan, new equipment will be built in sight of visitors. This will include the Beagle-2 probe, a Martian explorer, due to be launched by the European "Mars Express" team in June 2003.

Secondly, the education programme is one of the best around. In the Challenger learning centre, children get to work as astronauts and mission controllers in realistic simulations designed to tax their imagination as well as to help them understand the importance of teamwork. Thirdly, Nicholas Grimshaw's team of architects and engineers have designed one of the most distinctive and intriguing new buildings in Britain, one that everyone interested in buildings will want to see.

You can't miss the tower. It's tall, a curious shape, shrouds a brace of spindly space rockets - and it's clad in what looks like a translucent version of the Puffa jacket. Set between curved steel frames, the tower's cladding is made up of a soft, jellyfish-like grid of what are essentially inflatable plastic pillows. The material is ETFE, a self-cleaning plastic, resistant to damage or discoloration from ultraviolet light. So in 20 years' time this eye-catching and revolutionary tower should look much as it does now. And if some guttersnipe decides to take a crack at the tower's inflatable skin with an air-rifle, the pellets will merely sink into the pillows, then pop back out again as the material regains its shape.

The interior of the tower is reached via an elevated walkway inside the main body of the centre. This is a voluminous stainless-steel warehouse set low in what was the storm overflow tank of the old sewage and waterworks next door. This low-lying building contains, aside from shop and cafe, a small, superbly orchestrated "space theatre" or planetarium. Outside the building this appears in the guise of a Buckminster Fuller-like dome, a clever foil to the complex profile of the tower.

The rest of this air-conditioned box of tricks is taken up by displays and exhibits, with pride of place given to a dusty-green Soyuz spacecraft. The upper walkway leads from the darkness of the main building into the light-filled tower, which can also be reached by two sci-fi pod lifts. The views down the shafts of the rockets, up to the old sputniks dangling from the apex of the roof, and through the inflated ETFE pillows across Leicester, are thrilling.

From the top of the tower it's possible to see the project as a whole. Below, the buildings radiate out from the centre point of the dome of the space theatre, moving in a spiral out through the landscaped grounds and car park - and then, if you use your imagination, beyond the flatlands of Leicester and into infinity

It's up to the city of Leicester, not the country's most romantic destination yet one of the hubs of the international space industry, to promote this new attraction imaginatively. Not only is the space age beginning to interest a new generation ignorant of Neil Armstrong, but Nicholas Grimshaw and his team have produced a building that will excite the imagination of both the children who queue to see the animatronic tyrannosaurus in the Natural History Museum, and those of us who believed that one day, some time around 2001, we'd be flying around the universe in sleek spacecraft.

· The National Space Centre, Leicester, opens on June 30.
