fields.headline: Who's mad now?
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago, he was rubbished for warning that BSE could be transmitted to humans. We now know how right he was. So what does Richard Lacey think of the latest farming crisis?

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, he was rubbished for warning that BSE could be transmitted to humans. We now know how right he was. So what does Richard Lacey think of the latest farming crisis?
fields.body:
It's freezing cold. Professor Richard Lacey is standing outside the front door of his grand, dishevelled manor house. He's waiting for me, with a warm smile. The snow is falling off his purple pants and sloppy tie and haggard sports jacket. They could have been bought from Oxfam. He looks different from those pictures the papers were so fond of printing in the 90s. Older and healthier.

Lacey became a household name 10 years ago when he warned the world against BSE and variant CJD. The government adviser announced that half the herds in Britain should be destroyed and, at very worst, the disease could wipe out a generation. This was at the time that the government was denying its existence. Lacey became the scourge of the very establishment he was a prominent member of. He was vilified by the politicians, the civil servants, the food industry, you name it. The very people who had called on his expertise denounced him as a self-publicising scaremonger.

Late last year the Phillips report into BSE was released. By then, at least 80 people had died of vCJD in Britain. The politicians were duly criticised for their complacency and incompetence. If you search hard enough in one of the appendixes to the report you will also find a section that vindicates Lacey. Few newspapers bothered to report it.

Lacey took early retirement a couple of years ago, at 58. These days he potters and paints, he gardens quite brilliantly, he makes a small fortune from his antiques collection. He does so many things, fills his time so easily and happily. He says he's not given a big interview for five years. Why should he? That's an old life, the past.

When the Phillips report came out, he was on holiday in Switzerland. "Fortunately, so I avoided the media." Why fortunately? "Because I think I might have been tempted to say something that I might have regretted." Did he feel like gloating? "No. It's not a happy situation. There are no winners. Throughout I hoped I would be wrong. You can't gloat. It would be like people investigating the effects on radiation gloating. You know, it's dreadful."

Lacey is not vegetarian, but he stopped eating beef in 1988. His arguments were simple, and similar to those put forward by Tony Blair last week. By providing meat on the cheap we put our health at risk. "When you have these massive scales of operation from animal feed to large numbers of animals being reared, to the abattoir, to the processing, to the purchase by the retailers and the sell, if you have a developing problem the infective agent would spread very quickly." He says exactly the same is true for foot and mouth today, and that until we have a return to small scale local production there will always be a chance of national catastrophe.

The Tory government and its farming friends didn't like the message so they decided to destabilise the messenger. Lacey takes out a copy of one of his many books, and raises his vexed eyebrows into huge quotation marks. "The thing I got really angry about was that a group of MPs used parliamentary privilege to rubbish me at a press conference in the House of Commons." He reads from the book slowly and calmly. "This is what it said: 'That not all scientists bore equal authority was amply born out in our evidence. Professor Lacey in particular showed a tendency to extrapolate sensational conclusions from incomplete evidence in order to publicise his long-standing concerns about food safety. The result was a mixture of science and science fiction, a quite unsuitable basis for public policy. When he told us that if our worst fears are recognised we could virtually lose a generation of people he seemed to lose touch completely with the real world.' " He stops, appalled. The first he heard of the smear campaign was when reporters rang him for a comment.

But his conclusions were apocalyptic, weren't they? They did make for great headlines. "No," he says. "They sensationalised what I said, took it out of context. They didn't mention that I said it was a distinct possibility that no one was vulnerable. They deliberately focused on the worst-case scenario to discredit me."

Lacey has lost four stone since the 90s, when he came across as a lumbering beast. He's rather svelte now. When he talks food politics he sits still and serious, clutching his ankles. Suddenly he asks if I would like to see his cacti, and he's transformed.

He bounces off the sofa, and heads for the conservatory. He rushes over to a giant cactus, tells me it's an opuntia, and almost stabs himself with ants-in-the-pants enthusiasm. What does his love affair with cacti say about him? "A bit prickly?" He grins. "Cacti are naturally immune to most pests, so they grow quite well."

We're back in the lounge. He's clutching his ankles again, telling me how things went from bad to worse. Politicians suggested he wasn't qualified to talk about food because he was a professor of microbiology. He points to the mantelpiece. Alongside pictures of his two daughters and wife, there is a photo of Princess Diana presenting an award to him. "It was quite extraordinary that they said that. In fact that was a prize in 1989, the Evian Health Award, for my work on salmonella."

He says the government was well aware of his expertise. "After all, they asked me to advise something called the veterinary products committee for four years from January 1 1986 to December 31 1989." He can be very pedantic when defending himself. Lacey has learned the importance of detail.

He was also labelled a media tart. "I never went to the press though. They always came to me. Like you have done today." The first time a newspaper approached him, about salmonella, he refused to comment. In the end, he thought someone had to say something about the dangers, and at least his department wasn't sponsored by the food industry. He thought he was safe. But he wasn't.

Lacey seems a little restless. He asks me if I'd like to see jigsaws of the garden in bloom. He explains how he took photos, sent them to Scotland to be turned into 1,000-piece jigsaws, then spent a week making them and finally framed them. They are absolutely beautiful. At the end of the room there is row after row of vintage tea caddies. "The oldest is about 1760. There's a secret drawer there for the caddy spoon. Go on, you'll never find it." He lets me struggle. "D'you give in?" I give in. He's delighted. He tells me how he restored many of the caddies himself. The house is crammed with stuff he's nurtured or created.

Lacey is relaxed, and when he's relaxed he does tend to talk big. "I tell you the governments aren't going to recover from this for centuries ," he says of the various food crises. "They might be safe, but the trouble is you can't tell. And now any reassurance about GM foods will be dismissed." Lacey asks if he should put on his tie with the cows for the photograph.

It was in 1994 that things reached their nadir. His department at Leeds University was 60% funded by the health service. One morning a health service manager turned up for a surprise visit. "He said they were going to have a press conference in the afternoon, and they were going to announce all my staff's contracts would be transferred to another authority. It meant I couldn't do any work. I could be paid but do no work." The university, which remained loyal to him, worked out a package - the health service advanced his pension and agreed to reemploy him as a consultant in a small hospital for three years. "The total cost to the health service was half a million pounds."

But at least he was working as a consultant? "In theory. But I only had about 10 minutes work to do a day." So they paid you 500 grand to lie down? "Correct." He raises an eyebrow. "Anyway it didn't work." In March 1996, the government finally admitted the link between BSE and vCJD. "I was very prominent then, very vocal." When he finally retired in 1998, he was in for another shock. "They cancelled the transfer of my staff's contracts, and that's how it is today. I think it was a deliberate conspiracy."

Lacey says he was not a conspiracy theorist until BSE. In fact, he was what he calls a "hereditary Tory". He remembers his grandmother threatening to leave the country if Labour and the unions got into power. As an academic in the 80s he veered towards the Labour party because he believed his role was to challenge industry and society rather than appease it. These days, he says, he has given up on politics.

How badly did the rubbishing affect him? "Not really at all." Not at all? "Well it did slightly. I suppose it changed my personality a bit. I think I became withdrawn. They tried to damage me, but I don't think they've actually succeeded. I think many people would have settled for my life, don't you?"

He takes down one of his prized tea caddies and tells me it's made of marine turtle. I ask him whether he's an obsessive collector. "Yes, I am fairly obsessive," he says. "I am very determined. I keep at things."

webTitle: Overworked Britons feel ill and too tired for love

fields.headline: Overworked Britons feel ill and too tired for love
fields.standfirst: Health and family life suffer from lack of time off, says survey
fields.trailText: Birds do it, bees do it, but a lot of British workers are just too exhausted to do it. Long working hours are leading to middle class professionals amongst others losing interest in their love lives, according to a survey released today.
fields.body:
Birds do it, bees do it, but a lot of British workers are just too exhausted to do it. Long working hours are leading to middle class professionals amongst others losing interest in their love lives, according to a survey released today.

Over half the partners of workers questioned by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development said their loved ones were so tired when they got home from work that their sex lives suffered.

The survey also found that long hours led to mistakes at work, children being neglected, as well as physical and mental health complaints.

Over one-fifth of people are working more than 48 hours a week, according to the survey - and 56% of these said the balance between their work and personal life was wrong, being weighted too much towards their job.

Of those who work 48 hours a week or more, 35% described themselves as workaholics, with four in five of those being male.

Three-quarters of those working long hours told interviewers the main reason was a large workload, with 47% saying it was their own choice and that they did not mind, while 43% reporting that they sometimes worked long hours grudgingly.

Part of the survey reinterviewed people first spoken to two years ago, before the working time directive came into force to combat excessive working weeks. Britain has the longest average working week in the European Union: 43.6 hours.

The report's author, Melissa Compton-Edwards, said: "The working time directive is not having a great deal of impact. Of the people we interviewed two years ago, 60% are still working 48 hours a week or more; and just 2% reporting that their hours were reduced as a result of the working time directive. The rest are working fewer hours because they have changed jobs."

Half of those interviewed blamed excessive hours for mistakes at work, with 5% saying they had been involved in car accidents as a result.

"Two-fifths report that working long hours has resulted in arguments with their spouse or partner .. Nearly a third admit that work-related tiredness is causing their sex life to suffer and 42% say that friendships have been damaged."

Children also suffer, with 19% of workers saying long hours were causing damage to their relationships with their offspring, 22% saying they never saw their children before they went to bed, 34% saying they were so worn out they shouted at their children, and 29% experiencing guilt over missing seeing their offspring grow up.

Middle managers are most likely to be spending the longest in the office. The main type of employee spending 48 hours at work is a manager or administrator (26%), or professional (24%), or artisan such as a craft worker (22%). But 28% of those working long hours are self-employed.

Some 35% with long hours were aged 35-44, with 32% of those working over 48 hours aged 45-54.

The group working most are those earning just below or above average earnings.

John Monks, TUC general secretary, said: "This long-hours culture is as bad for business as it is for people's home lives.

"Employers should realise that the happiest, most productive workers are those who have time to enjoy a life outside work."

Ms Compton-Edwards said partners seem to accept an absentee and exhausted provider: "The Faustian pact seems to be that while they would rather have their 'long hours' partner working shorter hours, this is considered a price worth paying if it guarantees a decent standard of living."

fields.headline: Capitalism's casino
fields.standfirst: As social security dwindled, Americans gambled on the stock market to protect their futures. They're losing
fields.trailText: As social security dwindled, Americans gambled on the stock market to protect their futures. They're losing.
fields.body:
Six months ago a church worker in Harlem put me on hold for what felt like an indecently long time. Just as I was about to hang up on our conversation about the church's moral responsibility to balance the competing goals of historical preservation, economic development and racial and social diversity in the area, he returned to my ear as abruptly as he'd left. "Sorry," he said. "That was my broker. That's a call I had to take. Now where were we?"

A few days later I mentioned this to a social worker in Brooklyn by way of an amusing anecdote. He was amused - but only by my naivety. "You always take the call from your broker," he said. "I'd put my wife on hold for him. And she wouldn't be mad if I told you either. She'd do the same thing."

In a country where the percentage of people owning stock and equities had risen by 31% in four years, following the stock market had become a national sport. With more than a third of the nation owning stocks, Wall Street and Main Street appeared to have converged. The average investor might be in his or her late forties, white and professional but stock ownership had breached the barriers of race, social class, ethnicity, political affiliation and region in a way previously reserved for God and Coca Cola. Around 80m Americans owned stocks or mutual funds - more than watch the Oscars, surf the internet or voted in the 1998 congressional elections and double the number in 1983.

Everyone, it seemed, could be a dealer; and dealing and following your stocks could take place everywhere. Thanks to new technologies you could trade from your home and check your stocks on your mobile phone in an aeroplane and in most business foyers, where hungry eyes feasted on flashing numbers flickering across television screens.

All things considered, this was hardly surprising. Between 1982 and 1999 prices on the stock market climbed every year but one. In 1999 the Nasdaq leapt 86% and reached its high point this weekend last year. Just as Fukuyama proclaimed the end of history, so theorists believed the "new economy" could defy gravity and logic.

But the ramifications went way beyond the economic. Socially, the stock market was the main topic of conversation at water-coolers, barbecues and dinner parties. "I felt I had to get some stocks just so I'd have something to talk about," said a Brit who moved to New York two years ago. People joined investment clubs in thousands and some mutual-fund seminars with top money managers were standing room only.

Culturally, it was de rigueur. Business presenters became household names. The anchorwoman for the business channel, CNBC, found herself so besieged that she started asking her husband to pick up the Chinese takeaway. "I'm trying to get out of there with my food," said Sue Herera, "and the cook's asking, 'What's with Intel?'"

Television shows like The Street and Bull turned the stock market into prime-time soap operas. "Wall Street is the new American pastime," said Michael Chernuchin, the creator of Bull, last year. "People follow the Dow and Nasdaq like they are sports scores. The average New York cabby used to have the Daily News on the front seat beside him. Today, he also has Barron's and the Wall Street Journal."

So long as graphs went skywards the outlook remained sunny. But with markets plunging, and the economy flattening, the stock-buying American public now find themselves under a stubborn, dark cloud. Membership of investment clubs has dropped 23% in the past two years; advertising in personal finance magazines has nose-dived; The Street was cancelled halfway through its run thanks to poor ratings. In the space of just two weeks last month the number of investors describing themselves as bears almost trebled while the number of bulls more than halved, according to a membership poll by the American Association of Individual Investors.

T o some, this signals nothing more than the jitters of novices who were in it for the quick buck rather than the long run. The increase in stock ownership, argued the right, demonstrates both the invincibility and democratisation of capitalism, turning millions from spectators to players in the free market. With everyone from social workers to the clergy involved, the primacy of the market was entrenched.

Whether this was wilful disingenuousness or wishful thinking (or both) is not clear. Either way it represents a fundamental misinterpretation of the phenomenon. For while some joined the investor class with making an easy fortune in mind, the motivation for most of this new generation of investors is not getting rich but not becoming poor.

Since the Republicans started slashing spending on wealth, healthcare and education and weakening labour laws, prompting job insecurity, people have looked for ways to make themselves less vulnerable. A survey released last year by Ariel Mutual Funds and Charles Schwab revealed that saving money for retirement, children's college education and emergencies were all cited before "obtaining a better lifestyle" as reasons for investing in stocks.

This was not confined to the US. Many Britons invested in private pensions, endowment policies and private health care because they could see the writing on the wall for the welfare state, pensions and the NHS under the Conservatives.

And while the political complexion of governments may change, the basic belief that the market can, should and will play a meaningful role in supporting our social needs prevails. Herein lies the ideological impetus for the third way and private-public partnerships pushed by Blair. It also provides the glue for Bush's planned social security reforms, whereby workers will have "individual retirement accounts" with managers they can designate themselves.

With the stock markets taking a pounding, the fig leaf for this political direction has been removed. In its place we see that the politics of the past 15 years has been based on the assumption of permanent economic prosperity. What sense does welfare to work make if there is no work? What point is there in private finance initiatives if capital is scarce?

Meanwhile America's baby boomers sit and fret. With each market bulletin they see their hopes for a comfortable retirement and a sound educational grounding for their children fade. Worse still, with the paper value of their assets plummeting, many have spent against savings that have withered away.

Economists call it dis-saving. "The collapse of savings has been one of the most striking phenomena of the US economy in the 1990s," said the Financial Times. The trouble is, like those who took out endowments 20 or so years ago in Britain only to find they cannot pay off their mortgage today, many here thought they were playing it relatively safe. Naive? - possibly. But their choices were limited. Having been ideologically cajoled and politically coerced to invest in their "own future" they now find they have gambled it in capitalism's largest casino.

fields.headline: Turin Brakes
fields.standfirst:
Manchester Roadhouse
Rating: **
fields.trailText: Olly Knights and Gale Paridjanian met at primary school in London and so, one way or another, they have been play ing together for years. Turin Brakes, however, evolved directly out of soundtracks they wrote together during Knights's time studying film at Central St Martins College of Art and Design. Given this unusual genesis, and Olly Knights's supple, beguiling voice, you might expect Turin Brakes' folk-rock songs to sport an experimental, esoteric edge. In fact, but for Paridjanian's trademark dustbowl slide-guitar, they are suffocatingly orthodox.
fields.body:
Olly Knights and Gale Paridjanian met at primary school in London and so, one way or another, they have been play ing together for years. Turin Brakes, however, evolved directly out of soundtracks they wrote together during Knights's time studying film at Central St Martins College of Art and Design. Given this unusual genesis, and Olly Knights's supple, beguiling voice, you might expect Turin Brakes' folk-rock songs to sport an experimental, esoteric edge. In fact, but for Paridjanian's trademark dustbowl slide-guitar, they are suffocatingly orthodox.

Opener Once Around, to abuse an overused reference point, is middle of the road Radiohead. The second song, Slack, is Oasis in Black Crowe's crushed-velvet flares. The rest of Turin Brakes's output hovers ineffectually between the two.

Bolstered by three extra members (although, as they are all seated, you almost need to get on stage to spot them), Turin Brakes are bathed in a late-summer west coast warmth that bears out their claims that their debut album, The Optimist, errs towards philosophical realism rather than miserablism. Unfortunately, in early-1970s California passion was frequently edged out by expansive musicianship, and, as Emergency 72 descends into a bluesy coda, the vibe is of accomplished musicians enjoying one another's fretwork over crumbling spliffs.

Tellingly, The Boss, slightly musically skewed and lyrically direct, is Turin Brakes's best song. A B-side, it marries a delicate, melodically obtuse sigh of a verse to a lyric - "Who's good to you?/ I'm the boss of the century" - that captures McJob frustrations with all the grand sarcasm of Morrissey. Elsewhere, Knights's lyrics, like their flickeringly great, but ultimately passive songs, hint intriguingly - "My friends are all junkies, but they're still my friends," runs Future Boy - without quite hitting home.

Beyond the front few rows, there's a hubbub of conversation throughout the show. Not that this will trouble Turin Brakes unduly. Like Beth Orton before them, they're currently the folk act of choice for trendy Londoners - thanks to their hip label Source and gigs at The Social - and they have transcended musical divides, even remixing dance producer Midfield General. Later this month, they are due to support the earnestly songwriterly Stereophonics, while the hacks who guard the classic rock canon already love them. But, in a world that contains Eminem, The Strokes, Slipknot and Kellis - acts that are brimming with attitude and energy - it is difficult to care either way about Turin Brakes.
Turin Brakes play Northampton Roadmenders (01604 604222) tonight, then tour to Leeds and Wolverhampton.

fields.headline: Orgiastic frenzy at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
Karita Mattila
Barbican Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText: If you've got it, flaunt it, so they say. Soprano Karita Mattila certainly does. The "Finnish Venus", as she's known, is a phenomenon. She's as beautiful as Garbo, acts as well as Vanessa Redgrave, dresses in such a way as to make Liz Hurley look staid - and on top of that, she has an opulent, sexy voice that sends shivers down your spine. Her Barbican recital was greeted with a response that can only be described as abandoned, as she turned her audience into a rout of orgiastic devotees worshipping at her shrine.
fields.body:
If you've got it, flaunt it, so they say. Soprano Karita Mattila certainly does. The "Finnish Venus", as she's known, is a phenomenon. She's as beautiful as Garbo, acts as well as Vanessa Redgrave, dresses in such a way as to make Liz Hurley look staid - and on top of that, she has an opulent, sexy voice that sends shivers down your spine. Her Barbican recital was greeted with a response that can only be described as abandoned, as she turned her audience into a rout of orgiastic devotees worshipping at her shrine.

She swept on to the platform draped in a glittering gold cape, from which she disrobed part way through the first half to reveal a skimpy black trousersuit - at which point a shuddering gasp ran round the building. After the interval she returned in a green gown open from throat to midriff and slashed from crotch to ankle. At that point, audience restraint was thrown to the winds, as enthusiastic roars, shrieks and yells erupted. The wildness continued to the end of the evening.

Her programme was idiosyncratic and tremendous, opening and closing with some rarely performed material written in languages other than the composers' own.

Schubert's Italian songs were balanced by a curious group of early Wagner efforts in French. Each group culminated in a portrayal of a tragic heroine in extremis. Schubert's Dido implored Aeneas not to abandon her with a mixture of manipulative wheedling and awesome rage - Mattila, obsessively wringing her hands, suggested a woman whose nerves were passing beyond breaking point. Wagner's Les Adieux de Marie Stuart ostensibly depicts the Queen of Scots saying farewell to France, though in the process, Wagner endows her with prophetic fits that allow her intimations of her future disastrous career. Musically it owes much to Meyerbeer, against whom Wagner later turned vituperatively, though its extravagantly surging vocal line also presages Isolde's erotics and Brünnhilde's sacrificial immolation. Mattila unleashed a swirling torrent of elation, rapture and despair while the audience held its breath.

In between came contemporary Finnish music and songs by Henri Duparc. Jouni Kaipainen's Runopolku (The Poetic Path) is a ravishing, surreal song cycle that balances impressionistic pianism with declamatory, expressionistic vocals. Mattila proved that she can sing contemporary music as well as she can sing anything else. In Duparc's songs, she became a languid icon of Baudelairean sensuality - " luxe, calme et volupté " incarnate. The sexual charge Mattila generates is astonishing, and she ranks, without question, as the successor of the legendary vocal eroticists of the last century - singers such as Maria Jeritza, Ljuba Welitsch and Leonie Rysanek. At the piano, Malcolm Martineau, excellent as always, looked as if he wondered what had hit him. Everyone in the audience felt the same way.

fields.headline: Complex monopoly in banking
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The vexed issue of competition in the banking sector is likely to be reignited this week with the competition commission is expected to conclude that there is a "complex monopoly" in the small business banking market.
fields.body:
The vexed issue of competition in the banking sector is likely to be reignited this week with the competition commission is expected to conclude that there is a "complex monopoly" in the small business banking market.

The conclusions of the year-long investigation, expected tomorrow, will come as the office of fair trading gives further information about its controversial decision to refer Lloyds TSB's £19bn for Abbey National for a full-scale competition investigation.

When the decision to refer the bid was announced two weeks ago, the government cited the small business banking market as one of the areas for potential concern.

The decision by the competition commission to announce further details of its investigation into the small business banking market so close to the Budget on Wednesday is expected to lead to a chorus of criticism that the government is reneging on promises to keep politics out of competition issues.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst:
Holiday pay

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Holiday pay.
fields.body:
Secretaries are a well-travelled lot. Research from Thomson Holidays, which has a vested interest in learning everybody's holiday preferences, shows that 38% of secretaries take three foreign holidays a year.

Although this is the ski season, you won't necessarily find many secretaries on the slopes. Thomson's research indicates that they prefer sun to snow, and will go a long way for it. Thailand, Barbados, even Mexico, are the destinations most favoured by PAs.

The well-known penchant of secretaries for long-haul travel was one of the arguments the recruitment industry used against the introduction of statutory holiday pay for temps, which became law a couple of years ago. The industry argued that temps had no interest in an annual fortnight in Bridlington, but preferred a working pattern that left them free to take a month or longer at a stretch. As such, the agencies argued, the temps would rather work for a higher hourly rate than accrue holiday pay. If you gave temps holidays, they would just sneak off and work somewhere else for a fortnight.

This school of thought was notably to be found among smaller agencies, for which statutory holiday pay meant taking on a new layer of administration, at enormous expense, when profit margins were already squeezed by fierce competition. The big high street agencies had already been offering holiday pay to temps, long before legislation had even been thought of.

Not quite two years on, it has turned out that, given the chance, temps like paid holidays as much as everyone else. But the basic debate - do temps prefer high pay and no frills to full employee benefits? - rattles on in the industry.

And it will rattle even louder over the next few months, as the government is poised to reform the laws that regulate employment agencies.

Meanwhile, if you prefer a relaxing holiday to action and adventure, have you thought of The Algarve? This is where a fifth of all chefs go on holiday. They must know something.

fields.headline: Spinal tapped
fields.standfirst:
Sit up straight and pay attention. No, really. Back pain is now the nation's leading disability. Which should come as no surprise when you consider the hours workers spend slumped over their keyboards. Laura Barton reports

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Sit up straight and pay attention. No, really. Back pain is now the nation's leading disability. Which should come as no surprise when you consider the hours workers spend slumped over their keyboards. Laura Barton reports.
fields.body:
We weren't designed to sit still. If we were, surely we would have been born with washable, plush velour covers, neat little antimacassars in place of shoulders, and dainty brass casters for feet. Despite these obvious design flaws, the average British office worker spends 25 to 40 hours a week stagnating in front of a computer screen, chin thrust out and shoulders grazing ear lobes. The fact that back pain is the nation's leading disability is therefore hardly staggering.

According to BackCare, a UK charity that provides information for back pain sufferers, it is a problem that affects nearly two-thirds of UK adults, and loses British industry around £6bn a year through days spent off work. The average sufferer takes 13 days off, and one in eight unemployed people cite back pain as their reason for not working. Goodness only knows how many valuable hours are lost in moaning to your colleagues about the huge knot in your shoulder, and audibly cracking your neck in between telephone calls.

A report last month from the NHS centre for reviews and dissemination at York University, concluded that there is little we can do to help a bad back, other than swallow painkillers. But because many cases are attributable to our slouching postures, our sedentary professions, and our couch-lovin' lifestyles, there are a few simple measures that might help.

Caroline Murison, from the West End Physiotherapy Clinic in London, runs a service called the Nine to Five Check. A physiotherapist visits your office and spends 20 minutes assessing your posture at your workstation before instructing you in basic exercises - which you can do at your desk - to help prevent back pain. You don't even have to put on your trainers.

The first thing to look at is your chair. By law, says Emma Tate from BackCare, there is a minimum standard to which the chair must conform. "It must be stable, which means having a base with five legs in a star-shape; the seat should be adjustable in height and tilt, and it needs to allow freedom of movement".

The way in which you sit in your chair will obviously affect your back. Right now, I'm leaning slightly to the right, my middle back slouched and my legs crossed. This is wrong, and on no account should you try this at home. The spinal position we should be aiming for is a gentle S-shape - "Not upright, but not slouching," says Tate. Murison recommends that your knees be at a 90 degree angle to your body, with your feet flat on the floor.

"People who sit down all day tend to experience low back strain from sitting hunched forwards," explains Liz Ellis, president of the British Osteopathic Society. "This puts strain on the ligaments. You're putting a lot of pressure on the front of the discs, they bulge backwards and trap the nerves, which leads to referred pain going down the back of the leg." To stop yourself slumping forwards, Ellis advises that you "sit on the two bottom bones, not on the fleshy bit of your bottom". Those of you who are concerned that there is only a fleshy bit of your bottom may join the club.

Once she's got your chair sorted, Murison looks at the position of your computer, the keyboard, and the mouse. "A lot of people have their mouse too far away, they keep their wrist extended, and their wrist and finger cocked, which can lead to repetitive strain injury," she says.

It doesn't end there. Ellis explains that a host of problems can be caused simply by sitting a little cockeyed on your swivel chair: "Because they're not sitting straight, people tend to poke their chins forward, and so they get chronic tension in the muscles at the back of the neck and across the shoulders. The weight of the human head is enormous, and if you let the head poke forward, this affects the joints at the point where the neck meets the top of the spine and can alter how the vertebrae sit at the top of the neck, leading to headaches.

In addition, because people are hunched forwards, like little goblins, they find that they clench their teeth, which can bring trigeminal neuralgia and general facial pain. Sitting with legs crossed can cause haemorrhoids, varicose veins and circulatory problems, and inhibits good breathing and digestion. It's a whole body thing."

The there's the telephone. We all know what it's like trying to answer calls, switch on the computer and open the post at the same time, but Murison explains that the way we use the phone can also lead to back problems. "People tend to hook the handset under one ear, which is really bad for the neck," she says. "We recommend using headsets, or moving the phone from one side to another." Emma Tate suggests you try standing up for every other telephone call.

The predominant advice is simply to keep moving. "We're not made like machines or robots," Tate observes. "We need to take breaks." Every 15-20 minutes you should try to move around, change position, fidget a bit, maybe take a stroll to the water-cooler. "Do some exercises at your desk," suggests Tate, "go outside at lunchtime, whatever the weather. Walk upstairs instead of taking the lift."

Outside office hours (what? you mean there is life beyond Office Hours?), you should try to get a bit of gentle exercise, too. "Don't just go home, sit on your comfy sofa and watch TV," Murison says sternly. "We advise people to do stretching exercises. A lot of people go to the gym to try and tone up, but they need to remember to stretch when they warm up and cool down." There's some science behind it, too, Liz Ellis explains. "Unless people do some kind of body maintenance, they tend to have very lax abdominal muscles. Tense abdominals take the pressure off the back muscles. I recommend that my patients find a properly trained pilates teacher, and be mindful of their posture every day, tucking in your tail and holding in you abdominal muscles, rather than doing exercise twice a week."

BackCare recommends pretty much everything you can think of - stretching, swimming, walking, yoga, Alexander Technique, tai chi, exercise bicycles with upright handlebars . . . Anything to get you limbered up and out of that slumped, static posture of the nine to five.

The back pack

"There is so much back pain in this country that there simply aren't enough chiropractors, osteopaths and physiotherapists to go round. I simply suggest that you go to someone you have a rapport with and whom you trust," says Manya McMahon from the British Chiropractic Association.

 The West End Physiotherapy Clinic: 020 7734 6263.

 British Chiropractic Association: 01189 505 950.

 British Osteopathy Association: 01582 488 455.

 BackCare (formerly the National Back Pain Association): 020 8977 5474, or visit www.backpain.org. BackCare produces a leaflet, Back In The Office, which costs 50p and can be obtained by writing to BackCare, 16 Elm Tree Road, Teddington, Middlesex TW11 8ST.

 The Society of Teachers of the Alexander Technique: 020 7284 3338.

 Pilates: a list of Pilates studios nationwide can be obtained by sending an SAE to The Pilates Foundation, 80 Camden Road, London E17 7NF.

 Body Control Pilates: 020 7379 3734.

 The British Wheel of Yoga: 01529 306851.

Sitting comfortably?

 Staples, the office superstore, with branches nationwide, stocks a range of office chairs. Call Staples Direct on 0800 141414.

 When choosing a chair, look out for adjustable back and seat height, lumbar support, tilt tension, knee tilt, back angle, seat depth and synchro tilt (whatever that might be).

 Office furniture can be an expensive affair. But says BackCare: "If your employer feels that they cannot provide more than basic equipment, you can both be assisted under a government scheme called Access to Work." Contact the Disability Employment Advisor at your local job centre.

webTitle: Office hours: Suits you.  Alice Wignall  on why dressing down is fast going out of fashion

fields.headline: Smarty pants
fields.standfirst: Suits you.  Alice Wignall  on why dressing down is fast going out of fashion
fields.trailText: Suits you. Alice Wignall on why dressing down is fast going out of fashion.
fields.body:
Most people would prefer not to wear a suit to work. Or so you might imagine. But latest research shows that the old whistle and flute is enjoying something of a renaissance, even in the face of ubiquitous dress-down days and the flowering of oh-so-casual New Media offices. Figures from London and New York show that suit sales increased suddenly in the final quarter of last year.

Savile Row-based outfitters Gieves & Hawkes, suit-makers to generations of starched City workers, report that customers have been exhibiting somewhat strange behaviour of late. No longer do they fling themselves on the nearest sales person, wild-eyed with dread at the prospect of casual dress, begging to be shown something smart enough to persuade their line manager that they are promotion material, while still communicating that essential, "Hey, I may be an accountant, but I know how to chill" vibe. Instead, dapper young gents are positively embracing the restrictions of a three-piece (that's suit, not suite) and eschewing open-necked shirts in favour of a button-down collar.

"But why? Why?" I hear you wail, especially those of you who have no choice about whether or not you're going to wear a suit every day of the working week.

Well, here comes the economics, so concentrate. If City folk (yes, the same City folk who are flocking to Gieves & Hawkes en masse) are becoming slightly jittery at the prospect of a downturn in the international economy - and my FT-reading friends tell me that they are - then how better to convince your boss that you're a cut above the rest of the drones and really rather worth hanging onto, should push come to shove, than to turn up for work suited and booted and looking sharper than acutlery draw full of knives?

Whereas in the mid-90s, eager young things proved their commitment to eat, sleep and breathe their work by flinging on the nearest well-pressed Ralph Lauren shirt in the morning - "Godammit, I feel so at home in this office, I don't even need to dress up anymore" - these days simply everyone is at it. It's so much more millennial to look as if you've got a team of tailors working round the clock to keep you looking smart. Might even help convince people that you've got a life outside the office - well, you can't wear a tie 24/7, can you? Can you?

Add to this the fact that we fickle creatures have got bored of being allowed to wear whatever we want. Dress-down days and dress-code free offices might have been fun to start with, but the appeal soon fades. We end up giving the same blank stare to a distinctly uninspiring wardrobe day in, day out, wondering where all our interesting clothes have gone. I don't know about you, but I'm only prepared to put up with this kind of dilemma on a Saturday night.

A suit, on the other hand, is good to go in a matter of minutes. Patricia Coates, who works for a leading City accountant, believes this to be true: "A suit's just easier. You know where you are and you never have to worry about not looking smart enough."

Even fairly liberal employers will frown upon a misplaced Porn Star T-shirt, and this makes the suit a safe bet. As Coates says: "We've supposedly got a permanent dress-down policy where I work, apart from when you're with a client, or when you might run into one - so basically apart from any time that you're in the office."

Of course, there may be another, more shallow, explanation for all this. Surely it can't be coincidence that workers everywhere decided that, actually, they would really rather wear a suit today, if it's all the same to you, just as the world's designers sent rack-loads of matching pinstriped numbers careering down the catwalks of New York, Paris, Milan and London. In which case, we need only wait until the wheel turns again, and suddenly everyone will decide that, really, multicoloured kaftans are incredibly practical office wear. But I for one hope that the trend for suits is here to stay. They are sharp, smart and ever-so-slightly-sexy. And come on, be honest: during all the dress-down days that you ever endured, did you ever see anyone who looked good in cargo pants?

fields.headline: Minimum wage increase from October
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has announced a 10% rise in the minimum wage.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has announced a 10% rise in the minimum wage.

The increase, which will lift the minimum wage from £3.70 an hour to £4.10 from October 1, will be announced in the Budget on the recommendation of the low pay commission.

It means an adult working a 40-hour week on the minimum wage will earn an extra £16 a week. A 25-hour week will pull in an extra £10.

The low pay commission has advised a second increase in October 2002 to put the minimum wage at £4.20 an hour. Mr Byers said that the government accepted it, subject to economic conditions.

Mr Byers told the Commons that the raise was bold enough to make a difference but sufficiently prudent not to damage the economy.

"The minimum wage has been a success with nearly a million and a half people benefiting without any negative effect," he said.

Union leaders, who had been pressing for £5 an hour, will welcome the announcement but members of the business community have warned against such rises.

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, yesterday expressed concern that a higher minimum wage will place inflationary pressure on the economy.

"The real concern is the knock-on effect down the road at £5 an hour, £5.10 an hour. Anything over £4 is a problem for business," he said.

The minimum wage was introduced in April 1999. Mr Byers said today that it had done more to increase women's pay than any initiative since the 1975 Equal Pay Act and was smoothing out regional pay differences.

He added that unlike benefits which, he said, are "simply compensating" people in poverty, the minimum wage makes "work pay". He said it was the best form of welfare.

For the opposition, David Heathcoat-Amory told the Commons that the Tories would not oppose the increase.

The new rate will apply to part- and full-time workers as well as to agency staff and people working from home.

A decision about the youth rate paid to workers between 18 and 21 years of age will be taken in May, after the expected general election.

Professor George Bain, chairman of the low pay commission, said he was delighted that the government had accepted the recommendations, which had been made after extensive consultation with the unions and industry.

"The real concern is the knock-on effect down the road at £5 an hour, £5.10 an hour. Anything over £4 is a problem for business," he said. The minimum wage was introduced in April 1999. Mr Byers said today that it had done more to increase women's pay than any initiative since the 1975 Equal Pay Act and was smoothing out regional pay differences. He added that unlike benefits which, he said, are "simply compensating" people in poverty, the minimum wage makes "work pay". He said it was the best form of welfare. For the opposition, David Heathcoat-Amory told the Commons that the Tories would not oppose the increase. The new rate will apply to part- and full-time workers as well as to agency staff and people working from home. A decision about the youth rate paid to workers between 18 and 21 years of age will be taken in May, after the expected general election. Professor George Bain, chairman of the low pay commission, said he was delighted that the government had accepted the recommendations, which had been made after extensive consultation with the unions and industry. webTitle: Dave Holland, king of the bass

fields.headline: Dave Holland, king of the bass
fields.standfirst:
Dave Holland Octet
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Audiences used to head for the bar in the bass solos on jazz shows. But not any more. Better amplification, technical strides and the evolution of a collaborative philosophy have given the acoustic bassist a status unthinkable 40 years ago.
fields.body:
Audiences used to head for the bar in the bass solos on jazz shows. But not any more. Better amplification, technical strides and the evolution of a collaborative philosophy have given the acoustic bassist a status unthinkable 40 years ago.

This winter has provided many opportunities to reflect on that: the Norwegian bass genius Arild Andersen has just departed; Christian McBride and Ray Brown are due this month; and the UK expatriate virtuoso Dave Holland is on tour throughout this week.

Holland is here on a Contemporary Music Network tour, and with an octet that gives his intricately earthy music a dynamic span all the way from an intimate whisper to a raucous, Mingus-band clamour. On its second gig of the trip, the Holland octet certainly emphasised the Charles Mingus connection in the opener - Holland regularly echoes that unruly bassist/ bandleader's legacy in both the penetrative passion of his instrumental sound and the bluesy harmonies of his ensembles. The connection was pursued in the following Blues for CM, a bleary, stealthily stalking theme of Ellingtonesque brass effects and an astonishing solo of streaming double-time melody from vibraharpist Steve Nelson. That was followed by an alto sax break of wailing intensity from a very impressive Antonio Hart.

Nelson, who makes the sometimes sugary vibes sound uncharacteristically clear and purposeful, played a startlingly inventive extended solo in each half, and one of the few downsides of the gig was that he was otherwise relegated, or relegated himself, to a supportive role.

The Razor's Edge, a fast, zigzagging Holland postbop standby, benefited from a countermelodic complexity made possible by an extended line-up. Gary Smulyan's baritone saxophone boiled and burbled engagingly through it. UK trumpeter Kenny Wheeler then confirmed - on a ballad dedicated to him - that spacious pieces are the best setting for his skidding, upper-register sounds and quivering long notes.

All the performers are first class, but there were several solos of energy and poise from the gifted saxophonist Chris Potter; of rugged agility from trombonist Robin Eubanks; and a couple of rhythmic tours de force from drummer Billy Kilson. The leader makes the bass sound authoritative, agile and tender whenever he plays unaccompanied - but it was his introduction to the encore, Dream of the Elders, that was his most eloquent statement of the night. Very tricksy postbop jazz at times, but music with enough muscle and heart to dispel any sense of jazzbo exclusivity.

The Dave Holland Octet play the Royal Concert Hall, Nottingham (0115-989 5555), tonight, then tours to Warwick, Leeds, Darlington and Manchester.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: Steven Spielberg pigs out in his dreams and a nostalgic look back to a schoolboy football match in the 1950s.
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg pigs out in his dreams and a nostalgic look back to a schoolboy football match in the 1950s.
fields.body:
Steven's Dream
(www.countingdown.com)
Last autumn, DreamWorks SKG tiptoed away from Pop.com, their webfilm venture which was abandoned pre-launch. You can now sneak a peek at the celebrity content created for that ill-fated site at countingdown.com, where two cartoon curiosities are currently on show. The 'Steven' of Steven's Dream is Mr Spielberg himself, who narrates his own real-life dream of an insatiable eating episode, translated into agreeably rough-edged animation. Watching Steven demolish the buffet, you can't help but notice that the dreams of cinema's golden boy are just as banal as our own - it's a forbidden food fantasy, common to dieters the world over. Get out your Penguin Freud, however, to appreciate the meaning of his final morsel. (KS)
 View the film

A Soccer Story
(www.ifilm.com)
Can we pick 'em or what? Cybercinema was pleased to see one of our recent picks, The Periwig Maker (Jan 15) among the Oscar nominations for Best Animated Short. So we went to check out Paulo Machline's sweetly nostalgic retelling of a schoolboy soccer match in 1950s Brazil, the only other Web-hosted short in the competition. Nominated for Best Live Action Short, A Soccer Story has the classy looks and heart-warming traits (period setting, plucky kids, uplifting surprise ending) that traditionally warm the Academy's cockles. A serious contender, in fact. Try and view it using a broadband or ISDN line, since it's in Portuguese with English subtitles, which are illegible via a 56k modem. (KS)
 View the film

webTitle: Carolee Schneemann's rage against the male

fields.headline: Carolee Schneemann's rage against the male
fields.standfirst:
Carolee Schneemann
The Cornerhouse, Manchester
Rating:****
fields.trailText: The enduring image is of the naked artist reading a text from a long scroll that she unfurls from her vagina. Carolee Schneemann performed Interior Scroll over 25 years ago. All we are presented with here are two photographic images of the event, but they are images that define a significant moment in feminist art history. Schneemann's anti-life-class pose contributed to bringing several centuries of passive cultural acceptance of the idealised female nude to an end. After that, it seemed plain ridiculous for a circle of men to sit down and size up a reclining nude woman in the name of art.
fields.body:
The enduring image is of the naked artist reading a text from a long scroll that she unfurls from her vagina. Carolee Schneemann performed Interior Scroll over 25 years ago. All we are presented with here are two photographic images of the event, but they are images that define a significant moment in feminist art history. Schneemann's anti-life-class pose contributed to bringing several centuries of passive cultural acceptance of the idealised female nude to an end. After that, it seemed plain ridiculous for a circle of men to sit down and size up a reclining nude woman in the name of art.

Emerging from the experimental artworld of 1960s New York, Schneemann developed a reputation as a shamanistic gorgon-headed she-devil whose rage against female misrepresentation was conducted at a level of infectious magic that had no time for the academic perspectives of the sexual politician. A series of photographs of Up To And Including Her Limits, an eight-hour performance from 1975, shows the naked artist dangling precariously from a rope and surrounded by walls teeming with scrawled insectile fragments. The nightmare goes into bad-trip overload with the specially commissioned installation More Things Wrong, a convoluted maze of cables and flickering video footage of executions, demolitions, deforestations and cats toying cruelly with their victims.

More focused is Vulva's Morphia, a set of 36 painted laser prints of vulval images. The in-your-face up-front rudeness of the imagery is balanced by a bitterly ironic text: "Vulva recognises the symbols and names on graffiti under the railroad: slit, snatch, enchilada, beaver, muff, coozie, fish and finger pie . . . Vulva deciphers Lacan and Baudrillard and discovers she is only a sign, a signification of the void, of absence, of what is not male . . . (she is given a pen for taking notes)".

Typically the images are all daubed and smeared. Schneemann trained as a painter and it shows. She gets into an alarming but potent mess of moral ambiguities and emotional ambivalences. She gets her hands and mind and body dirty with it all. She doesn't argue from a perspective of analytical detachment; she demonstrates from a position of engagement. Like kindred spirit hellraiser Diamanda Galas, there is nothing cool, clean or correct about this artist, politically or otherwise.

Until April 22. Details: 0161-200 1500. Carolee Schneemann will present Vulva's Morphia, a performance/lecture, at Powerhouse, Nottingham (0115-848 6131), on March 13.

fields.headline: Mirror's Edge
fields.standfirst:
Tramway, Glasgow
Rating:*****
fields.trailText: Mirror's Edge, a broad, vibrant sweep of an exhibition, is a different sort of touring group show. Tramway is its only UK venue. It has avoided prestige art-world locations in favour of places overlooked by the establishment - Umea in Sweden, Vancouver, Turin and now Glasgow. The location becomes part of the exhibition - a tactic to flag up a dialogue between insiders and outsiders, the powerful and the marginal, and the politics more than the poetics of space.
fields.body:
Mirror's Edge, a broad, vibrant sweep of an exhibition, is a different sort of touring group show. Tramway is its only UK venue. It has avoided prestige art-world locations in favour of places overlooked by the establishment - Umea in Sweden, Vancouver, Turin and now Glasgow. The location becomes part of the exhibition - a tactic to flag up a dialogue between insiders and outsiders, the powerful and the marginal, and the politics more than the poetics of space.

Peter Spaans shows video footage of the "unknown" cities they have already toured to, while Meschac Gaba's sprawling Museum of Contemporary African Art (a house plant grows bank notes, nuggets of gold glisten next to wooden building blocks) makes a commemorative plaque for each venue.

One of the dialogues curator Okwui Enwezor sets up is between established European and American artists, and the work of artists based in countries and cities often overlooked by the art system. What this means is the chance to see some stunning work by Thomas Demand (photographs that manage to be the frosty side of chilly and deeply seductive at the same time), Steve McQueen's Deadpan, for which he won the Turner Prize, Yinka Shonibare's Victorian Dandy photographs, a wall of kooky images by Raymond Pettibon and an installation by Thomas Hirschhorn. This is crammed full of makeshift furniture made from ironing boards and plastic chairs.

It also means some moments of thrilling discovery and contrast. The understatement of Ceal Floyer's work meets the grand gesture that is Sophie Tottie's vast wall-painting, the stillness of Hiroshi Sugimoto's photographs of empty auditoria clashes with Isek Bodys Kingelez's carnivalesque architectural model in tribute to Jean Nouvel. Carlos Garaicoa mirrors a city skyline in a table of crystal, while the sound of Henrik Hakansson's crickets that greet you as you enter the gallery (real crickets, in an open-top glass case) chirrups through the place. As we move from one to the other, the exhibition makes its point: who we are is only where we look from. How all this is changing through globalisation is what we get a sense of here, peeking from the mirror's edge.

Until April 15. Details: 0141-287 3900.

fields.headline: Swollen Tongues
fields.standfirst:
BAC, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText: There is rhyme but not always reason in Kathleen Oliver's play that has originality and a cracking production in its favour. Oliver's drama is that rare beast, a modern verse drama. It also celebrates the love that dare not speak its name by shouting it from the rooftops. True love, it suggests, not only needs to be spoken of, but also only finds its greatest expression in the caress of words. Here it is language rather than organs that swell in a sexy, suggestive and provocative way.
fields.body:
There is rhyme but not always reason in Kathleen Oliver's play that has originality and a cracking production in its favour. Oliver's drama is that rare beast, a modern verse drama. It also celebrates the love that dare not speak its name by shouting it from the rooftops. True love, it suggests, not only needs to be spoken of, but also only finds its greatest expression in the caress of words. Here it is language rather than organs that swell in a sexy, suggestive and provocative way.

This is all very good and it only seems a pity that something so potentially modern should look backwards and be burdened with a narrative that is contrived and ridiculous. The play seems to owe much to Marivaux, but has none of that playwright's sophistication in its story. A brother and sister, Thomas and Catherine, are trying to write lyric love poetry under the tutelage of Dr Wise - not the man he appears. But while Thomas's love for the seamstress Sonja leads to verbosity and doggerel, Catherine is apparently struck dumb by her love for the same woman and the impossibility of telling her. Only by taking her brother's dreadful verses and transforming them, under the pseudonym Overripe, can she really express herself.

When Dr Wise sets up a verse contest between Thomas and the mysterious Overripe, the cross-dressing scenario becomes ever more complicated as Catherine and Sonja elope to a sapphic haven closely pursued by Thomas and Dr Wise. Soon even Thomas finds himself in a dress.

This is an evening of wit and verve but, how much you will enjoy it will depend on your taste for contrivance, pantomime and rhyming couplets. It is clever but not very deep and, despite the panache with which it is done, it can't disguise the fact that this is pastiche, not the real thing, and therefore devoid of real emotion. But it is cleverly done, the acting is sharp and there is absolutely no doubting the fact that Off the Cuff, which developed this work, is a really lively young company with heaps of talent and provided too much praise doesn't give them swollen heads, they should go far.

Until March 18. Box office: 020-7223 2223.
